Title: In Agra, a bit of awe but little admiration for President Trump
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

AGRA: Donald Trump means different things to different people. But the most commonly-held opinion among a cross-section of middle-class citizenry in the town of Taj Mahal is that the India visit of the US president is primarily intended to boost his image for the forthcoming polls back home. And that he shouldn’t have offered to mediate on Kashmir .

Those TOI spoke to – professors, shopkeepers, factory owners – do not follow Trump on social media. Their views on the 73-year-old businessman-turned-politician have been largely shaped by Hindi and English newspapers and news on TV.

Mohd Arshad, who teaches sociology in Agra University, reiterates that Trump is trying to project himself as a popular international leader to his domestic constituency. “That’s why he is constantly referring in his campaign speeches to the 6-10 million crowds which he says will line up for him in Ahmedabad,” he says.

Cloth merchant Gagandeep Singh agrees with that view adding that he is also trying to impress NRIs, Gujaratis being prominent among them. To bolster the point, he also points out that the US president is not signing any major trade deal during the two-day tour.

Hundreds of banners have been put up in Agra to welcome Trump. The optics underline the friendship and closeness between Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi . One of the banners picturing the two says, “Do mahaan desh, ek bemisaal dosti (Two great nations, one matchless friendship).”

But retired English professor Nirupama Sharma says genuine friendship between two political personalities of different nations is unlikely. “There are no friends or foes in politics. It changes as per needs. Such relationships are transactional,” she says. Arshad too believes there is a coalescing of interests between the two world leaders. “Both share good chemistry. And both have an autocratic style of functioning,” he says.

Sharma also differs with Trump’s America-focussed policies. “I see the world as a global village. You cannot isolate people. I believe in living together, not raising any kind of barrier for other people,” says Sharma, who has discussed the subject extensively with her friends and relatives in the US.

Durgesh Kumar, who sells kids-wear in Bijlighar shopping area, looks at Trump as a businessman always in search of a good deal. “India is a big market and the country offers opportunities for him. Which is why he is also trying to wean India away from Russia,” he says.

Durgesh has issues with Trump offering to mediate on Kashmir. “Kashmir belongs to India. Where’s the need for any mediation?” he says. Dinesh Kumar , who runs a small factory for leather goods, also agrees with that assessment. He feels that Trump wants to dominate India. “He wants us under his thumb,” says Dinesh. “It is probably due to Modi that he is unable to interfere as much as he wants to,” says Durgesh.

What’s undeniable is that Trump has made a major impact on the mindscape of people. They even recall policy decisions pronounced by him several years ago. One of them remembered him imposing travel restrictions on several Muslim-majority countries in 2017.

Trump may not evoke admiration but being the US president he does evoke awe. Brajmohan Singh, who sells petha for a living, said that it is good news that the most powerful man in the world is visiting India. “We can only expect something positive,” he says.

Several individuals didn’t know much about Trump, except that his impending arrival has spruced up the city and galvanized the local administration to action. Stationary mart owner Kulwinder Kaur laughed while speaking about what Trump had said last week: 6-10 million are likely to turn up for him in Ahmedabad. “But I like the way he keeps saying, ‘Believe me, believe me,’ in his speeches,” she laughs again.

Title: PM’s radio message: From aiding artisans to being ‘student for life’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

NEW DELHI: Starting the 62nd edition of his monthly address “Mann Ki Baat” with reference to his recent visit to Hunar Haat at India Gate , PM Narendra Modi on Sunday said one should attend such events to know India, to experience India and contribute in the progress and prosperity of hardworking craftspersons, especially women.

“A few days ago, at a small place at the Hunar Haat in Delhi, I witnessed hues of our country’s diverse expanse, cultures, traditions, cuisines and the warmth of emotions,” the PM said and shared his experience of interactions with some of the artisans.

“Listening to a divyang woman at Hunar Haat was a source of fulfilment. She told me that earlier, she used to sell paintings on the pavement. Her life changed after she connected with Hunar Haat. Today, she is not only self-reliant, she has purchased a house too,” Modi said and urged people to make it a point to visit the event.

He mentioned relishing Bihari delicacy ‘litti chokha’, which he had tweeted after his visit. He also mentioned specialities of other states including idli-dosa, chhole-bhature, daal-baati and khaman-khandvi.

Modi spoke about science, technology, biodiversity and upcoming exams while insisting on fitness, saying a country which was fit would always be hit and urged people to explore adventure sports during vacations.

He narrated stories of courage and strength to convey that 'age and disability' cannot be a hurdle in achieving goals. He gave the examples of 105-year-old Bhagirathi Amma who cleared 'level 4' examination in Kerala recently and 12-year-old girl Kamya Karthikeyan , who scaled Mount Aconcagua, the highest peak of the Andes mountains in South America, which is about 7,000 metres high.

“If we wish to progress in life, we should develop ourselves, if we wish to achieve something in life, the first pre-condition for that is the student within us must never die,” he said.

Modi also talked about Salman of Moradabad in Uttar Pradesh. Salman, a specially-abled person, set up a slipper manufacturing unit, overcoming all odds. “While Salman himself found it difficult to walk, he decided to manufacture slippers which help others to walk easily,” he said.

Modi said similar determination was manifested by residents of Ajrak village in Kutch , Gujarat. In 2001, after the devastating earthquake, most villagers were migrating from the village. However, one person, Ismail Khatri, decided to stay back and nurture his traditional art form of 'Ajrak print'. The entire village joined in on their traditional handicraft and fused it with contemporary fashion.

Modi hailed the use of a mixture of 10% indigenously produced bio-jet fuel to fly an IAF transport aircraft, saying such efforts would not only help bring down carbon emissions but also reduce the country's dependence on imported crude oil.

“This was the first time that this mix was used in both engines. Not just that, the airport from which this plane took off from Leh is not only one of the highest altitude airports in India but also in the world,” the PM said. He pointed out that the bio-jet fuel was prepared from “non-edible tree-borne oil” and was procured from various tribal areas of India.

Title: Uddhav to set up 3-party panel to study NPR issues
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

MUMBAI: A day after chief minister Uddhav Thackeray met NCP chief Sharad Pawar to thrash out differences between the allies on Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Population Register (NPR), Thackeray on Sunday announced the setting up of a three-party panel of ministers which will look at “problems” that could emerge during NPR’s implementation in the state.

“I have made my stand on the issue of CAA very clear and we are still discussing the issue with the allies. Though on the surface there seems to be no problems with NPR, a decision to form a committee with members of the three parties has been taken to take a closer look at the problems that could arise with it," said Thackeray on the eve of the budget session, his first full-fledged one in the assembly as CM.

The move to set up a panel is a concession by the CM to his allies who have, in principle, opposed the NPR while he has likened it to the Census. The panel represent the coalition’s intent to present a common front in the house during the session.

On Friday, Thackeray along with his son and cabinet minister Aaditya Thackeray had met Prime Minister Modi and afterwards Thackeray had said CAA and NPR will be implemented in the state. "No one needs to fear CAA. The NPR is not going to throw anyone out of the country," he said, prompting his allies to caution the need for more circumspection and consultation with allies on the issue.

Subsequently, a meeting was held by Thackeray, deputy CM Ajit Pawar and Sharad Pawar to forge a joint strategy on the issues. A senior minister said the government is expecting the opposition to try and exploit differences between the ruling allies on issues like CAA, NPR, Elgar Parishad and Savarkar.

Thackeray on Sunday drew a distinction between the Aghadi’s and the BJP’s handling of sensitive issues saying Maharashtra has seen several anti-CAA protests but no riots or law and order problems. "In Delhi, where the police is under the Centre, a mob enters JNU and assaults students. In my opinion they were no less than terrorists. In UP, there were riots and police action on anti-CAA protestors," he said.

Regarding the Elgar Parishad case, Thackeray said he did not hand it over to the NIA, it was the Centre using powers vested with it which transferred the case to the central agency. "There is no question of me handing over the case to NIA. We are upset with the manner in which it was taken away. It looked like they questioned the competency of the state investigating agency. We are upset about it and have conveyed the same to the Centre," said Thackeray.

Asked why the BJP, his ally in the previous government, boycott the customary tea party on the eve of the session, he said the party was only criticising him for the sake of it and that a capable opposition must also learn to appreciate. "I would like to tell them that our government has stabilised and taken many decisions and I think they cannot digest the fact that people are very happy with our government," said Thackeray.

The BJP has demanded a welcome motion to acknowledge the contribution of Veer Savarkar during the budget session. Thackeray said they would decide on it once the sessions begin. "Savarkar and Hindutva is not BJP's property," said Thackeray.

Title: AGR Dues: Finance ministry against penalty relief for telecom cos
Content:
(Representative image)

'Telecom should not be monopoly or duopoly'

NEW DELHI: The finance ministry on Sunday objected to deferring or waiving a part of interest and penalty for the telecom industry hit by the Supreme Court’s adjusted gross revenue (AGR) burden, effectively blocking a reprieve for the beleaguered mobile operators.At a specially-convened meeting in the telecom department headquarters, finance ministry officials said any concession on payment of penalty would “set a wrong precedent and lead to similar demands” from other sectors, sources told TOI. A full meeting of the multi-ministry digital communications commission is likely on Monday.The government is working overtime to sort out the mess as telecom companies have time till March 17 to clear the dues. The order of the top court has asked the companies to pay Rs 1.47 lakh crore to the DoT, and this is in lieu of previous licence fee and spectrum usage charges dues, apart from the interest and penalty. A large chunk of the demand is in the form of interest and penalty. For example, of the total licence fee dues of Rs 92,641 crore, only Rs 22,589 crore is the principal. Besides this, telecom companies owe Rs 55,054 crore in spectrum usage charge (SUC) dues.At Sunday’s meeting, there was unanimity that “all efforts need to be taken to save the existing companies” – which, if done, will provide a much-needed relief to Vodafone Idea that is on the brink.“There should not be a monopoly, or even a duopoly, in the sector,” a top government source told TOI.Vodafone Idea, which needs to pay Rs 53,000 crore in past dues, has paid only Rs 2,500 crore so far, while Airtel is required to clear Rs 35,000 crore (Rs 10,000 crore paid) and Tata group Rs 14,000 crore (paid Rs 2,197 crore). The discussions, led by telecom secretary Anshu Prakash , were attended by top officials from the finance and commerce and industry ministries as well as Niti Aayog. Sources said Prakash made a detailed presentation on the options on the table.One of the proposals was to offer soft loans to companies to help them tide over an immediate cash crunch and clear the AGR-related dues. But government authorities were split on the modalities.“However, it was mentioned that any such credit window should not be given through the telecom department, since it is also the receiver of the dues. Thus, it was proposed that public sector banks or other financial institutions or instruments can be used to provide emergency credit,” a source said.The government is worried that closure of any company may create panic in the Indian telecom market and disrupt the ambitious Digital India programme. Also, the upcoming 5G auctions look set to be hit hard due to the existing financial crisis that the industry is facing. While Airtel chief Sunil Mittal has said that his “company is safe, and was never unsafe”, Vodafone Idea has made it clear that it will not be able to survive without a government bailout.Vodafone Idea Chairman Kumar Mangalam Birla has already met finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman and telecom minister Ravi Shankar Prasad , where he has spoken about the need for a relief package.Only Reliance Jio, the country’s biggest mobile operator, is safe from the financial mess as its past dues were only to the tune of Rs 200 crore that it has already cleared.The Supreme Court’s AGR judgment was given on October 24, and had originally ordered the companies to pay the amount by Jan 23 (in three months). However, after the telecom department gave them a relaxation in this, the court expressed unhappiness over the issue, and asked the government to collect the money immediately.If the government is not able to collect the full amount, it will have no option but to invoke the bank guarantees submitted by the companies. And if this is also insufficient to collect the dues, then in “extreme cases”, the telecom department may cancel the mobile licence of the companies.

Title: Sonia Gandhi ‘ignored’, Adhir may skip President event, no clarity on Azad
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress leader in Lok Sabha Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury ’s decision to boycott the President’s banquet for US President Donald Trump has triggered questions if his counterpart in Rajya Sabha too will follow suit.

Congress sources said leader of opposition in Rajya Sabha Ghulam Nabi Azad was likely to attend the dinner.

Chowdhury has slammed the Modi government for not inviting Congress chief Sonia Gandhi to a meeting with Trump, saying it had reduced the foreign dignitary’s visit to a BJP function. His claim of BJP having slighted Sonia appeared to turn the party’s presence at the banquet into a tricky issue. According to a report, Azad ducked queries on the subject after a function in Mumbai.

But not all in Congress appeared comfortable with the idea of a boycott as it “involves diplomacy”. Till Chowdhury’s announcement, Congress had appeared set to attend the banquet through its two members. Party spokesman Anand Sharma said, “In the past, the Centre always arranged meetings of foreign heads of government with opposition leaders as foreign policy is bipartisan. This government has ended it.”

Title: Manipur board asks for BJP’s symbol, Nehru’s negative traits
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

IMPHAL: The political science paper of the Class XII state board examinations in Manipur has become a political football, thanks to two questions — “Draw the election symbol of Bharatiya Janata Party” and “Examine any four negative traits of Nehru’s approach to nation building”.

Opposition parties on Saturday accused the Council of Higher Secondary Education, Manipur, for trying to promote BJP and encourage Nehru-bashing. PCC spokesperson Kh Joykishan said the questions were part of an attempt to instil a certain political mindset among students . Council chairman L Mahendra Singh claimed neither question was out of the syllabus.

State BJP general secretary N Nimbus Singh said it was “relevant” to ask students about the “negative traits of Nehru’s approach to nation building” because he was the country’s first PM.

Title: Cadets learn about Raj culture
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

PATNA: The cadets of Sainik School Nalanda participated in a seminar organized on ‘The Evolution, Concept and Need of National Integration in the 21st Century’ under Ek Bharat Shrestha Bharat programme on Saturday.

Col MI Hussain was the chief guest and Ganesh Kumar Singh, principal of Doon Public School, was the guest speaker. Under the programme, various states of the country have been paired to understand each other’s art, culture, food, language, custom, tradition and history. Sainik School Nalanda has been paired with Sainik School of Rajasthan.

Cadets Saurabh Sagar, Shivam, Atul Tiwari Vivek Kumar, Vivek Sharma Purohit, Sundaram, Jatin Sigh, Vijay Kumar, Aditya, Aryan, Anugrah and Rohit discussed the history, language, dress, food, culture, folk art, agriculture and famous cities of Rajasthan. In the second session, Shrinivas, Sidhhant, Aditya Raj, Arihant Sharma, Vansh Kumar, Arihant Kumar, Nivedita Pandey, Anurag Shrivastav and Aryan Pandey discussed the various dimensions of national integration. Cadet Devansu Mishra explained the objective and background of Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat programme.

The paintings and portraits depicting national integration were highly appreciated by the audience.

Wing Commander PS Gujral (vice-principal) Major Ajay Chand (administrative officer), S K Pandey (PRO) and all the cadets and staff were present in the seminar. Cadet Ranveer proposed a vote of thanks.

Title: Sanjiv Oza appointed member of VNSGU VC search committee
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Surat: Veer Narmad South Gujarat University's (VNSGU) syndicate has finalized the name of Sanjiv Oza as one of the members of the search committee to select next vice-chancellor of the university on Sunday. A special meeting of VNSGU syndicate was called to finalize the appointment.

Oza, an active member of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, had earlier been vice-chancellor of Gujarat Ayurved University, Jamnagar. He is member of Central Council of Indian Medicine and University Grants Commission's Interface Committee, Eastern Region.

Oza will be one of three members of the search committee, with the other two yet to be appointed by the state government and governor’s office. The three-year term of existing vice-chancellor Shivendra Gupta will end this year, sources said.

Title: Bihar: High school, higher secondary teachers’ strike from Tuesday
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Around 40,000 teachers of government-run secondary and higher secondary schools have decided to go on indefinite strike from February 25, Bihar Secondary Schoolteachers’ Association (BSSTA) president and MLC Kedarnath Pandey said on Sunday.

Addressing media persons at BSSTA office here, Pandey said the teachers would not back off from agitation despite the warnings issued by the state government. “We are not scared of education department’s threat of strict action against agitating teachers for not joining the evaluation duty from February 26,” he said.

Pandey said the association had already written to the state government about the indefinite strike. “The Constitution has granted us the right to protest and no one can snatch this right from us. From February 25 onwards, we will boycott the state government’s work and evaluation duty,” he said.

The protests of secondary and higher secondary schoolteachers would start a day after the completion of Matriculation exams of Bihar School Examination Board (BSEB). Over 4.5 lakh contractual and some regular primary schoolteachers are already on strike since February 17 under the banner of Bihar Rajya Shikshak Sangharsh Samanvay Samiti (BRSSSS) in support of their eight-point charter of demands.

The state government had warned on Saturday that if the teachers boycott the evaluation duty, they be suspended and complaint will be lodged against them.

Pandey said the association has organised several protests since April 2019 in support of its three key demands – service condition for contractual teachers, sparing the teachers from non-academic work and removal of discrepancies in reimbursement of salary to teachers under the Seventh Pay Commission.

“In July 2015, the state government had announced that the contractual teachers will get all the benefits like pay hike, transfer, continuity of service, maternal and medical leave and promotion. However, nothing has been done so far,” the MLC said, adding the teachers should not be involved in non-academic work like election duty, preparation of mid-day meal and vaccination.”

Additional chief secretary of education department R K Mahajan, on the other hand, said regular teachers, teachers of government-aided schools and even some contractual teacher have promised to join the evaluation duty. “I have held a meeting with executive officers of zila parishads, DEOs, DPOs and executive officers of urban local bodies regarding evaluation of Intermediate answer sheets,” he said.

Mahajan said the government would rope in college and retired teachers for evaluation work. “Action will be initiated against the teachers if they fail to join the evaluation duty,” he said.

Title: ITI student among five killed in Bihar in 24 hours
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: At least five people, including a student of an industrial training institute (ITI) of Bettiah , were killed and five others injured in different incidents in the state in the last 24 hours.

A 35-year-old man was shot dead near Mahavir Ghat under the Alamganj police station area in Patna City on Sunday. Police said the victim was yet to be identified. SHO of Alamganj police station Sudhir Kumar said the assailants were probably known to the deceased.

Earlier in the day, a 40-year-old autorickshaw driver, Sunil Paswan, was shot dead by unidentified criminals when he was on way to Athmalgola from Barh to deliver the consignment of fish. The deceased was a native of Budhanichak village under the Barh police station area. SHO of Barh police station Sanjeet Kumar said the incident took place around 8.30am near Hasanchak village under Athmalgola police station.

On Saturday night, a 38-year-old man, Mukesh Kumar, was shot dead by unidentified criminals at Pethia Bazar under the Khagaul police station area in west Patna. The deceased was employed by the owner of a hardware shop and ward councillor Ritesh Kumar. Police said the incident was probably the fallout of Mukesh’s altercation with some local youths over misbehaviour with a professional dancer during Mahashivratri.

In East Champaran, police recovered the body of a 20-year-old boy from a canal under Sirsia police outpost on Sunday. The deceased, Raju Yadav, was a student of a Bettiah-based ITI. He had gone missing on Saturday.

In Buxar, a 62-year-old farmer, Umashankar alias Nanhku Yadav, was shot dead by unidentified criminals in his agricultural field in Shivpur diara under the Simri police station area on Sunday. Dumraon SDPO K K Singh said the farmer was attacked when he had gone to monitor the crop in his field.

In another incident, altogether five people, including two minor children, suffered serious bullet injuries in a violent clash between two groups of people over a property dispute at Morma village in Lakhisarai district.

Title: Arrested Maoist leader Koda dies in custody
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Siddhu Koda , a top Maoist leader of Bihar and Jharkhand, died in police custody late Saturday night. He was arrested from Dumka in neighbouring Jharkhand on Friday night. Koda (30), a native of Jamui district in Bihar, was facing around 100 cases of Maoist violence in Bihar, Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh.

An alert has been sounded in the bordering districts of Bihar and Jharkhand after the death of the self-styled ‘lieutenant general’ of banned outfit. Bihar and Jharkhand governments had announced a cash reward of Rs1 lakh and 10 lakh, respectively, for Koda’s arrest.

DIG, Munger range, Manu Maharaaj said on Sunday that Koda complained of pain in his chest and stomach on Saturday evening. He was rushed to the Sadar hospital at Jamui where doctors declared him brought dead. Koda was wanted in around 100 cases in three states, he said.

The DIG said Koda’s postmortem was conducted under the supervision of a medical board as per the guidelines of the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC). The postmortem was videographed and a magisterial inquiry was ordered into his death, he said, adding that Koda was chief of the CPI-Maoist’s East Bihar and North Jharkhand region.

Koda’s two associates — Illiyas Hembram and Sushil Hansda — were arrested from Chakai police station area in Jamui district on the basis of information elicited from him. One AK-47 assault rifle, one Insas rifle, one regular rifle, all looted from security personnel, a hand grenade besides a number of live cartridges were recovered during the search operation.

Jamui SDPO Ram Pukar Singh said Koda complained of pain in his stomach and heart during the search operation in deep forest and hilly terrain of Jamui. He was given the first line of treatment at a hospital from where he was referred to the sadar hospital at Jamui.

The SDPO said a joint team of the special task force (STF) and Dumka police had arrested Koda when he had gone there to collect extortion money from a contractor. He was brought to Jamui for interrogation and subsequently asked to accompany a police team during search operation. “The postmortem report will reveal the cause of Koda’s death,” he added.

Koda had blown up a patrolling team with detonators leading to the death of three people, including a patrolling magistrate, near Dipkarhar under Khaira police station in Jamui district in 1998. He had looted the weapons from security personnel. In 2001, he was appointed self-proclaimed area commander of the banned Naxal outfit. In 2003, he attacked the cavalcade of Jamui DM and SP in which a police officer was killed.

The major operation carried out by Koda at Mahulitand on the borders of Nawada and Jamui under Kauwakol police station in Nawada district in 2014 had left 11 security personnel, including the SHO of Kauwakol police station dead. In 20013, he had killed an STF jawan under Khaira police station in Jamui district.

Besides, an assistant commandant of the CRPF, Heera Kumar Jha, was killed by Koda’s armed squad. “The list of the cases pending against Koda is long,” said a police officer associated with anti-Naxal operation in Jamui district.

The police have also started probe into assets accumulated by Koda in Bihar, Jharkhand, Varanasi in Uttar Pradesh and Kolkata through unlawful activities. Authoritative sources said Koda had made huge investments in real estate and some contractors were on the radar of the state investigating agency.

Title: Bihar: Bhim Army bandh passes off peacefully
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bhim Army activists block the Ashok Raj Path near Patna College on Sunday during Bharat Bandh

PATNA: The Bharat bandh called by Bhim Army and supported by some opposition parties against a Supreme Court ruling that states are not bound to provide reservation in government jobs and promotion evoked a mixed response in the state on Sunday. Issues like CAA, NRC, NPR and alleged thrashing of dalits in recent past were also raised by bandh supporters.

In Patna, HAM(S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi protested at Dak Bungalow crossing along with party workers. He said the Centre was hell bent on snatching constitutional rights from SC, ST and OBC communities. “They want to make a new Constitution and take away the voting rights of weaker sections of society and minorities. Implementation of CAA is a step in this direction,” Manjhi said.

JAP-L chief Rajesh Ranjan alias Pappu Yadav also protested at Dak Bungalow crossing along with his supporters. The party workers shouted slogans and stopped a train at a Patna Junction.

State president of Bhim Army Amar Azad said the Centre was playing dirty politics with the weaker sections of society. “The SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act should be incorporated in the 9th schedule of the Constitution so that no one can interfere in dalit’s rights,” he said near the Kargil Chowk.

In Ara, the bandh supporters squatted on rail tracks for 65 minutes and blocked Ara-Patna road for four hours. At Ara railway station, the protesters were led by the CPI-ML’s Tarari MLA Sudama Prasad. They halted at least three passenger trains.

In Biharsharif, anti-government and anti-CAA, NPR and NRC slogans were raised by the bandh supporters. They burned tyres and blocked Biharsharif-Bind and Biharsharif-Sheikhpura roads for hours. Movement of vehicular traffic in Nalanda and Sheikhura districts was also affected.

The bandh supporters took out a procession in Sitamarhi where shops and business establishments remained closed in the morning hours.

In Samastipur, the protesters blocked the main road to Darbhanga for a few hours by burning tyres.

The bandh also paralysed traffic movement on NH-31 in Begusarai. Supporters of Bhim Army and JAP-L also blocked the highway near the Begusarai railway station. Vehicles remained stranded on the highway for several hours.

In West Champaran, the bandh had no effect. All shops were open in Bagaha town. However, the bandh supporters took out a procession in the town.

Title: 7 killed in road accidents in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

SASARAM/DARBHANGA: Seven people, including three of a family, were killed in road accidents in Rohtas and Darbhanga districts on Sunday.

Four passengers, including a couple, died while one dozen were injured near on NH-2 toll plaza when a bus collided head on with a orange-laden truck around 8am at Auwan gate under Sheosagar police station in Rohtas district. The bus was on way to Bhabhua from Sasaram. The deceased were identified as Mukhtar Khan (35) and his wife Rehma Khatun of Semari under Karahagar police station, Ajit kumar (25) of Basti Mor of Sasaram and Himanshu pandey of Saraiya under Kochas police station of the district. The district administration announced an ex gratia payment to to the family members of the deceased. The drivers managed to escape.

In a separate accident, three persons were killed and three others of the same family were injured when their car collided with a road divider on NH-57 and near Kakarghati in Darbhanga district, police said. The deceased were identified as Raju Jha (45), his mother Rekha Devi (75) and sister Madhu Kumari (22). Jha’s wife, his three-year-old son and a family friend were injured in the accident. The family was on way to their native village in Saharsa from Muzaffarpur to celebrate the boy’s birthday, police said.

Title: POCSO cells to handle sexual harassment cases in all Bihar government schools soon
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Bihar Education Project Council (BEPC), a wing of the state education department, has decided to form ‘Protection of Children from Sexual Offences ( POCSO ) cells’ in all government-run schools from the 2020-2021 academic session.

Students as well as women staff of schools will be able to file their complaints regarding any kind of sexual harassment and exploitation with the POCSO cell.

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act , 2012 aims to punish those engaging in sexual crimes against children, while safeguarding their interests at every stage of the judicial process.

The BEPC has directed all the district education officers to ensure that the government-run schools set up POCSO cell. A letter in this regard was issued last week by the BEPC’s state project director Sanjay Kumar Singh to all the DEOs.

Kiran Kumari, state programme officer of BEPC, said the POSCO cell in each school would be headed by the school principal. “A male teacher, a woman teacher, a non-teaching staff (clerk) and two students, including a girl, will be the members of the cell. The cell will initially be formed in secondary and higher secondary schools. The primary schools will be covered gradually,” she said, adding the schools have also been directed to display the child helpline number (1098) on their notice board.

“A complaint box should be placed in government-run schools for the students. After receiving the complaint, the POCSO cell will initiate action, like informing the local police station and child helpline about the sexual offence,” the letter issued by Sanjay read.

Sanjay said all the DEOs have been asked to notify schools regarding this and establish cells with immediate effect.

Kiran said the decision to form POCSO cell was taken following rise in sexual harassment and exploitation cases against women and children. “We have also started an awareness campaign – ‘Bal Sanrakshan aur Suraksha’ – in schools,” she said.

“Under the awareness campaign, the schools will make kids aware about the safe and unsafe touch, sexual harassment and cyber security. The BEPC is in the process of making 3-4 short videos as part of the awareness drive. One of the videos is based on cyber safety and the others are on bullying and bad impacts of porn sites,” Kiran said.

She added that the POCSO cell and awareness campaign would be monitored by the BEPC through ‘Unayan’, a mobile application for government-run schools. “The school principals have been asked to upload the daily report to the mobile application of BEPC,” she said.

Title: Surat: Five rounds fired at a jeweller
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Assailant emptied a magazine and was about to reload it, when staff caught him

SURAT: In a shocking incident, at least five rounds were fired from a pistol on an owner of a jewellery showroom in Mini Bazaar of Varachha on Sunday. Police suspect that the attackers may either have been assigned the contract to kill the jeweller, or it may have been an attempt to loot Amar Jewellers, the jewellery shop.

While the person who shot at the jeweller was caught, two others who were sitting outside on a scooter, escaped from the spot. Police identified arrested accused as Vijay Karpada, while his associates are Dinesh Shukla and Mayursinh Jadeja.

In the attack, shop accountant Sanjay Patel suffered bullet injuries on his hand and stomach, though cops claim he is out of danger. The attackers had come to shoot Nitesh Vavaiya, owner of the showroom , who, however, escaped unhurt as he rushed into his cabin after firing began in the front area of the shop. The bullets only hit his cabin glass.

Karpada emptied the first magazine and was about to reload it, when shop’s staff caught him. They later handed him over to the police. Police suspect that the accused have come to kill Vavaiya in some land dispute. The attacker were given contract to kill Vavaiya by some notorious criminal from Rajasthan. However, police are yet to reveal the exact details.

Preliminary investigation revealed that the trio — Karpada, Shukla and Jadeja — had escaped from Limbdi sub-jail of Surendranagar district on January 12 and an offence has been registered in Limbdi police station. Total four prisoners had escaped from the jail.

Title: 50 thieves arrested during Maha Shivratri fair
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: As many as 50 pickpockets , chain snatchers and mobile thieves had been nabbed during the four-day Maha Shivratri fair in Bhavnath Taleti (valley) of Junagadh that concluded on Saturday morning.

Deputy superintendent of police Pradeepsinh Jadeja had formed four teams of Rajkot special operation group, local crime branch and D staff of Bhavnath police station along with Junagadh A division and B division police stations.

“The cops dressed in plain clothes mingled themselves into the crowd and nabbed 50 persons on the basis of suspicion. When we check the criminal records of those arrested on Pocket Cop App, we found that 12 were history-sheeters involved in pickpocketing, cellphone thefts and chain snatching,” said DySP Jadeja.

The Pocket Cop App is a special mobile application designed under e-Gujcop project launched by the state government.

The arrested accused were from Rajkot, Junagadh, Porbandar, Amreli, Bhavnagar, Surendranagar and Gir Somnath districts.

A total of 15 cellphones lost in the fair were found by the police and returned to their owners. During this year’s fair, a total of 370 cases of purse and cellphone thefts were reported.

Title: ‘Muslims should focus more on education’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

GAYA: Muslim opinion makers should not be bogged down on trivial issues like triple talaq and common civil code and concentrate on larger issues like education, jobs and participation in democratic institutions, political activist Yogendra Yadav said in an interactive session at Gaya on Saturday evening.

“For too long you have allowed the conservative elements to retain the leadership to work as vote bank brokers. Shaheen Bagh has shown the way by discarding the traditional leadership. The spirit of Shaheen Bagh has to be promoted by allowing women and youth to replace self servers as community leaders,” Yadav said.

Regretting the extremely poor ratio of Muslims both as students and faculty members, Yadav quoted latest official figures and said the community comprised nearly 15% of the population in the country, but its representation as students in the institutions of higher education was just about 2.5%. The scenario was even worse in respect of faculty members where the representation of Muslims was just about 1.5%.

The community leaders cannot be absolved of their responsibility as, instead of concentrating on real existential issues like jobs and education, they remained preoccupied with personal law related issues like triple talaq. Triple talaq, besides being against the true Islamic spirit that empowered women was inconsequential as the divorce rate among Muslims in India was less than the national average (of all divorces).

CAA has unwittingly done some good to the community as it has broken the inertia gripping them and provided an outlet to its genuine grievances, he said.

When one of the participants raised the issue of MY (Muslim-Yadav) doing little good to the Muslims, Yadav said being a votary of value based politics, he never approved of political combinations along caste and religious lines.

Democracy to be really successful has to go beyond numbers.

The prominent participants included Dr Farasat Hussain, Dr Hamid Hussain, Samvidhan Bachao Morcha convener Omair Khan @Tikka Khan, Philosophy Professor Javed Anjum, Economics professor Abdul Hannan, CPI leader Masood Manzar and activist Javed Khan.

Title: Now, song on Trump’s visit
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

‘Namaste Trump', is a paean to Donald Trump's two-day visit to India

Surat: ‘Sher ne sher ko bulaya hai , vo bhi yari nibhane aya hai’ , a melodious song composed and sung by Chirag Thakkar, a city-based musician , has become popular on social media. ‘Namaste Trump’, a paean to Donald Trump's two-day visit to India from Monday, is dedicated to the friendship between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the US President.

It being the first visit of Trump to India, Thakkar planned to welcome him with a song and got it recorded in just 15 hours thanks to support of his friends namely Vihul Jagirdar and Darshan Zaveri. The 4.45 minute song is sung by Thakkar, Jagirdar and Pooja Modi Kalyani. The group has shot a video of the song as well.

“It was not pre-planned but after it was confirmed that Trump was indeed coming, we decided to honour the US President and Modi with a song. I think it is first time that a President of the USA is directly coming to Gujarat and it is a matter of pride for me,” Thakkar said.

“Trump is going to visit Sabarmati Ashram as well. Mahatma Gandhiji's favourite devotional song Raghupati Raghav Raja Ram too is there in 'Namaste Trump',” Thakkar added.

“Trump is arriving in Ahmedabad and as a Gujarati, we wanted to greet him. I have focused on the personalities of the two leaders. They both are loved by the people of their respective countries,” lyricist Jagirdar said.

‘Namaste Trump' starts with Raghupati Raghav Raja Ram tune. “We remember the Father of the Nation at the start of our song,” added Jagirdar.

Title: Two drown in sea off Somnath coast
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Rajkot: Two persons drowned in the sea off Somnath coast on Saturday afternoon.

Police said the victims, identified as Naresh Lakha (20) and Bharat Sajan (21), had gone into the sea for bathing.

“The victims did not know how to swim and a giant wave came and swept them away while they were bathing. We have managed to fish out the body of Lakha. However, the body of Sajan remains untraceable,” said an official from Prabhas Patan police station.

The victims hailed from Lathi of Amreli district. They had first gone to attend the Maha Shivratri fair in Junagadh then they had come to Somnath Temple. After performing puja, they went into the sea.

Title: Rough diamond sales of De Beers reduced by 26%
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Surat: For the first time , the rough diamond sales of the world’s largest diamond mining company, De Beers , has fallen by 26% in 2019 , due to the ongoing crisis in the Surat’s diamond industry and weak market conditions.

In its 2019 financial report, De Beers noted that due to the difficult market challenges, the rough diamond sales declined 26% at $4 billion in 2019 compared to $5.4 billion in 2018. However, the company asserted that the long-term outlook for global diamond demand remains positive, with significant growth prospects in the emerging markets.

Industry sources said that the rough diamond imports in the country had been on the decline during the whole of 2019 as the diamond unit owners exercised reduction in the diamond production due to the challenging market conditions and weak demand of polished diamonds. The manufacturing of diamonds was slashed to almost half due to the huge pile up of diamond inventory in the pipeline.

Diamond industry analyst Aniruddha Lidbide told TOI: “The diamantaires have reacted smartly to the challenging market circumstances by reducing the rough diamond import. Even as the mining companies reduced prices by over 6% to lure the diamantaires. Still, the industry is sitting on a good amount of polished inventories, which needs to the cleared. The rough imports will continue to be affected in the coming few months.”

Lidbide added, “There is a coronavirus threat looming large on the industry. The export of polished diamonds to Hong Kong and China is badly affected, which will further aggravate problems in the industry.”

According to the figures from the Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC), the import of rough diamonds between April-January-2020 declined by 15% at Rs 77,000 crore against Rs 90,000 crore during the same period in the previous year. Also, the polished diamond export between April-Janauary-2020 declined by 17% at 1,16,000 lakh crore against Rs 1,37,000 lakh crore.

A sight holder of De Beers on the condition of anonymity said, “De Beers had offered deferment of goods at few of its previous sales last year due to the challenging market conditions. There was 50% decrease in the sale as many deferred the purchase of goods. At present, the industry is focused on clearing its piled up inventories of polished diamonds.”

Title: Patna: Sigh of relief as one-way traffic movement starts on Digha flyover
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Newly built Digha flyover open for people in Patna on Sunday

PATNA: The Digha flyover , constructed with an aim to ease traffic on Ashok Rajpath-Danapur road, was thrown open to public on Sunday. The flyover connects Nahar Road near Patipul Ghat to the approach road of Digha rail-cum-road bridge.

The 1.2km-long flyover, built with an expenditure of Rs 80 crore, has come as a boon for people going to Sonepur, Chhapra and Hajipur via Digha Setu from Phulwarisharif and AIIMS-Patna.

On Saturday, a trial run was conducted on the new flyover. It was inspected by Sanjay Kumar Agarwal, managing director of Bihar State Road Development Corporation Limited (BSRDC), and executive engineers of road construction department.

Agarwal said one-way traffic movement will be allowed on Digha flyover for the next 15 days. “The vehicles coming from Phulwarisharif, AIIMS-Patna and Naubatpur will be allowed to use Digha flyover to reach Digha Setu. Vehicles coming from Digha Setu end cannot use the flyover for 15 days,” he said.

“The start of Digha flyover means that buses will no longer be unnecessarily parked on Ashok Rajpath-Danapur road. It will ease traffic on the road, especially during the peak hours,” Agarwal, who is also the Patna divisional commissioner, said.

Agarwal said heavy vehicles were not allowed to take U-turn from Ashok Rajpath-Danapur road due to the construction of Digha flyover. “As a result, traffic jam near Digha was a big problem. People of the city will now heave a sigh of relief, thanks to the Digha flyover,” he said.

Agarwal added, “The traffic cops will regulate traffic movement near Digha flyover and 200-metre approach road connecting Digha Setu. The service lane below the Digha flyover will be ready in next 15 days.”

Meanwhile, the locals have welcomed the opening of the new flyover. Suresh Kumar, who owns a medical shop near Digha, said it would ease traffic in the area. “Trucks and vans used to cause traffic congestion near Patipul,” he said.

Anshuman, a resident of Ashiana Colony, the flyover would come as a relief for schoolchildren as well. “Many school buses will also use the new flyover now,” he added.

Title: Puma India revenues grow 22% to Rs 1413 cr in a slowdown year
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

(Representative image: AFP)

BENGALURU: Sports lifestyle brand Puma has seen its sales grow 22% to Rs 1,413 crore for the 12 months ending December 2019. The growth was aided by increasing sales to women customers and higher demand in tier-2 towns across the country despite a slowing economy.

The German multinational has roped in a slew of brand ambassadors like cricket team captain Virat Kohli and boxing champion Mary Kom over the last few years. It expects to continue a similar growth momentum of over 20% this year even as it faces increasing competition from relatively newer entrants like Under Armour and Skechers. “India is a strategic market for Puma. The growing sportswear market, coupled with the country’s aspirational youth, poses a huge opportunity for us to tap into,” Bjorn Gulden, global CEO of Puma, told TOI.

He added that globally it has also been a record year for the brand with revenues of 5.5 billion euros. “Being the No.1 brand in India is a reflection of how well we understand our consumers and how pleased they are with our products.” Puma wants to double down on India, with plans to open about 20 exclusive stores in an existing network of 373 across the country.

Puma was one of the first major brands to actively tap the online retail sales route on Flipkart and Amazon India. This channel accounted for around 29% of sales in 2019, compared to 24% in 2018. Puma’s India MD Abhishek Ganguly sees this number stabilising at about 30%.

What has significantly been increasing sales for Puma is its business in tier-2 and -3 towns as it contributes 48% of the total online channel in 2019 from just 15% in 2015. These smaller towns — like Jalandhar, Bhopal and Nashik — also contributed 40% of the total offline sales in 2019 as compared to 22% in 2015.

In terms of overall growth rate, Puma has been able to edge past major rivals like Adidas (Rs 1,251 crore in FY19), which has been growing at 10%, while others like Nike (Rs 831 crore in FY19) and Reebok (Rs 407 crore in FY19) have been stagnant in India for the last few years. But these companies follow an April to March financial year, while Puma follows a calendar year format (January to December) for its results.

The competition in the segment is set to increase as Under Armour has opened 10 stores in India while US-based Skechers, which operated through a joint venture with Future Group, also consolidated its presence by buying out the Indian partner in the previous year.

Title: Varanasi: Students spread awareness on social issues with colours & creativity in Spandan 2020
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Students taking part in different contests held on the first day of the annual fest Spandan at BHU on Sunday

VARANASI: The five-day Inter-Faculty youth festival of Banaras Hindu University- Spandan 2020- was formally inaugurated by chief guest of the fest Padam Shri Dr Soma Ghosh on Sunday.

The annual festival aims to provide a platform for the students to show their skills and talents in 31 categories. The fest commenced with the preliminary round of quiz competition conducted at department of Journalism and Mass Communication. Six students

from 20 faculties participated in the event held under the supervision of Prof JS Jha, Prof Neeraj Khare, Prof Anurag Dave, Dr Neha Pandey, Dr Sanjeev Yadav, Dr Omprakash, Dr Ashutosh Mohan. Six teams have been selected for the final round of the quiz.

Participants gave message on various social and human issues like eye donation through colours in the rangoli contest organised at faculty of visual arts. Around 17 participants from different faculties took part in the event. Prof Jasvindar Kaur of faculty of visual arts, Dr Kiran Singh and Dr Swati Mital of faculty of Science judged the event.

Classical instrument event at Pt Omkarnath Thakur Auditorium witnessed performances by Hemant Pandey, Uday Shankar Mishra and Gopal Krishna of IIT BHU. The second session of the event, dedicated to classical instrumental non-percussion Sitar, witnessed participation of seven teams which enthrelled the audience with their performances with flute, sitar and santoor.

In the elocution competition held at lecture theatre of Institute of Science, over 58 participants gave their views on the topic ‘We want to live the dream of Mahamana, to be a good citizen’. The event was held in Hindi, English and Sanskrit languages.

‘On spot painting’ conducted by the faculty of Visual Arts witnessed participants expressing their ideas and views on themes of Holi and ‘Ek Bharat, Shresth Bharat’ with colours on canvas. The jury members for the event were Prof Satyendra Singh Bavni, Prof Saroj Rani and Suresh Chandra Jangid.

Another attraction of the first day was ‘Mime’ organised at Swatantrata Bhavan. Around 17 teams performed on various social and environmental issues.

The cartooning event was conducted on the theme- unity in diversity at the faculty of Visual Arts in which participants beautifully expressed their given tasks through their creations.

Title: Companies sniff better chance of consumer connect with exotic smells
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: ‘What’s visible would sell’ has been the basic principle followed by marketers. On a deeper, sensorial connect, it’s: ‘What smells good would sell good as well’. Sensorials play a very critical role when it comes to consumers’ choice of products.While over the years traditionally rooted fragrances like jasmine and sandalwood have had a distinct contribution, especially for soaps, a combination of fruity-floral fragrances are now gaining traction with marketers wooing younger consumers. Today, the more exotic the fragrance, the better the connect, say experts.CKC Aromas CEO Rishabh Kothari said there is a lot of experimentation happening in the fruity-floral space and some oriental notes such as ‘oud’ are catching up among the more affluent Indians who are looking for something different. “With the trend of naturals in FMCG, we also see a huge demand for notes which smell natural,” said Kothari, who is one of the leading players in the sensory market.Dabur recently launched a ‘floral bliss’ variant, which is a complex floral fragrance, and a ‘daffodil’ variant under its Odonil brand. Dabur India marketing head (home & personal care) Rajeev John said popular fragrances like jasmine and sandalwood continue to be relevant today, and these have also extended beyond beauty to enter the home care space. However, he added, one is now seeing the younger generation embracing newer exotic fragrances and floral fusions.“Fragrance is highly important as it is usually the first point of contact for any individual with a product. You tend to smell the product first before touching or experiencing it. Many a times, particularly in categories like personal care and home care, a fragrance becomes one of the most important factors when it comes to final product selection,” said John, who claims that the Odonil Zipper range has been a success mainly because it got the fragrance right.Godrej Consumer Products CEO (India & SAARC) Sunil Kataria said, “A product has to appeal to all senses of consumers to gain approval, with look-feel-smell forming a critical role. This is the very reason why some air freshener brands or variants have done well, while others haven’t — be it in personal care or air fresheners. When we test for fragrance in our products, we check for fragrance liking, fragrance strength (just right), fragrance spread (especially for air fresheners) and how long lasting the fragrance is.”Affluence is one of the reasons for the growing demand for newer experiences in fragrances. Over the years, as multiple brands of FMCG products moved into urban Indian households, traditional fragrances gave way to newer ones. Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting CEO Vineet Agrawal, however, said non-metro markets are still a one-soap household and often decision on the brand is made by the home maker. Jasmine and sandalwood products, thus, continue to have a stronger hold in these markets.According to Kataria, the occasion or space also determines which fragrance works well and where. “If the objective is to counter malodour like in a bathroom, consumers prefer stronger fruity fragrances. However, if the objective is to enjoy me-time in one’s bedroom or have a relaxing time with friends or partners in the living room, people prefer softer notes like aqua, fougere,” said Kataria.Some brands command a loyal consumer base owing to the fragrance, like Dettol Original, Cinthol Original and Pears original soap. On the other hand, there’s Lifebuoy — it was known by its strong carbolic smell — which underwent a complete makeover and continued to maintain a leadership position.“There is a loyal market for certain fragrances and flavours — for instance, Colgate dental cream. Whenever a marketer feared that an alteration could negatively impact sales, they introduced variants. Liril is known for its predominant lemon-freshness, but the brand has experimented with different notes in lemon to keep it contemporary,” said Kothari, who is also the president of The Fragrances and Flavours Association of India.

Title: Saran district board chief’s kin shot dead
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

SARAN/PATNA: Tension grips Saran district following the murder of a noted trader and close relative of district board chairperson Meena Arun under Marhaura police station in the district around 9am on Sunday. The deceased, Arjun Singh (55), is stated to be the elder brother of Meena’s husband and former mukhiya Arun Singh.

Meena was released from jail recently. Her name had figured in the killing of two policemen, including sub-inspector Mithilesh Kumar Sah, who was also heading the SIT in the district. An AK-47 assault rifle and a pistol were also looted in the incident under Marhaura police station in August last year. Meena’s licensed revolver was recovered from the spot.

Sources said Arjun’s son Subodh Kumar Singh is the main accused in the killing of police personnel Mithilesh Kumar Sah and Md Faruq in August last year. “Both Meena and her husband have been made key conspirators in the double murder case,” a police officer said.

Police said Arjun along with an acquaintance was on way to his shop at Marhaura from his native village Awari on a motorbike when the assailants fired at him near Marhaura railway station. He was rushed to the referral hospital where the doctors declared him brought dead.

A trainee IPS officer, Sandeep Singh, and Marhaura SDPO Dhirendra Kumar Sah rushed to the spot and inquired about the incident. The police had to face the wrath of the deceased’s supporters who also blocked the Chhapra-Marhaura road and disrupted vehicular traffic demanding immediate arrest of the accused.

“The reason behind the murder is yet to be ascertained. Some suspects have been picked up for interrogation on the basis of information shared by the man, who was accompanying Arjun,” the SDPO said.

DIG, Saran range, B K Verma and Saran SP Har Kishore Rai visited the spot. “Those involved in the murder wont’ be spared,” the DIG said.

Title: Government committed to promoting PACS in Bihar, says CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Highlighting the growth of cooperative movement in Bihar in the recent years, CM Nitish Kumar on Sunday said the number of Primary Agriculture Credit Cooperative Societies (PACS) members in the state has now gone up to 1.24 crore.

Addressing a joint conference of 7 apex cooperative bodies of the country, Nitish said the number of PACS women members has now gone up from 2 lakh to 36 lakh. He said his government was committed to meeting the expectations of the cooperative societies.

“People in the state are aware as to what were the condition of PACS and Bihar State Cooperative Marketing Union (BISCOMAUN) about 20 years ago. After coming to power in 2005, we started constituting new PACS and held their election on a regular basis. This led to sharp increase in the number of PACS members. These societies are engaged in procurement of paddy at a large scale across the state,” Nitish said.

He also said his government has allotted Rs56.35 crore for constructing altogether 22 ‘Sahkar Bhavan’ (cooperative buildings) in 17 districts and five divisional headquarters to promote regional cooperatives.

Referring to certain delay in procurement of paddy this year, Nitish said the government was working to sort out few issues in paddy procurement which were cropped up due to change in climate. “The cooperative minister and the chief secretary are monitoring the matter,” he said.

Nitish also said agriculture equipment worth up to Rs15 lakh would be provided to each PACS in the state. Of the total amount, the Centre would provide Rs10 lakh while state government provides Rs5 lakh as subsidy.

The CM requested the PACS chairpersons to purchase at least four agriculture equipment — happy seeder, zero tillage machine, rotary mulcher and reaper binder — for their members. State government is providing 75% subsidy on the purchase of these equipment, he said, adding the government recently made payments through government e-marketplace (GeM) portal for purchase of equipment in 2,917 cooperative societies.

Nitish said the state government has begun the process for appointment of 25 woman assistant managers in the cooperative banks.

Agriculture minister Prem Kumar, state cooperative minister Rana Randhir Singh, LJP MP Chirag Paswan, BISCOMAUN chairman Sunil Kumar Singh and Bihar State Cooperative Bank Limited chairman Ramesh Chandra Choubey also addressed the conference.

Title: Bihar: Madhubani jeweller robbed of cash and jewellery worth Rs 11 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Motorcycle-borne criminals shot at a jeweller and looted cash and jewellery worth over Rs 11 lakh from him in Madhubani district on Sunday. The victim, Shrawan Kumar, was admitted to the Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital (DMCH) for treatment.

The incident took place around 8.30am when Shrawan was on way to his shop from his house under the Rajnagar police station area in the district. Five criminals riding two motorcycles intercepted him near Narhari Bhagwanpur and attempted to snatch his bag containing money and gold jewellery.

One of the robbers pumped three bullets into Shrawan’s body when he resisted the loot. The criminals then escaped with the bag containing Rs 1.25 lakh in cash and gold jewellery worth Rs 10 lakh. The injured was rushed to the Raj Nagar referral hospital from where he was shifted to sadar hospital at Madhubani.

“The borders of the district have been sealed and vehicle checking drive launched to arrest the criminals involved in the incident,” Madhubani additional superintendent of police Kamini Bala said.

The victim’s younger brother, Manohar Kumar, told police that Shrawan had left home around 8am for the shop at Rajnagar on his motorbike. “I reached the hospital after being informed by some local residents, who had admitted Shrawan to the hospital for treatment,” a police officer quoted Manohar as saying.

Meanwhile, the jewellery shop owners of Rajnagar observed bandh to protest the incident. They have threatened to launch an agitation if the robbers are not arrested soon. “We have given a 48-hour ultimatum to police to arrest the criminals,” Rajesh Gupta, a jewellery shop owner, said.

Title: Tejashwi Yadav promises domicile policy for Bihar government jobs
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

RJD leader Tejashwi Prasad Yadav addresses 'Berozgari Hatao Yatra' public meeting at Veterinary College Ground... Read More

PATNA: RJD leader Tejashwi Prasad Yadav said on Sunday that if voted to power in the coming assembly election, his party would introduce a domicile policy and reserve 85% of the state government’s jobs for natives of Bihar.

Launching his much-publicized ‘Berozgaari Hatao Yatra’ from the Veterinary College ground here, Tejashwi said if voted to power, he would advertise vacancies and hold competitive examinations on a regular basis to provide jobs to the youths. “A strong political will is needed to remove unemployment . We have that political will. We will carry out all necessary exercises to provide jobs to the unemployed youths of the state,” he told a large gathering.

The younger son of incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad criticized the NDA government in state for failing to provide enough jobs to the unemployed youths.

He asked CM Nitish Kumar to either provide jobs to the unemployed or join his ‘yatra’ which was aimed to highlight the burning issue of unemployment. “In the last 15 years, Bihar has witnessed an unprecedented increase in the unemployment rate,” he claimed.

“This yatra is being launched to expedite our struggle against unemployment. State’s unemployment figures are highest in the last 45 years. Bihar is the youngest state, but I am sad to say that it has the highest unemployment rate in the country at 11.47%. We are fighting to provide you jobs but CM Nitish Kumar ji is busy in saving his job (chair),” Tejashwi, who is the leader of opposition in the state assembly, said.

Tejashwi, who is projected as the RJD’s CM face for the coming election, also accused the Nitish government of “killing reservation” in the state. “Nitish government is behaving like a contract killer. They are killing reservation. They are murdering the spirit of the Constitution,” he alleged.

The RJD leader also said he would set up special economic zones and information technology parks in the state to create job avenues for highly qualified youths.

It was for the first time that the picture of Lalu Prasad was conspicuously absent from the dais of an RJD event. Even after Lalu was sent to jail following his conviction in the fodder scam cases, his picture used to dominate the RJD podiums.

Title: Bihar: 2 universities plan revival of near-extinct scripts
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Two universities in Bihar have taken up the challenge to keep alive scripts such as Brahmi , Kaithi , Mithilakshar (Tirhut) and several others that are on the verge of extinction.

Patna and Munger universities plan to train students in writing and understanding these endangered scripts to help conserve valuable manuscripts and historical documents.

While Patna University is contemplating a workshop on the importance of these endangered scripts, Munger University (MU) has decided to introduce a certificate course. These scripts were widely used in Bihar, parts of Nepal and Uttar Pradesh until recently by scholars.

PU vice-chancellor Rash Bihari Prasad Singh told this newspaper that all records of government offices and courts were mostly written in Kaithi script, but now it is difficult to find people who can easily decipher them.

“The number of people using this script even in courts has dwindled considerably in recent decades. Hence, it is essential to train youngsters to read and write in this script. The university will soon organize a series of workshops and training programmes in this regard,” Singh said.

MU vice-chancellor Ranjit Kumar Verma said, “The curriculum for the certificate course in endangered scripts such as Kaithi and Mithilakshar has been prepared and the course would be introduced from the next academic session.”

The former head of PU’s ancient history and archaeology department, Jayadeo Mishra, said the importance of Kaithi in north Indian society can be measured by the activities for which it was employed and by the number of materials written and printed in the script.

“Use of Kaithi for administrative purposes is attested from at least the 16th century through the first decade of the 20th century. Kaithi was selected by the government of Bihar as the official script of the courts and administrative offices of the Bihar districts in 1880. Thereafter, Kaithi replaced the Persian script as the writing system of record in the judicial courts of Bihar,” he explained.

“Government gazetteers report that Kaithi was used in a few districts of Bihar till the 1960s. It is possible that Kaithi is still used today in a very limited capacity in these districts and in rural areas of north India. On account of the magnitude of documents in Kaithi, the script remains important for modern scholars working with such sources,” Mishra added.

The former head of PU’s Hindi department, Dinesh Prasad Singh, expressed his concern over these scripts on the verge of extinction. He said, “Maithili scholars have stopped writing in Mithilkshar and surprisingly enough, even the name of PU Maithili department is not written in Mithilakshar script.”

Singh demanded the implementation of the recommendations of the committee constituted by the Union HRD ministry in 2018 for the promotion and protection of Maithili language and its scripts. “A major recommendation of the committee was to establish a script and manuscripts centre in Darbhanga either at K S D Sanskrit University or at L N Mithila University,” he said.

“The committee had suggested completion of preparation of Unicode Script for Mithilakshar by Technology Development of Indian Languages and creating audio-visual teaching material for teaching Mithilakshar,” he added.

Title: Bihar governor to address joint sitting of House on Monday
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bihar governor Phagu Chauhan

PATNA: The monthlong budget session of the state legislature will begin on Monday with governor Phagu Chauhan addressing the joint session of the state assembly and legislative council in the central hall of the extended legislature building. It will be the present governor’s first address to the joint session of the state legislature.

Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi will table the Economic Survey Report for 2019-20 and follow it up by presenting the state budget on Tuesday. The budget session will have 22 sittings and the House will be adjourned on March 31.

The budgetary allocations for expenditures in the 2019-20 fiscal had been Rs 2.05 lakh crore. However, with the Centre constrained on the financial front, the state government’s expectations regarding the money flow from the Centre during the 2020-21 fiscal might not be bullish, the observers felt.

Around mid-March, Modi will also table three separate budgets – gender budget, child budget and environment, forest and climate change budget – giving details on the amount of money allotted by the government for expenditure during the 2020-21 fiscal.

While the opening day of the budget session would witness noisy scenes, the things might not remain the same on other days. “We will not disrupt the Question Hour on any day because we also the House to function in a peaceful manner. However, if the government does not give its replies on the burning issues, we will definitely register our protests,” senior RJD legislator Bhai Birendra said.

The CPI(ML), which has three members in the House, has decided to organize march to the state assembly on February 25, demanding a resolution passed by the House that the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Population Register and National Register of Citizens would not be implemented in the state.

Title: Students wash utensils in Jaipur government school in Sanganer
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Students who were washing utensils were around 12 years old

JAIPUR: While chief minister Ashok Gehlot allocated highest budget to the education sector stating education to be the top priority, students can be seen washing utensils in the government schools in Jaipur.

On Wednesday, the TOI reporter visited Government Higher Secondary School , Sanganer, where the students could be seen washing utensils. There were big steel pots and plates near water taps in the school. After the mid-day meal was served, three to five students were involved in washing utensils during school time.

Looking at the reporter clicking photographs, one school staff immediately called the students back. The students who were washing utensils were around 12 years old.

Later, one school staff who did not wish to be named said that the government has removed the cook-cum-help, which has made it difficult for the teachers to cope. “Since 2016, when Akshay Patra started supplying food to government schools, the government removed the cook-cum-helps from the schools. I agree that the food is not prepared at the schools, but we have big utensils where the food is collected from Akshay Patra. Who is supposed to wash them?” said one school teacher.

When TOI contacted district education officer, Ramchand Pilaniya, he said that department will look into the matter. “Government provides funds to schools to hire any person for washing utensils, but if the students are made to wash dishes, we will look into it and required action will be taken,” said Pilaniya.

Teachers however deny any financial assistance from the government. “Government provides Rs 500 for the milk scheme. Who is going to wash utensils in Jaipur city for Rs 500? Whenever we try to hire someone he/she asks for at least Rs 8,000 a month. Government should re-transfer the cook-cum-help in the schools. This is the only solution,” said another school teacher.

As the blame game continues between the teachers and the administration, students are washing utensils during their study hours.

Title: Admin wants complete ban on entry of tourists to Taj Mahal mausoleum today
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Agra: An order of the district administration directing the ASI not to sell any entry tickets to the main mausoleum on Monday – the day of the US President Donald Trump’s visit to Taj Mahal – has led to a lot of confusion as online sale of these tickets has already taken place and hence entry of tourists cannot be stopped.

The order, signed by SSP Babloo Kumar, which was issued on Sunday, directs the ASI to ensure that only entry tickets to the Taj should be sold for Monday and the main mausoleum be kept out of bounds.

The order also states that the ongoing Taj Mahotsav should not be held on Monday due to Trump’s visits. The SSP’s order has left the ASI officials in a quandary.

“We cannot stop the entry of the tourists with valid tickets,” said an official.

When contacted, ASI superintending archeologist, ASI (Agra circle), Vasant K Swarankar, said that tickets are available online and are pre-booked and it will be very difficult to stop sale of the tickets or the entry of the tourists who have bought them.

Surprised with the district administration’s move, Rajiv Saxena, vice-president of Tourism Guild, Agra, said that the government should ensure that the visit of VVIPs should not affect the trip of common tourists to the monument. They should understand the importance of tourism.

He said while it is understandable that movement of tourists is restricted during the VVIPs’ visit but “people should not be harassed in the name of security arrangements”. He said, “It’s unfortunate that the movement of golf carts was stopped on Sunday from Trident and elderly tourists were made to walk.”

The Union Ministry for Culture and Tourism had introduced a separate entry ticket of Rs 200 to the main mausoleum in December 2018. Prior to it, there was a single entry ticket for entering the Taj premises.

Meanwhile, ASI issued a notice that Taj Mahal will be closed for public from 11:30 am for one hour before the monument is closed on Monday. According to ASI officials, US President Trump will reach the monument by 5:10 pm and will leave after 65 minutes.

Title: Harassed by lender, trader gets him stabbed by three
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Rajkot: Fed up of pestering by his money lender , a trader allegedly got him stabbed on Morbi Road by three hooligans on Saturday evening.

The complaint in this connection was lodged with Rajkot B division police station on Sunday.

Police said the accused Prakash Thakkar gave ‘supari’ (contract) to Kana Bharwad, Gopal Bharwad and their unidentified associate to attack Dharmesh Himani (29).

Himani told police said that Thakkar owed Rs two lakh to him, which he had been demanding for the past fortnight. Kana, Gopal and their associate called Himani outside his imitation jewellery unit on Morbi Road.

“The trio kidnapped Himani a bike and took him to a ground behind Juni Dholakia School. They threatened to kill him if he continued to pester Thakkar for money. Then Gopal and his unidentified aide grabbed him from behind and Kana stabbed him twice in his stomach and back,” said V J Fernandis, inspector with Rajkot B division police station.

Police have launched a manhunt for the accused, including Thakkar, who have gone absconding ever since the complaint was lodged against them.

Title: Bootlegger torches cop and his car in Songadh during raid
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Surat: A head constable posted in squad of Vyara deputy superintendent of police suffered serious burn injuries when a bootlegger doused him in inflammable material and torched him during a raid on Saturday.

Notorious bootlegger Mulji Gamit also set the cop's private car ablaze in Maiyali village near Songadh of Tapi district. In the incident, Gamit too received burn injuries.

According to the police, Prabhatsinh Baraiya, head constable in Tapi district, suffered around 50 percent burn injuries in the incident. Baraiya, had gone to check on bootlegging activity in the area with two other colleagues. They stopped at Gamit’s residence to check. History-sheeter Gamit, who was present at the spot, objected to the checking.

Baraiya noticed a container and when he went to check its contents, Gamit lifted and flung the container filled with inflammable material towards Baraiya, said cops. Later he also poured the liquid on Baraiya's car and set it ablaze. Meanwhile, Baraiya and Gamit who were drenched with the inflammable material, got trapped in the flames.

Both were shifted to hospital with burn injuries, said cops, adding that Gamit was angry with the police since they frequently visited his home to check if he is selling liquor.

Police have booked Gamit for alleged attempt to murder.

"Following information Baraiya went to the spot to check if Gamit is selling liquor and during the checking the accused turned violent. Police have seized the container of inflamable liquor and have sent it to forensic science laboratory to find out what material was thrown on the cop and his car," said a police officer.

Title: House burgled; cash, valuables worth Rs 3.7L stolen
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Rajkot: Finding a vacant house , burglars looted Rs1.50 lakh in cash and gold and silver jewellery, all worth Rs3.68 lakh in Makaji Meghpar village of Kalawad taluka in Jamnagar district on Friday night.

The owner of the house Pradeep Parmar lodged a complaint with the police on Saturday.

“In his complaint, Parmar said the theft had occurred when he had been away along with his family to attend a marriage function in Makaji Meghpar village. The burglars had gained entry into the house by breaking the locks,” said S M Radadia, sub-inspector with Kalawad rural police station.

“This case has become difficult for us to investigate as there are no CCTV cameras in the village. Yet, we are confident that we will crack the case. We are now checking those cell phone numbers that were active at the crime spot during the crime and trying to get a clue and zero in on the suspects,” added Radadia.

Title: SMC panel begins probing ‘gynae tests’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Surat: A three-member committee formed by Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani has initiated probe into the alleged controversial gynaec tests of probationary woman clerks.

Some of the women alleged they had been made to stand naked in the state-run Surat Municipal Institute of Medical Education and Research (SMIMER), for a long time while lady doctors subjected them to a finger test and asked personal questions. The committee is registering statements of all the concerned parties to the issue.

The panel comprising Kalpana Desai, former dean of Gayatri Jariwala, assistant municipal commissioner, SMC and Trupti Kalthariya, executive engineer, SMC, are probing the issue. However, none of the women who had to face the humiliating test have come forward.

The committee members called SMC Employees Union (SMCEU) members to record their statements as well as provide details of the victims. However, SMCEU sources informed that the complainants’ names will not be divulged for fears of reprisal as well as not to breach confidentiality.
