The committee will also record statements of the gynaecologists in SMIMER and other senior officials. The committee has randomly chosen a few probationary clerks who underwent the gynaecology tests for fitness certificate and called them to register their statement.

Meanwhile, Gujarat State Commission for Women (GSCW) has asked for a report over the issue from the city police commissioner R B Brahmbhatt. “Police will submit a report to the commission that there is no criminal angle to the issue and hence, there is no role for the police in it," Brahmbhatt told TOI.

Title: City’ Hall of Fame to celebrate its iconic achievers & legends
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

VARANASI: The city will soon have its own Madame Tussauds Musuem housing life-size sculptures of the famous personalities of the city, though not in wax.

In a bid to attract more tourists, a plan to establish a ‘ Hall of fame’ like structure, with memorials dedicated to famous or illustrious personalities of the city, especially recipients of Bharat Ratna, Padma awards and those who have earned name in different fields living in other cities or abroad, is being worked on. The galleries dedicated to selected dignitaries will also have their life-size sculptures on the lines of Madame Tussaud ’s museum, although in place of wax, the sculptures will be made of metal, stone or clay here.

Disclosing the plan of the proposed museum of dignitaries to TOI on Sunday, UP minister of state (independent charge) for tourism, culture and religious affairs Neelkanth Tiwari said, “Apart from heritage and religious tourism we are also working for the promotion of cultural tourism to ensure more tourist footfall here. Stepping ahead in the same direction, a plan of developing a museum of dignitaries and legends of Varanasi had been conceived a few months ago and its detailed project report is also being finalised now.”

“The project will be collectively executed by the culture and tourism departments,” he said adding that apart from exploring venues to establish this mueseum in the limits of the city, areas area also being explored in outskirts of Varanasi as this museum is being proposed in 15 acre land. Huge land is required for the museum as the basic idea is to dedicate gallery to each dignitary to display his life since birth till death with achievements in fields concerned, said Tiwari.

Regarding the dignitaries selected for exhibiting in the proposed museum, divisional commissioner Deepak Agrawal said, “So far a list of 100 dignitaries including Bharat Ratna, Padma awards recipients and others, who, though living in other cities or abroad, remained associated with Varanasi and earned name in different fields, have been prepared. Basic documentation on their work and achievements has also been started. The work is likely to complete by March end. After the finalisation of this documentation and DPR by the end of the current financial year, it will be forwarded to the state government with the commencement of new financial year 2020-21 in April.”

The list of dignitaries to have galleries dedicated to them includes the names of Bharat Ratna awardees- Bhagwan Das, former Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri, Sitar maestro Pt Ravi Shankar, Shehnai exponent Ustad Bismillah Khan, founder of Banaras Hindu University Pt Madan Mohan Malviya and Padma awards recipients, who have a huge number in Varanasi from the fields of music, dance, religion, academics, medical, weaving art and social works.

The material to be used for creating sculptures of the selected dignitaries has not been finalised yet, said Tiwari. As per the sources, initially use of stone and bronze was proposed to make the sculpturs for this mueseum. But, now the possibility of using clay for sculptures is also being explored to promote clay artistes and also to bring down cost of the project, they added.

Title: Secunderabad: Tippler threatens to jump off street light pole, rescued
Content:
The man in question, Mohammed Ijaz, is a resident of Begumpet and was working as a cable operator, until he lo... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: A 35-year-old drunk man climbed on top of a street light and threatened to jump off at SP Road on Sunday. Civilians tried to lure him down with liquor bottles but failed. Officials from Gopalpuram police station, fire department and GHMC rescued him after an hour.The man in question, Mohammed Ijaz, is a resident of Begumpet and was working as a cable operator, until he lost his job a month ago.“He has been addicted to alcohol for years. He would come home drunk and fight with his wife regularly. He was fired because he would report to duty in a drunken state,” said Gopalpuram inspector, Sai Eshwar Goud.On Sunday, he climbed a street light pole at 1 pm in drunken state and threatened to jump off the pole. “Some 10 policemen tried to talk him out of it. We put a tarpaulin and a net below the pole, in case he jumped or fell.” added the officer.After almost an hour-and-a-half, the man was rescued. “He was upset about his job. He couldn't afford alcohol and his wife refused to give him money for liquor,” said the inspector. No case has been registered against Ijaz.

Title: Jafrabad Protest News: Kapil Mishra sets 3-day deadline for cops to remove Jafrabad blockade
Content:
Mishra said if anti-CAA protesters could agitate, those in favour of the Act, too, had the right to protest

दिल्ली पुलिस को तीन दिन का अल्टीमेटम - जाफराबाद और चांद बाग की सड़कें खाली करवाइए इसके बाद हमें मत समझाइयेगा , हम आ… https://t.co/8YADNolGMb — Kapil Mishra (@KapilMishra_IND) 1582458062000

NEW DELHI: BJP leader and former MLA Kapil Mishra on Sunday gave a three-day ultimatum to Delhi Police to remove the Jafrabad blockade . Mishra landed up with his supporters and party workers in the area on Sunday afternoon after which protesters threw stones at them and tension simmered in the area. According to police personnel present on the spot, stone-pelting started after Mishra left.“Dilli Police ko teen din ka ultimatum — Jafrabad aur Chand Bagh ki sadkein khali karwaiye..iske baad hamein mat samjhaiyega...hum aapki bhi nahi sunenge..sirf teen din..,” (Three-day ultimatum for Delhi Police — Get the roads of Jafrabad and Chand Bagh vacated...after this don’t try to persuade us...we will not listen to you...just three days) he tweeted at 5.11pm. Mishra had tweeted at 1.22pm asking people to assemble at the Maujpur Chowk traffic signal at 3pm to support CAA .Speaking to TOI, Mishra said the anti-CAA protesters who blocked the Chand Bagh road in north-east Delhi had forced him to come out and protest. “They have blocked two major roads, which will restrict the movement of over 35 lakh people living in that part of the city. People cannot go to work, children won’t be able to go to schools,” he said.The former MLA, who unsuccessfully contested the recent assembly polls from Model Town, said if the road was not opened within three days, he will “democratically and peacefully” protest from Wednesday. “If they (those opposed to CAA) have the right to protest, we too have that right,” he added. The BJP leader, however, insisted that the pro-CAA protesters didn’t indulge in any kind of violence.Speaking at the spot, Mishra said “These people want Delhi to keep burning which is why they have shut the roads and are making a riot-like atmosphere. We have not thrown any stone from our side,”Mishra then pointed at Ved Prakash Surya, district DCP, and said: “The DCP is standing with us, and I would like to let him know on behalf of you all (protesters) that till US President Donald Trump is in the country, we won’t do anything. But after he leaves, we will not listen to you.” He concluded with ‘Bharat Mata ki Jai’ which his supporters repeated after him.

Title: Alkaline water units start again after two-year gap
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: After a long gap, the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) has decided to re-launch the alkaline water units with new features in 200 places across the city.

To provide safe and clean drinking water to Pink City residents , JMC had launched these units in 2018. Initially, they were installed in 15 places. Later on due to revenue issues between JMC and contractors (EKA JAL), the units stopped functioning. Now, after an agreement, it has again begun.

JMC deputy commissioner Arun Garg said after due consideration, the units were again given a green light. “In few places, the units have started to function,” said Garg.

The company has even proposed to install sanitary pad vending machine, wi-fi and security cameras in the water units. Sanitary pad vending machines will be installed in front of the university, colleges and hostels. Camera will be connected to police headquarters for security purposes.

First opened at the time of former mayor Ashok Lahoty, these were meant to supply alkaline water with a content of silver. The normal cost of this water starts from Rs 600 to Rs 10,000 per litre in the world, but the company will be providing it to JMC for free with the help of the monetary help from the World Bank. About Rs 15 lakh has been spent on one drinking unit.

Currently, the units have been installed at JMC, one near Rajasthan University , railway station, at Jawahar Circle, Ganesh Temple, two on MI Road and other places. At many places, construction has started and is expected to be completed within a year.

Title: Donald Trump Agra Visit: Ahead of Donald Trump's visit, this Agra village recalls tryst with Dwight David Eisenhower 60 years ago
Content:
A village barely 15 kilometres away from Agra reminisces a winter afternoon spent with another US president ov... Read More

LARONDA (AGRA): As Agra is decked up like a bride to welcome US President Donald Trump and First Lady Milenia Trump on February 24, a village barely 15 kilometres away from the city reminisces a winter afternoon spent with another US president over six decades ago.Older residents of Laronda village in Bhichpuri block of Agra, especially those in their 70s and 80s, still remember how a convertible Dodge Kingsway of 1956 model had gently been driven into their village on December 13, 1959 with Pandit Jawahalal Nehru and then US President Dwight David Eisenhower perched on top of the backseat.Preparations were made beforehand. But they were nothing compared to what Agra has witnessed in the past week.“New roads were constructed, a proper drainage system was developed, a few ducks were brought for the village pond and all pucca houses and a primary school were painted white after putting a thin layer of cow dung. In fact, Pandit Nehru had flown to Agra a few days before the VVIP visit and inspected the preparations,” said Sukhbir Singh, 67, son of Tikam Singh, then block pramukh of Bhichpuri.Life was much simpler back then, recounts Ramesh Chandra, 69, son of then gram pradhan Karan Singh.“The village had a population of just 1,600. All of us gathered around Eisenhower and Pandit Nehru showering petals of roses and marigold on them. We offered them a simple lunch of bajre ki roti and lassi and then we roamed round the village with the leaders of the two nations, showing them our farms, cattle barns, school, pond and a newly constructed ‘panchayat ghar’,” Chandra said.“It was like a festival for us, which lasted for two hours. My mother Barfi Devi, now 91, brought an aarti thal to welcome the two leaders. During the aarti, Eisenhower was curious about the veiled faces of village women. To which, my mother and other women explained to him the importance of veil for Indian women,” he said.Barfi Devi has now lost her hearing ability, but her face beams when she is shown a picture of her her husband Karan Singh standing with the two leaders. “He (Eisenhower) was a tall man with a stately built. He bumped his head at the entrance of my house twice,” she recalls.Kale Devi, Barfi Devi’s sister-in-law who still covers her face with a veil at 81, said, “We explained to the US president that Indian women show their faces only to their father, husband, brothers or sons. On hearing this, both Eisenhower and Nehru told us to treat them as fatherly figures. We removed our veils and served them the lunch.”“During interaction with the villagers with the help of translators, Eisenhower revealed that he, too, came from country background and easily got attached to people who till land for a living,” Chandra said.The visit of Eisenhower brought both perks and plaudits for the village. The model village of 1959 still retains the crown.Kripal Singh, 54, the present gram pradhan of Laronda, said, “Our village has a prepaid water ATM, library with WiFi, solar street lights, two schools (a primary and a junior high school), water harvesting facility, concrete roads, city-standard drainage system and piped water connections. Besides, almost 75-80% of our population is literate and only 25% of the population is engaged in agriculture. Others work in factories, stores, private and government jobs. This happened because of Eisenhower’s 1959 visit.”The icing on the cake, however, was a letter the villagers later received from the White House.“…through my visit to Laronda, I learned much about the way of life in India’s half a million villages and their problems as farmers. I spent my own boyhood in a farming centre and when I am not in Washington, I’m on my farm. Thus close to the people who till the soil.“I was particularly interested in learning about the institution of the panchayat as counterpart of the kind of grass roots democracy we know in America,” Eisenhower wrote.Ever since that winter of 1959, both the village and its inhabitants had become a fond footnote to the history of Indo-US relations.

Title: Delhi Violence Today: 'Are you Hindu or Muslim?’;TOI photojournalist recounts Maujpur horror
Content:
A man walks past a vandalised shop following clashes between supporters and opponents of CAA at Bhajanpura on ... Read More

NEW DELHI: This story is all about how things have been spiralling out of control in northeast Delhi and how misguided youths have decided to take the law in their hands by unleashing violence based on religious identity.My horrifying experience began when I reached Maujpur Metro Station around 12.15pm. I was taken by surprise when a Hindu Sena member suddenly approached me offering to put tilak on my forehead saying it would make my work “easier”. He could see me with cameras, which identified me as a photojournalist. However, he was insistent. “You are also a Hindu, bhaiya. What is the harm?”Around 15 minutes later, stone-pelting began between two groups in the area. Amidst slogans of “Modi, Modi”, I spotted black smoke billowing in the sky. As I rushed towards the building on fire, a few men near a Shiv Mandir stopped me. When I told them I was going to take photographs, they told me not to go there. “Bhai, aap bhi to Hindu ho? Kyun jaa rahe ho? Aaj Hindu jaag gaya hai. (Brother, you are also a Hindu. Why are you going there? Hindus have woken up today,” said one of them.I stepped aside and after a short while navigated along the barricades to reach the spot. As soon as I started taking photos, a few men wielding bamboo sticks and rods surrounded me. They tried to snatch my camera, but my reporter colleague, Sakshi Chand, stepped in front of me and dared them to touch me. The men decided to slink away.A short while later I realised they were following me. A youth accosted me and asked, “Bhai, tu zyada uchhal raha hai. Tu Hindu hai ya Musalman? (Brother, you are acting very smart. Are you a Hindu or a Muslim?)” They threatened to take off my pants to confirm my religion. I then folded my hands and said I was just a lowly photographer. They then gave me a few threats, but let me go.Desperate to leave the area, I started looking for my office vehicle, but it was nowhere to be found. I then walked a few hundred metres towards Jafrabad when I spotted an autorickshaw. The driver agreed to take me to ITO.I later realised that the name embossed on the auto could land us in trouble with the mob around. As fate would have it, we were soon stopped by four men. They caught hold of our collars to drag us out of the auto. I pleaded with them to let us go, saying I was a press member and the auto driver was innocent.When the driver dropped me off, I realised he was shaken to the core. “I have never been questioned about my religion in this grotesque manner in my life,” he said before parting ways.

Title: Maharashtra: 4 new STPs set to battle Indrayani river pollution
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indrayani river

PUNE: The district administration is working on a plan to set up four sewage treatment plants (STPs) at Lonavla, Talegaon Dhabade, Kuruli and Alandi over the next one year for curbing the pollution of Indrayani river .

The condition of the river has deteriorated substantially as almost the entire stretch of its surface is covered by water hyacinth. This is the resultant effect of pollution. Release of untreated sewage water, generated at Lonavala, Talegaon Dhabade, Pimpri Chinchwad, Moshi and Alandi, has contributed to this situation.

"We plan to complete the STP projects in a year and have assigned work orders for the STPs at Lonavala and Talegaon Dabhade. Work orders for the Kuruli and Alandi STPs will be released in a few days,” Pune district collector Naval Kishor Ram told TOI.

The river originates from a spot near Lonavala and passes through Kamsheth, Talegaon Dhabade, Dehu, Pimpri-Chinchwad and Alandi before merging with Bhima river in Tulapur village, Shirur tehsil.

The Lonavala Municipal Council (LMC) has begun construction of 6 MLD capacity STP at Dongargaon village around 6km from the main town. “The old STP of 3.5 MLD capacity was not functional owing to multiple failure of systems in the last few months. The new STP’s work has begun at the site and we plan to complete the project by December 2020,” said Sachin Pawar, the LMC’s chief officer.

A 20km stretch of the river goes through the PCMC area. Many housing societies have released their drainage lines directly into the river at multiple locations. “We have initiated work for a drainage line network in Chikhali, Moshi and other areas which will be linked to STPs at Moshi and Charoli village. The work of a 15 MLD capacity STP at Chikhali is held up for now in view of a litigation before the NGT,” PCMC commissioner Shravan Hardikar said. “Alandi already has 4 MLD capacity STP which is not sufficient. We have decided to install new plant in coming months,” said Ram. Activist-lawyer Vilas Kate from Alandi said, “The river has literally turned black and remains the same all year .”

Title: Three held, one put under house arrest for Bhim Army’s bandh call
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: Three youths were detained while a local activist was put under house arrest to prevent any probable flare up in Meerut zone on the occasion of ‘ Bharat bandh ’ called by Dalit group Bhim Army on Sunday.

Badar Ali was put under house arrest. Ali had earlier led a protest march against Tabrez Ansari’s lynching case a couple of months ago that had turned violent. Meanwhile, Meerut SSP gave strict instructions to SHOs not to allow any “mob formation”.

Meerut SSP Ajay Sahni said, “All the station house officers were instructed to ensure that no crowd assembles on various road crossings and police were deployed at every location. All the station house officers were instructed to remain on their toes at the major crossings to ensure law and order.”

Members of the Bhim Army had called for a ‘bandh’ on April 2, 2018, to protest against SC/ST Amendment Act. At that time, vehicles were vandalised and burnt on Kankerkhera crossing. Shobhapur police post was also burnt. At least 200 people were arrested and sent to jail at that time.

The intelligence department had alerted the police about possible protests by Bhim Army on February 23, especially in the backdrop of CAA and NRC. In this regard, police officials in Meerut stepped up their security in Soti Ganj, Sadar Bazar, Partapur, Mavana and Parikshit Garh, among other areas.

Title: Muzaffarnagar cops bust illegal arms making factory, one arrested
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: Police in Muzaffarnagar busted an illegal arms making factory inside a forest area in Charthawal on Sunday. Police arrested one person and seized several illegal arms making equipment.

After receiving information, a team from Charthawal police station raided a forest area in Khusropur and arrested a man named Jahangir. One of his associates managed to flee. Police have recovered four country-made muskets, seven pistols and welding machine, among other equipment and materials.

Superintendent of police Satpal Antil said, “We are now trying to find the place from where the arrested man used to get raw materials and where he used to supply these illegal weapons to. We are also trying to trace his associate who fled from the spot.”

Police sources said a case under various sections was registered at Charthawal police station and accused was sent to jail. Notably, Muzaffarnagar police busted an illegal arms factory and seized country-made weapons and arms manufacturing equipment from the Kotwali area, last week.

Title: Man attacked for objecting to open defecation in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Requesting two men to avoid open defecation near his house on Friday night proved costly for a 45-year-old transport operator from Shel Pimpalgaon near Chakan , about 40km from here.

A man assaulted him with a sharp weapon while his accomplice tried to attack the victim’s tenant. The victim, Avinash Shitole, sustained blows on his back, left hand and near his left ear. Shitole’s tenant escaped unhurt as he dodged the blows.

The Chakan police arrested Nitin Karale (21) and Sandip Sonawane (30) both of Shel Pimaplgaon under sections 307 (murder attempt) and 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) of the IPC.

Shitole was discharged from the hospital on Sunday night. He told TOI that on Friday around 9.15pm, he was sitting outside his house. “I heard some noise, so I went to check along with my tenant Ramu Prajapati. I saw two men defecating in the open near my house,” Shitole said.

He requested them not to do it in the open. “Karale began abusing me and removed a sharp weapon and threatened to kill me. He assaulted me. I received three blows on my body and fell,” Shitole said. The other man tried attacking Prajapati. “He dodged the blow and fled. My relatives took me to a hospital,” he said. “We have arrested the duo” a Chakan police officer said.

Title: Fragrance of jasmine and itra to welcome Donald Trump in Agra
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Workers carry Indian flags to decorate a road leading to Taj Mahal in Agra (AP Photo)

AGRA: Fragrance of jasmine and itra will welcome US President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump at the Taj Mahal today. Hundreds of garlands of jasmine and dozens of diffusers with itra, especially supplied from Kannauj, have been placed in the vicinity of the Taj.

On February 19, during his visit to Agra to check preparations for hosting the state guests on February 24, chief minister Yogi Adityanath had expressed discontent over stench in the vicinity of the monument. Mayor Naveen Jain had told CM that it is due to the Taj east drain. The CM had issued strict orders to the local authorities to get time-bound solution for the problem.

On the next day, the Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) started deep cleaning of the Taj east drain located just 200 metres away from the east side of the monument.

Using bioenzymes supplied from Visakhapatnam, on Friday, phytoremediation process was started to reduce foul smell emanating from the drain.

According to the civic body officials, the scientific process takes 72 hours to remove any foul smell from the time it is implemented.

AMC executive engineer (environment) Rajeev Rathi said, “Phytoremediation process is doing its job. Best results will emerge by Monday morning. Now, no foul smell can be experienced in the vicinity of the Taj Mahal. The jasmine flower garlands and diffusers with itra have been placed by the horticulture department.”

The civic body in coordination with the horticulture department has installed pots of variety of flowers on footpaths and at roundabouts. Exotic flowers have been planted on the road dividers.

Meanwhile, teams of AMC workers began final washing of the 14-kilometre VVIP route from Kheria airbase to Taj Mahal on Sunday afternoon. Trees on the route are also being washed using water sprays. The work will continue till 12 noon on Sunday.

Title: Maharashtra NCC squadron starts four sorties for air cadets
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

PUNE: The 3 Maharashtra NCC Air Squadron of Pune has started giving four air sorties to its senior division air cadets to acquaint them with flying training and teach nuances of aircraft and its cockpit systems.

The squadron could arrange only one or no air sortie to air cadets due to administrative reasons like unavailability of aircraft and runway in the recent past. As a result, most of the cadets could only learn the theory aspect of the training.

The city’s NCC’s Group Headquarters got two new microlight aircraft – Pipistrel Virus SW 80s — to facilitate flight training for its cadets in 2018. Since then, the squadron has been conducting training sessions on a regular basis at the NDA runway.

“Our endeavour is to give maximum first-hand flying experience to our cadets. Hence, we have increased sorties from one to four for the first time. In the first sortie, air cadets just get confidence about flying and in subsequent sorties, they understand many aspects of aircraft system and its functioning. This clears several concepts that they have learned in theory syllabus,” Wing Commander Vikram Thiagaraman, commanding officer of the squadron, said. The flight training curriculum stated that an air cadet would accompany an IAF pilot in the cockpit for a sortie that can last in the range of 15 minutes to an hour.

NCC Group Commander Brigadier Suneel Limaye said, “Getting flying experience in the formative years of career makes a positive impact on students. We are also giving flying exposure to rural students.”

Title: Madurai: Corporation organises free medical camp
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

Madurai: A Health Mela was organised in the city on Sunday to provide free medical check-up and speciality consultation for the public, by the Madurai corporation and health department. It was inaugurated by Madurai MP Su Venkatesan and minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju, who gave away nutrition kits for pregnant women in the presence of district collector Dr TG Vinay and other senior district officials.

Around 1,000 people took part the medical camp held at Thiru Vi Ka higher secondary school in Aruldaspuram. Doctors from around 10 different specialities including dentistry, dermatology, ophthalmology, gynaecology and orthopaedics were available at the event. “Everyone who registers get their basic height, weight, BMI and blood pressure checked. Then, a general medicine doctor would see them and direct them to the necessary speciality. We even included ECG and ultrasonogram facility for pregnant women,” said a medical officer.

Cancer screening for women, including breast examination was also done. Pregnant women were also educated about various nutritious foods they should include in their diet. Spot registration for getting Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) ID, a unique identification number mandatory for all pregnant mothers, was also done at the mela.

Various exhibits were also kept by health department officials about both communicable and non-communicable diseases including AIDS, dengue and leprosy to create awareness. “We cannot afford to go for health check-ups regularly and nor do we have the luxury of going to different specialists. Such camps are helpful for us since we can find all services of different specialists at one place,” said Kanimozhi K, a resident of Aruldaspuram.

In Tuticorin, a special medical camp and eye care camp was inaugurated by information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju. The minister also gave away free spectacles to those diagnosed with poor eye sight.

Title: Delhi violence: TOI correspondent tells her first hand experience
Content:
Visual of violence from Chand Bagh. (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Walking from Jafrabad metro Station towards Maujpur-Babarpur station , I could never imagine that the second day of the protests would be as ugly as what unfolded in front of my eyes.As I stood a few metres ahead of Maujpur-Babarpur station, I could hear rounds being fired one after the other. My first instinct was that it was a gun going off, but after seeing a white plume of smoke I realised that police were firing tear gas shells. Minutes later, I saw two men running carrying an injured policeman on their shoulder. The cop was rushed away in a police Gypsy.Some youths were putting tilak on the forehead of passersby and when they approached me, I politely refused. The loudspeakers at Maujpur Chowk were constantly blaring “Jai Shri Ram”.I soon saw anti-CAA protesters on one side of the road near Kabir Nagar and pro-CAA agitators on the other side. The small bridge over the drain was the only saving grace as police stood guard there creating a no man’s land. Mediapersons trying to move ahead were asked to stay back as stones were being hurled. The stone-pelters were wearing helmets.Even as police tried to defuse the situation, news of protesters setting a house on fire spread. I ran towards the chowk and saw a tower of smoke coming out from near a garbage dump. I saw a mob breaking the locks of shops with lathis and throwing something on fire inside.When I tried to capture it on my cellphone, a youth shouted: “Snatch her phone. The media is recording us and not them.” I quietly put away my phone. A mob soon came charging towards us and I managed to hang on to a railing with the help of TOI photojournalist Anindya Chattopadhyay. This happened twice.I walked back to Maujpur Chowk and saw a 60-strong mob asking a man walking out of Kabir Nagar for his identity and then thrashing him. Police rushed in and the man with a bloody face was carried away by four people. I next saw a man breaking the nameplate of a bakery with the others around him clapping gleefully.The biggest fear I witnessed was walking out of the area. Walking over the stones and bricks, people thought I was a stone-pelter. Luckily, I and two other reporters managed to reach our car. The fear of a stone being thrown from a rooftop hitting me still haunts me. I will carry a helmet tomorrow.

Title: Officials go all out to rein in copying mafia
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Varanasi: District administration, police and education department officials in Ballia are making concerted efforts to hit at the root of copying mafia who are still facilitating admissions to candidates as regular students in local colleges assuring help in copying during examinations.

District magistrate, Ballia, Hari Pratap Shahi on Saturday talked to 43 students from Saharanpur and Shahjahanpur districts of UP and also from Uttarakhand, who quit the examination as they were not helped by copying mafia as promised, and directed Bansdih police to lodge FIRs against the persons named by the candidates.

Talking to TOI on Sunday, Shahi said: “These 43 students revealed how they were contacted by middlemen, who offered them to facilitate admission as regular students in schools and colleges in Ballia and get registered for UP Board examination without attending classes.”

He said the accused men had even assured students that they would help them pass the examination. “The students said despite paying huge amount they could not get chance for copying due to which they had no option but to quit the examination,” Shahi said.

He said in view of notoriety earned by Ballia due to copying mafia in the past, the district administration ensured deployment of static supervisors at all 213 examination centres in Ballia, besides deploying zonal and sector magistrates.

These measures are apart from implementation of all other directives of state government like covering examination rooms with CCTV network and webcasting of all centres.

District inspector of schools (DIoS), Ballia, Bhaskar Mishra said: “Besides these 43 students, 12,431 examinees of high school and 8,049 of intermediate have quit UP Board examination in the district this year. As many as 82,206 and 77,099 students, respectively, were enrolled for high school and intermediate examinations.”

Earlier, sector magistrate and tehsildar Gulab Chandra ensured the arrest of a peon Biskut Yadav. An FIR was lodged against Yadav and Ram Kumar Shukla, manager of Sukhpura Public Higher Secondary School, on Saturday in connection with copying.

SDM, Bansdih, Dushyant Kumar Maurya in Ballia also detected a case of mass copying at Panchev Devi Rajmuni Devi Inter College in Bigahi Bahuara. A case was registered against the centre in charge who managed to escape.

The DIoS said re-examination of physics (intermediate) examination at a centre in Bhauara area had been recommended following detection of mass copying.

“So far, 35 students have been caught for copying. A candidate was arrested after it was found that he was appearing for both high school and intermediate examinations,” he said.

Title: To cut costs, Jaipur metro phase-II route will be totally elevated
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot addresses a gathering at Birla Auditorium on Sunday

JAIPUR: Jaipur Metro phase-II corridor proposed between Ambabari and Sitapura, which was scheduled to run partially underground, will be entirely elevated.

To reduce the cost of the Rs 13,000-crore project, Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) has proposed to construct approximately 23-km corridor overground.

Sources said the DMRC had prepared the revised DPR, which is likely to be forwarded to the state government this week. The approval of detailed project report (DPR) will be made in the state cabinet meeting.

The project cost is expected to be reduced to half if it is elevated. “Now, we have proposed to construct an elevated corridor on major part of the route. While construction cost of an elevated corridor is Rs 200 crore per km, it goes up Rs 550 crore per km underground,” said a senior Jaipur Metro Rail Corporation (JMRC) official.

In the DPR prepared in 2014, it was mentioned that project required land worth Rs 2,000 crore. “It would require less amount than mentioned in the previous DPR. The estimated cost for acquiring land will be reduced to Rs 800,” said a source

The official further said Metro stations, which will be constructed under the Jaipur Metro Phase-II, will not be lavish and spacious as the existing ones. JMRC has proposed to construct small structures, which would occupy less land and need less funds. The decision was taken after taking a cue from Delhi and Chennai. To bring the cost down, suggestion to run three coaches has been also been proposed.

“Many cities in past adopted rationalisation method during the construction of new Metro projects. In Jaipur too, few ways including reducing width of the viaduct by 15%, cutting down length of Metro stations, reducing size of the two Metro rail depots and outsourcing fare collection system are proposed,” said a JMRC official.

After the change in regime, hope of launching the Phase-II project has revived as Metro was the pet project of chief minister Ashok Gehlot in his previous tenure. The JMRC prepared its first DPR in 2011 during the Congress government’s tenure.

Title: HC notice to Centre over green nod for Central Vista
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

New Delhi: A day before the Centre begins the process of seeking environment clearances (EC) for the new Parliament and Central Vista project , Delhi high court on Monday heard a plea challenging the move .

The court asked the Centre and the Central Public Works Department (CPWD) to respond to the plea seeking that no EC be granted to cut trees for the expansion and renovation of the Parliament building, which is part of the Central Vista redevelopment project. Justice Rajiv Shakdher issued a notice to the housing ministry and CPWD to submit their stand on the application filed by a Delhi resident, Anuj Srivastava.

While refusing to stay the ministry’s expert appraisal committee from entertaining CPWD’s application for EC on Tuesday, the judge said its decision must be communicated to the court immediately.

Srivastava has earlier filed another petition opposing the entire project on the ground that it involves a change in the land use of the green area adjoining Rajpath and Vijay Chowk for building a new Parliament and government offices. On Monday, the court pointed out that even if EC was granted, CPWD could not cut trees as the main legal challenge on the land-use change had been pending.

Appearing for CPWD, additional solicitor general Maninder Acharya assured the court that the trees cut for the project would be transplanted at a suitable location and if any of them didn’t survive, trees aged 7-8 years would be planted as replacement.

Title: Delhi Lucknow Highway Accident: Vehicles run over accident victim for 12 hours on Delhi-Lucknow highway in Amroha
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

AMROHA: A pedestrian, who “in all likelihood” got mowed down while crossing Delhi-Lucknow highway in UP’s Amroha, was reduced to bones as hundreds of vehicles passed over his body taking away bit-by-bit of his flesh in their tyres for over 12 hours, without noticing him.

According to sources, there were several police response vehicles in the region around National Highway 9, but none noticed the body or got any information about it lying in the middle of road.

The man allegedly met with the accident on Saturday evening, soon after the darkness fell, and police was informed about it on Sunday morning. In between, hundreds of heavy and small vehicles continued to trample on it. Police had to scrape off the remains of the body from the road. It was only in the post-mortem room that doctors and policemen identified the gender of the body with his clothes.

“There is still no clue about who he was,” a police officer said, adding that the incident took place close to Shahwazpur gate in Amroha’s Gajraula area.

Gajraula’s station house officer (SHO) Jaiveer Singh said, “The accident might have taken place during the wee hours of Sunday. The body was crushed badly. It was very difficult for us to lift the pieces. It has been sent to district hospital for autopsy. We will preserve its DNA for identification.”

The incident brought to the fore the apathy of the passersby, and also that of local police. There were several ‘Dial 100’ cars patrolling on the stretch of NH-9, but none got the information about the body.

On June 5, 2016, a man was crushed to death on NH-74 and hundreds of vehicles passed over him in a similar manner. He is yet to be identified.

Title: Madurai city police commissioner post upgraded to ADGP rank
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

City police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham

MADURAI: The Madurai city police commissioner’s posting, which was at the level of Inspector General (IG) of police, has now been upgraded to Additional Director General of Police ( ADGP ) on Sunday through a government order.

City police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham will continue in the same post as he was in the list of officials fit for promotion for ADGP released by the state government. He was promoted on Sunday as ADGP. The orders of upgradation of posting and retaining him in the same post came on Sunday evening.

Davidson, who took part in an event earlier in the day, said that crime incidents like murder, attempt to murder, house break-in, robbery and chain snatchings in the city has been on the decline. However, he was concerned about the increase in the number domestic violence, dowry harassment cases, cheating cases involving money and property.

Davidson took charge as city police commissioner in June 2018. The 1995-batch IPS officer was educated in Loyola College in Chennai and Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi. He started his career as ASP Paramakudi and has served in various cities and districts in various capacities. Davison has also served in the UN peace keeping force in Kosovo and as IG Intelligence.

Title: Madurai: Medians have helped in reducing accidents says Police
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The accident rate has come down on roads where temporary centre median has been set up, city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham has said, after inaugurating a police club building next to the police control room at Periyar on Sunday. The facility will to provide accommodation for police personnel and their relatives visiting the city at nominal rate.

Talking to reporters, the commissioner said that they have identified 21 stretches in the city where temporary medians will be introduced, while work has been completed on most of the stretches. “The number of accidents has come down by close to 25% in January this year, compared to the previous year. Accidents can be brought down by 40% if all the important stretches in the city get central medians, he said.

“In the city, most of the deaths are due to own-damage or accidents involving pedestrians and not involving multiple vehicles,” he said.

“Apart from accident reduction, the centre median will also help to streamline parking on city roads. Once median is introduced, space available for parking of vehicle will be reduced. Naturally, no one will park on a road realizing the disturbance it would cause to traffic movement,” he said.

They have written to road owners like corporation and highways to introduce concrete dividers. “Once it is done, the dividers can be shifted to smaller roads,” he said.

He said that a proposal has been sent to the state government to take over the maintenance of some of the signals, which were hitherto maintained by advertisers.

Title: Army recruitment test: One held with fake Aadhaar card
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Varanasi: A man was held taking exam in place of some other candidate during the common entrance examination (CEE), held under the second phase of army recruitment process at Army Public School in Cantonment area on Sunday.

The exam was conducted by the Army Recruitment Office Varanasi. During the exam, Corps of Military Police (CMP) caught one Anand Singh for appearing in place of Ram Niwas Chauhan.

Inspector, Cantt police station Rakesh Kumar said that after Chauhan cleared the initial tests for army recruitment process, he sent a proxy candidate Anand Singh, a Ghazipur native and diploma holder of electric trade to appear for the CEE. A fake Aadhar card of Chauhan was also recovered from the possession of Anand.

The local Military Intelligence (MI) team and Cantt police also reached there. In the basis of the information given by Anand they launched a search for Chauhan. According to the police, when Chauhan, who was in Sadar area, noticed the police heading towards him he tried to escape. However, the police and MI officials caught him after chasing him.

Both of them are being interrogated by the officials of army and concerned agencies, said the inspector. The police will lodge an FIR in this connection after a complaint is lodged by the ARO and hand over the duo following completion of their investigation, he added.

Title: Worker dead, minor rescued after falling in 25ft pit
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indore: A worker succumbed to injuries, while two minors were rescued , when they fell into a 25-ft deep pit dug up for a sewerage in Durga Nagar of Dewas district on Sunday morning.

The incident took place around 12. The rescue operation continued for two hours. Earth movers were used to conduct the operation. Dewas administration and civic body officials reached the spot to take stock of the rescue operation.

The minor- 17-year-old Arvind - was brought up with ease, while one Vinod succumbed. It took a lot of time to rescue another minor- Manish (17). “Manish has sustained some injuries and he is stable now. He is under observation in emergency ward,” said doctor Shashank Tiwari.

ASP Jagdeesh Dawar said, “The body of the man was sent for postmortem. The death has been recorded and we are investigating the case.,”

Meanwhile, Dewas municipal corporation commissioner Sanjana Jain suspended a sub-engineer Dinesh Chouhan after the incident and ordered a probe. The incident which will be investigated by a committee under 10 points.

The deceased and minors are residents of Jhabua. They had come to Dewas two months ago and earned 2,500 per month, said police.

Title: Atrocities against women on rise in Tamil Nadu, says DMK president M K Stalin
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

DMK president M K Stalin

MADURAI: “The Palaniswami government has no right to celebrate the birth anniversary of Jayalalithaa as girl child protection day, when crimes against women are on the rise in Tamil Nadu ,” said DMK president M K Stalin on Sunday.

Stalin was addressing a meeting organized in Madurai as part of welcoming former AIADMK minister R S Raja Kannappan with thousands of his followers to the DMK. Pointing at the death of Subashree in Chennai and the Pollachi crimes against women, he said that the government has no right to celebrate the day.

He said that he did not want to politicize the issue, but a Tamil magazine, in its recent issue, had spoken about deputy speaker Pollachi Jayaraman’s son’s involvement in the crime in which more than 250 women were abused. “People booked as goondas in the case have been released, because police had not registered the case properly. But Stalin will not rest till the real culprits are brought to book, and this would be ensured once we came to power,” he said.

The AIADMK government was only interested in its own wellbeing and did not care about people. It is also making false claims about its achievements, he said. “I have been asking Edappadi K Palaniswami to come out with a whitepaper on his claims of Rs 3 lakh crore investments. It is not done and he continues to fool people,” he said.

The government is talking about its achievements, as they have gone down in all indexes compared to other states, including human resources, economic growth, and industrial growth. But it stood second in crimes against women, he said.

The AIADMK government is full of corruption. There are pending cases of corruption and wealth accumulation. Even a case against Edappadi K Palaniswami is pending before the court. Stays can be obtained for these cases till AIADMK is in power, but its rule will come to an end in 12 months. Then these cases will be taken up, he said.

Stalin said that Palaniswami was also trying to fool farmers by declaring the delta region as a protected agricultural zone without doing anything. He also listed out the developmental activities in the state, from naming of airports after Kamarajar and Anna, metro rail, roads and bridges and said that all of them had been implemented during the DMK rule.

Former AIADMK minister R S Raja Kannappan, who switched over to the DMK with his followers, said that the AIADMK had become a rule of slavery, corruption and commission and that he was joining the DMK as he saw Stalin as the future of Tamil Nadu.

Former ministers K N Nehru, I Periyasamy and Madurai North DMK organising secretary P Moorthy spoke.

Title: Pilot seeks Rs 1,622cr from Centre for PM housing scheme
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Jaipur: Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot and additional chief secretary (ACS) rural development and panchayati raj department Rajeshwar Singh have written to Union rural development minister Narendra Singh Tomar urging him to release funds amounting to Rs 1,310 crore, which is due since December, for the second installment to build 3,64,000 houses in the state under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana-Grameen (PMAY-G) this financial year.

The state has also urged the Centre to release the first installment for the construction of additional target of 86,816 houses, amounting to Rs 312 crore, to be built in 2019-20 by the rural department department. The total amount sought by the state government is Rs 1,622 crore.

The Centre had given a revised target of 86,816 houses to be constructed under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (Grameen) in 2019-20 in the state, apart from already sanctioned 3.64 lakh houses for this financial year. Singh had earlier directed all the district collectors to issue sanction for these houses in 7 days.

“The second installment is given after 60% utilisation of funds released for the first installment. The claim for the second installment was made in December,” said the official.

According to the official, of the total target of 3.64 lakh houses, construction of 75,000 houses have already been completed. The state has to complete building the remaining 2.89 lakh houses apart from the additional target of 86,816 houses by March 31, 2020.

Earlier, the Centre had approved a labour budget of 30 crore persondays under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) for the financial year 2020-21 in the state.

Title: PMAY-G: State asks districts to improve tally
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Jaipur: Looking at the drop in national rankings and poor performance of the districts in four different categories under the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana-Grameen ( PMAY-G ), additional chief secretary, rural development and panchayati raj, Rajeshwar Singh has expressed concern over this. He has directed collectors to complete the Aadhaar seeding of the beneficiaries and complete construction of the remaining 19,616 houses at the earliest to improve the state's tally in the rankings.

The top ranking by a Rajasthan district is 29th (Ganganagar) and lowest ranking is 250th (Tonk). In 2018-19, the state’s ranking in implementation of the scheme was 3rd and 4th. Now, the overall ranking of state has slipped below 4th position.

Currently, Aadhaar seeding of 1.76 lakh beneficiaries is yet to be done in all the districts. “Due to shortfall in the 100 per cent Aadhaar seeding of the registered beneficiaries in 2019-20, the state has a deficit 1.48 points compared to the other states,” the order stated.

The order states, even after four years of introduction of the scheme, the Permanent Wait List (PWL) has not been uploaded on AwaasSoft in 96 gram panchayats across the state and due to this 7,881 beneficiaries are still deprived of the benefits of the scheme. “The total deficit due to this is 1.54 points (compared to other states). This has affected the state’s overall ranking directly,” it states.

Therefore, the collectors have been directed to upload the PWLs on AwaasSoft in two days.

Title: Varanasi: Two held for cloning ATM cards, cheques of government department
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: Crime branch and Mughalsarai police in Chandauli district , on Sunday, nabbed two fraudsters, who used to clone ATM cards and cheques of institutions like Banaras Hindu University , Kashi Vishwanath temple and others to withdraw money.

SP Chandauli Heman Kutiyal said that the police nabbed the two criminals identified as Ramashish Singh and Kundan Seth, when they were in a SUV. Police have recovered 20 ATM cards, 13 sim cards, nine mobile phones, three laptops, cash worth Rs 55,730, cheque books of various banks and institutions like BHU, KV, Sampurnanand Sanskrit University and organisations of Delhi, Assam , Allahabad, two country-made revolvers and live cartridges.

Initial investigations revealed that both the miscreants used to clone cheque and ATM cards to with draw cash fraudulently.

They confessed to have withdrawn cash from the accounts of Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Nagar Palika Parishad, Jal Nigam and many other departments.

Title: 10-day deadline set to paint speed-breakers in Mangaluru limits
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: The markings for all the new and existing speed-breakers will be done within 10 days, said MCC commissioner Shanady Ajith Kumar Hegde .

“The new asphalted speed-breakers only pose a hazard to motorists who are involved in erratic driving,” he alleged.

Shanady’s response comes after several complaints from motorists and the public that unmarked speed-breakers pose a hazard to motorists in the city.

On Wednesday, TOI carried a report on how unmarked speed-breakers pose a hazard to motorists in Mangaluru city.

One social activist from city said, “With the Mangaluru City Corporation hardly being bothered about spending a little more on the warning signs which are very necessary, it has put vehicle users at risk. One evening a few days ago, a two-wheeler rider went flying after he failed to notice an unmarked speed-breaker, and crashed into the divider, after which he bounced and fell back on to the road. Larger vehicles had to swerve away with their tyres screeching, to avoid hitting him. The motorist’s full-face helmet was unstrapped and perched on his forehead, resulting in him sustaining deep scratches to his face. He managed to limp away to safety. The incident took place near Nanthur.

In another accident, which took place on Wednesday morning, a mother taking her son to school, fell down from her scooter, as she failed to notice the new speed breaker installed near Kadri. She and her son escaped with a few bruises.”

The new and old speed-breakers with no marking, pose a great danger, especially at night, when motorists cannot see them.

“We cannot highlight speed-breakers immediately after they are asphalted. It has a curing period for two weeks, only after which the white marking is done. MCC has built more than 40 speed-breakers in the city limits as per Indian Roads Congress (IRC) standards. IRC is the apex body of highway engineers in the country. According to my knowledge, only erratic drivers are at risk due to them,” said Hegde.

Title: Kin protest after teen ‘declared dead’ found ‘alive’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indore: Over 50 people, including family members of a 19-year-old boy, created ruckus on premises of Medanta Hospital in Vijay Nagar for three hours on Sunday alleging that movements were found in his body after doctors declared him dead.

Family members of the teen , Chandrashekhar Sheriya, a resident of Malviya Nagar, alleged that when they were taking his body to home in an ambulance some movements were found in Chandrashekhar’s body. He even spoke for a while to them

Chandrashekhar was rushed to the hospital on Friday midnight after he suddenly became unconscious at his house. He was admitted in ICU and put under observation since he had brain haemorrhage, said family members.

On Saturday, the doctor treating Chandrashekhar declared him dead and asked to take his body from hospital. But, the hospital administration refused to release the body since some payment was due. Later, they took the body after making payment, alleged family members.

When Chandrashekhar shown some movements his family members took him back to hospital. But, a doctor came to observe him only after an hour and referred him to Bombay Hospital. At Bombay Hospital, he was declared brought dead.

Denying the allegations levelled by Chandrashekhar’s family, medical dean Dr Sandeep Srivastava said that doctors had never declared the boy dead. His family took him after signing leave against medical advice form, said Srivastava.

“We had never declared Chandrashekhar dead. He was brain dead. The boy was insured under a policy of national insurance. But his family paid Rs 5,000 in cash before showing copy of insurance policy. We made the refund cheque against the payment,” said Srivastava.

Vijay Nagar police station in charge Tahzeeb Kazi said, “We have recorded the death and sent the body to MY Hospital for postmortem.”

Title: Health department struggles to contain swine flu as cases rise to 37 in Meerut
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: With two more patients testing positive, the number of swine flu cases has risen to 37 in Meerut on Sunday. Despite efforts, the health department is yet to contain the H1N1 virus.

“As many as 37 patients have tested positive for swine flu in Meerut so far. The number of cases has been on the rise since January-end. In this backdrop, all the residents are being advised to ensure cleanliness and hygiene so that the infection doesn’t spread,” said Dr Rachna Tandon, Meerut district epidemiologist.

“We have over 20,000 Tamiflu tablets – which is enough stock. When and if needed, more stock will be procured from the state authorities. Awareness camps are being set up in the district to spread awareness about the disease and also inform locals about the symptoms to look out for. They are also being informed about the preventive measures that one should take,” said Dr Raj Kumar, Meerut chief medical officer.

The flu spreads from person to person either by inhaling the virus or by touching surfaces contaminated with the virus and then touching the mouth or nose. Fever, cold, cough and vomiting are common symptoms, which may prove fatal if not attended to on time. Therefore, one must consult a doctor as soon as possible.

Doctors have advised that only one member of the family should engage in taking care of a swine flu patient to prevent everyone from contracting the infection. One should wash one’s hands frequently, wear a mask when in the vicinity of the patient, take care of cleanliness inside the patient’s room and use separate utensils for the patient, doctors said.

In areas where swine flu cases have been detected, surveillance is being conducted to check if there are more cases in proximity. Awareness camps are also being organized there so that people in those areas are aware about it. Also, epidemiological study and travel history of patients is being checked, the health department authorities said.

Title: Illicit liquor making unit found in Muzaffarnagar
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: An illicit liquor making unit was found in Muzaffarnagar on Sunday where the police seized 8,500 litres of rectified spirit, over 100 drums of chemical and liquor making equipment, among others.

Illicit liquor was being made at the unit for the past few months. Superintendent of police (city) Satpal Antil said, “In a joint operation of excise department and police, an illegal liquor making unit was busted. Equipment and chemical, including 8,500 litres of rectified spirit, was recovered from the spot. Further investigation is on.”

Materials worth around Rs 1 crore were recovered from the spot, the SP added. Sources said police and excise officers raided a spot on Joli Road under Sikheda police station and caught two persons Sonu and Amit.

Title: Madurai: AIADMK not in the hands of any individual: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Minister Co-operatives Sellur K Raju

MADURAI: AIADMK in the hands of the people and not with any individual, claimed minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju , here on Sunday. He was speaking after launching a new TNSTC service from the Arapalayam bus stand here in the presence of the district collector Dr T G Vinay, corporation commissioner S Visakan and MLAs on Sunday. The above reply was to a question on BJP leader Muralidhar Rao’s statement that there was nothing wrong in a chief minister being in the hands of the Prime Minister. “Chief Minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam have made their stand on CAA and NRC clear,” he said, adding that the AIADMK was always committed to the welfare of the minority communities. “DMK president M K Stalin is trying to divide the people for his personal gains by spreading false information among Muslims and minorities,” he added. Asked about former minister R S Raja Kannappan joining the DMK in a mega event in Madurai , he said that Raja Kannappan was known for switching loyalties between the AIADMK and DMK and there was is no need for DMK to be jubilant about it.

Title: US backup planes at Jaipur airport for Donald Trump in case Delhi weather fails
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

US Air Force Boeing 757 and a C-17 Globemaster have been stationed at Jaipur airport on Sunday

JAIPUR: The Airports Authority of India (AAI) Jaipur is geared up to receive Air Force One carrying US president Donald Trump in case weather plays truant in Delhi on Monday.

As a backup plan, a US Air Force Boeing 757 landed here on Sunday evening to ferry Trump in case there is a technical snag in his plane. In addition, a C-17 Globemaster landed here for the second day with some more equipment needed for ground-handling.

According to sources, at least 50 people including security personnel, officials of US embassy, technical surveillance experts and others are already in town to take care of arrangements.

Reliable sources from Jaipur airport said security personnel from the US arrived in the Boeing 757. The aircraft landed at 7.48 pm.

However, citing security concerns Jaipur airport authorities refrained from commenting much on the developments.

“We are not much aware on this. We have received a Boeing 757 aircraft of America at our airport. We don’t have any further directions or intimation about it,” said a senior officer at the airport.

Jaideep Singh Balhara, director, Jaipur airport said, “All what I can tell you is that we are ready in case the aircraft carrying American president Trump and others land here. Our airport is an alternative airport in case Delhi’s weather goes awryon Monday.”

Security has also been fortified in and around Jaipur airport. “If this diversion happens, we may witness the landing of the aircraft carrying Trump and his team by 1pm to 1.30 pm on Monday,” said an officer.

Title: Wanted in 200 cases, on the run for 20 years, don Pujari brought to India
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

MUMBAI: Gangster Ravi Pujari , on the run for 20 years, was hauled to India on Sunday by officers from the Research & Analysis Wing (RAW) and the Karnataka Police , who camped in Senegal for three days to obtain the fugitive’s custody. The plane carrying Pujari arrived in Delhi on Sunday afternoon via Paris. Pujari is the latest in a long line of criminals including Abu Salem, Chhota Rajan , Ejaz Lakdawala to have been deported or extradited to India.

Sources said Pujari was taken to an undisclosed location where he was questioned by RAW, IB and Union home ministry officials for more than four hours. A source said he was showing symptoms of high blood pressure and diabetes. He was taken to a hospital for a check-up before being handed over to Karnataka Police. In the evening, he was to be flown to Bengaluru, as confirmed to TOI by Karnataka DG & IGP Praveen Sood.

Pujari, who jumped bail and went missing after being nabbed in Senegal 13 months ago, was rearrested in a remote village in South Africa on Saturday and taken back to Senega l.

Karnataka home minister Basavaraj Bommai told TOI th e ministry of external affairs had coordinated Pujari’s deportation. “(He was to be) brought to Bengaluru as early as possible. There were a few legal hurdles which have been sorted out,” Bommai sai d.

Pujari has over 200 cases against him in India, including murder, attempt to murder and extortion. Ninety of those cases are in Karnataka, including 39 in Bengaluru and 36 in Mangaluru. The most well known of them include the murder of builder Om Prakash Kukreja and an attempt on the life of advocate and MP Majeed Memon.

Senior Union home ministry and external affairs ministry officials coordinated with Senegalese authorities to deport Pujari at the earliest. Compared to extradition, a long-drawn process, deportation is simpler. The team that was with Pujari on his flight included Bengaluru cops led by joint commissioner of police Sandeep Patil, and additional DGP Amar Kumar Pandey.

Ne ws of Ravi Pujari’s rearrest was kept secret as the agencies did not want to risk a repeat of what happened last year: Pujari got a false cheating case registered against himself in Senegal and delayed deportation; later, he jumped bail and went missin g.

Sources say the Union government plans to hand over all Pujari cases to the CBI , like it did for gangster Chhota Rajan, with state police departments assisting investigations.

Pujari’s arrest brings the curtains down on another chapter in Mumbai’s gangland era. Barring Dawood Ibrahim, who is a fugitive living in Pakistan, and some of his accomplices, many others including Abu Salem, Dawood’s brother Iqbal Kaskar, Chhota Shakeel ’s brother-in-law Arif , Pujari’s own aide Ashok Devadiga, Tariq Parveen, late Mustafa Dossa, Bunty Pandey, Chhota Rajan, Santosh Shetty, Fazlu Rahman, and Ejaz Lakdawala were all brought to heel.

Title: Madurai: Commute on AA Road a nightmare for motorists
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

AA Road, which connects Arasaradi with DD Road at Arapapalayam bus terminal

MADURAI: AA Road, which connects Arasaradi with DD Road at Arapapalayam bus terminal , is riddled with potholes and giving bumpy ride to hundreds of motorists using it regularly.

The busy road, which connects important commercial areas and thick residential areas on either sides, has been in shambles for long although intermittent patch work have been carried out.

More than the bumpy ride, motorists are concerned about the safety of people as potholes result in accidents. P Vijayaragavan from Melaponnagaram said, “AA Road is not only giving bumpy ride to commuters, it also poses threat to people as many make sudden turn to avoid hitting potholes. It results in accidents.”

The traffic on this road is peak in the morning and evening as a large number of parents and students use it to reach schools. “If the entire stretch is in a bad shape, people will drive slowly. But, it has sudden potholes which result in people making sudden stops and turns. While regular commuters know the road well and adjust to the condition, incidents happen because of people who rarely take this road,” said K Vijayan, a resident of Ellis Nagar.

CPM area secretary for Melaponnagaram V Stalin said that apart from AA Road, nearby stretches like DD Road, New Jail Road and Melaponnagaram Main Road are also in a bad shape. They had recently staged a protest mobilizing public highlighting pathetic condition of the road, but officials are yet to act. They have also met officials in zonal level and petitioned them to take up road works, he said.

When contacted, an official from Madurai corporation that they will fix the road in a few days. He acknowledged the problem on other roads too and said that all roads will be taken up for repair one by one.

Title: 7th Delhi assembly starts, 69 MLAs take oath in five languages...
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

CM Arvind Kejriwal with MLA Ram Niwas Goel who was re-elected as speaker of Delhi assembly.

NEW DELHI: The first session of the seventh Delhi assembly began on Monday with the oath-taking ceremony of its 68 newly elected members . The exercise started with chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, followed by the ministers and then the rest of the MLAs.

Sixty Aam Aadmi Party MLAs and the Bharatiya Janata Party’s eight members took oath in the assembly while AAP’s Janakpuri MLA, Rajesh Rishi, was absent as he was out of town. He is likely to take oath on Tuesday in the speaker’s chamber. The session will end on Wednesday.

Earlier in the day, the senior-most member of the House, AAP’s Shoaib Iqbal, took oath in the presence of lieutenant governor Anil Baijal at Raj Niwas as the pro tem speaker. Iqbal represents Matia Mahal.

The linguistic diversity of India was apparent in the House with 61 MLAs taking oath in Hindi, three in Urdu, two in Maithili and one each in Punjabi and English. Kejriwal and his six cabinet colleagues used Hindi while Mustafabad MLA Haji Yunus, Seelampur’s Abhul Rehman and Okhla’s Amanatullah Khan took oath in Urdu. To stress their Maithili identity, Burari MLA Sanjeev Jha and Kikari’s Rituraj Govind Jha not only turned up in their traditional attire but also took oath in Maithili, while Tilak Nagar’s Jarnail Singh went for Punjabi, both included in the Eighth Schedule of the Constitution. Jangpura MLA Praveen Kumar took oath in English.

The Leader of Opposition, Ramvir Singh Bidhuri, elected from Badarpur for the fourth time, hugged Iqbal after taking oath. Both of them were elected to the first Delhi assembly in 1993 from their current constituencies.

While most MLAs took oath in the name of the god, AAP’s Wazirpur MLA, Rajesh Gupta, took oath in the name of his late parents, Rithala MLA Mohinder Goyal in the name of God, Allah and Waheguru, Patel Nagar MLA Rajkumar Anand in the name of God and Mother India, and Kondli MLA Kuldeep Kumar in the name of Maharishi Valmiki and B R Ambedkar.

AAP has stormed back to power for the third consecutive term winning 62 out of the 70 seats in the assembly.

Title: 33 ‘students’ caught taking UP Board exams with fake documents
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: As many as 33 “students” were caught taking the English examination of the UP Board with fake documents at Major Asharam Inter College in Meerut ’s Mawana area on Saturday.

Action was taken against them when it was found that the date of birth on their Aadhaar cards and admit cards did not match. On Friday, the students were asked to come with their Aadhaar cards for the exam. While at least 48 of them skipped the exam, 33 of the examinees had fake Aadhaar cards - the QR code of which were found to be fake. An FIR has been filed against the principal of the school for allegedly being hand in glove with the “students” who were caught.

The students of PD Kanya Higher Secondary School were taking their exam at Major Asharam Inter College in Ganeshpur, when 33 with fake Aadhaar cards were caught. All the students were taken to Hastinapur police station and it during interrogation, police learnt that the principal of PD Kanya Higher Secondary School was involved in some irregularities with the documents. An FIR has been filed against the principal of the school and a probe in on,” said Meerut district inspector of schools GK Chaudhary.

Sources revealed that the students who were caught admitted to having cleared the UP board exams earlier. They said they were appearing for the exam again only to get their age reduced for securing government jobs with the help of fraudulent papers.

“An inquiry has been set up and a committee has been set up to probe the matter. The committee has been asked to revert as soon as possible,” said Chaudhary.

Title: Mangaluru: Athlete, novelist bag award
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Shreema Priyadarshini

MANGALURU: The Dakshina Kannada district administration has selected eminent novelist Usha P Rai and athlete Shreema Priyadarshini for the Abbakka Award 2019. The award carries a purse of Rs 25,000, and will be presented to these achievers at the two-day Abbakka Utsav that the district administration is organising at Assaigoli Central Ground in Konaje village near here from February 29, said district minister Kota Shrinivas Poojari.

Announcing the names of the awardees on Sunday, Poojari said a seminar and poets meet will be held in the run up to the utsav at Ravindra Kala Bhavan of University College on Thursday. Kotresh, HoD of history, Tumkur University, will chair the seminar on the topic ‘Tulunadina Raniyaru’. Arathi H N, senior programme executive, Doordarshan, Bengaluru, will chair the multi-language poets meet to be held later that afternoon.

The administration has arranged for essay and painting competitions for primary and high school students at St Jerosa High School, Jeppu, at 9.30am on Tuesday. The topic for the essay is ‘Historical milestone of Rani Abbakka’, and for the painting competition, a scene depicting Rani Abbakka’s valour. Government First Grade College for Women, Balmatta, will host the district level elocution and mini drama contest for degree students on the same day from 9.30am onwards.

Noting that the Veera Rani Abbakka Kreedotsava was held at the venue of the utsav on Sunday in the run up to the main event, Poojari said the state government has sanctioned a grant of Rs 30 lakh for the utsav. There are no immediate plans to merge the Abbakka Utsav with Karavali Utsav that the administration organises every year, Poojari said, adding the themes of the two events are different, and organised with different specific purposes altogether.

Title: Sathwaras flagged for genetic disorder
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Ahmedabad: Practice of marriages within specific geo-cultural groups has led to founder mutations of genes in several parts of India. While two communities from Gujarat were flagged by researchers for genetic disorders earlier, experts on Sunday said that new studies have also identified Sathwara community in Gujarat and Agarwals of Mumbai having tendency for founder mutation leading to muscular dystrophy (MD).

Dr Siddharth Shah, a paediatric neurologist based in Ahmedabad, said that their study on Sathwara community has found genes responsible for the same type of MD. “In an earlier study of Agarwal community in Mumbai, it was found that two ancestral founder mutations were leading to MD. It might have arisen due to the practice of intra-communal exogamy,” said Shah. He was speaking on the sidelines of Annual CME Conference 2020 organized on theme of ‘Diagnosis, Screening, Treatment and Prevention of Rare Diseases.’

While prevalence of MD is very low — 1 case per two lakh live child births — such knowledge can help identify the signs earlier and can also motivate the community members to go for genetic match before matrimonial, said experts.

Dr Jayesh Sheth, chairman of the conference and chairman of city-based Institute of Human Genetics, said that earlier studies had pointed at prevalence of Tay Sachs in Parmar and Morquio in Patidar communities due to mutation of specific genes present in the community. “The motive of the conference is to encourage more paediatricians, neurologists and general practitioners to go for genetic tests for identification of rare diseases,” he said. “The school health programme is now identifying several of these cases.”

The conference highlighted rise in prevalence of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a disorder where the person’s adrenal glands doesn’t function normally and affects metabolism and immune system among other symptoms. Practitioners said that they used to see about three to four cases annually but now a few of the practitioners are attending to three to four cases on monthly basis.

BOX

‘These disorders can be treated’

Dr Nitish Vora, a city-based paediatric neurologist and one of the speakers at the event, talked on diagnostic approaches to paediatric neurology diseases. “Collectively, genetic disorders affect about 15% of the total population which is not a small number. Many of these disorders can be treated and can also be prevented from spread in next generation with proper treatment. Need of the hour is better awareness and genetic tests,” he said. Dr Vykunta Raju, a speaker from Bengaluru, said that in Karnataka availability of specialists in identification and treatment of these disorders has increased in past few years which has resulted in better identification and treatment.

BOX

Disintegration of nerve cells

In multi-centre study published in Journal of Human Genetics last year, the researchers found that a specific gene mutation leading to Tay Sachs disease — leading to disintegration of nerve cells in brain and spinal cord — was found in five of the patients, which was 14% of the study, from Gujarat. Median year of detection was 15 years and boys’ number was slightly higher than the girls. Experts at the conference on Sunday said that they have advised dissemination of information related to the mutations not with the names or genes but common symptoms associated with it so that even the health professionals in rural areas can conduct primary screening for the same.

Title: No foreseeable signs of water scarcity in Dakshina Kannada this summer: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: There are no foreseeable signs of water scarcity in the coming summer across Dakshina Kannada . The district administration in conjunction with the panchayat raj department has already taken stock of the situation at a review meeting recently, and will periodically keep reviewing the water situation based on which future decisions will be taken, said Kota Shrinivas Poojari , minister for fisheries and religious endowment.

Interacting with the media on Sunday, Poojari, also district minister, said there is steady inflow of water into Thumbe vented dam, the main source of potable water for this coastal city. The administration is maintaining water at a level of six metres at the dam, and excess water is being allowed to overflow from the vented dam, he said. The survey to determine the land that will be submerged if the water level is raised to 7 metres too is under way, he said.

Deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said state chief secretary T M Vijay Bhaskar, who visited the vented dam recently, too has suggested that the district administration and Mangaluru City Corporation maintain the water level at its present height of six metres. As things stand now, we do not foresee any immediate water scarcity even as summer is approaching, she said, basing this optimistic assessment on continuing inflow into the vented dam.

Noting that the district administration is carrying out a survey to determine the extent of land that will be submerged if the water level is raised by an additional metre, Sindhu said another road barrage-cum-vented dam that the minor irrigation department is constructing at Adyar, downstream from the Thumbe vented dam, will further augment water availability. This barrage is expected to be ready in the coming two years, and tenders for it have been finalised, she said.

Title: Trump Ahmedabad Visit: More than 1,000 industry representatives to attend ‘Namaste Trump’ event
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Over 650 industrialists, businessmen and representatives of chambers and industry bodies from Vadodara will at... Read More

AHMEDABAD: More than 1,000 representatives of Gujarat’s trade bodies and industries will participate in the `Namaste Trump’ event. Of these, around 200 will represent the Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (GCCI). Another 150 will be from Associated Chambers of Commerce in India (ASSOCHAM).
