“We have sent names of more than 150 industrialists for attending the Namaste Trump event. All promoter-level industrialists will attend the event on Monday,” said Chintan Thaker, co-chair, Assocham Gujarat chapter.

Various industry bodies in the state were earlier asked by the state government to pre-register businessmen and industrialists for the event.

About 370 delegates from the Diamond City, Surat, will also take part in the Trump-Modi mega show. Leading diamond cutting and polishing unit owners, along with top representatives of Surat’s textile, chemical, weaving and real estate sectors will attend the event.

Over 650 industrialists, businessmen and representatives of chambers and industry bodies from Vadodara will attend the event. These include office-bearers of various trade and industry bodies of central Gujarat along with several representatives of industries based in the region.

Title: 15-year-old boy dies after coming in contact with power line
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

AMROHA: A 15-year-old boy died after coming in contact with a high tension power line passing over the terrace of their house on Sunday. Accident took place in Amroha city’s Batwan mohalla. The victim, identified as Sabir, was playing when he came in contact with the high tension power line and died immediately.

Family members rushed Sabir to a hospital where doctor declared him brought dead. They claimed that they had earlier requested the authorities concerned that the power line be shifted but their request fell on deaf ears.

Police rushed to the spot and took the body to district hospital for autopsy.

Title: Rajasthan: 53,000 health workers to get mobile phones for survey
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Over 53 ,000 ASHA workers will be given android phones for the digital health survey (DHS) to be conducted across the state.

The health department is promoting use of digital technology for conducting its one of the biggest health surveys.

For the purpose, training of ASHA workers has been started in different districts. “Under Nirogi Rajasthan , 53,000 ASHA workers deployed in different parts of the state will conduct door-to-door survey for DHS,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.

Training has been started in Jodhpur and other parts of the state. Since the survey will be done digitally, the training will be important, said a health department official.

These workers will go door-to-door to collect details of the family members and about their health, which include name of the patient, disease, for how long the patient has been taking the treatment, who is providing the treatment are some of the points in the survey, which is likely to be launched in the state from April.

According to the health department officials, the digital health survey will help the state government formulate health policies and better treatment facilities to the patients. The health department will also be able to know the actual burden of diseases in the state such as hypertension, diabetes, cancer, tuberculosis. Also, it will be able to gauge the actual burden of diseases related to heart, liver, and kidney.

Title: High-level probe ordered into undertrial’s death
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Allahabad: A high-level probe was ordered into the death of an undertrial on Sunday, a day after he died on way to hospital after complaining of chest pain in Manjhanpur in Kaushambi.

According to reports, the deceased was identified as Rinkoo Singh (45), a resident of Kanwar, and he was arrested on charges of drug peddling on Saturday evening. Late Saturday night, he complained of chest pain and was taken to Sirathu community health centre (CHC). Doctors at the CHC referred him to the district hospital. However, he was declared dead on arrival.

Singh’s family alleged that he died due to police torture. They alleged that they weren’t informed about the deteriorating condition of the deceased on Saturday night and came to know about his death on Sunday morning.

The family alleged that Singh was working along with some labourers at his home on Saturday morning, when a policeman came to their residence and took him along. He was later arrested and put behind bars.

However, police claimed that Singh was addicted to liquor. SP (Kaushambi) Abhinandan instructed Additional SP (Kaushambi) Ashok Kumar to conduct a probe into the death.

The body has been sent for postmortem examination. A panel of three doctors would conduct the postmortem and the procedure would be captured via videography, said police.

Title: Kanpur: Activists allegedly religious conversion, create ruckus
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Anand Singh

KANPUR: Activists , allegedly belonging to the Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP), on Sunday morning created ruckus at Shiv Katra area of Chakeri in the city over ‘religious conversion’ of people.

After knowing about the incident, the circle officer (CO) Cantt RK Chaturvedi along with heavy police reached the spot, pacified the mob and brought the situation under control.

According to police sources, the VHP activists reached the house of one Anand Singh in Shiv Katra locality that was being used as a church and alleged that religious conversion of people to Christianity was going on there.

The CO said a probe into the matter was on and Anand Singh was being questioned.

“We have questioned Anand Singh, who denied the VHP’s allegation of religious conversion. He claimed that as usual, Sunday prayer was underway at one of the rooms which he often used as a church in his house. Security has been beefed up in the locality to prevent any untoward incident” the CO said. “Both groups have lodged complaints. After verifying the facts, police will register an FIR,” he added.

To recall in July 2019, a right-wing group had created a ruckus over suspicion of conversions by a pastor in Kashiram Colony of the city. The pastor was allegedly beaten by the activists over rumours of conversion.

Title: Mercury soars, Kottayam records 38.5 degrees Celsius
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Title: Tension in Mhowgaon as miscreants pelt stones at cars, houses
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Mhow: Residents of three colonies in Mhowgaon area are having their worst nightmare since some unidentified miscreants are damaging parked cars and windows of their houses by pelting stones at night.

The miscreants seen riding on five to six bikes are running amok since Friday night in Jawaharnagar, Shantinagar and Supercity under Kishanganj police station limits.

On Saturday morning, a resident Deepak Mourya lodged a complaint against identified accused for vandalism on Friday night at Kishanganj police station. But the incident took place again on Saturday night.

Some of the accused had covered their faces, while others were moving freely. They seemed under the influence of alcohol, said residents.

Kishanganj police station in charge Shashikant Chaurasiya said that footage of CCTVs installed in the areas were being scanned to identify the accused.

Title: Ahmedabad: CBSE asks Army to permit use of internal road
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has asked the Army Cantonment Board to permit Class X and XII students taking the board exam to use the cantonment’s internal roads.

The board’s officials have requested the cantonment to allow students going back home from the exam centres to drive through the cantonment and exit at Ghevar Circle. Mrugen Shah, the city coordinator of the examination and principal of Prakash High School, said that 417 examinees will be affected. The examination is scheduled to begin at 10am.

Shah said six to seven teachers have been given the task of ensuring that —if required — students are moved to the main gates of the cantonment. That will enable the parents to pick up their wards from the other side of the cantonment from Ghevar Circle.

Shah said that usually parents are not permitted inside the premises of the exam centres but as a special case, they will allowed inside the compound. The exam hall will remain out of bounds for parents. Shah said that CBSE chairwoman Anita Karwal has had a telephonic talk with the police commissioner to ensure that students are not stopped on their way to exam centres.

Title: Odhav factory fire deaths: Village in shock
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Laxmi, the mother of Dayanidhi, and others in mourning in Jamadhar village, Rajasthan

A pall of gloom descended on Jamadhar, a tiny village in Jajpur district on Sunday, after three of its residents — Dayanidhi Khuntia (33), Chinmaya Khuntia (25) and Kamesh Singh (23) — died of asphyxiation in a fire accident at a garments manufacturing factory in Ahmedabad on Saturday.

Talking to TOI over phone from the Gujarat capital, Raju Khuntia, 24, who escaped the fire that broke out on the third floor of Lotus Label Industries in Odhav , said, “We were asleep in a room on that floor when the fire broke out at 3pm. I managed to rush to the top floor but three of my friends died.”

Raju said the authorities in Gujarat had promised to send the trio’s bodies to Odisha soon. On Sunday, people in and around Jamadhar and its neighbouring villages began gathering in front of the houses of the deceased. Laxmi, the 68-year-old widowed mother of Dayanidhi, sat frozen with shock and disbelief. She has been unable to speak properly ever since she learnt of her son’s death.

“My son had called me a few days ago, saying he would return by March 9 to celebrate Holi,” Laxmi said in a feeble voice. “I don’t know what the future will hold for me.” Dayanidhi leaves behind his mother, his wife Sraddhanjali and two minor daughters.

Title: AAP MLA Ram Niwas Goel unanimously elected as Delhi assembly speaker for 2nd straight term
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia proposed Goel’s name for the post of speaker

NEW DELHI: Aam Aadmi Party MLA Ram Niwas Goel was unanimously elected as the speaker of the Delhi assembly for the second consecutive term on Monday.

Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia proposed Goel’s name for the post of speaker, which was supported by MLAs Kuldeep Kumar, Satyendar Jain, Praveen Kumar, Dinesh Mohaniya, S K Bagga, Vishesh Ravi and Raghav Chadha. The motion was passed by voice vote without any opposition.

Elected from Shahdara, this is Goel’s third term as an MLA of Delhi assembly. He was first elected on a BJP ticket in 1993. In 2015, Goel was elected as an AAP legislator.

Pro tem speaker Shoaib Iqbal presided over the House when the election took place. Goel was escorted to the chair by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and Leader of Opposition Ramvir Singh Bidhuri.

Kejriwal appreciated the fact that Goel had been unanimously elected by both ruling and opposition members. “In the past five years, we saw that Ram Niwas Goel-ji was like ‘Bhishma Pitamah’ of the House. He also did not give any opportunity to the opposition to complain against him,” he said.

Congratulating Goel on being elected unopposed, Sisodia said, a “new story of development” would be written under his guidance. “Under your leadership, the government will work towards developing all Delhi constituencies on a faster pace,” he said.

Opposition Leader Bidhuri said he and Goel were members of the first House of the reconstituted assembly in 1993. Bidhuri, who was then a Janata Dal member, said the then speaker, Charhti Lal Goel, had not only allowed him to raise the issue of water crisis but even cajoled the BJP government to support it. “I urge you to give as much time to the opposition as you give to the MLAs of party in government,” Bidhuri said, adding that BJP would offer its full cooperation in running the House.

Thanking the MLAs for his re-election, Goel said he hoped that the opposition would play a good role and promised to give sufficient time to all for constructive debates.

Title: Stop dreaming like ‘Mungerilal’: Dy CM to Akhilesh
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya and Union minister Piyush Goyal with other BJP leaders in Allahabad... Read More

Allahabad: Asking former Uttar Pradesh chief minister Akhilesh Yadav to stop “daydreaming like Mungerilal”, deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya on Sunday said the Samajwadi Party cycle would slow down in the 2022 assembly polls and the party would not be able to win even 51 seats.

Maurya was reacting to the SP president’s recent claim of returning to power in the state by winning 351 seats.

He said the people have seen the all-round development in the state and the BJP would again form the government in the state in 2022.

Speaking at the ‘Pichra Vaishya Mahakumbh’ organised under the banner of Bharatiya Janata Party on KP College ground here, he said the BJP-led central and state governments are working for the welfare of all sections. “Bua, Bhateeje and others have lost their ground on political pitch... The Congress has also drastically lost its vote bank,” he said.

“Gone are the days when Kanwariyas were not allowed to sing bhajans. They are now greeted with rose petals.” he added.

Chief guest and Union railway minister Piyush Goel said: “The Vaishya community has been supporting the party since the days of Jansangh. This Mahakumbh will help spread the message across the country that entire ‘Pichra Vaishya Samaj’ is supporting Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah.”

Talking about the welfare policies launched by the Centre like Ayushman Bharat Yojana and Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana, the minister said: “We introduced Vande Bharat Express on February 15, 2019, and after one year of its completion, we have brought Kashi Mahakal Express to serve the people.” He claimed that the Modi government had also brought a pension plan for traders which is benefiting them across the country.

Goel said, “It was BJP which formed the traders’ welfare board... Since the party came to power in the state, traders are doing business without any fear.”

State BJP chief Swatantra Dev Singh said: “The country is in the safe hands of PM Narendra Modi and the country has emerged as a strong power.”

Title: With defunct CCTV cams & locks, ATM cash vans flout safety norms
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Citizens queue up outisde an ATM kiosk in Allahabad on Sunday

Allahabad: Most cash vans supplying currency to ATM kiosks in the city do not meet security guidelines laid down by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), making them easy targets for robbers.

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “During recent drive, we conducted physical verification of 38 cash transit vans and found that most of them were violating security guidelines set by the RBI.”

During the week-long drive, we found that just two cash transit vans which were complying with the rules. Of the 38 vehicles checked, only 15 had functional CCTV cameras,” the SSP added.

Besides, the door lock for gunners in three vehicles were defunct was, while six vans did not have functional sirens.

“Security personnel travelling in just five cash transit vans knew the right procedure to lock cash boxes using chains and clamps. However, the locks on the vans’ back doors were in poor state,” Pankaj said.

Police also found that the cash carry boxes in all vans checked during the drive were not as heavy as mandated. They also saw that many vans were still being used to transport cash, despite not being in good condition. As per RBI guidelines, vehicles cannot be used as cash transit van if it has been 10 years since their manufacture.

Police have instructed security agencies to upgrade services and security features in these vans to ensure safe transportation.

“We have conveyed the concerns raised by the police to the security agency,” said an official of a private bank.

Title: Nine get 1-year jail for stealing diesel
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

Title: Bidhuri to lead charge of Opposition in House
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

New Delhi: Veteran BJP functionary and four-time MLA, Ramvir Singh Bidhuri , was unanimously elected as the Leader of Opposition in Delhi assembly on Monday.

Bidhuri’s election took place at the BJP’s state headquarters hours before the newly elected MLAs took oath at the first session of the seventh Delhi legislative assembly.

According to a statement issued by BJP, Bidhuri’s name was proposed by Rohini MLA Vijender Gupta and seconded by his Vishwas Nagar counterpart, Om Prakash Sharma. Gupta was the Leader of the three-member Opposition in the sixth legislative assembly.

The meeting for choosing the Leader of Opposition was presided over by national general secretary Saroj Pandey. Pandey was appointed as a central observer to oversee the election. National vice-president and Delhi in-charge Shyam Jaju, Delhi BJP president Manoj Tiwari, Delhi co in-charge and national secretary Tarun Chugh, union minister Harsh Vardhan and all eight MLAs were present in the meeting.

Talking to TOI, Bidhuri, who represents Badarpur constituency, said he will ensure the saffron party discharges the duty of a constructive opposition in the House. He added that his party will first corner AAP on rising air pollution in the capital.

Bidhuri, who was elected to Delhi Assembly in 1993, 2003, 2013 and 2020, said he will also request the AAP dispensation to give the deputy speaker’s post to BJP. “In 2008, the Congress government had made Shoaib Iqbal deputy speaker of the House despite the fact that he was in opposition,” Bidhuri said. He, however, added that if AAP refused, BJP will not contest the election of deputy speaker.

Title: IMFL worth Rs 40,000 seized in Rajkot
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Indian-made foreign liquor ( IMFL ) bottles worth Rs 40,800 were seized from an autorickshaw on Dudh Sagar Road at Riddhi Siddhi Gujarat Housing Board Society in Rajkot on Saturday night.

“We had received a tip-off that a large cache of liquor was being ferried in an autorickshaw that was scheduled to pass by Dudh Sagar Road. Acting on this information, we had kept a watch and intercepted the rickshaw. However, the rickshaw driver, whose identity could not be ascertained, abandoned his vehicle and vanished into the cover of darkness,” said an official from Thorala police station.

Title: Masks in short supply in Delhi: Blame it on coronavirus
Content:
A team led by director of NCDC at Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital to review the preparedness for providing treatmen... Read More

NEW DELHI: With China hit by coronavirus outbreak and supply being stalled from the neighbouring nation, city pharmacy stores are facing shortage of masks.At present, only locally manufactured products are available. “There aren’t enough masks available in the market. If you want to buy, you can or leave it,” shopkeepers have been telling customers who are protesting the high prices.The surgical masks that are usually sold for Rs 10 in retail market are currently being sold at Rs 40. The N95 masks, which has multiple layers for better protection and re-use, are being sold anywhere between Rs 150 and Rs 500.“We are also paying extra to purchase the masks from suppliers,” said a shopkeeper, justifying the increased price.Vivek Tiwari, founder and CEO, Medikabazaar, said they have witnessed 10 times growth in demand for face masks, particulate respiratory masks, protective suits, sterile surgical gloves and safety goggles. “In the last few weeks, we have received multiple queries from China, Japan, Singapore, and even India and other countries and we have increased our procurement of masks and other items many folds to meet the demand,” he said.Every time a patient coughs or sneezes, the droplets containing the virus are released and they tend to spread. Masks are advised for people visiting crowded areas such as hospitals or airports.“I was travelling to Lucknow to attend a family function with parents. So I thought of buying the masks. Some of the pharmacy stores said they didn’t have any, while others were selling at inflated rates. If this is the situation now, I wonder what will happen if the infection spreads in the country and there is actual need for more masks,” Ashish Goyal, a resident of Noida said.Delhi has not reported any positive case of coronavirus.

Title: Allahabad: Kaushambi couple injured on railway tracks
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: A day after a couple was found dead inside a locked room at Saiyed Sarawan village in Kaushambi, a young couple was found critically injured near Bharwari railway station under Kokhraj police limits in Kaushambi on Sunday.

Satish (20) and Puja (18) — residents of Jalalpur Gorian village — were rushed to Manjhanpur district hospital from where they were referred to SRN hospital in Allahabad. Additional SP ( Kaushambi) Ashok Kumar said Satish works as a labourer in Allahabad and returned to his native village two days back.

He said: “According to an initial investigation, the couple made an abortive bid to end their life by jumping before a moving train.”

On Sunday morning, locals alerted the police when they spotted them in a critical condition.

Police said the couple was in a relationship for the last three years and they used to meet secretly. A month back, when the girl’s family members came to know about her affair, they stopped her from moving out of the house. On Saturday, the girl managed to give a slip to the family members and reached Manoharganj railway station. She then called up her lover, who too reached Manoharganj. After spending night together, they reportedly jumped before a moving train near Bharwari railway station early on Sunday.

Police, however, said that they are still ascertaining whether the couple jumped before a running train or from a moving train. Once the couple are out of danger, they would be grilled to know the exact sequence of events, police said.

Title: Hyderabad: Three in drunken daze killed in car crash, seat belt saves another
Content:
Three persons killed after a car in which they traveling met with an accident, at Saroornagar, in Hyderabad on... Read More

HYDERABAD: A night of drunken revelry with old friends left three dead and one injured after their car hit a tree and turned turtle in Saroornagar limits in the wee hours of Sunday. The man who survived was the only one wearing a seat belt. The accident occurred at around 2am near Karmanghat Sagar road when the six friends — four in car and two on a bike — were returning from Gurram Guda in Ranga Reddy district after a party.The victims were identified as Vinayak Malikarjuna (29), a software engineer from New Saidabad; P Sainath (27), a private employee from Saraswati Nagar in Saidabad; and Sreeram Naik (28), a software engineer from Santosh Nagar. M Ramaprasad Kalyan (28), a private employee, who suffered head and internal injuries, has been admitted to hospital, cops said.According to police, the six men were friends since college and had planned a party as they were meeting after one year. “While returning, Vinayak lost control due to high speed and slammed the Hyundai i20 into a tree. All the four were drunk. The two other friends on the bike called for help,” said Saroornagar inspector Srinivas Reddy.“Seat belt saved Kalyan, who was in the rear seat. The other three were not wearing seat belts and died on the spot with severe head and multiple injuries. Only the driver’s air bag opened after the accident,” said another cop.“Kalyan is still unaware that the other three have died. It will be a shock to him as all of them have been close since college days,” said Srinivas K, uncle of one of the victims, Sainath.The bodies of the victims were shifted to Osmania General Hospital for post-mortem. A case was registered under IPC Sections 304-A (causing death by negligence) and 337 (Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others).

Title: Kanpur: Teenager sexually exploited by village goon attempts suicide
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: A teenage girl , student of a local degree college, attempted suicide by hanging herself after being sexually exploited by a goon in a village under Ghatampur police station.

The girl attempted suicide on February 20 when a local hoodlum tried to rape her again.

Police sources said the accused is a grandson of an alleged ex-bandit, while the girl’s father works in Delhi. She lives with her mother and a younger brother in the village under Ghatampur police station.

He had allegedly raped the girl at gunpoint about a year ago. Since then he had been sexually exploiting her, the police sources added.

“The victim stated that she did not tell about the sexual assault to anyone as the accused used to threaten to kill her younger brother. On February 20, while she was on way to give fodder to the cattle, the accused waylaid her and tried to rape her again. The goon, after threatening her with dire consequences, fled the site when she raised an alarm. She then locked herself in her room and attempted to kill herself by hanging”, said another police official.

“The victim was saved as her parents managed to admit her in a hospital in time,” he added.

SP (rural) Pradyuman Singh said that a probe has been ordered in the matter. “I have instructed inspector Ghatampur to conduct a probe and act accordingly in this regard. Raids are underway to arrest the accused”.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Delhi: Deadline for longest skywalk is pushed again, now to June-end
Content: NEW DELHI: The Rao Tula Ram Marg flyover has been functional for seven months now, but the second phase of the project has missed its fourth deadline — it has been pushed from March 31 to June 30 . The public works department (PWD) is constructing Delhi’s longest skywalk — 1.5km long — and a 1.2km underpass in this phase.The construction of the entire project started in November 2014 to decongest Outer Ring Road between IIT and National Highway-8, which will offer relief to people travelling to and from Indira Gandhi International Airport.A PWD official said the construction of the second phase got delayed due to several obstacles, such as clearances from the railways and the Army. In case of the underpass, making the way through large rocks without obstructing traffic movement also took time. The last block — a dispute with the railways over clearing of high-voltage power lines — was cleared a few months ago. The digging work is now going on near Satyaniketan, creating trouble for those heading towards Dhaula Kuan and Naraina.Almost 85% of the Phase-II work has been completed, claimed the official. PWD has also increased the workforce to meet the next deadline, he added.While the skywalk, starting at Durgabai Deshmukh metro station, will be on Benito Juarez Marg, the Y-shaped underpass will have two arms, easing traffic movement on Benito Juarez Marg and San Martin Marg.A senior government official said students of Delhi University’s South Campus would benefit the most from the skywalk. “We hear of several accidents on this stretch and there was no foot overbridge or underpass for safe movement,” he said, adding that the underpass had been designed in a way that it would make maximum use of the unutilised space on the stretch.A coffee shop, which was planned on the skywalk earlier, may be considered again depending on the number of people using the facility, said a PWD official.

Title: Clashes between anti-CAA protesters and police leave 8 injured in Aligarh
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Police personnel at the violence-hit area in Aligarh

AGRA: Hundreds of anti-CAA protesters fought a pitched battle with security personnel and a youth, 22, was shot at and seriously injured in the mayhem which erupted on the streets of Old city in Aligarh on Sunday evening.

The violent clashes sent the government and the local administration into a tizzy as they were busy giving final touches to the visit of US President Donald Trump to Agra, just 90 km away from Aligarh.

“Five protesters and three policemen were injured in the clash,” said Muniraj G, Aligarh’s senior superintendent of police (SSP). Mobile Internet services were snapped in the city for 24 hours as a precautionary measure, and the situation was brought under control after additional police force was deployed, he added.

Police claimed that the violence started after a vehicle of a police officer, who was travelling with his family, was pelted with stones by women protesters in Upper Kot area around 4:30pm on Sunday.

However, the protesters claimed that some policemen resorted to “unprovoked” baton-charge after they demanded a tent at a ‘dharna’ site in Shahjamal, where they are holding a sit-in for the last one month against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Aligarh district magistrate (DM) CB Singh said, “Some women students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) were behind the clash and they had turned violent to disrupt the peaceful atmosphere of the city. They all have been identified and their role is being investigated.”

The DM said that protesters had been given a designated spot to protest, but they were not ready to listen and were trying to spread it to other parts of the city. “Police used tear gas to disperse them after the protesters pelted stones on the police vehicle,” he said.

Police claimed that incidents of stone-pelting also took place in Babri Mandi area after “news about police action” in Upper Kot area spread. However, the situation was brought under control soon, they said.

One of the women protesters, Huma Tariq, who is a teacher and who was present at the protest site in Upper Kot area, told TOI that they had been protesting peacefully and demanding permission to erect tents in Shahjamal as many of them had fallen sick due to the cold weather and heavy rains. “The administration had been denying us the permission and resorted to unprovoked ‘lathi-charge’,” she claimed.

Another protester in Shahjamal area, Mohammad Tariq, alleged that police personnel “misbehaved” with the women protesters, and when the men present there protested, they resorted to cane-charge. He admitted that in retaliation, some protesters did pelt stones on the policemen.

Title: 13-year-old clerical error lands 545 rural hamlets on bumpy roads in Telangana
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

HYDERABAD: A clerical error by state officials has been haunting 545 habitations in Telangana for the past 13 years, depriving them of good motorable roads as nearly Rs 800 crore central funds is stuck in bureaucratic maze. Instead of “unconnected” roads, the note from then undivided Andhra Pradesh seeking funds under Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojna (PMGSY) mentioned it as “connected”, leading to the fund impasse.

The requisition in 2007 from panchayat raj and rural development seeking central funds for developing roads in rural hinterland stated on paper that 676 habitations were “connected” by tar roads when, in effect, 545 habitations had only dirt roads. These 545 hamlets, with a population of 200-500, are located across Telangana (except Hyderabad) and account for 1,469 km of dirt roads which require black top (BT) roads.

The main aim of PMGSY is to provide road connectivity from habitations in rural areas to mandal and district headquarters so that the rural poor and farmers get access to schools, colleges, banks, hospitals and agriculture markets.

“For the past 13 years, every time we have submitted a representation to the Centre about the error, they have said that they would look into it. But not a rupee has been released for road development for these habitations till date,” said Rajasekhar Reddy, panchayat raj and rural development chief engineer in-charge of PMGSY

With the state’s financial position not that good, the Telangana government has now decided to not only pursue the Rs 800 crore for the 545 habitations, but also request the Centre for more funds to develop 4,000 km of rural roads in the state.

Panchayat raj minister Errabelli Dayakar Rao has now taken up the matter with the Centre and also written a letter to director-general of the National Rural Infrastructure Development Agency. State government officials have said that the response from the Centre has been positive and that they were expecting the 13-year-old mistake to be rectified in phase-IV of PMGSY, which starts from April 1 of financial year 2020-21.

Title: Bharat Bandh call receives lukewarm response in Roorkee
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Roorkee: The nation-wide call for Bharat Bandh given by Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad to protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens received lukewarm response in Roorkee.

Heavy security arrangements were put in place in view of the bandh call but no violence was reported as the bandh remained peaceful.

Most shops remained open and the traffic remained normal. However, protesters disrupted vehicular movements for about an hour at the Military Chowk crossing. The agitators gathered there with anti-CAA and anti-NRC placards and raised slogans against the Centre over refusal of reservation in promotion. Later, Mahak Singh, who was leading the protest, handed over a memorandum to joint magistrate Namami Bansal. “The President must curtail wings of the central government as they are dividing the nation for their vested interests,” he said.

Title: Kochi: Old Venduruthy Bridge to step into future
Content:
Its objective is to regulate street vending as well as protection of livelihoods

KOCHI: In an effort to rehabilitate street vendors in the city, Kochi corporation has mooted a ‘Walk the Street’ project for the old Venduruthy bridge . This will entail kiosks on the bridge.Mayor Soumini Jain has asked the town planning standing committee to explore the feasibility of the project. “As per the Street Vendors Act, we have to rehabilitate street vendors. There are around 2,000 street vendors and a section of them can be given kiosks on old Venduruthy bridge . This would address the issue of rehabilitation to a certain extent. It will also help protect the nearly 84-year-old structure built during the British Raj,” the mayor said. “We should secure the nod from public works department (PWD), which owns the stretch,” she said.TOI had campaigned for protection of the structure by publishing a series of reports. Following this, Aswas Public Amenities Ltd, an independent agency under PWD, had mooted a plan to set up a ‘Walk the Street’ on the 700-metre-long old Venduruthy Road. Though the agency sought the approval from the government for the same, the then secretary of PWD put it on hold and the project was shelved.Old Venduruthy bridge has been lying idle for nearly nine years after traffic was rerouted through the new Venduruthy-Vikrant bridge. According to Sunila Shelvan, chairperson, town planning standing committee of Kochi corporation, the committee would soon explore the possibilities of setting up the ‘Walk the Street’.“We will hold discussions with various stakeholders and take a decision accordingly. We will also consider similar project for the Alexander Parambithara Bridge near Thevara as well,” Shelvan said.The Street Vendors Act, introduced by the Union government, came into force on May 1, 2014. Its objective is to regulate street vending as well as protection of livelihoods. As per the Act, local bodies should identify street vending zones within their limits and shift street vendors. But, Kochi corporation is still unable to rehabilitate the street vendors.

Title: Secunderabad: Shutdown of Nizam-era railway press deferred
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nizam-era railway printing press at Secunderabad

SECUNDERABAD: The shutting down of the Nizam-era railway printing press at Secunderabad and four others across the country has been postponed from March 31, 2020 to June 30, 2020.

“The decision of closure of five printing presses in Secunderabad, Mumbai, Howrah, Delhi, Chennai has been deferred for a three-month period by the board,” read a letter addressed to general managers of railway divisions, by C Ravindran, director, railway board.

As much as the decision has brought a sigh of relief for employees and railway unions, the printing press are expected employees to print extra tickets to create a buffer while hiring more people on temporary basis.

“Our printing press has been printing cardboard tickets, forms and documents related to railway operations since the 1880s. The closure of the press means the material printed by us will now be outsourced from private printers, which is not good for railway employees,” a source told TOI.

Title: Ro-Ro vassel collission: Kerala Maritime Board to rein in tour boats
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A tourist boat collided with a Ro-Ro vessel near Fort Kochi boat jetty on Friday

KOCHI: The incident in which a tourist boat collided with a Ro-Ro vessel near Fort Kochi boat jetty on Friday has turned out to be an eye-opener for authorities. The Kerala Maritime Board (KMB) has called for a meeting at Alappuzha on Tuesday to discuss regularizing operations of tourist boats.

Currently, there are no stringent rules regarding the areas of operations of small and large tourist boats in the backwaters and the shipping channel. Officials stressed the need to have proper rules as there is an increase in tourist boat traffic in Kochi backwaters. When services of Kochi Water Metro begin, there will be increased movement of passengers boats too. The boats operated by the state water transport department and Water Metro will focus on passenger services. “These boats operate at a fixed timing along fixed routes. But private tourist boats, particularly those operating from Marine Drive, do not follow a fixed time or route. The movement of these boats has to be regularized without affecting tourism,” said Kerala Inland Vessel (KIV) Rules chief surveyor Renjith M J.

It is pointed out that tourists prefer boat rides to see places like Mattancherry, Willingdon Island, Fort Kochi and Vypeen. This enables them to get a view of Cochin Port, Vallarpadam Terminal and Cochin Shipyard.

Meanwhile, the fisheries department has hinted at the need for regulating movement of fishing boats in the shipping channel. There were instances of fishing boats colliding with passenger boats in the shipping channel.

Ernakulam fisheries deputy director Maja Jose said that their department is keen about creating an awareness among fishing boat operators and owners.

“Those operating fishing boats are unaware of the routes, which they should take while traversing the busy shipping channel. Though buoys have been placed to show direction, they often do not understand its significance. The general practice is to move away when they see a boat or a large vessel,” she said, adding that if experts from KMB are willing to create awareness on the paths that fishing boats should take in the busy backwaters of Kochi, the fisheries department is more than willing to associate with them. The department has funds for conducting such awareness programmes.

Title: Nagaur man, who killed three children arrested
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Jaipur: A man accused of killing his three children in Nagaur in November last year was arrested from Fatehpur on Saturday.

The accused had been on the run for nearly three months before finally being arrested after police received information through a source. The motive for the murders remain unclear.

Nathuram Banjara hanged his three children to death who were identified as identified as Seema (7), Manisha (5) and Vishal (3).

Ladnun SHO Mukut Bihari said, “His wife had lodged a case against him claiming that he killed the children when she and her mother-in-law were out for work. When they returned home, they found the children dead and the father missing. We lodged a search for him and through a source found out about his location following which he was arrested by our team.”

Cops, however, are yet to find out the motive behind the murders. The SHO added, “We are interrogating Nathuram, but till now he has been unable to give a reason why he killed his children. He was a drunkard and it is highly likely that he was under the influence of alcohol when he killed his children. We questioned his family members, but they have also been unable to give any concrete reason.”

According to the initial investigation, Nathuram was essentially unemployed and his wife and mother ran the house by working as labourers in the village. The accused spent most of his time drinking alcohol and stayed at home to take of the children.

He is currently in police remand till he is produced in court. A case under IPC Section 302 ( murder ) has been registered against him.

Title: Collegiums main culprits for rising vacancies in HCs: Government
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

NEW DELHI: Blamed for not filling up vacancies in high courts , the Centre has told the Supreme Court that HC collegiums were the main culprits as there was inordinate delay on their part, in some cases going back to more than five years, in recommending names for judgeship after the vacancy arose.

Placing a detailed analysis of the vacancies in HCs and the reasons for delay in filling up the posts, the Centre told a bench of Justices S K Kaul and K M Joseph that no names were forwarded by HCs for 199 out of 396 vacancies, some of which occurred way back in 2014. The sanctioned strength of judges in 25 HCs is 1,079 but the working strength, as on February 1, was 683. Some HCs like Patna and Rajasthan have more than 50% vacancies.

Attorney general K K Venugopal told the court, which is examining reasons for delay in appointment of judges, that the Centre was waiting for recommendations from HC collegiums which were yet to forward names for 199 vacancies —134 from the bar and 65 from the judicial service.

Agreeing with the AG’s submission, the bench said, “There is an important aspect which the attorney general emphasises by referring to a chart submitted before us showing the inordinate delay in making recommendations to fill vacancies by high courts. The situation in some high courts is more alarming than the others but it is no better than the others, including the court in the capital of the country.

“Needless to emphasise that chief justices of HCs must endeavour to recommend names against the vacancies as early as possible, even if they are not made at one go. We may also note that there appears to be some hesitation in some courts to recommend names without the earlier list being cleared. We understand that there is no such impediment and it should be a continuing process of recommending names without waiting for the result of the earlier recommendations. Otherwise, the time period to process names is such that by the time appointments take place, another set of vacancies arise which brings the problem of vacancies to square one.”

Blaming HC collegiums for the delay, Venugopal urged the court to issue notice and seek explanation from HCs. But the bench refrained from issuing notice and said, “We desist from doing so at present but call upon registrars of different high courts to send us the vacancy position as on date, when did they arise and number of vacancies likely to arise in the next six months, explaining as to what is the time period within which one can expect recommendations to be made.”

Title: Row over Pak team visit to Ajmer Dargah
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Times News Network

Jaipur: The proposed visit of the Pakistani delegation to Ajmer Dargah is under a cloud. . Two days before the formal start of Urs , the local administration is not clear about the arrival of delegates from the neighbouring country. In Pakistan , however, the selected 240-280 devotees are busy making last-minute preparations.

Officials remained tightlipped on the status of the visit, but have started making preparations to handle the guests.

The local administration, which had red flagged the visit in its internal report submitted to the central agencies on February 15, was taken by surprise to receive directions from Delhi to make the preparations. The officials approached the Dargah committee office on Saturday asking them to begin preparations for the Pakistani guests.

The internal report prepared by the officials, including police said the visit might invite protests from the locals. “Since tension has heightened due to abrogation of Article 370, the chances of pilgrims engaged in arguments or at loggerheads can happen and can create law and order situation,” said an official.

Meanwhile, the delegates in Pakistan have started travelling to Lahore to begin their journey on February 27. Mohammed Hussain, a resident of Pak Pattan, told TOI over the phone that he has been asked by the authorities to be in Lahore on February 26 to collect his stamped visa.

“Our government has told us to assemble in Lahore to complete formalities on or before February 26. We submitted our passports three weeks ago and hoping to travel on time. Since trains from Pakistan from Wagah and Khokrapar are not operating since August, we were told to cross over Wagah by foot and to board buses for Ajmer from Amritsar,” said Hussain.

The delegation did not turn up in the last two years due to tension between the two countries while chances of the visit this year in the wake of abrogation of Article 370 has remained dismal.

Title: Indresh Kumar address Sufi conference, seeks minority support on CAA
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Ajmer/Jaipur: RSS national executive member Indresh Kumar on Sunday asked Muslims to support the controversial CAA and hinted discussions on NRC while delivering his keynote address at a national-level Sufi Conference organized by Rastriya Muslim Manch (RMM) in Ajmer on the eve of Urs.

Kumar was initially named in the chargesheet of the 2007 Ajmer Dargah bomb blast. Later, his name was dropped. He is the founder member of the RMM. During the conference, the participants were taken aback when the organiser asked them to raise their hands if anyone would like to settle in Pakistan while making a point that the neighboring country was unpopular among Muslims in India.

“The entire country is gradually accepting CAA and discussions should start on NRC so that peace and tranquility remains in the country,” said Kumar, whose statement is seen as a scope on a possible deliberation on NRC.

Kumar minced no words in support of CAA stated that the Act was in support in Insaniyat (Humanity) while its virodh (against) is shaitaniyat (devil’s act).

“Those against the citizenship law are supporting the persecution of minorities in neighbouring countries,” said Kumar. The conference, which was held on the eve of the largest Muslim gathering in India, is seen as a step by RMM to build consensus over the CAA.

Taking on Shaheen Bagh protesters, he said blocking the passage of anyone or protesting against the rule for Muslims is anti-Islamic acts. “BJP, which is part of the central government, is showing great patience that they have not used any force on places where women and children protestors are present,” said Kumar. He handed over a chadar to be offered at the Dargah.

The conference was attended by participants from 10 states. “Indian Muslims should spread the message of Antim Rasool (Last prophet) of getting cool breeze from India which means peace, universal brotherhood and security. India is the only country which has assimilated all faiths and given them equal respect which should also be propagated by Indian Muslims,” said Kumar.

Title: 3 die in two separate road accidents
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: Two friends, who were riding a two-wheeler and on their way to the city from Nakrekal in Nalgonda district to attend a wedding, were run over by a goods truck at Pedda Amberpet on Sunday.

Hayathnagar police said that Khaja Moinuddin, 20, a BTech student, and Sai Surya, 19, a private employee, started their journey to Hyderabad on their bike at 9am.

“Around 11am, Khaja, who was riding the motorcycle, and Sai, who was pillion rider, reached Laxmareddy Palem in Pedda Amberpet. A lorry hit them from the rear and both died on the spot,’’ Hayathnagar sub-inspector R Shankaraiah told TOI.

Both suffered head injuries. Officials said that both Khaja and Sai, who were also neighbours in Nakrekal, were coming to Hyderabad to attend their friend’s marriage. The driver of the lorry was taken into custody and a case was booked under Section 304-A (negligence causing death) of the IPC.

In another accident , a 74-year-old woman, a pedestrian, identified as G Elizabeth, was run over by a lorry while she was on her way to a church in Hayathanagar police limits around 10am on Sunday. She died on the spot.

Title: High temperatures heighten fire risks in Ernakulam district
Content:
A fire force personnel clears a well at Gandhinagar fire station

KOCHI: The fire brigade is having a busy season. It’s only February and some units in the district are attending to over half a dozen calls a day, mostly regarding minor fires.Fire-force personnel say that it is time to stay alert as dry-weather conditions prevail and parched vegetation is waiting for a spark that could ignite a major blaze.“The scorching heat that we are experiencing now can engender two types of fires. There is heavy use of electrical devices such as coolers, fans etc, and short circuit-related incidents can happen at homes. The other category involves fires that break out in the open. These happen more often and can become major fires that can cause heavy losses and even causalities, if not handled carefully,” said district fire officer Gogy J S.According to the fire department, the Eloor (60 cases), Aluva (50), Thrikkakara (55) and Gandhinagar (50) fire stations in the city have received the most number of calls.Most of the blazes are man-made and being careful, itself, can prevent most of them. “It is common for residents to pile up garbage and set it on fire. These fires may not be dangerous, by themselves, but a flare can easily travel in the wind and land on some shrubbery, causing a major fire,” said Gogy.Fire officers say that careless handling of objects like cigarette butts, matchsticks, and other substances that can cause a fire is another reason for fires. Burning of garbage near groves and shrubs, transformers, parked vehicles and other inflammable substances can increase the gravity of the fire, they said.Gandhinagar station officer, A Unnikrishnan, said that many try to clear out plots covered by vegetation during the summer.He said fire personal have taken note of water sources that can be relied on in case of emergencies. “On Saturday, we cleaned the well on the premises and did some basic dredging,” said Unnikrishnan.Two major fires was reported at North Paravur on Sunday evening. Fire-force teams from Aluva, Mala, Eloor, Ernakulam, and Vypeen had to be brought in when a blaze engulfed a huge pile of garbage. Bushes caught on fire in the second incident and it was extinguished in an hour, sources said.

Title: Fraudsters exploit remote access apps to dupe victims
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Posing as employees of e-wallet service providers, cyber fraudsters have been duping hundreds of people by making them install remote desktop access applications such as TeamViewer QuickSupport and AnyDesk.

On January 9, B Venkatesh, a 53-year-old steel merchant from Ram Nagar approached cybercrime sleuths of Hyderabad stating that an unknown person had called him on January 7. Introducing himself as Rajendra Prasad, an employee of Paytm, the caller asked him to update KYC details of his Paytm account.

“The fraudster asked the complainant to download AnyDesk app in his phone to update KYC details. After making the complainant install AnyDesk, the accused remotely accessed his cell phone by obtaining the access code from him. Subsequently, the fraudster obtained Paytm account details of the complainant, including UPI PIN and siphoned off Rs 1.03 lakh from his bank account,” cybercrime inspector D Prashant said.

On January 7, T Anand, 59, a private employee from Ameerpet, lodged a complaint with cybercrime sleuths alleging that he received an SMS on January 6 stating that his Paytm account had expired.

“In the message, the fraudsters mentioned a fake contact number of Paytm customer care. When Anand called the fake number, the fraudster made him install TeamViewer QuickSupport remote desktop access app. After the installation of the app, the fraudster gained access to the mobile phone of the victim by obtaining the required code from him. As per the instructions of the fraudster, the accused also made the victim recharge his Paytm wallet with the linked ICICI bank account and made him link his credit card to the wallet, all the while looking at the cell phone details remotely. With the information obtained, they siphoned off Rs 1.88 lakh from his bank account and his credit card,” the inspector said.

Similarly, on January 21, a case was registered based on the complaint of Md Saqib Jawab, an Imam of a mosque in Tolichowki, regarding fraudsters siphoning off Rs 40,000 off him by posing as representatives of Bank of Baroda and making him install AnyDesk app.

According to the cybercrime police, fraudsters also siphoned off Rs Rs 1.96 lakh from the bank account of businessman P Narsing Rao Aravind Kumar of Narayanguda and Rs 99,000 from businessman Dheeraj Agarwal of Bahadurpura, posing as customer care executives of banks or e-wallet services and making them install theQuickSupport app.

Title: 4 arrested with elephant tusks in Sikar
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Jaipur: Sikar police on Sunday arrested four accused for smuggling elephant tusks weighing approximately 3.5kg. The accused were trying to sell it when they were caught red-handed.

Police are trying to ascertain the means by which the accused got the tusks. The accused are Shivchand, Pratap Jat, Sandeep Jat and Omprakash Jat. While the latter three are in their 30s, Shivchand is in his 50s.

Uma Shankar, SHO, Ramgarh police station, said, “We received information that the accused had on them elephant tusks which they were trying to sell in the area. We formed teams and nabbed them with the animal parts. The consignment comprised elephant tusks and jaw. Each of them was carrying the tusks in certain quantity.”

The tusks were between 5-7 inches long and 1 to 1.75 inches thick. The cops are still trying to find from where the accused procured the banned item. The jaw was approximately 5 to 7 inches in thickness and 1.45 inches in length.

“The investigation is currently under way and we are questioning the accused to find the source from where they got the tusks. There is a nexus which is supplying these tusks, which means there is demand for it in Rajasthan as well. We are interrogating the accused to find out their other gang members as well,” said the official. The accused were booked under Wildlife Protection Act 1972. Cops are also checking the past criminal records of the four arrested to find if they have dealt in some other animal parts.

Elephant is protected under Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. It lists it as ‘most endangered animal’. Poaching it or having any ivory item calls for a minimum three years in jail and Rs 50,000 fine.

Title: IMAGE’s plant: ‘ABC unit faces closure’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Veterinary hospital and animal birth control unit at Brahmapuram

KOCHI: Kickstarting a row, revenue authorities are planning to take over the land where a veterinary hospital and animal birth control (ABC) unit of Kochi corporation is functioning at Brahmapuram for setting up a biomedical waste treatment plant. This is when the ABC unit is proposed to be elevated to the status of training centre for ABC.

A few days ago, revenue officials conducted a survey for allotting three acres to Indian Medical Association Goes Eco-friendly (IMAGE) for setting up the plant. IMAGE was allotted the land from the 115 acres owned by Kochi corporation at Brahmapuram. Still, the land ownership will continue to rest with Kochi corporation. The veterinary hospital and ABC unit is in the said three acres. “So, the ABC unit will have to be closed. This situation should be avoided,” said Gracy Joseph, chairperson, standing committee for development, Kochi corporation. According to ABC officials, they have sterilized around 6,000 street dogs. “We are planning to impart training to vets on animals’ birth control. The current move will affect our firm adversely,” an official said. The ABC unit is located in 35 cents.

Office-bearers of IMAGE said they wouldn’t cause any damage to ABC unit. “The officials conducted survey for allotting three acres to us. The land where the ABC unit is located falls within this. So, the district administration has identified another 25 cents where the ABC unit can be relocated,” said Dr K P Sharaffudeen, IMAGE secretary. “We are ready to set up our office and facilities like road access in the 25 cents. We will set up our facility only after ensuring that the ABC unit is there, it may have to relocated though,” he said.

Title: Anand bank loot: 3 robbers lock staff in vault, loot Rs 90 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Cops said the vault contained Rs1.1 crore cash, but the robbers did not touch Rs21.16 lakh

VADODARA/ANAND: In a daring bank robbery, three armed persons looted nearly Rs 90 lakh cash from the Bandhan Bank in ‘Milk City’ Anand on Sunday. The robbers barged into the branch of Kolkata-headquartered private bank located on 100-feet road when two customer relation officers – Anuj Patel and Shabnam Pathan – and two cashiers – Rajvi Shah and Shahnawaz Bhatiyara – were present.

Police said two robbers, who had covered their faces with handkerchiefs, entered the branch and brought down the shutter. They asked the four employees in Hindi to not raise an alarm and demanded the vault’s keys. When the bank staffers did not respond, one of them took out a knife and another pulled out a country-made gun. Shah handed over one bunch of keys to them when threatened and then the third robber also entered.

The four staffers were asked to sit together on a sofa and not move. When the vault did not open, one of them came back asking for second bunch of keys. Shah, who had hidden the keys in the dustbin, had to bring them out as the robbers threatened to kill them. As the vault opened, Shah and Pathan were tied with a cloth in storage room and Patel and Bhatiyara in the pantry.

The robbers then entered the vault and came out after a while with cash. They then locked the four staffers inside the vault and switched off the lights. The robbery came to light only when Pathan called up her husband who rushed to the bank and informed manager of Vidyanagar branch.

Cops said the vault contained Rs1.1 crore cash, but the robbers did not touch Rs21.16 lakh. They also fled with digital video recorder of CCTV cameras installed in the branch manager’s cabin.

Bank officials told police that the branch remains open on Saturday and Sunday as well and that no security guard has been hired by the bank.

“We have alerted police in neighbouring districts and started combing rural areas besides checking in the town. The robbers are believed to be aged in their 30s,” said DySP B D Jadeja.

Title: West Bengal to launch e-vessels to improve Kolkata’s air, water quality
Content:
Such two electric vessels, which will cut down on air, water and noise pollution will be introduced in Kolkata... Read More

KOLKATA: The government plans to introduce electric vessels on the Hooghly, aiming to cut down on pollution by replacing the current fleet of old and rickety ferries, which West Bengal Pollution Control Board said, added to the air and water toxicity and noise level.Track the pollution level in your cityWith a massive rise in passenger count using the ferry services across 28 ghats dotting the city and surroundings, the transport department wants to augment the facility, make it safe and at the same time, control pollution so that it turns into a viable means of commute that can ease the pressure on the road network, already creaking under the burden. “We are thinking of introducing at least two electric vessels to understand its viability in our ferry system,” said an official, adding the government was in the process of acquiring 20 modern vessels, complete with improved emission system.The vessels used currently are reportedly big guzzlers of fuel and wreak havoc on the city’s ambient air because they also emit toxic fumes. “Though the pollutants from a ferry disperse fast because it’s all open on a river, the long-term harm being caused to the city’s ambient air is significant,” said a pollution control board official. So, the push for a shift to clean-fuel vessels; the 20 ferries that are being brought in will reportedly make little or no noise whatsoever.This will be part of a government initiative to optimize underutilized river transport and tourism with a $151-million (Rs1,021-crore) assistance from World Bank. While the Centre’s Rs 5,369-crore Ganga Jal Marg project aims at seamless cargo movement along National Waterway-I from Varanasi to Haldia, the state is primarily exploring the potential of cargo and passenger movement on river.Bengal shares 560km of the 1,380km NW-I, which has only 12 bridges over it, including three in Kolkata. The World Bank-aided project aims to fill the gap by adding 10 roll-on-roll-over or Ro-Ro services, which offer seamless solution to ferry vehicles, with passengers on board, and cargo. According to state sources, each of the new Ro-Ro facilities will cost around Rs 25 crore, and the cost will include setting up of specialised jetties as well.The state will also build 56 modern jetties at Rs 4 crore each and renovate 24 existing jetties along the 156-km stretch from Haldia to Triveni under World Bank assistance. To supplement operations, nearly 320 new vessels will be pressed into service. A separate plan is underway to modernise jetties from Triveni in Hooghly to Farakka in Murshidabad, using state resources. “There are roughly 500 ferry services along the river in Bengal. Some of them are wooden jetties. With time, we will modernise them all,” said a transport department official.With modernisation, the state aims at better regulation of ferry operations. Now, the service is unorganised, with different departments and civic bodies owning jetties. Most jetties are poorly maintained, leading to accidents. The plan is to bring the entire facility under an organisation under the transport department to ensure better and safer services.

Title: Andhra Pradesh vigilance to probe welfare fund embezzlement claims
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The vigilance and enforcement department will take up investigation into allegations of misappropriation of funds from the welfare board of building and other construction workers in the last five years.

Trade union leaders had alleged that the misappropriation of funds could be bigger than the ESI drug purchase scandal.

Trade unions sent representations to the chief minister’s office seeking probe into the misuse of workers’ welfare fund.

“We have information that about Rs 400-Rs 500 crore was siphoned off from the welfare fund during the TDP regime. A thorough investigation will bring more facts to the light,” said P Gautham Reddy, YSR Trade Union Congress leader.

The Building and Other Construction Workers’ Welfare Board was set up in 2007 when Y S Rajasekhara Reddy was the chief minister. The government started levying 1% cess on all constructions raised in and above 200 sq yard of land while granting building plans. The cess collected from the builders and individuals was routed to the workers’ welfare fund to take up different welfare activities for those engaged as daily wagers in the unorganized sector including masons, carpenters, painters, rod bending workers, plumbers and electricians. The board had a reserve fund of nearly Rs 1,200 crore at the time of bifurcation of the state.

The TDP government, which shifted a majority of state level offices and corporations to Amaravati in 2015, had allowed the workers’ board to remain in Hyderabad till January 2019.

The government had decided to distribute tool kits such as trowels, iron crowbars, chisels, rods, shoes and others in 2017 by spending funds from the welfare board.

Allegations are rife that the tools were purchased without calling tenders at very high prices. The officials also raised bogus bills without even purchasing kits in some instances as there was no audit for the distribution of the tool kits. Workers alleged that massive amounts were withdrawn for the purchase of tool kits between 2015-2019.

Sources said the welfare fund was also spent for outdoor publicity of Chandranna Bima, which is against the rules of the board.

“This is yet another attempt to damage our reputation. They are free to go ahead with the inquiry. We are not worried as we have not committed any wrong,” said former labour minister K Atchnnaidu. He said that the TDP government had allowed the board to remain in Hyderabad due to legal complications in the division of the board between the two states.
