Title: Bonus, benefits for Aapli Bus drivers, conductors from March 2020
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The hunger strike launched by employees of three red bus operators and two ticketing agencies of Aapli Bus at ... Read More

Nagpur: Some 2,200 employees of the three red bus operators and two ticketing agencies of Aapli Bus will be getting bonus and other benefits from March 2020. This had been a long pending demand of these staffers. Their protests, the latest of which was launched from Monday morning, ended after some workers sat for a hunger strike and Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) conceded their demands.

Out of the 2,200 employees, 1,100 are bus drivers and the other half are conductors. The operators include Hansa City Bus Services, RK Travels, Travel Time, Unity Infrastructure and SIS. The workers’ long standing demand was that no employee should be made to work for more than 48 hours in a week, employees should be given a weekly off, overtime pay for any employee working for more than eight hours, and Diwali bonus of Rs5,500.

They also demanded 15 days of paid leave for any employee who has worked for 240 or more days, along with basic improvements.

NMC’s transport committee chairman Narendra Borkar convened a meeting with all Aapli Bus operators and discussed the issue. “The operators also agreed to the demands made by the union,” said Borkar. He said the employees of three red bus and two ticketing agencies of Aapli Bus will get the benefits from March 2020.

Title: Stray cattle continue to menace streets
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Vijayawada: Stringent action initiated by Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) seem to have had little effect on owners of stray cattle, which continue to stall traffic in the city.

Hundreds of stray cows and bulls are seen roaming some of the arterial city roads in One town, Kothapeta, Gandhi Nagar, Governorpet, and Gunadala. Moreover, besides being a major source of problem for fruit and vegetable vendors, the VMC horticulture wing is having a hard time keeping them off their road dividers, where plants have been potted.

The VMC has constructed a cattle shed at Rajarajeswari Peta for the stray cattle. The veterinary wing of VMC have shifted around 80 cows to the shelter since December.

“We have intensified efforts to control stray cattle. Even the animals are suffering after consuming plastic and other garbage. We have identified that owners are allowing their cattle to graze save expences on the feed and shelter. Around 40 stray cattle have been left in our shelter for more than 20 days and no one has come forward to claim them,” said Ravi Chand, chief of the veterinary wing at VMC.

“We have recently conducted a meeting with around 25 stray-cow owners and warned them that we will permanently take them away,” he said.

Animal rights activists have demanded action against owners of cattle that allow them to graze in the streets. “VMC authorities should file criminal cases against the cattle owners and take stringent action,” said A Tejovanth, functionary at Help for Animal Society.

Title: Time to fight taboos, period; ‘Mahabhoj’ to dispel myths
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The women cooking the food were dressed in white aprons, which declared that they were on their period

NEW DELHI: A dozen menstruating women got together to prepare a feast early on Sunday. Their kitchen was a tent at Central Park in Mayur Vihar, their menu undecided and the guest list eccentric. But the purpose of the feast was singular: to dispel myths around menstruation .

The ‘ mahabhoj ’ was organised by Sachhi Saheli, an NGO that works to create awareness around menstrual hygiene. The women cooked food while dressed in white aprons, which declared that they were on their period . The feast was inaugurated by deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia, who said there should be no taboo attached to menstruation.

“In today’s scientific day and age, there is nothing pure or impure about menstruation, it is a natural biological process that should be taken as it is,” Sisodia said.

The feast was attended by over 500 people, including activists Kamala Bhasin and Benwada Wilson and theatre personality Arvind Gaur, who got together to “reclaim” women’s dignity and voice their opinion against gender-based discrimination. “We were extremely disturbed when we got to know that women in Bhuj were forced to remove their undergarments to prove they weren’t menstruation,” said Dr. Surbhi Singh, a gynaecologist-turned-activist, who is the founder of the NGO.

“A baba recently said that we will be born as dogs if we prepared food while we are on our period. This feast is an answer to such people. We want to tell them that there is no place for such superstitions in our society,” said Preeti, a school student who had volunteered to cook for the event.

Preeti was referring to the comment by Swami Krushnaswarup Dasji, who runs the college in Bhuj where 68 girls were forced to remove their underwear in a menstruation check. Renu, another woman who volunteered to cook, said the only way forward was to engage with superstition in a logical way.

Title: Gujarat: ‘Shiv Sena member hires two killers to avenge son’s death’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Satish Patil had hired Mohammed Zakir Siddiqui and Mohsin Siddiqui to kill the shopkeeper named Chaturvedi as ... Read More

VADODARA: In a new twist to a teenager’s murder in 2016, his father, a core committee member of Shiv Sena’s Gujarat unit, and the latter’s two accomplices were arrested by Bharuch police on Sunday. The trio had planned to kill a shopkeeper to avenge the teenage boy’s death.

Satish Patil, former vice-president of Shiv Sena Gujarat , had hired Mohammed Zakir Siddiqui and Mohsin Siddiqui to kill the shopkeeper named Chaturvedi as he suspected him to be involved in his son’s murder. Patil’s teenage son Vivek was allegedly killed by his second wife Rohini and a security guard Sudhakar Simpi. Some days later, Rohini died in jail and Simpi was released on bail. As the murder was conspired at Chaturvedi’s shop, he was made a witness in the case by police. However, Patil suspected that he was equally involved in the murder, so wanted to kill Chaturvedi.

The murder plan was blown up when cops from Bharuch local crime branch (LCB) found Mohammed Zakir and Mohsin moving around Chaturvedi’s shop on a bike on February 21. “Since their bike’s number plate was broken, we asked them to show its documents. They said the papers were with the bike’s owner and so were asked to come to LCB office on Saturday with them,” said a police official.

Meanwhile, the cops received information that the duo had been hired by Patil to kill Chaturvedi. The duo was brought for questioning during which they admitted to looking for an opportunity to kill Chaturvedi as they were hired for the job by Patil. “Patil had paid them Rs50,000 and also prepared a pesticide injection to kill Chaturvedi,” said LCB inspector J N Zala. Based on their statements, Patil was questioned and he confessed to his crime and thus was arrested.

Title: Menu revised, not the pay, say midday meal workers
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Vijayawada: Midday meal workers across the state are on the warpath demanding additional charges for the revised menu. The Andhra Pradesh Midday Meals Workers’ Association (APMMWA) conducted a state-level conference at MBVK Bhavan in the city on Sunday and demanded the state government to revise the tariff.

The new government after taking office decided to improve the quality of midday meals supplied in government and aided schools across the state and renamed the existing scheme as ‘Jagan Anna Gorumudda’. It revised the old menu and introduced egg, peanut chikki, and other nutritious foods.

But following the development, midday meal workers have alleged that the state government, which revised the menu, did not revise the meal charges. The APMMWA president Varalakshmi, while addressing the conference, said the state government is still paying Rs 6.57 rupees per meal for primary class students and Rs 8.80 per meal for secondary school students that is adding a huge burden on the workers. On an average workers of secondary schools are spending around Rs 9,666 from their pocket to feed the kids, she said.

K Swaroopa Rani general secretary of APMMWA alleged demanded that at least Rs 12 should be paid for primary class meals and Rs 15 per meal for secondary classes.

Title: Kolkata Rain: Met predicts light rain today
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Image used for Represenational Purpose

KOLKATA: The city is set to receive light to moderate rain on Monday . The showers could intensify on Tuesday and gradually cease by the second half of Wednesday. A cyclonic circulation that will trigger the rain is approaching Bengal and has reached eastern Uttar Pradesh, said the Met Office.

“We expect rain from the second half of Monday. The city will remain overcast from the morning, though. As the circulation approaches the state the rain will turn heavier on Tuesday,” said Regional Meteorological Centre director GK Das.

The showers should bring down the maximum temperature to 28 degrees on Monday, predicted the Met Office. It is expected to plunge further to around 25-26 degrees on Tuesday.

The rain will provide temporary relief from the early summer heat that has started setting in. Day temperature soared past the 30-degree mark for the first time this season last Thursday. With the cool northwesterly wind having stopped the mercury will now rise steadily, according to the RMC.

Title: Tourism dept steps in, Butt Road Beach to get a makeover
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Kozhikode: The tourism department is set to give a major facelift to Butt Road Beach , a favourite hangout of many city-dwelling families . The plan is to develop the Butt Road Beach into a venue for cultural programmes and improve children’s play area and other amenities.

The district tourism promotion council has received nod for a Rs 1 crore project for the improvement of the beach destination. The project aims to transform the beach to a family beach which will be explored by persons belonging to different age groups.

The construction activities at the beach will be carried out by Nirmithi Kendra, said an official with the tourism department. The work includes the construction of separate tracks for skating and cycling, the official added.

Butt Road Beach is a favourite destination for many health-conscious citizens including senior citizens. Many reach the beach in the morning and in the evening to sweat it out. On completion of the renovation, the beach is expected to attract more exercise-conscious citizens. The facility will help many to jog and exercise safely and at a calm area.

A skating track is planned to provide opportunity to children to practice skating, said an official. It is the first skating track planned in a public place in the city. At present children depend on Sarovaram Road and other roads and the pavement at the beach for practicing skating.

The DTPC is also planning to introduce cultural programmes on the road. The beach has a stage which can host music programmes and other cultural programmes planned by DTPC and other private groups to conduct musical nights and other programmes. The district administration is also working to promote Butt Road Beach as a cultural zone. Music programmes are organized on Sundays with singers and musicians from different parts of the district participating.

A cycle track is also coming up at Butt Road Beach as part of the renovation project, said Beena Madhusoodanan, DTPC secretary. The cycle track is planned in the front part of the beautified stretch of the beach, she said. The cycle track will be constructed modelled on the track at Kothi-Pallikandi stretch. The cycle track will help bicycle users, especially children, to ride their bicycles safely. The installation of a fountain in the pond on the beach is also part of the renovation work.

Title: Hyderabad: 27-year-old marketing executive who died in car accident was family's sole breadwinner
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Mangled remains of the car at Saroonagar police station on Sunday

HYDERABAD: It was a double whammy for the family of Pabba Sainath , 27, a marketing executive with a private firm, as they not only lost a youngster in a car accident at Karmanghat in the early hours of Sunday , but also the sole bread winner.

Sainath had been shouldering the responsibility of his family since he was 21 after his father’s demise.

“He was just 21 when he started working, soon after his father died, almost seven years ago. My sister is a housewife and he started working at a young age because he wanted to contribute financially for the family. He started his career at a low position, but became achieved success with hard work,” said Sainath's maternal uncle KV Srinivas told TOI.

Sainath, a resident of Saraswathi Nagar in Saidabad, was meeting college friends after a long time and decided to go out partying on Saturday night. “When he told us he was going out for a party, we asked him to go in a car instead of taking his bike, fearing for his safety. We presumed it will be a safer option for him to go in a car. However, we found that all of them (four) were drunk when the accident occurred. We had on several occasions warned and explained to him not to drive under the influence of alcohol or encourage other to do so,” Srinivas added.

According to the family, they found out about the incident late at night through his friends. “I saw the body, and I don't think my sister and niece can see that. That's why I am here in the mortuary, with other relatives. The family, especially my sister, has been in a state of shock after losing her husband, now she lost her son too,” he added.

Title: Man commits suicide
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Jaipur: A 40-year-old man committed suicide in Vidhyadhar Nagar police station area late on Saturday by hanging himself. The man’s body was found by his family, though no suicide note has been found till now. His post-mortem was done on Sunday morning.

The deceased Rupesh Pareek was found hanging from the ceiling at his house around 10pm on Saturday.

Radha Raman Gupta, SHO, Vidhyadhar Nagar police station, said, “The deceased was found by his family when they returned home and despite knocking multiple times, he did not open the door. We received the information and kept the body in the mortuary. We have not found any suicide note yet.”

According to officials, Pareek worked as a financier. “He used to drink alcohol regularly, though till now that does not appear to be a reason behind the suicide. We are also looking into the possibility that he might be under some kind of financial duress due to which he took his own life though nothing can be said with certainty as of now,” a police official said.

Title: A year to go for polls: AIADMK, DMK may begin poaching allies
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Chennai: With about a year to go for the announcement of the schedule for the Tamil Nadu assembly elections, political parties have to take stock of the ground realities. An analysis of the voting trends in the 22 assembly bypolls a few months ago and the final voting figures for the first phase of the local body polls , (counting in January 2020), now made available by the Tamil Nadu Election Commission, shows the ruling AIADMK cannot bask in the glory of its victories in the two assembly bypolls in October last year, but be concerned about the lead established by the DMK-led front of average 7% in the past one year.

The crucial question before the parties is whether the AIADMK has managed to turn the tide since the defeat in the Lok Sabha polls and the assembly byelections held in April-May 2019 or not. On the face of it, things appear rosy for the AIADMK after it won the Vikravandi and Nanguneri assembly byelections. But, one should factor in the reality that micro-management in two bypolls with more than 30 ministers camping there is one thing, but a mini-general election across the state, is quite another.

In the 22 assembly byelections, the DMK-led front managed a lead of 6.89% (DMK+ 45.07% vs AIADMK+ 38.18%). The AIADMK thought it could turn the tables on the DMK in rural local body polls since the AIADMK was considered stronger in the villages, given the popularity of MGR and the two-leaves symbol. In 2011, the AIADMK dominated the local body polls, decimating the DMK even in the urban areas of 10 municipal corporations (where the DMK stood a better chance of besting the AIADMK). The AIADMK then bagged all 10 corporations, besides a large number of rural bodies.

This time, the AIADMK, to its consternation, found that the DMK, which seemed more intent on pitching legal roadblocks to the election process, had fared far better than expected.

Voting figures of the rural local body elections reveal the DMK-led front polled nearly 8.4% more than the AIADMK-led combine in elections for the posts of district panchayat ward members and about 5.24% in elections to the posts of panchayat union councilors. The average lead for the DMK-led front is about 7% which is more or less the same lead as in the 22 assembly byelections (6.89%) held just a few month ago. And that should worry the managers of the AIADMK campaign. This means the opposition parties have been able to hold on to lead of the assembly bypolls, though it was on a weaker wicket than the AIADMK, which had the might of the ruling establishment.

Though the DMK could not maintain the huge lead of the LS polls (more than 22 %), it has been able to stave off a strong AIADMK challenge, which is aided by a resilient PMK, and continue the momentum of an anti-BJP platform, where the AIADMK is targeted for its ‘soft approach’ towards the BJP and its Hindutva ideology. The AIADMK tried to shed the image of being a pro-BJP party (asking the BJP leaders to keep away from the AIADMK campaign in the bypolls), it continues to defend the BJP-led government at the Centre at the risk of alienating the minorities and indirectly consolidating the minority votes in favour of the DMK-led combine.

The anti-CAA protests too have come as a boost and unifying factor for the constituents of the DMK-led front. The DMK hopes to consolidate this movement and build an anti-BJP, anti-AIADMK mood to catapult the opposition party to victory in the assembly polls next year The AIADMK has another source of worry — the Rajinikanth factor. Political circles are agog with rumours that Rajinikanth may wean away a section of the AIADMK leadership to his new outfit.

The DMK too has to read the writing on the wall. It can ill-afford to make the PMK its main enemy, when tactically it would be better off training its guns at the AIADMK and the BJP. Stung by the harsh DMK campaign against its leaders, the PMK has vowed to hit back. PMK founder S Ramadoss has warned the DMK that the forthcoming elections to some of the corporations, especially Villupuram, Vellore and Kancheepuram would go against the DMK. The DMK leadership has also failed to take note of adverse signals especially in the northern TN and not been able to cash in on differences between the PMK and the AIADMK over seat-sharing and post-sharing.

Lessons have to be learned and changes made accordingly on the drawing boards in the war rooms, since there is enough time for equations and alliances to change. Will the parties of Rajinikanth and Kamal Haasan upset the apple-cart of the major parties?

If the BJP chooses to quit the AIADMK-led alliance and launch its own front, the AIADMK doors may open for prospective allies. The DMK too has to do a fine balancing act in taking its allies along. The DMK also may try to wean away some allies of the AIADMK. T T V Dinakaran could play spoiler for the AIADMK. A realignment of forces is possible given the fragile nature of the alliances, enough to cause a tightening of the race.

(The writer is a veteran journalist)

Title: Survey of India DG offers job to member of Nain Singh Rawat’s family
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Dehradun: Lieutenant General Girish Kumar, director general of Survey of India, has offered a job opportunity to a member of Pandit Nain Singh Rawat’s family. Lt Gen Kumar made the offer after learning about the financial crisis being faced by the fourth generation of Pandit Rawat .

Pandit Rawat, who hailed from Johar Valley of Kumaon region, was one of the first Indian explorers to explore the Himalayas for the British.

Lt Gen Kumar told TOI, “We have offered a job to Kamla Rawat on compassionate ground. The job offered is in keeping with her educational qualification.”

Reacting to the job offer, Kamla told TOI, “We currently live in Pithoragarh’s Madot village but I will shift to Dehradun to work in the Survey Office. I want to repay the loan amount.”

On February 21, 2020, TOI had published a news report about a Mumbai-based man, hailing from Uttarakhand, who has launched a crowdfunding campaign to collect money for paying back Rs 19 lakh bank loan taken by Pandit Rawat’s family in 2015. The family is yet to pay Rs 9 lakh as the final settlement amount for the loan taken by Kamla’s late husband Kavindra Singh Rawat.

Title: After Golf Green death, focus on elderly & lonely
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Kolkata: The death of an 81-year-old widower, whose decomposed body was recovered from his Golf Green second-floor flat on Saturday after neighbours alerted the police, has highlighted the plight and helplessness of elderly and ailing citizens living alone in the quiet, residential neighbourhood.

Golf Green Central Coordination Committee, the residents’ welfare body, has launched a door-to-door survey to reach out to such elderly people living alone. Committee president Sandip Nandi Majumdar said, “This is an unfortunate incident. We are trying to reach out to every home and prepare a database of all the 60-70 elderly people living alone,” he said. “We will collect their details, contact numbers of their families and will form teams, who will reach out to them periodically.” Majumdar said Kolkata Police was also looking to extend Pronam, the force’s programme for the safety of senior citizens, in Golf Green.

TOI on Sunday reported on the death of Balasubramanium Srinivasan (81), who used to work in a Dalhousie accountancy firm and started living in the WIBM 3/6 apartment several decades ago. . His wife, who died a few years ago, locals said, worked at IOCL. Srinivasan’s son lives on Rashbehari Avenue and his daughter abroad. The neighbours claimed Srinivasan was ailing and that Manoj Paswan, who works in the building, recounted meeting him a week ago, when he had seen that his legs were swollen.

Thespian Bivas Chakraborty, who lives on the floor above Srinivasan, said, “I had known him for several years. His daughter and my daughter were classmates. His daughter was married nearly a decade ago and lived in the US and Chennai. His son lives in south Kolkata. A widower, Srinivasan was an affable person. I last saw him 10-12 days ago. He wasn’t well but I thought it was due to his advanced age. These days, he kept mostly to himself.”

Most of the population in Golf Green, who set up home in the green neighbourhood in the 70s, have aged. A majority of them live alone as their children live either in another part of the country or abroad. Chakraborty said, “This is not the first time that such an incident happened in our building. There was another similar mishap in an apartment right below Srinivasan’s flat. In that case, we could luckily inform the son who stayed abroad. He flew in immediately.” Majumdar, the resident body’s president, said, “This is precisely the problem we are trying best to address. In cases of emergency, the children are more often than not unable to reach immediately. We will try to get them admitted to a government facility, till their children can arrive and handle the crisis.”

Santana Sarkar, an elderly resident herself, said, “With age-related ailments, many people here are now confined to their homes. With interactions reducing, no way we can know whether someone needs any help or not.” Gautam Biswas, another resident, said, “Many people here live alone and during emergencies, they can’t even call their relatives or neighbours. This is a very helpless situation for many.”

Title: State reports its first swine flu death of 2020
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Jaipur: A 22-year-old student, resident of Mundawar in Alwar district, succumbed to swine flu on Friday at a private hospital in Jaipur during treatment. It was the first swine flu death of the current year.

“He was preparing for competitive exams at a coaching institute in Jaipur. He might have got infected in Jaipur as he did not come to Alwar for quite some time,” said Dr OP Meena, chief medical health officer, Alwar.

Dr Meena on Sunday said that the student died two days ago while undergoing treatment at a private hospital. “He got admitted to the hospital after his condition become critical,” he said.

Swine flu is rearing its ugly head in the state, especially in Jaipur. Till February 20 from January 1, the state has reported 24 swine flu cases. However, in comparison to corresponding period last year, the cases in 2020 so far are negligible. According to the health department report, last year in the first 51 days, 51 people had died of the disease, while 3,692 were tested positive for swine flu.

This year, most of the cases have been reported from Jaipur. According to a health department report, 16 persons have already tested positive for the disease in Jaipur. However, doctors are alert on swine flu as they have tested 656 patients with symptoms for swine flu. Among them, 639 persons tested negative for the disease.

Jodhpur and Ajmer reported two cases each of swine flu this year, while Tonk, Alwar, Kota and Udaipur reported one case each in the first 51 days of the new year.

Title: ‘Govt should allow peaceful protests’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Vijayawada: The Indian Association of Lawyers on Sunday condemned state governments which are taking action against people who were criticising them.

The 10th national conference of IAL held in Vijayawada was attended by eminent lawyers from across the country. It said governments should not suppress peaceful agitations over Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Speaking to reporters on Sunday, IAL president Rajinder Singh Cheema said protests over the contentious CAA and NPR and NRC were peaceful and the governments should respect people’s rights to voice their opinion. It is the duty of the state to explain and convince the people as any enactment of law should be in the interest of people, he said.

The IAL also said judges, advocates and law students should work together to safeguard the Constitution and to guarantee the fundamental rights of citizens. The IAL has decided to provide stipend, financial assistance and health insurance to law students.

IAL also called up on all like-minded people to work with them for economic equality in society.

Asked about uncertainty over the shifting of the high court to Kurnool, Cheema said the issue was local and IAL would take a view on the issue at an appropriate time. IAL state general secretary Chalasani Ajay Kumar and national secretary Bommagani Prabhakar also participated in the interaction with media.

Title: Kathgodam railway station to get memorial for state war heroes
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

NAINITAL: The Kathgodam railway station is all set to become the first railway station in the state to have a memorial for war heroes hailing from Uttarakhand.

Railway officials said that the station would have sections dedicated to soldiers who have lost their lives while defending the country. “The memorial will depict soldiers from the state and will therefore be a tribute to them. The work will start soon and is likely to be completed by March. We are planning to display information about 350 soldiers from Uttarakhand,” said an official.

According to the official, the memorial would have busts and display boards about various soldiers including Gajendra Singh Bisht , Bahadur Singh Bohra and Mohan Nath Goswami.

“We had asked for a list of martyred soldiers from the state. On receiving the list, we have started our preparations and the aim to finish the memorial by March,” he added.

Bisht was an NSG commando who lost his life while fighting terrorists during the 2008 Mumbai attack. Bohra was posted in Kashmir where he was killed by terrorists. However, before being killed, he had gunned down five ultras. Similarly, Goswami was also posted in the Kashmir valley where he killed 10 terrorists. He was later killed by terrorists while he was trying to save two of his men.

Title: SC/ST employees held protest demanding reservation in promotion
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: State government employees, from Scheduled Caste (SC) and Scheduled Tribe (ST) communities, staged protest at all district headquarters in support of their demand of reservation in promotion.

Employees under the banner of SC/ST Employees Federation submitted memorandums addressed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat, to the district officials.

The protesting employees threatened to intensify their stir if the state government fails to fulfill their demands — reservation in promotion being the primary one.

Karan Ram, president of the federation, told TOI that the employees have been forced to go on agitation after state government failed to give them any assurance regarding their demands. He added that in the next phase of the agitation, a national-level meet of SC/ST employees will be held in Dehradun in the first week of March on the issue of reservation in promotion.

“The aim of the proposed meet would be to take up this issue at a national level and fight for it with a united force,” said Ram.

Title: Mega dog show on February 29
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Guntur: Guntur Kennel Club (GKC) is organising a mega dog show in Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan on February 29.

Speaking to media here on Sunday, Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan secretary P Ramachandra Raju said, participants have to pay an entry fee of Rs 500 to bring their dogs to the show and participate in the competition. He said applications would be accepted till February 26. “We are making elaborate arrangements for the big show. We appeal to all pet lovers to allow their pets to participate in the show,” said Raju.

He said there would be breed-wise competitions for the dogs and winners would be awarded with championship trophies and there would be an overall champion in the competition.

“We are making arrangements to set up separate stalls for pet needs and food courts for the participants at the venue,” said Raju.

Title: Dehradun: Now, separate unit to collect information about active criminals
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Represenrtative Image

DEHRADUN: Police have set up a criminal intelligence unit (CIU) at the district level on Sunday to collect information and keep a tab on activities of criminals.

According to senior superintendent of police Arun Mohan Joshi, the CIU would obtain intelligence about activities of criminals active in and around the district, and take necessary steps to prevent crime. He said, “CIU will collect intelligence and keep a tab on the activities of criminals. This information will be shared with the officials concerned so that necessary action is taken on time.”

Till now, the district police only had a special operations group (SOG) to crack criminal cases but there was no specialised unit to monitor the activities of criminals.

Title: Barmer youth not sodomised: Report
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

JAISALMER: The preliminary medical report received by Barmer police on Sunday revealed that the Barmer youth was not sodomised with an iron rod.

Though the sonography report was yet to be received, prima facie no inhuman act with the victim has come to light. However, the medical test was done more than 20 days after the incident happened.

Revenue minister Harish Chaudhary and Barmer MLA Mewaram Jain on Sunday spoke to the victim and his brother at Barmer rural police station. The victim reiterated what had been mentioned in the FIR and demanded justice.

Victim’s brother had told police that his sibling kept quiet about the attack on him on January 29 until someone shared a video clip purportedly showing two men attacking him repeatedly and later using a rod to sodomise him.

However, revenue minister Harish Chaudhary assured the victim that the state government will ensure impartial probe in the matter. Chaudhary also met Jodhpur IG Navjyoti Gogoi and IG human rights Vipin Kumar Pandey.

Chaudhary said the incidents in Barmer and Nagaur are very disappointing. He said he met the Dalit family at Nagaur and took information of the entire incident. The victim was satisfied with the kind of action the government and police were taking, he added.

Barmer SP Sharad Choudhary said the medical report of the victim has been received and prima facie there has been no inhuman act.

The SP, however, said there are marks on shoulder and back of the victim.

Title: Chennai: 21-storey building, skywalk part of Broadway bus terminus plan
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

MAKING SPACE: The 21-storey building would provide parking space for around 2,000 cars and 2,600 two-wheelers

CHENNAI: Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC) is working on a project to develop Broadway bus terminus as a hub that connects public transport by road, metro rail and suburban rail. The civic body has submitted a detailed proposal to the Tamil Nadu Infrastructure Development Board (TNIDB) for a ₹900-crore project to transform the terminus with demarcated space for bus bays, a multi-storey parking complex, commercial space and rail connectivity.

Broadway is close to Chennai Beach suburban station, High Court metro station as well as Fort suburban station, which is likely to emerge as a terminal for MRTS once it is handed over to Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL). The proposal includes a skywalk to link the railway stations to the bus terminus.

At the centre of the planned terminal is a 21-storey building that would provide parking space for around 2,000 cars and 2,600 two-wheelers. “Now, many cars and two-wheelers are parked on roads in and around Parrys and the high court, causing traffic chaos. The parking area in the basement will help avoid haphazard parking on roads,” said a senior official.

Bus bays will be on the lower and upper ground floor, sources said. GCC has proposed 80 to 100 bus bays in the remodelled terminus. The parking plan will be part of the off-street parking project, which is being planned also in other areas like MG Road in Nungambakkam. Parking rates would be ₹50 per hour for four-wheelers and ₹20 per hour for two-wheelers. The complex will offer on lease commercial space across 50,000sqm to 90,000sqm.

GCC officials have lobbed the ball into the court of the state government, which now has to take a call on how this project can be financed. Sources said the current model being discussed is a public-private partnership, which may not work out due to the poor shape of the economy. If the state government finds the internal rate of return sustainable, it may allocate funds.

Title: Rituals mark Malleswara Swamy Rathotsavam fest
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Vijayawada: The chariot festival (Rathotsavam) of Lord Bramaramba Malleswara Swamy was held at Canal Road in the city on Sunday.

The festival started at around 5 pm amid elaborate security arrangements. The organisers had decorated the chariot with fruits and flowers. Festive deities from Sri Durga Malleswara Swamy Varla Devastanams were placed at the chariot after special offerings of vedic scholars.

Devotees pulled the chariot with huge ropes amid chants of ‘Har Har Mahadev’.

Traditional dance forms like Kolatam, Bethala Nruthyam, Bharata Natyam were performed in front of the chariot.

Sri Kanyaka Parameswari Anna Sathram conducted the Rathothsavam in which endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas, Sri Durga Malleswara Swamyvarala Devastanams executive officer Suresh Babu, Vijayawada city police commissioner Ch Dwaraka Tirumala Rao and other participated.

Devotees appreciated the efforts of organisers who has been conducting the Rathothsavam in the city as a part of Shivaratri celebrations.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man, 27, with woman’s voice cons and blackmails 350 men
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 27-year-old engineering graduate who had a voice that sounded like a woman’s used it to lure some 350 men into sex chats and then extorted money from them since 2017 landed in police custody on Sunday after one of his victims finally mustered the courage to register a complaint.

Police identified the man as Vallal Rajkumar Reegan of Panakudi in Tirunelveli district and said he targeted men who downloaded the app Locanto looking for jobs.

Police got on his trail when P Udhayaraj of Maduravoyal approached the Mylapore police station alleging that a woman named Priya was making threatening calls to his mobile phone demanding money.

Udhayaraj told police he was browsing on the net on February 16 and downloaded Locanto looking for job opportunities, when a chat popped up offering sexual services.

A couple of minutes after he began to chat, he received a call from a woman who introduced herself as Priya. She spoke to him in a suggestive manner and offered to provide sexual favours. Udhayaraj said he then received a SMS on his mobile number to pay Rs 100 on a digital wallet platform. Soon after he sent the money, he received a nude picture of a woman. Later ‘Priya’ asked him to pay Rs 1,500 to send a video. He refused to pay and blocked the number, Udhayaraj told the police.

A while later he received a complaint copy on his mobile phone which showed a woman had filed a sexual harassment complaint against him. Later he began to receive calls from different numbers, all of which he blocked.

Police began their investigations with ‘Priya’s’ mobile number, which Udhayaraj shared with them. They found it belonged to a man and initially they thought he was trying to mimic a woman. Police said that when they interrogated Reegan, he told them he had been running the scam since 2017 and that he had cheated more than 350 men.

Reegan used to lodge fake complaints against all the victims giving fake mobile numbers. This was possible since the online complaint system does not ask for an OTP number. He has lodged 150 such complaints in Mylapore police district and a similar number in Kilpauk police districts in the past two years.

“While investigating the each complaint, police ended up dialing the complainant’s number which proved to be mostly fake,” said joint commissioner of police, East, R Sudhakar.

“He had been doing this only to extort money. None of the victims approached the police as they feared their names would get exposed,” Sudhakar added.

Police have registered cases against Reegan under IPC section 384 (punishment for extortion), 506 (i) (criminal intimidation) and the IT Act.

Title: Mayor peeved with garbage pile-up
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Kolkata: KMC mayor Firhad Hakim on Sunday morning visited some places in Tollygunge and Mudiali , where waste and garbage have been dumped by the road. Hakim also inspected a railway land near Tollygunge tram depot and urged the authorities to ensure that the place is kept clean.

On his visit, Hakim was accompanied by MMiC (solid waste management) Debabrata Majumder and other senior conservancy department officials. He was visibly displeased to see a damaged bus abandoned next to the Tollygunge police station and a huge pile of garbage dumped across the road. “In some places, waste and garbage have piled up over a long period, due to negligence of our own staff. The DG conservancy have been apprised on this matter. Besides, there is a plot belonging to the rail authorities, where garbage has piled up. Water has accumulated inside some coconut shell, where mosquito larvae have already started breeding,” Hakim said.

Shortly, the bus was towed away and the waste cleared. The conservancy department officials have been instructed to keep these places clean.

The mayor said central agencies, like the railways, must look into the matter. “KMC alone can’t prevent the spread of dengue. Central agencies will also have to join in the drive. It can’t happen that the railways won’t take care of the plots they operate out of,” Hakim said after the inspection.

Title: Mom-daughter charred to death in Haldia were from N Barrackpore
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Haldia: Using social media and analysing call records, East Midnapore police on Sunday claimed a breakthrough in a February 18 incident in which charred remains of bodies of two women were found in Haldia’s Jhikurkhali. Police said victims Riya Dey (22) and her 40-year-old mother Rama were from New Barrackpore . Two persons arrested — Haldia contractor Saddam Hussain and his aide Sk Manjur — had allegedly set them on fire. A Haldia court remanded the duo in police custody for a fortnight.

Eight missing diaries were tracked state-wide in which two persons were reported missing but this lead hit a dead wall. Police then banked on social media appeals. One person responded saying that his relative and her daughter had left their New Barrackpore home and were unreachable. Police then did a call record analysis of the numbers.

Prima facie, police said, Saddam had an affair with Riya who was pressuring him to marry her. tnn

Title: GFP files complaint against CM via email
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

GFP on Sunday filed a complaint alleging violation of code of conduct by chief minister and some cabinet ministers. They attached copies of advertisement announcing flagging off Carnival Parade by CM and ministers, in the complaint emailed to SEC.

Title: Trump India Visit: 13 routes blocked from 8am till 'Namaste Trump' event is over
Content:
Seven more routes will be closed from 8am on Monday till the Namaste Trump event is completed. (AFP)

Ahmedabad police commissioner Ashish Bhatia on Sunday issued a notification that seven more routes will be closed from 8am on Monday till the Namaste Trump event is completed. With this, total 13 road stretches will remain closed on Monday.For the closed stretch — Airport Circle, Camp Road, Shahibaug Dafnala, Picnic House, Shilalekh Tower Crossroads, Subhash Bridge Circle, Sabarmati Ashram and Vadaj Crematorium — the alternative route will be Sardar Patel Smarak in Shahibaug towards Civil Hospital in Asarva, Ghevar Circle and Namaste Circle in Shahibaug.For another closed stretch — Riverfront East police station to Shahibaug Dafnala — the alternative will be from Riverfront East police station towards Madhavpura and Dadhichi Bridge.The road stretch Prabodh Raval Circle, Subhash Bridge Circle and Shilalekh Tower Crossroads along with a lane between the Central School in Shahibaug and Shilalekh Circle will remain closed during the event. Another stretch between Vadaj Circle to Sabarmati Ashram and Subhash Bridge will be closed. Similarly, a route between Torrent Power House towards Keshavnagar and Subhash Bridge Circle will be closed. The route Ranip Police Line, Sabarmati Central Jail to Subhash Bridge Circle will be closed. People can take Ranip Police Line, Ranip village and Ranip T-Junction road.Earlier on Saturday, it was announced that the stretches between Torrent Power House and Zundal Circle and from Power House Circle to Tapovan Circle will remain blocked. People can take alternative route from Power House Circle towards ONGC Road.A road between Janpath T-junction and Motera T-junction will be closed. The roads between New CG Road, Sangath Mall and Motera stadium, between Koteshwar T-junction and Krupa Residency, between Devarsh Flats and the Club House in Motera and from Bhat Circle to Koteshwar Crossroads will remain closed.The road between Noble T junction, Indira Bridge Circle and Airport Circle will also be closed.

Title: Senior lawyers give Delhi's Shaheen Bagh a miss on the last day of mediation
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The protesters said their stand hadn’t changed and they were not willing to clear the area

NEW DELHI: On the last day of mediation, senior advocates Sanjay Hegde and Sadhana Ramachandran, the interlocutors appointed by Supreme Court, gave Shaheen Bagh a miss leaving thousands of protesters disappointed.

A brief disruption took place on Sunday when a crowd gathered on the other side of the barricades to protest against the blockage of the road since 71 days now.

The protesters said their stand hadn’t changed much since the first day and they were not willing to clear the area.

Many speakers from across the country gathered at Shaheen Bagh and heaped praises on the protesters for their perseverance, expressing hope that Supreme Court would listen to them on Monday. A few protesters, however, were apprehensive of the government’s intention, saying such protests should come up in each corner of the country.

The crowd cheered every time something interesting was spoken by those on the dais. Jamal Khan, a speaker, said, “Hum desh bachane nikle hain, aao hamare saath chalo (We’ve come out to save our country, come with us).” The women there replied with cheers of “Inquilab Zindabad”.

Another speaker, Urza, said, “We have spent 71 days here. Now they want us to vacate the area for a few people who find it inconvenient to cross the stretch. This is a movement all of us have created for all those alive and for all those who’ll ever live. If the commuters, who are saying what we are doing is wrong, are educated about why exactly we are here, they will stand by us.”

Meanwhile, the troubled residents of Sarita Vihar and Jasola also began a protest demanding opening of the roads. Raising slogans like “Save the Constitution”, “Respect the Constitution”, “Empty Our Roads”, and Vande Mataram, they said they were not opposed to the cause of the Shaheen Bagh protesters, but demanded immediate opening of the roads for restoring normalcy in their daily commute.

Title: Video goes viral: Man held for assault on migrant worker
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: For six years, Kerala was like a home to Goutam Mondal, a 25-year-old construction labourer hailing from Malda in West Bengal. The state gave him an opportunity to earn a decent living and support his family. But on Saturday, one incident changed his perception at least for a night with him on the verge of packing his bags to return home. He was publicly harassed, both physically and verbally, by a man at Vizhinjam who even went on to question his identity and citizenship.

However, by next day morning, Mondal got to see the righteous side of the citizens of the state with many of them expressing solidarity with him, both in person and through the social media. As the night passed, a video of the incident went viral on social media prompting police to register a case. By Sunday afternoon, police tracked down and arrested the accused –– a 47-year-old autorickshaw driver named Suresh Kumar alias Kadala Suresh of Mukkola.

The incident happened at Mukkola near Vizhinjam around 9.30pm on Saturday. According to witnesses, Kumar’s rickshaw hit Mondal while the former was trying to park his vehicle, driving in reverse gear. Mondal was stepping into a mobile phone recharge shop beside the road when he was hit by the rickshaw.

“When Mondal questioned his rash and negligent driving style, the accused slapped him on his face and started verbally abusing him,” said Vizhinjam SHO S B Praveen.

However, an onlooker recorded the episode on his mobile phone and shared it on WhatsApp groups. The video that went viral within half-an-hour, reached the police too. Soon, a probe was launched. Though Kumar tried to flee, police tracked him down and arrested him by Sunday afternoon.

In the video, Kumar can be seen demanding Mondal’s ID proof documents. He even snatched them when Mondal took them out. However, he returned them before leaving the scene.

He was charged with relevant sections of attempt to murder, criminal intimidation, using obscene language, causing hurt and wrongful restraint. He was produced before a court and remanded in judicial custody.

Police said that Kumar had another case pending in the station. It pertained to a similar assault on a 22-year-old youth who worked in a mobile phone shop at Mukkola. The incident happened inside the shop. Though a complaint was filed on the same day, police had failed to take any action.

Residents in the area said that the accused was a substance addict and had even undergone a rehabilitation programme.

Meanwhile, Mondal was overwhelmed by the support he received. He admitted that he planned on booking a rail ticket back to Bengal in the morning itself, after he faced the harassment.

“Everywhere there will be at least one person like him (the accused), who are trouble makers,” said Goutam in broken Malayalam, adding that he does not hold any ill-will towards the people here for the actions of one man. Mondal currently resides in a labourers’ camp at Mukkola.

Title: Piduguralla market yard gets its first woman chair from minority community
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Piduguralla: In a first, a woman from the minority community has been named as agriculture market yard chairperson in Piduguralla in Gurazala constituency. The state government appointed Shaik Chand Bi as agriculture market committee chairperson.

Interestingly, Chand Bi’s husband and local YSRC activist Gafar was made vice-chairman of the market committee. They are the first couple to head a governing board of an agriculture market committee in the state. Piduguralla market committee is one of the largest market places in the district after Guntur and Duggirala market yards.

Local legislator Kasu Mahesh Reddy took the bold decision to appoint the couple as market yard chairperson and vice-chairman as he promised to give the minority community a prominent share in the nominated posts before the elections. The move is likely to help YSRC consolidate its footprint among the locally-dominant minority community. Interestingly, Mahesh Reddy played a key role even when his father Krishna Reddy appointed a minority leader Jilani as Narasaraopet market committee in the past.

Sources said Piduguralla market committee, set up about four decades ago, had been in the hands of upper-caste dominant groups in the constituency. “

It is our promise to give minorities a respectful position in all the government nominated posts as they are the backbone of our government,” said Mahesh Reddy.

He, however, explained that all the communities would get their due under the YSRC rule. He said they would take everyone along with them as support of all sections is crucial for the development of the constituency.

Responding to the appointment, market yard vice-chairman Gafar said that the minorities would unitedly work for the party’s victory in the coming local bodies’ elections. “We are happy to know that we are the first couple to head the market committee,” said Gafar. He said that TDP had humiliated them after getting their votes polled in several elections in the past.

Title: ‘Goa CM flagged off Carnival parade, poll code violated’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

PANAJI: Congress said it will file a complaint with the state commission for code of conduct violations after the Carnival parades at Panaji and Margao were flagged off by politicians.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant flagged off Saturday’s parade in Panaji in violation of the poll code for the zilla panchayat elections that came into force on Friday, general secretary Goa Pradesh Congress Committee Amarnath Panjikar said on Sunday.

The Margao parade on Sunday was flagged off by tourism minister Manohar Ajagaonkar in the presence of deputy chief minister Chandrakant Kavalekar, he said.

Panjikar said the SEC had written to the tourism department stating that there was no objection to celebrating Carnival. “However, no political functionary should inaugurate, close the function or deliver speeches throughout the event,” SEC had stated.

Title: Hailstorm, rainfall in some parts of eastern Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image



JAIPUR: Hailstorm and rainfall were recorded in some parts of eastern Rajasthan on Sunday which brought the mercury down.

Met officials, however, said the weather will be mainly clear sky in most parts of the state from Monday with no possibility of rainfall or squall. Sikar remained the coldest in the state with 9.5 ℃.

Attributing the climatic change, especially the cloudy conditions in some parts of the state, to active upper air cyclonic circulation and western disturbances, Jaipur Met office said majority of the places in the state would witness dry weather except some parts in the eastern Rajasthan where there is a possibility of rainfall, squall and hail storm in the next couple of days.

People in Jaipur woke up amidst cloudy conditions, though no rainfall was recorded. There was, however, some rain on the outskirts including Shahpura, Bassi and Kothputli. Jaipur recorded a minimum temperature of 15.6℃, almost 3°C above normal. It was followed by a comparatively chilly afternoon with a maximum temperature of 24.5 ℃. Mild fog and mist was witnessed on the highways near Jaipur which affected road traffic on Jaipur-Delhi, Jaipur-Agra and Jaipur-Bikaner.

Hailstorm and rainfall was also recorded at some of the districts including Alwar, Bharatpur, Dholpur and Sawai Madhopur districts.

Sikar was followed by Pilani where a minimum temperature of 12.1 ℃ was recorded, Churu 12.8, Sriganganagar 13.2, Kota 13.8, Phalodi 14.2, Jaisalmer 14.3 and Jodhpur and Ajmer 15℃ each.

In its forecast, Jaipur Met office said weather would mainly remain dry in the state except some parts in the eastern Rajasthan in the next 24 hours.

Title: Nine vehicles, eatery set on fire in Delhi’s Karawal Nagar clash
Content:
The mob did not allow the fire trucks to move till the fire had completely gutted the vehicles

NEW DELHI: Fresh clashes erupted in northeast Delhi’s Karawal Nagar late on Sunday when miscreants set fire to at least nine vehicles and a roadside eatery. Though police managed to control the violence, the mob didn’t allow the fire tenders to move in till the vehicles were completely gutted. The mob also pelted stones at the police teams trying to disperse them.Police said the violence broke out around 9.45pm when a 60-strong mob went on a rampage on Dayalpur Road, which is about 6km from the Maujpur protest site. The miscreants also stoned the windows of some residential buildings along the way.The two tenders sent by the fire department were stopped by the protesters nearly a kilometre away. The mob threatened to set them on fire too. The fire teams reached the spot after two hours under police protection.The situation remained tense till late at night as the protesters kept pelting stones at police. Cops had to lathi-charge the miscreants and use tear gas .Later, senior officers reached the spot and a flag march was conducted. The security personnel asked locals to go back to their houses. A few policemen were injured and some private vehicles parked on the roadside were also damaged by the stone-pelters. A case of rioting, arson, causing damage to property has been registered.Police said the rampage was captured on video by some mediapersons. They will use the footage to identify the miscreants.In Video: 2 metro stations close as violence erupts during anti-CAA protests

Title: Pro-capital protesters lay siege to MP’s convoy
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Amaravati: Tension prevailed at Lemallle in Tadikonda when people agitating to retain Amaravati as the capital tried to attack Bapatla MP Nandigam Suresh on Sunday.

The pro-capital city activists threw chilli powder on gunmen and aides of the MP after forcing the driver to stop the vehicle. The incident took place when Suresh was on his way to Guntur after attending Rathotsavam at Amaralingeswara Swamy temple in Amaravati.

The activists surrounded the MP’s vehicle and raised slogans in favour of Amaravati as the capital and asked the MP to support their cause.

Sensing trouble, the gunman and other aides came down from the vehicle and tried to protect the MP. Women activists pushed the MP’s aides away and attempted to attack the MP.

Soon, police reached the spot and rescued the MP. Suresh said that it was the handiwork of TDP. “TDP has been hatching a conspiracy against our government by creating law and order trouble. They should feel ashamed of using women as cover,” said Suresh.

He said TDP was trying to vitiate the atmosphere. He said the farmers should be aware of TDP’s dirty politics. Fisheries minister Mopidevi Venkata Ramana condemned the attack on Suresh.

In another incident, a farmer, Hanumantha Rao, was injured when he accidentally went under Suresh’s vehicle in Amaravati village while trying to protest. He was taken to hospital and was discharged after first-aid.

Title: Gujarat gains second spot in MHRD school performance index
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In a latest school performance grading by the Union ministry of human resources development (MHRD) Gujarat has been ranked second in the country.Gujarat has overtaken Kerala and moved from third rank to second, in the Performance Grading Index (PGI) released recently by the MHRD. The Union territory of Chandigarh occupies the first place, according to the report. The top three states are followed by Maharashtra and Delhi.Gujarat has improved on several counts and scored high in governance processes and equity, said an official in the state education department.“We are focusing on improving learning outcomes, quality of education and on ensuring best infrastructure facilities in the coming months. We aim to build a robust school transportation system for better access,” the official added.The survey exercise examined 70 parameters that were used for the PGI 2017-18. The states were marked on a scale of 1,000. Chandigarh, Gujarat and Kerala scored more that 850 points.The report stated that the exercise is to pinpoint gaps and accordingly prioritize areas for intervention to ensure that the school education system sees improvement. The summary report was published in January while the detailed report will be available in April. The report further states that the MHRD has proposed a performance-based grant to the states and Union Territories based on the Performance Grading Index. (PGI).In the domain relating to governance and management the top score of 279 was that of Gujarat. This was 78% of the maximum points. Governance and management is of the highest importance as insights help in critical structural monitoring from the attendance of teachers to ensuring a transparent recruitment of teachers and principals.The report states that the shortage of teachers, principals and administrative staff, lack of regular supervision and inspection, inadequate training of the teachers, issues with timely availability of finances are factors plaguing the education system. The second important domain is infrastructure and facilities which measures all the above factors. Gujarat when its comes to infrastructure has scored just 116, which was less than Chandigarh (136) and Kerala (123).

Title: Delay in release of funds hits AMRUT project
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

T’puram: As water crisis is becoming severe, the Kerala water authority (KWA) is pinning hopes on the 75mld water treatment plant at Aruvikkara. However, the delay in release of funds is causing a delay in commissioning of the plant.

Not just the 75mld treatment plant, but various projects under Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (AMRUT) have been delayed. This is due to the delay in releasing funds from the city corporation.

KWA sources said that the 75mld treatment plant was the only solution to the water crisis. “It was expected to be completed in March. Now, the crucial works including purchase of machines are stuck due to delay in release of around Rs 15 crore. Commissioning of the plant is likely to happen only by July,” sources said.

The AMRUT fund is shared by Centre, state government and local bodies on 50:30:20 basis. Sources said that while Central funds are already released, the delay happened from the part of the city corporation. When contacted, a senior official of city corporation said that the delay happened as they were waiting for corporation council to give permission to release the fund. “Since it was a huge amount of around Rs 18 crore for various AMRUT works, the consent of council has to be taken. Considering the urgency of work, now we have asked for sanction of mayor. Funds could be released in a couple of days,” a corporation official said.

Due to delay in release of funds, other AMRUT works, including construction a 5mld sewage treatment plant, too have slowed down. Most works will miss the March deadline.

“The construction of the 75mld treatment plant is likely to be completed only by July. Earlier, the KWA used to release 10% funds as advance amount for AMRUT projects. However, now there is no such measures from the part of KWA,” sources said.

With the commissioning of the 75mld treatment plant at Aruvikkara, KWA will be able to tackle the water crisis. Currently, the water authority is releasing around 280mld water per day, which is insufficient. Elevated areas in the city often experience water shortage.

Title: Munirka building demolition: Removal of debris to take at least a week, say civic officials
Content:
The upper floors of the structure crumbled onto two adjoining buildings

Watch: Tilted building at Delhi's Munirka demolished #MunirkaBuildingDemolition #MunirkaTowerDemolition https://t.co/54T7i6IQ9y — TOI Delhi (@TOIDelhi) 1582439261000

NEW DELHI: After four days of efforts, South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC), along with police and Delhi Disaster Management Authority, on Sunday finally managed to raze a tilted six-storey building in south Delhi’s Munirka . The building, located on Baba Gangnath Marg, had started tilting last Thursday.“It was impossible to bring down the 10-feet-wide structure manually as it had tilted a lot towards other buildings. We were afraid of sending labourers inside as the building could have collapsed any time. We even tried to make it fall on the main road,” said a senior official overseeing the operation. He added that a beam on the ground floor was attached to an adjoining house. The beam had to be cut before razing the structure.The ground floor of the building was about 25 feet higher than the road, making it equivalent to an eight-storey structure. “The building was in a rocky area with narrow lanes. We used three hydraulic excavators, one 100-foot crane with pneumatic hammer and gas cutters in the 72-hour operation,” said the official.The people living in the tilted building had been shifted to an anganwadi centre and a temple. Though their relatives and local residents were helping to feed them, the biggest worry for the building’s residents was starting life from scratch as most of their household items were damaged in the demolition.Neetu Devi, a resident of the building, said, “We were asked to leave the building all of a sudden. We did not even get the opportunity to collect our cash and valuable items. Despite repeated requests, the officials didn’t allow me to go back to my house. We have been in the same clothes for the past four days. The studies of my children is getting affected adversely.”When the demolition began, the upper floors (fifth and sixth) crumbled on two adjoining buildings, a double-storey and a six-storey, damaging their top floors. Locals were concerned about the manner in which the corporation had carried out the operation.The civic official said, “We don’t know the extent of damage caused to the other buildings. We later sent labourers to remove the debris.” He added that the portion of the building that collapsed on the adjoining structures will be removed in two days. People will then be allowed to move into their homes.“Removal of debris is likely to take a week after which the neighbouring buildings will be surveyed. No compensation has been demanded by the owners of the other buildings for the damages caused during the operation,” the civic official added.Tears welled up in the eyes of 17-year-old Rohit Kumar when the building was demolished as he couldn’t get a chance to collect his books and admit card for the Board exams beginning February 27. “The officials said they will take a week to remove the debris. How will I study for my English paper that is due on Thursday?” he asked.A senior SDMC official said they were helpless as they couldn’t risk anybody’s life by allowing them to go inside to collect their belongings and household items.

Title: Goa: Manohar Ajgaonkar’s son’s carnival float stirs controversy
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The float by Manohar Ajgaonkar’s son’s night club featured posters of the venture inviting people to attend th... Read More

PANAJI: Tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar had set the tone of the Carnival parade this year by taking a strong stand on various issues related to the annual revelry. From changing the parade route to coming out with strict guidelines regarding tableaux themes, the deputy chief minister even stressed that drinking on roads would not be tolerated. However, a float put up by his son’s night club has courted controversy.

Rules this year stated that products of a sponsoring company should not form the main part of the float, and that the tableau must have a cultural theme. Brands were not allowed to liberally promote their products at this year’s float parade in Panaji .

Going against these rules, the float by Ajgaonkar’s son’s night club featured posters promoting the commercial venture pasted in front of and around the vehicle inviting people to attend the club’s Carnival dance party, complete with promotions and timings.

Tourism minister maintained that if there was any violation of the rules, it was the duty of the screening committee of the Panaji Carnival Committee to take action.

“It is true that the night club belongs to my son Privesh which he runs along with a partner. As he was out of station, the manager of the club arranged the float. I am not aware if there was any violation or not but my stand is clear – whoever violated the rules, action should have been taken by the screening committee,” Ajgaonkar told TOI.

Participants that had pre-registered were briefed prior to the Carnival. On Saturday, the Panaji Carnival Committee’s screening team started scrutinising the floats from 1pm onwards to ensure that spot registrations abide by rules as well. But this tableau made its way into the parade.

CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues had said, “Branding can be done, but direct cutouts of products should not be projected in front of, back, or on top of the float. This is not a product display festival,” Rodrigues said, “Brands can only feature their logo or banner on the sides of the floats.” However, the float in question had a large owl mounted on the top of the float. The owl is the mascot of the night club.

However, mayor Uday Madkaikar softened his stand on the CCP rules. He said, “We never said commercial floats were not permitted. From what I know, there was no problem with any of the floats.”

Title: NMC removes encroachments from Don Bosco road
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The official said several food vendors used to set up stalls along the stretch, especially during the evening ... Read More

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has finally removed encroachments near Don Bosco , off College Road, after an order from the Bombay High court on Thursday.

“Encroachments have been removed from the Don Bosco road , which has five educational institutes, including a hostel, along it,” a senior official from the municipal corporation said.

The official said several food vendors used to set up stalls along the stretch, especially during the evening hours.

Residents had complained about the nuisance being caused by the vendors. The NMC action followed directions of the high court, which asked municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game to remove all encroachments from the area within a week.

The bench comprising Justice S Kathawala and Justice Milind Jadhav directed Game to clear the stalls. Game was also ordered to be present in front of the bench because of delays in action.

The NMC commissioner — in an affidavit before the court — had said the NMC had finalized hawking zones based on norms set by the civic administration’s general body. He said Don Bosco road was not part of the resolution. But vendors continued to park food vans in the area.

During a hearing on February 17, the NMC had sought more time to remove encroachments from the road. But the court asked the commissioner to be present in person for the hearing. Authorities added they would ensure food vendors do not return to the road.
