Title: Fake tribal website set up, offence registered in Nashik
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The cybercrime police in the city have registered an offence against an unidentified person for setting up a fake website — purportedly of the Tribal Development Commissionerate in Nashik — and placing recruitment advertisement on the same to cheat people.

On a complaint of a senior official from the Tribal Development Commissionerate, the cybercrime police have booked the unidentified person under sections 468 (forgery), 471 (using a forged document or electronic record as genuine) and other sections of the IPC and the Information Technology Act.

Devraj Borse, the senior PI of the cybercrime police station, said some unidentified person had set up the fake website online. The aim was to place advertisements on the website and make people pay money as examination fee for the posts. The police said the officials of the tribal commissionerate only came across the fake website on February 18. He said the site could have been online from even before that.

On the website — https://mahatribal.webs.com — the fraudster had advertised for filling the posts of junior engineer, civil engineer assistant, supervisor, lab assistant, peon etc. in places like Mumbai, Pune, Nashik, Jalgaon. The complainant also found that the examination fee mentioned on the website was Rs 500 for the general category and Rs 350 for the reserved categories.

The police said the website had a link for filling up the application form and a separate link for exam fee payment.

The complainant said on the website, the name and logo of the department were fake. He clarified that the commissionerate had not advertised for any post.

Borse said they are investigating the case. The website would also be removed from the internet. So far, no one has approached the police or the cybercrime police station to register a complaint saying that they have been cheated through the website.

Police officials said it is possible that since the amount of the examination fee is less, people have come forward to lodge complaints. However, the fraudster could have collected a huge amount of money if many people have fallen for the scam.

Title: Six new gecko species found in Western Ghats
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Research shows that the geckos are very habitat specific

PUNE: Scientists have found six new species of the endemic genus of Dravidogecko in the Western Ghats .

The six new species have been named Dravidogecko septentrionalis, D janakiae (in honour of Janaki Ammal, a botanist from Kerala), D tholpalli, D meghamalaiensis, D douglasadamsi (in honour of British author and satirist, Douglas Noel Adams) and D smithi (in honour of British herpetologist Malcolm Arthur Smith).

These geckos are nocturnal, exceptionally good climbers and prefer setting up their homes in tree trunks and abandoned structures. The findings were recently published in the international taxonomic journal Zootaxa.

Speaking to TOI, Pune-based Varad Giri, one of the team members, said the discovery was significant. “It is one of the oldest geckos that evolved in India. Around 58 million years ago, this gecko evolved and diversified into various parts of India. Until recently, only one species was known and the genus is endemic to the Western Ghats. This was the Dravidogecko anamallensis.”

Lead researcher R Chaitanya’s investigative expeditions in the Western Ghats led to the discovery that these geckos were very habitat specific and confined to a particular habitat. He collected them and made a close examination of their DNA, looked at their taxonomy and identification characteristics. After thorough investigations, he realised that it is more than one species. Altogether six new species have been described.

Chaitanya, a Bengaluru-based IT engineer turned independent researcher, said, “We started examining this genus in 2015. In 1875, Albert Günther, a British-German herpetologist first described the species in this group, naming it Dravidogecko anamallensis as it was found in the Anaimalai hills.”

After Chaitanya and his team conducted fieldwork in the Western Ghats, they came across the different species. “We’ve been encountering these geckos in various places, not just Anaimalai, for long. So, we realised that this cannot be just one species, because they’re found in so many places in the Western Ghats,” he added. Their study led them to collect geckos from other places in the Western Ghats.

The other team members were Deepak Veerappan, Natural History Museum, London, Aniruddha Datta-Roy, National Institute of Science Education and Research, Bhubaneswar, BHCK Murthy, Zoological Survey of India, Kozhikode and Praveen Karanth from the Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru.

Title: Donald Trump's visit: Khaman, samosa with kadak chai for guests
Content:
Donald Trump and Melania Trump walk to Marine One prior to departure from the South Lawn of the White House in... Read More

AHMEDABAD: As US President Donald Trump arrives in Ahmedabad on Monday, along with his family, he will be served a scrumptious mix of traditional Gujarati and English snacks. Gujarati delicacies including khaman, samosa and kadak chai will be part of the spread laid for the US president, his family and 100 other delegates, over high tea, which will be served during the US president’s visit to the Sabarmati Ashram.“Gujarati delicacies including khaman, samosa made of broccoli and corn, chai and kaju-katli would be part of the high-tea menu. That apart, juice, assorted cookies, fortune cookies and apple pie would also be part of the specially curated menu,” said chef Suresh Khanna, executive chef at Ahmedabad-based Fortune Landmark Hotel.The Gujarat tourism department has approved the menu, Khanna added. Since the temperature in the city has begun getting warm, special care has been taken to avoid use of potato and cottage cheese in the menu.

Title: Trichy: National Research Centre for Banana all set to produce iron-rich, bio-fortified banana
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Dr AK Singh, Deputy Director General (Horticulture Science) ICAR, New Delhi and Director of National Research ... Read More

TRICHY: The wilt disease surfaced in Cavendish group of bananas poses a great threat to the banana production in the country. With no proper interstate quarantine protocols, spread to various places is not very far, Dr A K Singh, deputy director-general (Horticulture Science) ICAR , New Delhi, has said.

“The emergence of wilt disease in Cavendish bananas poses a great threat to the production especially in Bihar, UP and adjoining regions. Being soil-borne, Fusarium wilt TR-4 can spread easily through soil, air and humans. With no proper interstate quarantine protocols, spread to other states is not very far. This is expected to shake the Indian banana industry,” Singh told reporters here on Sunday. He was in the city to attend the second-day event of the four-day international conference on banana – 2020.

The disease has thrown a huge challenge to researchers working on bananas and also the quarantine officials to thwart the spread. TR-4 has not only affected Grand Nain but has the capacity to eradicate the entire banana industry in our country as it can infect the entire cultivated banana except for a few indigenous varieties, he cautioned.

National Research Centre for Banana (NRCB), Trichy and Queensland University of Technology, Tamil Nadu Agriculture University (TNAU) have joined hands to produce bio-fortified bananas, which are rich in beta-carotene and iron through transgenic approach, he said.

He also stressed the need to produce 40 million tonnes of bananas by 2030 to cater to 130 crore people in the country against the present production of 29.3 million tonnes.

“Banana is being cultivated in a very smaller area, but played a big role, and in future, it will play a bigger role. The germplasm of banana, which is being maintained in the field gene bank of NRCB, is Asia’s largest collection. Most of these wild banana varieties possess resistance to many biotic stresses. The centre coming out with a few novel banana varieties suitable to grow in different states is a milestone in banana R and D. Though we lead in the production of bananas, the crop is more prone to the vagaries of abiotic stresses and faces threats from many biotic factors such as pest and diseases. We hope the ongoing conference will bring out valuable suggestions for the improvement of the bananas,” he said.

Export of banana from India is very meagre, that is 0.3% and there is an ample scope to increase the export to the Middle East countries and also European markets. The technologies developed by the NRCB, especially the shipping protocol, which has witnessed a quantum jump in the export of Nendran to Middle East countries, a value worth several crores, he said. NRCB, Trichy director S Uma and senior scientists were also present.

Title: Schools to educate students on value of tolerance
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: As the celebrations of 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi will culminate in October 2020, schools will be holding a number of programmes during the new academic year from June to October, including lessons on ‘values of tolerance and democracy’.

Students will carry out programmes for taking care of trees and animals in the neighbourhood as part of a kindness initiative and will also participate in shramdaan to learn dignity of labour.

The celebrations were to take place over two years from October 2018 to October 2020. Schools have now been given month-wise themes, based on which the programmes are to be held.

Director of education Vandana Rao has asked schools to hold a Gandhi Olympiad and have suggested activities like writing 150 quotes of Mahatma Gandhi, 150 days of community service over one year by schools, planting 150 trees, cycling for 150kms, doing 150 acts of kindness, saving 150 litres of water, mass jogging with 150 schools in the district, among others.

When the schools reopen after the summer vacations, they have been told to carry out activities through the month of June based on ‘love and kindness to animals, plants and birds’. It has been suggested that students can maintain the school garden and provide food to animals and birds in their neighbourhood and homes.

In July, students will learn the ‘ value of tolerance and democracy’, where teachers will deliver lectures on fundamental rights and duties of citizens. It has been recommended that a bal sansaad (kids’ parliament) be organised.

While August will be the month to learn dignity of labour through shramdaan, September will see focus on nature conservation. Tree plantation, water conservation, waste disposal and sensitisation on climate change are the suggested activities.

Title: Uproar over illegal filling of Guirim comunidade fields
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

SALIGAO: The issue of illegal filling up of field belonging to the Guirim comunidade was hotly debated at the Guirim gram sabha held on Sunday. Deputy sarpanch Sunny Nanodkar chaired the meeting.

At the start, the panchayat secretary read out the minutes of the previous gram sabha and the budget allocation for 2020-21 under which the panchayat has been allocated nearly Rs 14.9 lakh under the 14th Finance Commission.

Later, an argument broke out between deputy sarpanch Sunny Nanodkar and Guirim comunidade attorney Victor Zuzarte over the illegal filling up of fields in the village. Zuzarte accused the panchayat of issuing NOCs for dumping. Refuting the charges, Nanodkar said it was the comunidade itself which was permitting this. After much deliberation, a resolution was adopted that no illegal filling will be permitted in the fields.

The issue of rising cases of accident due to movement of heavy vehicles on internal roads, loaded with construction material for highway expansion work, also came up for discussion. Pointing to a recent incident where one such truck had collided with an oncoming vehicle, locals demanded that action be taken. A resolution was adopted not to allow these trucks to pass through the village. Nanodkar said the panchayat would send these resolutions to the transport department and to the RTO.

One villager, Phondu Naik , demanded that the panchayat preserve the water bodies of the village. Nanodkar agreed to this and a resolution was passed.

Title: No smart cities plans talk about sports
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Trichy: Trichy City Corporation is yet to realize the importance of developing sports infrastructure in the city, the population of which has cruised past 10 lakh as on 2020. While the civic body spends more than Rs 900 crore through the smart cities mission under various developmental heads, it has spent nothing exclusively for establishing new stadiums and sports complexes or developing the existing playgrounds.

The 25 smart cities mission proposals suggested by the corporation mostly focus on beautification of the city neighbourhoods, developing green spaces, and solid waste management. Sports infrastructure development was completely ignored by the civic body in the proposals. The civic body in its 25 years of existance has failed to establish a dedicated sports complex for sports enthusiasts in the city. The only exception is the Anna Sports stadium at Khajamalai.

A playground to train students in outdoor games at an affordable price is still a dream for many parents. In the absence of stadiums, sports associations depend on the grounds and courts on city college campuses to host state and national level sports tournaments.

"An integrated sports complex with space for various sports activities will nurture local talents. Such a facility will prevent players from migrating to other cities for achieving their goals," said C Rengaraju, secretary, Tiruchirappalli District Football Association (TDFA). Recently, a national tennis tournament was conducted at a couple of private clubs here as the existing tennis courts at Anna Stadium were inadequate.

However, the smart city projects never had plans to set up playgrounds to train talents from economically backward families. "Like the cricket ground inaugurated in Salem recently, Trichy can also have one. To encourage young talents and train them, Trichy desperately needs a new sports complex," Scorer R Kannan, a sports enthusiast, said. Even as the corporation and the district administration have lands on the Madurai Road and Pudukkottai Road, they do nothing on setting up any kind of sports infrastructure.

"Drainage and water supply projects are our priorities in utilizing the smart cities mission fund. There are no immediate plans to focus on sports infrastructure development," a senior official with Trichy City Corporation said. A plan to establish a swimming pool near Thennur is also uncertain.

Title: Naveen set to be re-elected as BJD chief for eighth time
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik is set to be re-elected as the BJD president for the record eighth time. He filed his nomination papers at the party headquarters here on Sunday.

Given that he is the only leader to have filed his papers for the post, Naveen’s re-election as the BJD chief is a foregone conclusion.

Accompanied by senior party leaders, Naveen filed the nomination papers before the party’s state returning officer Pratap Keshari Deb. Altogether 10 leaders, including two general secretaries of the headquarters and the organization, leaders from different regions and SC/ST communities signed as proposers on Naveen’s nomination form.

Eighty other leaders also filed their nominations for election to the state executive committee, which is the apex decision-making body of BJD.

“We are in the last phase of the organizational polls. The nomination papers for the post of party president and for the state executive committee will be scrutinized on Monday. The leaders can also withdraw their nomination papers on Tuesday. The results will be announced in the meeting of the newly-formed state council on February 26,” Deb told reporters after the nomination process.

After his re-election as the party president for the eighth time, Naveen is also scheduled to address the party workers at the BJD headquarters on February 26. With the election to the post of BJD president, the party’s organizational poll process, which had started in December will be concluded.

“Our party president has always emphasized on maintaining democracy within the party. Accordingly, the organizational election was held from the level of ward to the state president in a democratic manner,” BJD Rajya Sabha member Amar Patnaik said.

Endorsing Naveen’s leadership, senior BJD leader Bhartruhari Mahtab said, “Under Naveen babu’s leadership, our party has won five assembly elections. People of Odisha have high hopes from his leadership. We all support his re-election.”

Naveen has been leading the party since its inception on December 26, 1997. He has also led the party to a record five-term victory in the recent assembly election.

After his re-election, the ruling party will restructure its organization with the induction of new leaders as vice presidents, general secretaries, secretary and treasurer. Party insiders said the students, youth, women and other frontal organizations will also be restructured soon.

Title: Reis Magos to stop issuing realty licences
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Saligao: The Reis Magos panchayat on Sunday resolved to stop issuing construction licences to new projects.

At the gram sabha held on Sunday, the villagers said the town and country planning department has been putting conditions on the panchayat’s technical clearance orders, stating that the panchayat has to verify the water and electricity requirements of the village before granting construction licences.

The villagers further said the panchayat has been violating the condition since 2009.

The locals said that the influx of migrants and their increasing population is the reason for the inadequate water supply and interrupted electricity in the village.

The meeting, which was held at Reis Magos government school, was chaired by panch member Kedar Naik in the absence of sarpanch Virendra Shirodkar.

The budget allocation for the next financial year could not be placed before the gram sabha owing to various issues raised by the villagers.

Title: Donald Trump Ahmedabad Visit: 12,000 security personnel on ground, IAF to patrol skies in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Security personnel walk past a banner featuring an image of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and U.S. President Do... Read More

AHMEDABAD: With US President Donald Trump’s visit to Sabarmati Ashram confirmed late on Saturday night, the bandobust figures have gone up. Ahmedabad police commissioner, Ashish Bhatia, said that Defence Research and Development Organization (DRDO) has been roped in to check for drones and no one should fly such objects near the route of Trump’s convoy and the Motera stadium. Bhatia added that police have had meetings with residents in areas near the airport and Motera stadium and made them aware of the importance of security for the US president’s visit.

This is the first time in Gujarat that the IAF and the DRDO is being deployed for the security of a state guest, sources said. US secret service agents will also be present for the security of the US president. Police said IAF will man the skies and keep fighter planes ready for any emergency.

The number of police officials and security personnel deployed for the security of US President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi, for their visit to Sabarmati Ashram and the Namaste Trump event has gone up to 12,000 said Bhatia. Police sources added that 600 walkie-talkie sets will be used at the bandobust.

Bhatia said that the stadium can hold 1.08 lakh spectators and appropriate security arrangements, water and parking facilities have been made. A PSI will be present at each parking slot.

Top police officials said that on Sunday an advance security liaison (ASL) was held. Agencies such as the city police, US secret service, DRDO, IAF, SPG and NSG participated in the meeting and discussed the security plans.

Title: ARI experts: No threat to ‘endangered’ grass species
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The grass is used for thatching of roofs by locals before monsoon

PUNE: Scientists from city-based Agharkar Research Institute (ARI) have found a grass species that was declared 'endangered' by the Botanical Survey of India may not be so threatened after all.

Dichanthium jainii, colloquially known as 'kolim' was tagged “Endangered (EN)” in 2001 after a critical threat status assessment was carried out as per IUCN Red List Categories. But upon critical field investigations by ARI researchers, it was found to be utilized by local communities of northern Western Ghats for various purposes like roof thatching. The presence of the species in the region is extensive and thus, it may not be threatened, the researchers said. The study was published in the journal National Academy of Science Letters.

Mandar N Datar, a scientist in ARI, who led the study, said, “The grass is used for roof thatching before the advent of monsoon. It was placed under threatened plant category due to its under-representation in herbarium collections. The categorization of the grass as threatened stems from the fact that there are just a handful number of specimens of Dichanthium jainii, endemic to Sahyadri, northern Western Ghats, deposited in various herbaria of the region.”

He said there are very few specimens of the species in literatures like (apart from its types in western India herbaria) Agharkar Research Institute herbarium (AHMA), Botanical Survey of India, Western Regional Centre (BSI), Shivaji University Herbarium, Kolhapur (SUK) and Blatter herbarium, Mumbai (BLAT), which reinforce its rarity in the wild. “But upon critical investigations, we found that the practice of using and growing Kolim is prevalent in local communities around Mahabaleshwar and it is grown in abundance in northern Western Ghats,” he added.

Ketaki Ghate, founders and managing partner, Oikos for Ecological Services, who was part of the research, said, “This grass is not only conserved by local inhabitants in situ but also planted for domestic use by every household. The paradoxical situation of its threat status, based on herbarium studies, and its extensive extent of occurrence, is a result of overlooking traditional knowledge in taxonomic surveys.”

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation completes 75% survey of existing land use for development plan
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has completed about 75% survey pertaining to the existing land use (ELU) patterns in 11 villages merged in the city limits in 2018.

The ELU survey is a key element in drafting the development plan (DP) for these merged areas, which the PMC started since last year. The draft DP is expected to be ready by next year and sent to the state government for approval.

Civic officials said the ELU survey was a detailed study of how the land has been utilised in the merged villages. “Preliminary observations have pointed to mixed land use since residential and commercial activities have gone up in the merged areas in the last few years. There have been changes in land tiles and the ownership has been fragmented in many areas because of additions in the family over the years,” an official said.

The areas that have been merged in the city are located on the periphery. The residents here have been demanding better civic amenities and planned development.

A population of 3.5 lakh has been added to the city because of the merger.

A senior PMC official said that the ELU survey will continue for another six months. “We are expecting to complete the remaining 25% work by mid-2020,” he added.

The administration has also started demographic, socio-economic and house survey conducted by the city-based Gokhale Institute of Politics and Economics. The survey will help in understanding the housing patterns, population density and social background of the existing population residing in the merged areas.

The official said the civic administration plans to start the proposed land use study after completion of ELU and demographics survey.

“There is a plan to complete all the studies in the next one year. The draft of the DP will be ready by next year,” the official said.

Title: MSU study finds out what makes Gujaratis obese and diabetic!
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Vadodara: If the moment you step on a weighing scale and the meter acts crazy, don’t take the weight on your head. Blame your genes.

A genetic study has found a combination of nucleotide, identified as ‘GGTG’, responsible for obesity amongst Gujaratis. And it may also be responsible for type-2 diabetes, said a team of researchers from M S University’s Department of Biochemistry.

The researchers have detected the presence of this unique set of nucleotides (haplotype) in the adiponectin gene among obese and type-2 diabetic patients in Gujarat.

Nucleotides are the building blocks of DNA and RNA of a human body, explained Prof Rasheedunnisa Begum, who, along with professor A V Ramachandran from Zoology department, has been working on population genetics for more than 10 years now.

“My students had done genotyping of adiponectin gene in 1,000 Gujarati individuals. Of them, 500 were suffering from type-2 diabetes and the other 500 were healthy individuals,” said Begum.

The genotyping revealed that this combination of nucleotide was found to very predominantly prevalent among type-2 diabetes patients who were also obese.

Adiponectin gene synthesizes adiponectin hormone. This hormone is less in people suffering from obesity and type-2 diabetes, the professor said, adding that less hormone levels develop insulin resistance among these individuals which eventually leads to type-2 diabetes.

Research scholars involved in this work with Begum include Sayantani Pramanik Palit, Roma Patel, Shahnawaz Jadeja, Nirali Rathwa and Dr Ankit Mahajan.

The research findings have been published in Scientific Reports, a peer-reviewed reputed scientific journal.

While type-2 diabetes and obesity are a global phenomenon, its prevalence is also based on ethnicity owing primarily to food habits and lifestyle besides the genetic makeup of the ethnic groups to a certain extent.

“Adiponectin gene and its hormone on the DNA within the gene depends on ethnic variation among different populations,” said Begum, who earlier conducted a similar study among Kashmiri individuals and didn’t find any such genetic association.

“This means that GGTG is one of the genetic factors that make Gujaratis prone or at risk of becoming obese and developing type-2 diabetes,” Begum added.

Begum’s earlier collaborative study in Jammu & Kashmir (J&K) was done along with Dr Swarkar Sharma and Prof Manoj K Dhar affiliated to Shri Mata Vaishno Devi University, Katra and Jammu University.

Title: Internal roads more prone to accidents, reveal records
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Highways passing through the city are dangerous, but the city’s interior roads are more accident-prone. Going by the figures available with the city police, more people die on the interior roads than on the state and national highways.

Last year, there were 553 road accidents in the city. Of them, 135 accidents took place on the highways — mainly on Mumbai-Agra and Nashik-Pune highways or other state highways — as many as 418 took place on the city’s internal roads. The accidents on the internal roads also claimed the lives of 119 people as against 58 on the national and state highways.

ACP Mangalsingh Suryawanshi of the city traffic branch attributed the accidents to the driving habits of motorists. “Motorists are usually more careful while driving on the highways than they are while driving on city roads or internal roads. Most of the two-wheeler riders have helmets, but they do not wear them. We often find women keeping their helmets in the dickey of their scooters and men hanging them to their bike handles.”

A week ago, two youngsters were killed in a road accident on an internal road in the Nashik Road area when they were knocked down by a truck.

Many residents said that there is no discipline among motorists or even the general public about the way to drive or park their vehicles on the road.

Mahesh Kasar, an engineer who lives in the Nashik Road area, said, “There are various issues on the internal road. Groups of youngsters stand on the road without any consideration for the heavy movement of vehicles. There are also haphazardly parked cars that occupy half of the road. Then there are pedestrians walking on the carriageway unmindful of the vehicles. Many internal roads also have shops and vegetable markets.”

Title: Pune: Smoke and odour of trash burning irk 1 lakh residents
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Garbage burning has affected the quality of life for residents of Nigdi and Talawade villages in Pimpri Chinchwad city, with locals unable to even open a window or breathe in fresh air.

As many as lakh of residents of Nigdi and Talawade villages in Pimpri Chinchwad city are affected by the smoke and foul odour emanating from rampant garbage burning in the Dehu Road Cantonment Board (DCB) limits, MNS corporator Sachin Chikhale said.

“Around a lakh residents living along the border with cantonment are affected by this garbage burning. Senior citizens, children and asthma patients are worst hit. PCMC and DCB must find a permanent solution to the problem otherwise we would conduct agitations at the PCMC office in Pimpri and DCB office in Dehu Road,” he said.

DCB dumps its dry garbage on defence land bordering Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) limits. The villages of Nigdi and Talawade are located along the border that is affected by the smoke emanating from the burning garbage.

“Fires occur regularly at the cantonment garbage dumping site. We have to close the windows after 6pm due to the heavy smoke,” Vijay Salve , a resident of Sector 22 in Nigdi, said.

A civic health department official said the garbage dumping and burning occurs outside the municipal limits so the civic body cannot take any action.

“Dry garbage is only dumped on defence land near Nigdi. We do not burn garbage. Fires occur naturally as methane produced by the garbage catches fire. There was a major fire a fortnight ago which was immediately doused. We have stationed water tankers to douse the fires,” a cantonment official said.

PCMC municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar could not be contacted despite repeated attempts.

Title: Liquor worth Rs 1.22 lakh seized
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik rural police’s local crime branch (LCB) on Saturday seized illegal liquor worth over Rs 1.22 lakh from the the tribal dominated Harsul village.

The LCB received information that liquor from Daman, which is banned for sale in Maharashtra, was illegally sold in the village.

They immediately raided the place and detained a 32-year-old man of Harsul, Trimbakeshwar, and recovered 60 boxes of country liquor along with Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL).

Title: Koyya Prasada Reddy slams TDP
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Senior YSRC leader Koyya Prasada Reddy slammed the TDP leadership for making false allegations against the government.

He alleged that the TDP leadership was worried that their misdeeds were getting exposed by the present government.

Prasada Reddy said senior TDP leaders were responsible for rumours about the Navy voicing security concerns over hosting the secretariat in the Millennium Towers. He said this was another move by TDP to plot against the state government and prevent it from establishing the executive capital in the city.

Prasada Reddy said TDP was not able to accept the fact that the state government was reaching out to the masses and providing housing for the poor. He said allegations of land grabbing by the YSRC government were a false campaign by TDP. tnn

Title: Pilgrims from Maharashtra die in accident in Narmada district
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Four pilgrims from Ahmednagar of Maharashtra died after their car collided head-on with a truck in Narmada district on Sunday.

Nand Kishor Sampat, Kishor Kolhe, Gorakh Ghorpade and Pravin Sirsaath had visited Kuber Bhandari temple in Chanod on Saturday. Police said after offering prayers on Saturday, the four persons decided to leave for Ahmednagar in the early hours of Sunday as it was a 10-hour drive.

Around 5.30am when they were passing through the ghats near Vishal Khadi village, Sampat, who was driving the vehicle, overtook a truck but did not notice another truck coming from the opposite direction. Police said the truck from the opposite direction was slow as it was loaded with cotton bales, but Sampat’s car, which was speeding, collided with it with a loud bang. The car’s bonnet got completely mangled and the four pilgrims died on the spot. The driver and helper of the truck were unhurt.

Villagers rushed to spot on hearing the loud sound. Many tried to call ambulance and police but as the region is hilly, there was no mobile network. Police sources said the villagers went to a higher terrain and could connect to Rajpipla police station. An ambulance reached the spot and paramedical staff declared the four car passengers namely Nand Kishor Sampat, Kishor Kolhe, Gorakh Ghorpade and Pravin Sirsaath dead.

Their bodies were taken to civil hospital in Rajpipla for postmortem.

Title: RTO asks dealers to obey ‘2 helmets per 2-wheeler’ rule
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nagpur: The two regional transport offices — Nagpur city and deputy east — are registering two-wheelers only if the dealers are providing two helmets to the buyers following high court orders. Apart from bills, the RTOs are also taking an undertaking from two-wheeler buyers that they have received two helmets with the purchase of the vehicle.

Deputy RTO Atul Adey said, “City RTO Dinkar Manwar has issued a notification and directed all 20 automobile dealers in the city to supply two protective headgears to the buyers at the time of delivery of two-wheelers.”

Apart from high court orders, the city RTO has also cited the Central Motor Vehicles Rules, 138 (4)(f), which says, “At the time of the purchase of two-wheeler, the manufacturer shall supply a protective headgear confirming specifications prescribed by Bureau of Indian Standards under the Bureau of Indian Standards Act, 1986 (63), provided that these conditions shall not apply to category to person exempted in terms of Section 129 and the rules made there under by the concern state governments.”

Nikhil Kusumgar, one of the two-wheeler dealers, said that following high court’s directives, all the dealers in the city are mandatorily providing two BSI headgears to the buyers. He admitted that many buyers were trying to confront the decision by saying that they already have helmets. “But we reject such an argument,” he said.

The deputy RTO said, “Our motor vehicle inspectors (MVIs) and assistant motor vehicle inspectors (AMVIs) too are cross checking the bills of every buyer that they got two protective headgears apart from asking them to provide an undertaking about receiving two helmets with the purchase of the vehicle.” Manwar has issued instructions to all AMVIs and MVIs registering new vehicles to strictly follow the rule.

“This new order is unrealistic and problematic for all those consumers who might be purchasing their second two-wheeler or already have a helmet,” said Gajanan Pande, organizing secretary of Akhil Bharatiya Grahak Panchayat, Vidarbha chapter.

He said, “The order is a welcome move but at the same time, the high court must ask enforcement agencies like RTO and traffic police to ensure even pillion riders wear helmets. The order has also added to the bill of newly purchased two-wheelers to cover the costs of new helmets.”

Title: Student creates medicine bank to distribute medicines among needy
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Shubhankar Darbari (in a white T-shirt) at a donor’s residence

PUNE: A 17-year-old student, Shubhankar Darbari, has created a medicine bank by collecting surplus drugs from relatives and families living around his school for the people in need.

Shubhankar, who started this “bank” as a part of a community project in school about four years ago, has now turned it into a non-profit organisation, “Aid2Needy”, and created a stock of medicines he sends to charitable hospitals for distribution.

The medicines the Victorious Kidss Educares (VKE) student collects are usually donated by people who have a surplus of them. The teenager has also developed a cellphone-based application for people to raise donation requests. Once there’s a donation request alert on the app, the volunteers appointed by Shubhankar can collect the drugs from their doorstep.

“It’s a unique ‘bank’ for the well-offs to donate their surplus medicines. People from the economically challenged section, who cannot afford to buy medicines, can get them free of cost from the ‘bank’ through the charitable hospitals,” said Shubhankar, who aspires to set up similar units across the country.

The idea of ‘Aid2Needy’ came to him when he, in 2015, met Omkar Nath Sharma , popularly known as “medicine baba” conducting a similar activity in New Delhi. “After meeting him, I realized that the cause should be carried out in other cities by using technology as a leveraging tool. Keeping this in mind, I created a prototype portal by online training programmes.”

VKE president Robbin Ghosh said, “Shubhankar is inspired by the philosophy that our life is meant to serve people. He is working meticulously for the past four years to give something back to the community. He is also studying seriously to set a mark in academics. Such thoughts and efforts at an early age are extraordinary.”

Title: Lawyers to attend regular court hearings from today
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Sambalpur: The Central Action Committee (CAC) of all western Odisha bar associations on Sunday announced that the lawyers would participate in regular case hearings in courts across the region from Monday.

The lawyers, under the aegis of the CAC, have been agitating since September 5, 2018 to step up the demand for the establishment of a high court bench in western Odisha. Though they had been participating in all court works, they were abstaining from regular case hearings since March last year.

The CAC decision to restore normalcy in courts followed after after a meeting held on the premises of the Sambalpur Bar Association here on Sunday.

Addressing the media after the meeting, senior CAC member Sureswar Mishra said, “The CAC appeared in Supreme Court on February 17. Its secretary filed an affidavit giving details regarding the genesis of the movement for the establishment of a high court bench in western Odisha before the Supreme Court. The SC has accepted the affidavit and enlisted it for hearing. The next hearing over the issue has been scheduled on March 23.”

He further said in accordance with the direction of the Supreme Court, the CAC decided that lawyers across the region would participate in the regular hearing of cases in the courts.

The CAC has also issued an ultimatum to the state government. “If the state government does send a comprehensive proposal to the Centre regarding the establishment of an HC bench in western Odisha by March 31, the lawyers will intensify the agitation,” CAC convener Ashok Dash said.

The agitation for the establishment of a high court bench dates back to more than five decades. The lawyers had started the ‘no court, no hearing agitation’ on September 5, 2018. The state bar council had also recommended to the Bar Council of India (BCI) to take disciplinary action against the agitating bar associations of western Odisha.

Title: Bala makes winning debut in SWPL
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Panaji: Ngangom Bala Devi made her debut in the Scottish Women’s Premier League as Rangers FC put it across Hearts Women FC 3-0 at the Rangers training centre in Glasgow on Sunday.

India’s first woman professional footballer got 80 minutes on the field, and even though she didn’t add her name to the scoresheet, she did enough to impress.

“She had a good game for 80 minutes and was the last to be substituted. This is a good beginning for her. She can only get better,” said her representative Anuj Kichlu.

The match was initially scheduled to kick off at the natural turf ground but inclement weather with fears of snow meant the match had to be pushed indoors. Bala – handed the No. 10 jersey -- knew she would be handed a start and did well not to get overawed.

Rangers, who are among the two professional teams in the SWPL, led 1-0 at the change of ends and controlled proceedings from start to finish. Megan Bell (12th minute, 61st) scored a brace, while Kirsten Reilly hammered the final nail as the title aspirants kicked off their campaign on a winning note.

Title: Vijai: People got what they wanted
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Margao: The government’s overtime efforts to shift the Carnival floats parade from Fatorda have failed miserably, Fatorda MLA and Goa Forward Party president Vijai Sardesai said on Sunday. The show was finally held not where the government wanted but where the people and court wanted, he said, in reaction to the high court declining to change the route. He further said If the government had to put in similar efforts to save Mhadei, perhaps something what the chief minister called the mother could have been saved.

Title: Gujarat: Four from Maharashtra die as car rams truck
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Four pilgrims from Ahmednagar of Maharashtra died after their car collided head-on with a truck in Narmada district on Sunday.

Nand Kishor Sampat, Kishor Kolhe, Gorakh Ghorpade and Pravin Sirsaath had visited Kuber Bhandari temple in Chanod on Saturday. Police said after offering prayers on Saturday, the four persons decided to leave for Ahmednagar in the early hours of Sunday as it was a 10-hour drive.

Around 5.30am when they were passing through the ghats near Vishalkhadi village, Sampat, who was driving the vehicle, overtook a truck but did not notice another truck coming from the opposite direction. Police said the truck from the opposite direction was slow as it was loaded with cotton bales, but Sampat’s car, which was in speed, collided with it with a loud bang. The car’s bonnet got completely mangled and the four pilgrims died on the spot. The driver and helper of the truck were unhurt.

Villagers rushed to spot on hearing the loud sound. Many tried to call ambulance and police but as the region is hilly, there was no mobile network. Police sources said the villagers went to a higher terrain and could connect to Rajpipla police station. An ambulance reached the spot and paramedical staff declared the four car passengers namely Nand Kishor Sampat, Kishor Kolhe, Gorakh Ghorpade and Pravin Sirsaath dead.

Title: One killed in jallikattu at Nagiyampatti in Salem
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Salem: A 32-year-old bull tamer, who was injured critically in the jallikattu that was held at Nagiyampatti village near Thamampatti here on Saturday, has died in the government hospital without responding to treatment.

Police identified the deceased as Prabhakaran alias Kanagaraj, of Pudukottai. He was knocked down by a bull in the arena. A police officer said the identity card possessed by Prabhakaran did not have his name and instead bore the name of Mahendran. He said they were inquiring whether Prabhakaran had impersonated as Mahendran and entered the arena.

“We are inquiring if it is a case of impersonation. We have approached the organizers for details of all the bull tamers, who had registered with them,’’ the officer said.

The event, which featured more than 550 bulls from Salem and neighbouring districts and about 350 tamers, commenced on Saturday morning in the presence of district collector S A Raman, superintendent of police Deepa Kanikar and other senior officials and went on till 5pm.

Those who suffered minor injuries were treated near the jallikattu arena by a team of doctors and those with major injuries were sent to the government hospital.

“Along with 20 other injured bull tamers, Prabhakaran was undergoing treatment at the government hospital, where he succumbed to the injuries the same night. Five other injured are still being treated at the hospital, while the rest have been discharged,” the officer said.

Title: Gujarat: Khambhat flares up again, 13 injured in riots
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

More than 30 shops and houses were set ablaze in Akbarpura area

VADODARA/ ANAND: Communally sensitive Akbarpura area of coastal town of Khambhat in Anand district turned violent again on Sunday afternoon with at least 13 persons injured in incidents of stone pelting. More than 30 houses and shops were also set ablaze by the rioters in the late afternoon flare up that soon escalated beyond control.

According to sources, the rioters vandalised dozen-odd vehicles including auto rickshaws, two-wheelers and cycles.

Local police had to lob around 30 tear gas shells to bring the situation under control.

Absence of enough police presence in the town is said to be why the rioters couldn’t be brought under control immediately. Most of the cops have been deployed to Ahmedabad for US President Donald Trump’s visit.

The riots initially broke out in Akbarpura area when groups belonging to different communities resorted to heavy stone pelting.

Later, it spread to other areas of the town including Lal Darwaja, Bhoi wadi, Teen Bati, bus stand and Bhavsarwad. The skirmishes continued for nearly two hours.

Almost all the shops in the town remained closed during the day as tension gripped almost all the major markets that wore a deserted look.

“The situation is under control now,” said Kheda district superintendent of police Divya Mishra, who is currently in-charge of neighbouring Anand district, while talking to TOI. He confirmed that one of those injured is serious.

“One company of Rapid Action Force (RAF) has arrived and has been deployed. Once the situation normalises, a formal offence will be registered,” he said.This is the second communal flare-up within 30 days in Akbarpura. Earlier on January 24, similar clashed between members of Muslim and Chunara community had led to wide spread riots in the town that had left 15 cops injured and an elderly man dead in the firing. Cops had arrested over 50 accused in connection to the riots in which 10 houses and shops were set ablaze while several vehicles were vandalized.

Title: Aurangabad: Army jawan booked for raping woman on pretext of marriage
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

Title: Jailed doctor Kafeel Khan’s uncle shot dead over ‘land row’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

GORAKHPUR: Dr Kafeel Khan ’s maternal uncle was allegedly shot dead in front of his house in Rajghat area over a land dispute on Saturday night. Two persons have been booked for murder , on the basis of the family’s complaint.

Khan, a paediatrician suspended from Gorakhpur BRD Medical College in 2017, was arrested last month for allegedly making inflammatory statements during anti-CAA protests in Aligarh Muslim University . He was also charged with the National Security Act .

Police said Dr Nusratullah Warsi (55), a property dealer, was returning from his neighbour’s house, where he had gone to play carom, when he was shot. Hearing gunfire, his family rushed out only to see him lying in a pool of blood.

In their police complaint, the family has named Imamuddin of Kotwali and Anil Sonkar of Gorakhnath as murder suspects. A hunt has been launched to nab them. Cops added that the attackers may have been acquainted with Warsi as they knew his routine.

Police said the motive for murder seemed to be a property dispute, as per preliminary investigation. “In November last year, Warsi had won a case related to 4.5-acre land from Imamuddin and Nikhat Ara after they had illegally registered the land in their name. Warsi also had a dispute with Imamuddin for 12-acre land in Siddharthnagar . Sonkar had invested Rs 1.9 crore in Warsi’s construction company and was trying to get his money back,” Kotwali CO V P Singh said.

An FIR has been registered against two persons under sections 302 (murder) and 120 B (criminal conspiracy) of the IPC.

Title: School chale hum: Nagpur principals’ association to study Delhi schools success model
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nagpur: A group of city principals will be visiting Delhi government schools to study the turnaround witnessed by these institutions under Arvind Kejriwal-led Aam Admi Party (AAP). School Headmasters Charitable Association (SHCA) office bearers said the visit is likely to happen in second or third week of March.

Zafar Khan, founder-president of SHCA, said, “The Delhi school model is something which needs to be studied in great detail. It is amazing how Kejriwal and education minister Manish Sisodiya have transformed schools there. SHCA will be visiting some of these schools and interacting with education department officials at Delhi to understand how the change was achieved.” Khan, who is currently in Delhi, is completing the preliminary formalities for the visit which will happen next month.

SHCA, which represents aided school principals from Nagpur district, says this visit will not just be for photo-ops. Khan said, “The Delhi visit and meet with education officials will be precursor to a serious introspection among us all. Once back in Nagpur, we will hold intensive meets with members and see how we can do the same with Maharashtra schools.”

After these meets within the principals’ fraternity, SHCA plans to take feedback from other stakeholders like parents, students, social workers, counsellors etc and prepare a comprehensive report. Khan said, “Our report will contain all aspects about Delhi schools and how they achieved this turnaround. Then, we will discuss ground realities about Maharashtra and what needs to be done to repeat the Delhi school success model.”

SHCA won’t be the first group from Nagpur to head out to Delhi to learn from their schooling success. Last year, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) had also sent a team comprising corporators and some officials to Delhi to survey how schools are working there.

Even MLC Nago Ganar, who represents the teachers constituency, has been a vocal supporter of the Delhi model. Ganar said all governments must increase expenditure on school education drastically to achieve desired results.

Title: Cheque cloning case: Rs 16 lakh recovered from suspect by Pundaliknagar police
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Pundaliknagar police , probing the inter-state cheque cloning racket, has recovered Rs 16 lakh that was withdrawn by one of the suspects.

It is the first recovery made by the police after an FIR was registered in the cases that reportedly has connections in different parts of the state and in Bihar.

According to police , they are looking for three more suspects in the case — a local politician, an educationist and a banker. “All three are from different districts of the state, and only after their arrest, other members of the racket would come on record and procedure to arrest them would be initiated,” a police officer said.

Investigation officer and assistant inspector Ghanshyam Sonawne said, “We have recovered Rs 16 lakh from an accused identified as Bhagwan Muley of Karmad.”

Currently, Muley and Shivaji Thombre of Gadhejalgaon are in the judicial custody. An accomplice of Thombre has gone underground.

Investigation team has found that an amount of Rs 97,000 was withdrawn from a nationalized bank on February 4 and this was followed by transfer of Rs 16 lakh on February 5. Later, on February 7, an attempt was made by the suspects to withdraw Rs 78 lakh. All the transaction was done by using cloned cheques.

“Initial probe has revealed role of a suspect hailing from Vasmat, but we are finding it difficult to trace him. Thombre along with his close-aide from Vasmat bought material worth Rs 10 lakh from Muley, who apart from being an influential sarpanch, has several businesses in Karmad and surrounding areas,” the officer said.

“The duo handed over cloned cheque of Rs 16 lakh belonging to Bablu Laxman Hari of Bhagalpur in Bihar to Muley and asked him to get the amount transferred to his account. The suspects then asked Muley to deduct the outstanding amount and give back Rs 6 lakh to them,” he added.

Thombre along with the suspect from Vasmat have been working closely with a Vidarbha man, who through his contact in banks got details of accounts that do not have mobile phone numbers linked to them and misused the information for carrying out the fraud transactions.

Title: Discoms eye 280 spots in Delhi to power e-vehicles
Content:
Delhi government itself has been targeting induction of 35,000 electric two-, three- and four-wheelers, 1,000 ... Read More

NEW DELHI: In tune with the Delhi Electric Vehicle Policy 2019, the discoms in the capital are eyeing a network of more than 280 charging stations for e-vehicles (EVs) by the end of this year.While Tata Power, which has 12 charging stations, is planning 50 new ones, the two BSES discoms are trying to add 179 to their existing infrastructure. BSES, which now has 45 stations, expects to get nine more by March 31, taking the count to 54.BSES has gone into partnerships with several organisations to set up smart EV charging stations across its licensed areas, said an official. A Tata Power official pointed out that as Delhi government had been focusing on scaling up the use of electric vehicles in the next five years, the vehicles running on clean fuel would need these additional charging stations for smooth operation.The e-vehicle policy aims at curbing vehicular pollution by adding five lakh EVs in five years and focuses on its key contributors — two-wheelers, shared transport vehicles and goods carriers or freight vehicles. To improve Delhi’s air quality by bringing down emissions from the transport sector, the policy wants to drive rapid adoption of battery electric vehicles in such a way that they constitute 25% of the new vehicle registrations by 2024.Delhi government itself has been targeting induction of 35,000 electric two-, three- and four-wheelers, 1,000 electric vehicles for last-mile connectivities and 250 public charging and battery-swapping stations.The BSES official said the company had signed a memorandum of understanding with Ola Electric for setting up battery-swapping and charging stations at mutually identified spots. “While BSES Rajdhani Power Limited will set up the stations in south and west Delhi, BSES Yamuna Power Limited (BYPL) will do so in east and central Delhi to hasten the adoption of EVs in the city. Two- and three-wheelers will be able to avail both services at these stations. Electric cars can also be charged at some of these stations,” he added.Battery-swapping stations will virtually eliminate the wait time for charging, thus removing a major impediment in the adoption of EVs. Such measures will provide the much-needed trigger to increase the penetration of EVs in Delhi and go a long way in reducing pollution, the official claimed.Space constraints, however, may prove to be a hurdle in setting up more charging stations. “It may pose a slight challenge in certain pockets when the number of electric vehicles increases significantly. The authorities and various land-owning agencies will then have to proving land for more stations,” the official said.

Title: Poll code curtails acrimonious Candolim meet
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

CALANGUTE: A short gram sabha of the Candolim panchayat ended amidst ruckus after it was announced that no development proposals could be discussed due to the code of conduct being in force for the upcoming zilla panchayat polls.

The budget proposals for 2020-21, amounting to Rs 12.9 crore were present and villagers have been invited to give their suggestions, if any, within one week.

Earlier, during the reading of the minutes of the last gram sabha held in November, members pointed out that many of the points they had made as well as some resolutions taken were missing. Pending the corrections , the minutes were not confirmed.

Members also pointed out that the minutes of a gram sabha held in August, which had been read out at the November meet, had also not been recorded properly, and that those corrections too are still pending. Due to this, the minutes of the August meet have also not been confirmed.

The gram sabha witnessed frequent interruptions by members while others were speaking.
