Title: BC Patil: Bring law to shoot anti-nationals on the spot;Karnataka minister
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A file picture of BJP workers protesting against Amulya Leona Noronha’s pro-Pakistan slogans

BENGALURU/KODAGU: Three days after the sloganeering by 19-year-old college student Amulya Leona Norohna at an anti-CAA rally and her subsequent arrest on charges of sedition kicked up a storm, Karnataka minister BC Patil on Sunday advocated central legislation that enables authorities “to shoot at sight” those chanting pro-Pakistan slogans .

Responding to reporters’ queries on the ongoing fracas over the chants, Patil said he would appeal to Prime Minister Narendra Modi to bring in a law so that anti-national elements are “killed on the spot”.

“The Centre must promulgate a law that enables authorities to shoot those who do anything that is seen as anti-national and chant pro-Pakistan slogans,” Patil said. “These elements must be killed on the spot. I am appealing to the PM, through the media now, to bring in such a law. I will also write to the PM.”

In Kodagu, Union minister for chemicals and fertilizer, DV Sadananda Gowda, echoed state home minister home minister Basavaraj Bommai’s line that stringent action will be taken against those indulging in anti-national activity, saying there will be “no mercy” for those taking a pro-Pakistan stance.

“The Union government will assist in the police investigation in Amulya,” he said. Gowda went on to claim that many anti-national organizations have been using CAA protests for political gain.

“We will curb such incidents forever. We will not allow such incidents to happen in future. Organisers of such rallies should be thoroughly questioned,” Gowda said.

Bommai on Saturday had also claimed the government will initiate action against educational institutions and hostels it they fail to act against students indulging in such activity.

“The government will discuss ways to prevent such incidents in colleges and hostels. We will instruct heads of educational institutions and hostel wardens to initiate action against such students. If they fail, the government will take action against them,” Bommai said, without defining what constitutes anti-national activity.

However, despite Congress saying there is no room for anti-national activity and stringent action must be taken against those indulging in such activity, former minister and senior functionary DK Shivakumar suggested he found nothing in Amulya’s background to suggest she is anti-national.

“Let me make it absolutely clear that the Congress party will not support any person or persons who hail another country and bring shame to India,” Shivakumar said. “However, I have seen the girl’s [Amulya’s] previous posts on social media and read her statements on various forums. She has been making statements on an ideological ground. Let us not jump the gun, but investigate exactly what she meant to say.”

Title: Madurai: Man gets hand stuck inside commode at petrol bunk
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

MADURAI: A man from Thanjavur had a harrowing experience as he got his right hand got stuck inside an Indian commode while attempting to recover his car keys in the early hours of Sunday.

The man had to spend more than an hour and a half inside the toilet at a petrol bunk with his hand stuck before he was freed with the help of the fire and rescue department from Thideer Nagar station. Although he had been screaming for 30 minutes, the incident came to light only when a petrol bunk employee went to use the toilet.

The man was identified as K Manimaran, 29, from Thanjavur, who had came to Madurai to drop a passenger in his cab.

Officials from fire and rescue department said that during the one-and-half hours of struggle, he maintained calm and composure. The only thing at the back of his mind was to get his hand back without any fracture. “He wants to join the police department and had appeared for the written test for recruitment of sub-inspector of police held recently and is waiting to take part in the physical test to enter into uniformed service,” a fire official said.

Thideer Nagar fire station officer R Venkatesan said they got an alert at around 5.30am and reached the spot in no time. They had to break the lavatory and tile floor using a mini driller to widen the PVC pipe in which his hand got entangled . They poured some oil on his hand to loosen a bit, which helped withdraw his hand out slowly.

“When he inserted his hand, he first found a mobile phone which was lost by someone else. He though the keys would be next to it and inserted his hand further. When the hand got entangled he could not move a bit and stayed there till help arrived,” he said.

Manimaran got treated to minor injuries at a nearby hospital.

Title: Drunk students in Pune varsity boys’ hostel disturb others, police called in
Content:
Some students got drunk and began shouting and creating a nuisance which disturbed others in the building

PUNE: Tension prevailed at the boys’ hostel number 9 inside Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) late on Saturday when some students got drunk and began shouting and creating a nuisance which disturbed others in the building.Inspector Maya Devare of the Chatuhshrungi police station told TOI that a police team went to the hostel after the university officials called them.“We questioned the students and found them in an inebriated condition. We spoke to all of them and let them off with a warning. The university officials told us that they would take action against the students after an inquiry,” Devare added.The university’s administration said the process of suspension of one of the students was in process. The incident created some tension in the hostel till late in the night.Registrar Prafulla Pawar said the security department of the university received a call at 11pm from a student stating that some students were drunk and were creating a nuisance in hostel number 9.“On receiving this call, the security officers and the hostel in-charge went to the hostel room. They reported to me that the students were drunk and they had called the police. The process of suspending a student is going on. We will undertake a review of the security aspects of the hostel,” he added.A student staying at the hostel said, “In the past too, such incidents have taken place and other students have been affected. The security of the hostel at SPPU has always been an issue.”When the security guards arrived, the students who were drunk refused to open their room. “The security personnel tried to break down the door when they refused to open it at first. After a while, the students opened the door and the security personnel decided to call the police.”The SPPU has taken steps to tighten the security of the campus. The administration has decided to issue a gate pass to every vehicle carrying goods inside the campus.Pawar said, “Many vehicles enter the campus with goods required by the departments. Till now, such vehicles were not registered, but henceforth, this action will be undertaken to maintain security. The gate pass will be issued at the main gate. A notification will be issued soon.”In 2018, around 60 guards — 50 men and 10 women — were given ‘special police officer’ power to strengthen the security on the university’s campus.They were trained at the Range Police Training College (RPTC) and could arrest an offender without a warrant. The officers were given special power under sections 16, 17, 18, 20 and 21 of the Maharashtra State Security Corporation Act, 2010, under which they were deemed to be public servants. The Police (Incitement to Disaffection) Act, 1922, and Police Forces (Restriction of Rights) Act, 1966, was to apply to them.

Title: Pune: Summer-like weather condition by February-end, forecasts IMD
Content:
On Sunday, the day temperature in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon touched 34.7 degrees Celsius and 35.3 degrees Cels... Read More

PUNE: The city is expected to experience summer-like weather condition towards the end of February as the daytime temperature may hover between 36-37 degrees Celsius, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said on Sunday.There are three main reasons behind this weather phenomenon.“First, the flow of Northerly wind would recede in the coming days. Secondly, Southerly and South Easterly will bring hot air from the Southern Peninsular region. And thirdly, the season is advancing towards the summer. Because of these factors, the daytime temperature will rise to 37 degrees Celsius on the last few days of this month,” a senior Met department official told TOI on Sunday.On Sunday, the day temperature in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon touched 34.7 degrees Celsius and 35.3 degrees Celsius, respectively, maintaining the above normal trend by 2.4 degrees Celsius and 2.3 degrees Celsius, respectively.“On February 25 and 26, the maximum and minimum temperatures may fall by 1-2 degrees. On February 27, 28 and 29, the city may experience partly cloudy condition in the early morning and evening,” another IMD official said.“There is a chance of formation of trough over Konkan and Madhya Maharashtra region. Because of this, the moisture incursion is likely to occur in these regions, resulting in cloudy condition. This would have an impact on the day and night temperatures for a couple of days. But this condition will not remain for long period,” the official added.For the last two weeks, the city’s temperature had hovered between 33 degrees Celsius to 34 degrees Celsius. The day and night temperatures are likely to maintain the above normal trend by 2-3 degrees in the coming days, a source from Met department said.

Title: Kafeel’s kin shot over land row in Gorakhpur
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

GORAKHPUR: A property dealer was shot over a land dispute in front of his house in Rajghat area here on Saturday night. An FIR was registered against two people on a written complaint of his family members.

The deceased, identified as Dr Nusratullah Warsi (55), is the maternal uncle of Dr Kafeel Khan, the suspended doctor of BRD Medical College here.

Police have launched a hunt for the accused. According to reports, Warsi went to play carom at the house of his neighbour, an advocate Siraj Tariq’s house. On return, he was attacked by man near his house. Hearing the gunshots, the family members came out and found Warsi lying in a pool of blood. On being informed, senior police officials including SSP Sunil Kumar Gupta, SP city Dr Kaustubh and circle officer (Kotwali) V P Singh reached the spot and sent the body for autopsy.

“On a written complaint of family members, a case of murder was registered against one Imamuddin of Kotwali police station area and Anil Sonkar of Gorakhnath police station area. Police are searching for both the accused,” said CO Kotwali V P Singh said.

He said: “Prima facie, it’s a property dispute case. In November last year, the deceased had won a court case related to a 4.5-acre land from Imamuddin and one Nikhat Ara. The duo had illegally registered the land in their name. Warsi also had a dispute with Imamuddin for a 10-12 acre land at Itwa in Siddharthnagar. Sonkar had invested Rs 1.9 crore in Warsi’s construction company and was trying to get his money back.”

“The attacker seems to be an acquaintance as he knew about Warsi’s daily routine. However, things will become clear after a detailed investigation,” Singh added.

Gorakhpur SSP Sunil Kumar Gupta said: “It appears be a case of a property dispute. A case under IPC sections 302 (murder) and 120 B (criminal conspiracy) has been registered against two people. Three teams have been constituted to investigate case and the culprits will be caught soon.”

Title: Poll preparations may delay Aurangabad’s Development Plan formulation
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The DP for Aurangabad was created in 2001. An exercise was attempted over four years ago for zones that experi... Read More

AURANGABAD: Upcoming civic body polls are likely to delay the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation's execution of orders from the state government, which wants it to create a fresh Development Plan for the city.

The DP for Aurangabad was created in 2001. An exercise was attempted over four years ago for zones that experienced an increase in population, but that was soon mired in controversy. The matter is currently in the Supreme Court.

In the latest directive, issued early this month, the state town planning authority has asked AMC to prepare DPs for both old and newer areas within city limits.

Aurangabad deputy mayor Rajendra Janjal said the process of DP formulation could require considerable time because of the upcoming civic elections .

Janjal said: “The AMC has been asked to prepare separate DPs for the old city limits and the outskirts, which includes 18 villages. These DPs will be merged to form a consolidated DP for the whole of Aurangabad. The entire process requires crucial components, which includes existing land use surveys and public suggestions or objections. This DP may take some more time because the upcoming civic elections are now a priority for many stakeholders.”

While the AMC must revise the Development Plan as per the provisions of the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning (MRTP) Act, 1966, the draft plan created in October 2015 has been caught in a legal tangle. The old plan was sanctioned in 1991.

A DP spells out proposed land-use patterns and public amenities as per future population estimates. These plans are approved by the urban development department of the government and incorporate proposals of zoning for various purposes, including transport and water treatment amenities.

Civic activist Rajendra Datey-Patil said the formulation of DP should be given priority instead of the upcoming civic polls. “Aurangabad is perhaps the only metro city in the country that hasn’t had an updated DP in such a long while. The absence of a DP often proves to be a major problem during the allocation of funds. Moreover, unplanned development continues to impact the city and this is because of the lack of an updated DP,” Datey-Patil said.

Title: Sabarmati Ashram: Finally, Donald Trump’s tryst with Mahatma Gandhi
Content:
Donald Trump

After a week of uncertainty over US President Donald Trump and first lady Melania’s visit to Mahatma Gandhi’s Sabarmati Ashram , protocol officials of the state government and Union ministry for external affairs finally heaved a sigh of relief when they were told on Saturday night to stick to the ‘original plan’.PM Narendra Modi will arrive 10 minutes ahead of the President Trump’s arrival and will be received by the trustees of the Sabarmati Ashram Preservation and Memorial Trust (SAPMT). Sources said that the US president will spend about 15 minutes at the Ashram.The protocol details were being worked out when TOI called late on Sunday night, but state government officials said that President Trump’s son-in-law Jared Kushner and his wife and Trump’s daughter and advisor Ivanka may not visit the Ashram. Gujarat government officials said that the PM will receive the US president near Hriday Kunj around 12:15pm and then accompany the guests to the cottage. The trio will remove their footwear before entering the cottage, sources said. After a small tour, president Trump and Melania will witness a demonstration of the spinning wheel."President Trump and the first lady will be gifted a copy of the Mahatma’s autobiography, a small charkha, and if time permits, a khadi cloth with Bapu’s talisman and a framed pencil drawing of Mahatma Gandhi," said a state government official. He said the Centre will be gifting the guests a nine-inch tall marble memento of the three wise monkeys.The US president and first lady will then be led to a table outside Hriday Kunj where they will both pen down their experiences at the Ashram and their message. "A major concern for us was that the US president was coming from Washington, where temperature is around 11°C, to a hotter place like Ahmedabad where the temperature is around 35°C around noon. The whole protocol is being worked out to avoid the harsh sun," said the state government official.In Video: Namaste Trump: Trump signs guestbook at Sabarmati Ashram, fails to mention Gandhiji

Title: In Alappuzha, floriculture is a blooming business
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Fields of Jamanthi or chrysanthemum flower spread over two acres are helping these young farmers to harvest a ... Read More

ALAPPUZHA: Kanjikuzhy in Alappuzha is famous for organic vegetables. It bagged the state’s maiden Swaraj Trophy for best local body. Now, a group of youngsters from the village are making it big in flower cultivation.

Ministers and floriculture enthusiasts are visiting the local body to get a glimpse of the successful business.

Fields of Jamanthi or chrysanthemum flower spread over two acres are helping these young farmers to harvest a good profit.

Eleven youngsters from Ambalakkara self-help group (SHG) of Puthanambalam, Kanjikuzhy, are behind this.

The SHG was set up around 10 years ago and consists of government employees and daily wage workers. The group is led by Sujith Swaminikarthil, who received the state government’s award for best young farmer in Kerala .

The group successfully conducted cultivation of organic vegetables, water melon and fish farming. Ministers and MLAs are regular visitors. “After harvesting organic vegetables, we got a gap. So, we have decided to start flower cultivation. We never thought this would become a big success.

Our soil is not friendly for flower cultivation. We have planted 5,000 saplings of Jamanthi collected from Suresh Perumbalam, a nursery owner. Two months ago, we started it and the lifespan of this plant is three months. Now, we are daily selling 50kg to 60kg of flowers. For one kg of flowers, Rs 60 is the price. After hearing our cultivation story, people visit our flower farm. Minister T M Thomas Isaac, politicians and people from districts like Thiruvananthapuram visited our farm. People can visit our farm for free,” said Sujith.

“We started this on an experimental basis and it bore fruit. So, we will also do floriculture along with organic vegetable cultivation,” said the Ambalakkara members.

Title: Only 34% groundwater drawn out in Goa: WRD
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Goa utilises only 34% of its groundwater and continues to be in the safe zone where groundwater usage is concerned, according to the latest analysis by the central groundwater board.

The state’s groundwater drawal is low compared to neighbouring states like Karnataka , where utilisation is upto 200%, water resource department chief engineer Shrikant Patil told TOI.

As the density of population and built structures is increasing in the state, there are concerns that the state could be under threat of overexploitation of groundwater. But Patil said that as per the 2017 findings of the central groundwater board, Goa only extracts 60,000 hectare meter annually.

“The central groundwater board monitors 85 wells in the state,” said Patil.

He said that new wells are not allowed to be dug up within 100m of existing wells. Patil said that before allotting permission for commercial use of well water, a technical study is carried out to determine the yield of the well and then, the limit of water extraction is set accordingly.

A committee headed by the chief engineer meets every month to scrutinise requests for such extraction of groundwater by industries for new construction and by individuals for sale by tankers etc.

There are 6,502 wells and 1,025 borewells currently registered with the WRD.

The central groundwater board’s report states that the overall groundwater availability scenario in Goa remains safe, but a ‘negligible to moderate’ fall in water level was recorded during the premonsoon season.

It shows that groundwater consumption has gone up in Goa. Of the stations (observation wells) analysed, 54% showed a fall in water level, while 46% showed a rise in water level.

Rise in water levels of 0 to 2m was observed in parts of Sanguem , Quepem, Canacona, Salcete, Sattari, Bicholim and Pernem taluka .

Fall in water level of 0 to 2m was observed in almost all talukas. The fall in general is negligible to moderate.

“It indicates that groundwater consumption has picked up over the years in almost the entire state,” states the report ‘Groundwater Resources of Goa - March 2017’.

Title: Lucknow: Over 5 lakh patients examined at Arogya Mela in Ayodhya
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Over 90,000 kids were benefitted in fourth Arogya Mela in Ayodhya

LUCKNOW: Over 5 lakh patients were benefitted in the fourth Mukhyamantri Arogya Mela (health fair) at Surya Kund in Darshan Nagar area of Ayodhya on Sunday. “At least 5.02 lakh patients (over 1.7 lakh men, 2.4 lakh women and 90,000 children) were benefited in fourth Arogya Mela held in Ayodhya.

A total of 12,345 serious patients were referred to hospitals for treatment,” government spokesman said. He said over 17 lakh patients have benefitted from four Arogya Melas organised across the state so far. CM Yogi Adityanath had started the programme on February 2.

The government spokesman said more than 55,000 serious patients were referred to hospitals through health fair, which is being organized every Sunday at more than 4,200 primary health centres in the state. In the four health fairs held so far, 1.31 lakh gold cards have been made.

Meanwhile, Delhi BJP president Manoj Tewari met Yogi Adityanath at his official residence and said health fairs conducted in over 4,000 PHCs was a bigger achievement than 34 ‘mohalla clinics’ being run by the Aam Aadmi Party government in Delhi. The CM presented Tewari a coffee table book on Kumbh organised in Allahabad last year.

Title: Protest against CAA, NRC in Gorakhpur
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Dalit outfits stage a protest against CAA, NRC in Gorakhpur

GORAKHPUR: Dalit outfits Bhim Army, Asur Chatra Sangathan and Purvanchal Sena staged a sit-in against Citizen Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) at Laxmi Bai Park in Gorakhpur on Sunday. They also protested against indirectly ending reservation in government jobs.

The protesters, carrying placards, banners and posters, raised slogan ‘Aarakshan Bachao, constitution bachao’, ‘CAA,NRC –NPR hatao, Desh bachao’. They also gave a memorandum addressed to the President, PM and Home Minister of the country at the DM’s office.

President of Purvanchal Sena Dheerendra Pratap said, “CAA is anti-constitution and actually it is a way of changing constitution. NRC based on a piece of document is not acceptable to us. Instead we demand DNA-based NRC.

Title: Mhadei, Tarini off on maiden mixed crew sailing expedition
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Each boat will be at sea for 55 days and cover a distance of 6,100 nautical miles

PANAJI: Indian Naval Sailing Vessels, Mhadei and Tarini, have set sail for a Bay of Bengal offshore sailing expedition.

Rear Admiral SJ Singh, commandant of the Naval War College, Goa, flagged off the expedition on Saturday from the Indian Naval Ocean Sailing Node.

With a crew composition of five naval officers including two women officers in each boat, this will be the Indian Navy’s maiden major mixed crew sailing expedition.

Captain Vipul Meherishi, the skipper of Tarini, will be the expedition leader while captain Atool Sinha will be the skipper of the Mhadei. Both skippers are accomplished yachtsmen who have won medals at national and international-level competitions.

Each boat will be at sea for 55 days and cover a total distance of 6,100 nautical miles. As part of the expedition, the vessels will make replenishment halts at ports of Phuket, Yangon , Chittagong and Colombo. The halts will include interaction with various state officials and harbour sorties for visiting dignitaries.

The expedition aims at generating goodwill among visiting nations and inspiring participation in the forthcoming BIMSTEC sailing expedition being planned with mixed crew of member nations onboard Indian Naval Sailing Vessels. The nearly three-month long expedition will also showcase harnessing of renewable energy namely wind energy to propel the boats.

The expedition is also in keeping with the country’s ‘Nari Shakti’ mission, of providing opportunities to women officers on par with men.

Title: Karnataka: Anna Bhagya rice to be cut
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The state government is reportedly mulling reducing the quantity of rice being distributed through the public distribution system (PDS) under the populist Anna Bhagya scheme . The move is certain to create a political furore with the opposition Congress, as the scheme was launched by the Siddaramaiah regime

The government at present provides 7kg rice under Anna Bhagya and a source said chief minister BS Yediyurappa is considering cutting it to 5kg. The chief minister is likely to announce the decision in his budget to be presented on March 5.

"The idea is to curb irregularities and save funds. If we reduce the quantity of rice, we can provide more of other commodities like pulses and sugar. However, nothing has been finalised," said K Gopalaiah, minister for food and civil supplies.

A similar proposal was mooted by the HD Kumaraswamy-led coalition government, but was dropped owing to vehement opposition from the Siddaramaiah camp.

Title: 40 booked for trespassing into reserve forest for poaching in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The forest department booked 40 people on Sunday under the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 for trespassing into a reserve forest in Trichy for hunting wild animals.

The incident happened in the late hours on Saturday when 48 people, including minors along with 18 dogs and traps entered Thatchankurichi reserve forest for poaching.

Following a tip off, a 15-member team detained the group along with their belongings. Four vehicles were also seized from them.

None of them was found to be a habitual offender. They have come from Somarasampettai for Parivettai – a traditional practice of hunting animals in the wild once in a year.

“They were brought to the forest department office in Trichy. Their belongings were seized, and 40 people except the minors were booked and imposed fine,” said district forest officer D Sujatha.

They were released after collecting the fine. Such incidents are not happening for the first time. These many people were not detained by the forest department in the recent past for poaching activities, said the officials.

In September last year, the forest department detained 21 people near Siraganur in Trichy after they hunted a wild boar. They were let off on bail after collecting a meagre fine.

The forest department had thwarted another poaching activity in Manapparai on Saturday when a section of people approached Manapparai tahsildar with permission for poaching as part of the Mahashivrathri celebrations.

More than 50 village heads laid siege to the tahsildar officer on Saturday evening. Tahsildar B Tamilkani and the forest department officials held talks with them.

The villagers dispersed from the spot only after the forest department officials warned of action under Wildlife Protection Act 1972 against any poaching activity.

Title: Madurai: New mutton stall in central prison turns hit in a month
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The busy morning hours saw seven goats slaughtered and their meat sold to a long line of mutton lovers.

MADURAI: Less than a month since a mutton stall was launched at the Madurai central prison involving the inmates, the outlet seems to be drawing an impressive number of customers, selling more than 70 kg of meat in three hours on Sunday morning. The busy morning hours saw seven goats slaughtered and their meat sold to a long line of mutton lovers.

Reared in the Open Air Jail at Kalayarkovil in Sivaganga district, the goats will be sold to the central prison after obtaining clearance from government veterinarians. While the stall has functioned in the past couple of Sundays, it became fully-fledged stall only this Sunday.

Around 15 inmates from the prison are involved in various process involving like skinning, chopping meat, seasoning of head and limbs using fire and sales. “The overwhelming support of customers is down to the fact that many hardly get to buy pure goat meat. Most stalls sell sheep meat, under the guise a mutton,” officials said.

Compared to muttons stalls in the city, where a kg of boneless meat is sold at up to Rs 820, the prison bazaar sells meat only at Rs 700. A pair of limbs used for preparing soup are sold for Rs 100 and head for Rs 200. Despite a competitive price, the inmates make a decent money with 20% of the profit going to them.

“The meat became popular by word of mouth. Many who bought meat her suggest the shop to others. We sold a good quantity of meat without making any publicity to the stall,” said the official.

Prison authorities have been introducing various manufacturing and trade activities to empower inmates under the prison bazaar scheme. They can learn new skills, which can be used to support their family members, once they walk out of the prison. Mutton stall is one of them. Recently, they began manufacturing nursery pots and are selling them directly on the cheap.

In all, 105 inmates are involved in various farming and farm related activities in the Open Air Jail spread over a 84 acres of land. Raising cattle and poultry are some of them, officials said.

Title: ‘World-class’ renovation at Inox multiplex
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Panaji: For the next International Film Festival of India (Iffi), 2020, the four-screen government multiplex operated by Inox Leisure ltd will be of world class standard as it is set to undergo major renovation soon, said the vice-chairman of Entertainment society of Goa (ESG), Subhash Phal Desai.

He said that a tender was floated by ESG in October 2019, and the work has been awarded to Inox for refurbishment and renovation of the multiplex.

“They were selected as their bid was higher than the other bidders – PVR,” he said. ESG was set up in 2004 as a nodal agency to help organise Iffi, and ESG has the mandate to help turn Goa into a world-class international entertainment centre.

Inox will undertake the renovation project and will run the multiplex for another 12 years, while paying a monthly rental of Rs 54 lakh to the government. The agreement also carries an annual increment of 5% in the rental amount.

Inox had been paying Rs 20 lakh per month as per the earlier agreement signed with the Manohar Parrikar government.

Unlike elsewhere in the country, where multiplexes are built by private players, in Goa, it was constructed by the state government to host the debut Iffi in Goa in 2004. Delhi-based PVR had recently moved the high court against the latest decision to allot the tender to Inox Leisure ltd.

“PVR has lost the case in the High court”, said Phal Desai, adding that the renovation work will begin by April 1.

“We have asked them to complete the work within six months, by September-end. For Iffi 2020, we will have a world class multiplex”, Phal Desai said.

Title: MiG-29K crashes off Goa, pilot ejects safely
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The MiG-29K aircraft, part of the 303 Black Panther squadron, was on a routine training sortie when it suffere... Read More

PANAJI: In yet another crash for the Indian Navy in just over three months, a naval fighter jet which took off from the INS Vikramaditya crashed into the Arabian Sea about 35 nautical miles from Goa’s coast on Sunday.

The MiG-29K aircraft, part of the 303 Black Panther squadron, was on a routine training sortie when it suffered a serious technical glitch, said naval officials. Sources said that after the pilot realised that the aircraft was unrecoverable, he ejected around 10.30am.

“The pilot ejected safely and has been recovered,” chief public relations officer Commander Mehul Karnik said.

Karnik said further details were awaited as the Navy was trying to ascertain the depth where the MiG-29K crashed.

The Russian-made MiG 29K is the naval version of the MiG 29 which is in service with the Indian Air Force. It forms the lethal wing of the Navy’s air assets.

The Navy has reported that the MiG 29k has suffered several engine malfunctions and Sunday’s crash is the latest in a string of losses that the Navy has had to deal with.

In November 2019, a trainer version of the MiG 29K crashed about 30km from Goa’s capital after it encountered a flock of birds after take-off from INS Hansa air base at Dabolim, Goa.

The MiG 29KUB had crashed at the Verna plateau and the pilots, who had ejected, were rescued by locals.

As is the process, the Navy has launched a formal investigation into the circumstances that led to the fighter being ditched into the sea. “A board of enquiry has been instituted by the Indian Navy,” said Karnik.

Even as the Indian Navy navigates the long drawn process to procure 57 fighter jets, it’s fleet of fighter jets continues to decline.

Title: Tamil Nadu government urged to launch river water management scheme to rejuvenate water bodies
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Cauvery (kaveri)river trichy

TRICHY: Tamil Nadu Rivers Retrieve Movement urged the state government to launch an integrated river water management scheme, during a meeting organized with the theme-- ‘Strategies to revive and rejuvenate river basin resources and water bodies’-- here on Sunday.

Among various resolutions, the movement stressed the government for an integrated river water management scheme that should be launched comprising of four major basins including Cauvery, Vaigai, Thamirabarani, Paalar and Pennaru. Tamil Nadu government should take effort to launch the scheme keeping the model of Kaleshwaram lift irrigation scheme in the Godavari river as an example.

They also insisted that a peninsular river water grid should be formed by using the annual flow index to share water equitably between the riparian states of rivers such as Mahanadi, Godavari, Krishna, Cauvery, Pennar and Paalar.

Another resolution sought for from the government was to establish a water literacy centre as a resource centre to promote water literacy education, training and research taking the model of states like Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Maharashtra with financial assistance from central government.

Meanwhile, the federation has decided to form water parliament for each river basin with the participants of river bank-based villages. This parliament, at each panchayat level, would be involved in restoration and rejuvenation of river courses – both inlets and outlets, including the attached water bodies.

A state-level committee will also be formed for efficient functioning of Tamil Nadu Rivers Retrieval Movement, to form a network of water volunteers and action groups at panchayat level, including farmers and other stakeholders in the state. It also decided to organize ‘Cauvery River Rejuvenation Walk’ to create awareness on the rejuvenation of water bodies among the general public.

Indian water conservationist and environmentalist Rajendra Singh spoke at the meeting. Functionaries of Tamil Nadu Rivers Retrieve Movement Gandhipithan, T Gurusami, Puliyur N Nagarajan, Vayalur Rajendran were also participated.

Title: Trichy: Four killed in two road accidents in Karur, Thanjavur
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Four people were killed in two road accidents that happened in in Karur and Thanjavur on Saturday night. Police have registered cases and are investigating into it.

According to police, the deceased have been identified as Raja Raja Cholan, 25, of Kathadipatti, Durairaj, 20, of Kalvirayanpettai in Thanjavur district and U Imran, 20, and S Khadar, 25, of Pallapatti near Aravakuruchi in Karur district .

Police said that Raja Raja Cholan and Durairaj were returning to their village on a mini truck with their bull after participating in a jallikattu event held at Madhakottai near Vallam in Thanjavur. Their friends Vettriselvan, 17, Mathi, 35, and Madhavan, 17, were also travelling in the truck.

While the vehicle was approaching Vilar on the bypass road, the driver, Mani, tried to overtake a vehicle but their vehicle overturned on the road. All the five sustained injuries and were rushed to Thanjavur government medical college hospital, where the Raja Raja Cholan and Durairaj succumbed to their injuries and others were under treatment. Thanjavur taluk police registered a case and are searching the driver Mani, who fled the scene. The jallikattu bull, which was on the truck, escaped without any injuries, police said. In another incident, Imran and Khadar, who were working in a textile shop in Aravakuruchi, were heading towards Karur on Saturday night on a two-wheeler. When they were approaching Seethapatti village located on Dindigul-Karur national highway, the bike rammed on the rear side of a stationery tourist bus, police said.

As they were travelling speeding, both of them died on the spot. Aravakuruchi police rushed to the spot and retrieved their bodies and sent them to Karur government hospital for postmortem.

Title: Karnataka: Royal row over CT Ravi’s casino idea
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

CT Ravi

BENGALURU/KALABURAGI: Tourism minister CT Ravi on Sunday insisted the government has no plan to open casinos in the state, a U-turn on a comment made a day earlier that the state could permit gambling houses to attract tourists.

In a tweet, Ravi said, "During my interaction with FKCCI, I had mentioned that many countries have promoted Tourism through Casinos. Isn't it a fact that lakhs of Indians go abroad to play in Casinos? Can anyone stop them? At the moment, there is no proposal before Our Govt to set up Casinos here. (sic)"

Speaking to reporters on Sunday, Ravi clarified that his comment was only in response to a question at the interaction. "I did speak to them about these casinos, but that was only a response to questions on why Karnataka cannot emulate Goa tourism’s success," Ravi said.

Department officials say permitting casinos would require a special law. "When we speak about gambling, the first thing that comes to mind is the Bangalore Turf Club. But the turf club is governed by laws pertaining to horse racing. Similarly, in Goa, casinos are off-shore and along the coastline. We need to look at existing laws and also bring in a special law if Karnataka is to allow casinos," an official said.

Meanwhile, in Bidar, opposition leader Siddaramaiah decried the idea. "If casinos are allowed, then it means BJP supports gambling," said Siddaramaiah, who labelled the idea "foolish".

Title: Mathura cops indicted for botching up abduction case, letting off kidnapper
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: An internal probe by the police department has indicted Mathura police of blatant corruption and criminal conduct in the abduction and release of a doctor.

After the safe release of the doctor, Mathura police nabbed a kidnapper and recovered Rs 15 lakh from him but let him off after handing over the money to the victim.

After allegations came to light, IG (Agra range) was asked to conduct a probe who submitted his report to ADG (personnel). The report was scrutinised by senior officials and sent to government for further action. According to cops, orthopaedic surgeon Dr Nirvikalp Agarwal was kidnapped on December 10 last year and later released after he paid a ransom of Rs 52 lakh to abductors. The doctor did not inform the matter to police.

However, when the doctor received another call from the same criminals on January 19, asking for another Rs 50 lakh, he informed the police. A senior police said, “Highway police nabbed one of the kidnappers from Meerut and recovered Rs 15 lakh out of Rs 52 lakh from him. There was no trace of the remaining amount. Though Rs 15 lakh was handed over to the doctor, the criminal was released and no case was registered.” It was found during investigation that the kidnapper was set free after three days of detention. No FIR was lodged on the basis of complaint made by Dr Agarwal.

SHO highway police Jagdamba Singh and CO Refinery Jagveer Singh were removed on charges of dereliction of duty. The case was transferred from Highway police station to crime branch for further probe.

Title: Metro’s Hingna depot to be ready by May end
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nagpur: MahaMetro’s Hingna car depot, where coaches used in Reach III (Sitabuldi to Lokmanya Nagar stretch) are parked at night, will be ready by May end. At present, it is half complete and facilities for parking the trains are available.

A MahaMetro spokesperson said that the depot has an area of 65 acres out of which 30.19 acres is utilized for the rolling stock maintenance work. The depot has twelve components: time and security office (TSO), auto coach wash plant (ACWP), traction substation (TSS), auxiliary substation (ASS), underground tank pump room, maintenance building, pit wheel lathe (PWL), engineering train unit (ETU), internal cleaning platform (ICP), unloading platform, stabling lines and biodigester.

The TSO is for the usage of security purposes as the depot is restricted for common citizens. It is complete. The ACWP is for the machineries of the wash plant bed where the train is washed from the outside. It is also complete. The TSS steps down 33 KV supply from MSEDCL to 25 KV. It is ready but the ASS, which steps down 33 KV to low tension (LT) level, is under construction.

The UG tank pump room will be used to provide water supply to different buildings inside the depot. It is under construction. The maintenance building is also under construction.

The under construction PWL will have a wheel-orientation machine where the wheel profile is checked on regular intervals. The ETU, which will be used to store the track machines rerailing equipment is complete.

The ICP will be used to clean the inside and underfloor of the rolling stock. Currently, this building is being used for maintenance of the rolling stock as the maintenance building is under construction. The unloading platform on which the new train is unloaded with the help of the unloading equipment is complete.

Work on the stabling lines where rolling stock is stabled, is under progress. Work has, however, not started on the biodigester.

Title: PepsiCo unit at Kanjikode to reopen today
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A file photo shows agitating employees in front of PepsiCo India plant

PALAKKAD: The soft drink unit of PepsiCo at Kanjikode , which remained closed since February 8 due to strike by workers of a labour supply contracting company, will reopen on Monday after the high court directed police to provide necessary protection to the factory.

The company management said that they moved out 39 loads of the cool drinks stored in the company with police protection on Saturday and Sunday. They said that only 10% of the stock was removed during the last two days. It will take another 10-15 days to move the entire stock.

The HC order was on a petition filed by the company management alleging that the police did not implement its interim order to provide protection for the smooth functioning of the company.

The petitioner sought protection for ingress and egress to their employees and removal of finished goods.

The court had also appointed Palakkad taluk legal services authority “to depute a competent officer to observe and report before this court in regard to the compliance of the direction of this court.”

Title: After Delhi, AAP sets eyes on Uttar Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

AAP MP Sanjay Singh during the roadshow in Lucknow

LUCKNOW: After its emphatic return in Delhi, Aam Aadmi Party has now turned focus on UP. AAP MP Sanjay Singh said the party will contest the next district panchayat elections in the state.

Singh, who took out a ‘victory roadshow’ from Charbagh till Gandhi Bhavan here on Sunday, said AAP will set foot in UP by visiting 1.07 lakh villages in the next three months and after doing a survey of people’s problems across the state, give feedback to Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal.

There is no law and order in UP, nobody pays heed to farmer issues and youth is wary. Communal and caste politics is not what people here want and we will be focusing on farmers issues as priority,” Singh said.

Title: ‘Attempts to divert attention from economy’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Kolhapur: State cabinet minister and NCP leader Jayant Patil said that everyone is being trapped in caste and religious issues and no attention is being paid to the dwindling state of the economy.

“Attempts are made to divert the attention. The poor from every community are adversely affected by the state of economy,” said Patil, during a two-day convention called by the Brahmin community.

When asked by the media, Patil said that the statement by the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh’s general secretary Bhaiyaji Joshi reveals that the Devendra Fadnavis will soon be made minister in the central government. Joshi, while speaking at Nagpur, had said that Fadnavis’ status as former chief minister and leader of opposition will not stay for long.

“I think what he meant was that Devendra Fadnavis is going to be made a minister in the Union government. I will be happy and wish that he will do good work,” said Patil.

About the visit of chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to Delhi and meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Patil said that they are working under Thackeray’s leadership. “He has spoken on the CAA and NRC issues. I will only say that we are running the state government effectively. My party’s position on the CAA and NRC is public and I have nothing much to say about it,” added Patil.

Patil was attending the two-day convention of the Brahmin community at Dasara Chowk. Representatives of the community had gathered to discuss various issues. “Every community strives to make the last man standing happy. Every community has poor people. These days, the trend is to call out people from other castes. This may make such people leaders. It shows we are getting trapped in caste and religious issues. Attempts are made to divert attention from core issues,” Patil said.

Title: Serious water crisis looms, says expert
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A sample study of Nagpur’s rainfall says it is the same - 1000mm - for last 20 years

Nagpur: Of the entire water on Earth, only 3% is fresh and fit for consumption. Of this, 68.7% is in the form of glaciers, 30% is groundwater and only a mere 0.3% is surface water in the form of lakes and rivers which is readily available, said Sandeep Shirkhedkar, an alumnus of Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology and consultant to the state government, on Saturday.

Delivering a lecture on ‘Rainwater harvesting: Urban and rural water conservation systems’, organized by The Eco Club of Chitnavis Centre, he said everyone should act with a sense of responsibility and use water judiciously, .

He said, “According to a NASA satellite report, groundwater resources of northern India are depleted. This is a serious crisis. According to WHO, by the year 2040, one in every four children will go thirsty. Today, we have reached a situation where we are extracting 300-year-old water from the confined aquifer of groundwater table. Do we have a right to do that,” he asked.

Talking about Nagpur, he said, “A sample study of the city’s rainfall has revealed that it is the same since the last 20 years (1000mm). The amount of rain falling is the same, however the intensity is increasing.” According to him, at this rate, Nagpur’s entire monsoon water will fall in just 10 days.”

Shirkhedkar pointed out that the next war in the world will probably be for water. “There are so many water disputes between countries, states, villages and even families. There needs to be optimization of water usage.”

He inferred that solution to the water crisis lies in construction of big reservoirs. “Apart from big reservoirs, river linking, construction of small reservoirs, river diversion, watershed management, water use optimization, community and individual initiative will go a long way.”

Shirkhedkar has designed a wide variety of large and small conservation projects. He spoke about rainwater harvesting, watershed management, structures for conservation, treatment of water, do’s and don’ts, people’s participation and various case studies.

Title: Manish Sisodia: Respect concerns expressed by US embassy
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Manish Sisodia

NEW DELHI: Hours after getting confirmation that Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and deputy CM Manish Sisodia will not be part of an event at a government school on February 25, in which the first lady Melania Trump is a guest, Sisodia said he “respected” the concerns expressed by the US embassy.

In a statement issued late on Sunday, Sisodia said it was a great appreciation that AAP government’s work in the education sector was being recognised in the world and he and CM Kejriwal would have “loved” to explain the concept of happiness classes to the first lady of the United States .

“However, certain concerns were expressed by the US embassy regarding the CM and deputy CM accompanying her during the school visit. We respect the same. We welcome the first lady wholeheartedly and will do our best to facilitate the tour,” Sisodia said in a statement.

“It is a matter of great pride for Delhi government , the teachers and students that first lady Melania Trump is visiting a government school… We would have loved to personally receive her in the school and brief her about the concept of happiness classes and the positive impact it has had on students during her visit to the classrooms,” the statement read.

The US embassy in India had earlier said on Sunday: “While the US embassy has no objection to the presence of CM and deputy CM, we appreciate their recognition that this isn’t a political event and that it’s best to ensure focus on education, school and students.”

Aam Aadmi Party had reportedly alleged on Saturday that both Kejriwal and Sisodia were scheduled to welcome Melania Trump at the south Delhi government school, but their names were dropped by the Centre. The name of the school where Trump will go has not been disclosed, but some Delhi government schools are being decorated.

AAP functionary Preeti Sharma Menon had tweeted about this issue. “There is no match for the pettiness of Narendra Modi. You may not invite Arvind Kejriwal and Manish Sisodia but their work speaks for them,” she had tweeted.

BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra responded to it and said, “There shouldn’t be low-level politics on some issues. India comes under disrepute if we start pulling each other’s legs.”

Title: Trichy: Twelve programmes offered by Sastra University get global accreditation
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Richard Morling, IET accreditor and panel chair for the accreditation visit to Sastra

TRICHY: Twelve engineering programmes offered by Sastra University (deemed-to-be university) have received Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) accreditation - an internationally recognised benchmark awarded to quality engineering and technology programmes.

The university said it was a recognition to its progressive approach to higher education and will allow better international mobility, job prospects and acceptance of students in foreign universities and opportunities for interdisciplinary research. This accreditation has been awarded for a term of five years and apply to 12 graduating batches from 2016 to 2024. In addition to validating the quality of programmes offered, IET accreditation also provides direct benefits to students graduating from Sastra University. “It allows better international mobility, job prospects and acceptance of graduate students in foreign universities and opportunities for interdisciplinary research as well as exchanges,” said a staff.

Richard Morling, IET accreditor and panel chair for the accreditation visit to Sastra, said that the accreditation panel was impressed with the way in which the university team approached IET accreditation. Sastra started preparation in 2014, applied in 2016 and completed the process in 2019.

“I am happy to see that the leadership team is committed to continue improving the quality of their student experience as per international standards,” he said “Nine years for twelve engineering programmes is a massive global recognition for Sastra,” said S Swaminathan, IET coordinator at Sastra University.

Title: Water board’s voluntary scheme fails to deter illegal water connections
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: The Voluntary Disclosure Scheme ( VDS ), which Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) had launched to regularise illegal water connections, has failed to deter the city’s water thieves.

A 90-day long campaign, with the deployment of more than 300 water board officials’ has resulted in only 11,000 requisitions. The water board has fetched Rs 1.5 crore revenue through this scheme.

The VDS scheme was stopped on February 21.

Multiple tasks given to the officials other than this scheme could be a reason for the campaign not doing well in their respective O&M Divisions, water board officials claimed.

In O&M Division-II (part of Old City), areas covering include Malakpet, Moosarambagh, Asmangadh, Yakutpura, Chanchalguda, Bandlaguda and adjoining areas came out on top in implementation of VDS. Here, nearly 3,000 requisitions have been received from the property owners.

“Apart from a massive campaign, we have explained about the registration of criminal cases and imposition of heavy penalties against people having illegal water connections. People scared about criminal cases have come forward to regularise their illegal water connections,” general manager of O&M Division-II, HMWS&SB, P Nagender Kumar told TOI.

Though officials conducted a massive campaign in posh areas like Banjara Hills, they failed to counter water thieves.

Though the VDS scheme has been stopped, the requisitions to regularise the illegal water connections are being accepted. The applicants have to pay double the connection charges, three years-worth of water bills and Rs 300 as service charge, placing an additional burden on the applicants.

Title: Financial crisis: Karnataka government looks to rationalise engineer posts
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

CM BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: Faced with a financial crisis , the government is looking at ways to cut down on expenditure and has trained its focus on "rationalising" manpower, to correct what it believes is largescale "mismanagement" of its workforce.

It is estimated the government spends a staggering 63% of its budget outlay on salaries to its employees — which translates to a total Rs 180 crore a month. A majority of this goes to engineers, some 18,000 of whom are on its rolls, including those attached to civic agencies and boards and corporations.

However, on the other hand, the administration believes there is a shortage of personnel in most departments and continues to hire engineers, each of whom commands a salary anywhere between Rs 75,000 and Rs 1 lakh a month. For example, the PWD department last week put out notice seeking 600 assistant engineers and 300 junior engineers earlier last week.

Mindful of the situation, the state cabinet headed by chief minister BS Yediyurappa , held an informal discussion on the issue last week and proposed a "merger" of posts. The government could bring engineers together under a single department to utilise their services more efficiently.

"While the discussion centred on engineers, it also included a debate on other posts like joint directors in agriculture department and the necessity of regional commissioners in the administrative setup," a senior minister said.

"What is the role of JDs and RCs? It is a total waste of taxpayers’ money and a burden on the exchequer."

The government believes a clean-up is necessary also because ministers and MLAs claim it has become tedious to get work done at constituency level.

"With four or five engineering branches — drinking water, PWD, major irrigation, minor irrigation besides others — at the taluk level, it is hard to get work done. In Bengaluru also, people are confused as to whom to approach since there is the BBMP, BWSSB, BDA etc. A merger may prove fruitful," said another minister, who insisted there is no intention to remove existing engineers.

On a pilot basis, the government is planning to merge engineering divisions of drinking water schemes at the taluk panchayat level and the rural development and panchayat raj (RDPR) department.

However, engineers say such a decision will be detrimental to development.

"Like specialised doctors, we engineers also specialise in irrigation, civil and mechanical works. Any merger will be detrimental," said M Nagaraj, president of Ahimsa, an association of retired and serving government employees from other communities.

Nagaraj also said it will create chaos in promotions as an engineer with five years of service could be ranked above a junior engineer with 20 years of experience waiting for promotion in BBMP.

Title: Follow IAP guidelines to give kids a healthy lifestyle: Doctors
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nagpur: Pediatricians in India have drafted and issued Indian guidelines about unhealthy food in October 2019 after following the international standards and studying local food habits for more than a decade. Now, these recommendations need to be implemented nationwide. Parents, schools and government should come together for this task, said veteran paediatrician Dr Piyush Gupta, president-elect of Indian Association of Paediatrics (IAP) on Sunday.

“Consumption of junk foods, ultra-processed foods, nutritionally inappropriate foods, caffeinated/coloured/carbonated foods and sugar-sweetened food/beverages are rampant in Indian kids. IAP has coined new acronym ‘JUNCS’ for all such foods,” said Dr Gupta, who headed the research team of IAP that issued these recommendations.

“Initially, we recommended a ban on sale of JUNCS foods in school canteens and in near vicinity. We also suggested to ensure availability and affordability of healthy snacks and foods. Support of schools and government authorities is must to do take this further,” he said.

Dr Gupta was delivering the late Dr DG Gan oration organized by Academy of Pediatricians (AOP) Nagpur chapter. He spoke about latest IAP guidelines on junk food, fruit juice and energy drinks. Dr Shubhada Khirwadkar was installed as president while Dr Mustafa Ali as secretary of the AOP Nagpur chapter during this function.

“Not only parents and schools but many paediatricians were unaware about the IAP recommendations issued last year. These guidelines are ideal and most important for good lifestyle of our kids,” said Dr Khirwadkar.

Earlier, Padmashri Dr Rani Bang spoke about responsible parenting in modern era. She appealed the parents to avoid their kids to be a part of rat race. “Winners of rat race will only remain rats and will never become tigers or lions in their lives,” she said.

AOP Patron Dr Uday Bodhankar, president (2019) Dr Ravindra Bhelonde, secretary Mahesh Turale, Maharashtra medical council (MMC) Vice-President Dr Vinky Rughwani, and paediatricians from across Vidarbha attended the event.

Title: Board fears pressure from corporators
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: Though sleuths of vigilance wing of HMWS&SB intensified raids against water thieves, they are worried about pressure from the civic body corporators.

The reason is the ensuing GHMC polls. Though there are six months left to announce GHMC polls, the vigilance wing is predicting increasing pressure on them by the local corporators to not conduct raids.

“So far, we have not received such pressure, but according to IPC, criminal cases are being registered against water thieves when we have identified illegal water connections during our raids,” sources in Vigilance wing told TOI.

Raids were conducted in Old City and posh areas and the board registered criminal cases. But over 60% consumers have come forward and regularised their illegal water connections, said a source. TNN

Title: Lucknow Firing: Firing near Clock Tower, but cops deny link with protest
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Video grab of clash on the Husainabad Road on Sunday

LUCKNOW: Tension ran high on Husainabad Road — a stone’s throw from Clock Tower where women are staging anti-CAA protests — when a man fired in the air during a clash between two groups on Sunday evening.

Police have detained two persons, including an advocate, for questioning and sent the licensed pistol of the latter for forensic examination to determine if the shot was fired from the same firearm.

ACP (Chowk) Durga Prasad Tiwari said the two rival groups, each comprising 7-8 youths, engaged in stone-pelting at a park near Clock Tower.

“One group was led by Kamil and the other by Eraz. The advocate, who was at the protest site, reportedly tried to pacify the warring groups, but nobody paid heed. So, he took out his licensed pistol and reportedly fired a shot in the air,” Tiwari said.

The ACP said that Kamil’s brother Imran and the advocate were being questioned at Thakurganj police station. “We are trying to verify the claim of the advocate that he did not belong to any group. We will initiate legal action after completing the probe,” the officer added.

Police commissioner Sujeet Pandey said the clash and firing had no connection with the ongoing protest at Clock Tower.

An empty shell has been recovered from the spot and the advocate’s pistol sent for examination, he said, adding that there was no need to panic. The firing nevertheless triggered panic among protesters who were reminded of the February 1 incident at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi. “We heaved a sigh of relief later,” said a woman.

As police quizzed the two detainees, a crowd of supporters assembled outside Thakurganj police station. Security was beefed up to avert a law and order situation. Police are also scanning video clips of the clash circulating on social media to identify the troublemakers.

While police said the clash had nothing to do with the Clock Tower agitation, some women protesters claimed the dispute started on Saturday when a few youths stalking some female participants were stopped by another group.

Title: Didn’t want to let go this chance: Jr French champ
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Panaji: Yash Fadte continued to make the best of his last year in the junior circuit as he won the prestigious French Junior Open 2020 in Lille on Sunday.

Exhausted after a gruelling five-setter in the semifinal that lasted for 75 minutes, Yash gathered strength for another epic squash battle as he defeated second seed Marek Panacek of Czech Republic 10-12, 11-5, 11-4, 11-5.

“I was nervous, exhausted as well after difficult games earlier in the championship. But having travelled so far, I didn’t want to let go of this opportunity,” Yash told TOI after his triumph.

The French Junior Open is among the three most prestigious junior tournaments in the world behind British Open and the US Open. While Yash has won the US Open (U-17 category) in the past and missed his flight for this year’s event, he made a quarterfinal exit at the British Open this year.

Yash, 18, is among the world’s top-six best-ranked player. He recently travelled to England for a training stint and has been growing in confidence.

“My ultimate aim is to win the Junior World Championship and I am determined to overcome all the obstacles that might come my way. There is no looking back now,” said Yash, whose father Dilip has been his pillar of strength.

In Goa, the Vasco-based player has received absolutely no support from the government. Despite an assurance from chief minister Pramod Sawant in the state legislative assembly that the Asian junior finalist would be considered for financial support, the government has stayed mum since then.

Earlier in the quarterfinals, Yash accounted for France No. 2 Baptiste Bouin 11-5, 11-7, 12-10 but his biggest challenge was in the last-four clash against the number one Toufik Mekhalfi. Yash dropped the first set against the crowd favourite but eventually had the last laugh as he won 9-11, 11-6, 8-11, 11-7, 11-9 in a match that lasted for more than an hour.

In the final, Yash surrendered the first set again but had enough in the tank to outgun his Czech Republic opponents in the next three sets.

Title: Uthralikavu sample fireworks conducted amid tight security
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The fireworks started at 8.46pm and according to Thrissur district collector S Shanavas, it lasted for five to... Read More

THRISSUR: The sample fireworks display arranged by the Enkakkad wing as part of the famous Uthralikavu Pooram festival was held on Sunday evening amidst tight security.

The fireworks started at 8.46pm and according to district collector S Shanavas it lasted for only five to seven minutes. He said as per the information received by him no excess quantity of explosives were used during the display.

The collector said the Kunnamkulam ACP T S Sinoj and tahasildar P U Rafeeq, who were supervising the fireworks display from the government’s side, had directed the organizers to remove some of the excess quantities of fireworks stocked at the display site. Pollution control board officials, who were monitoring the event, said noise levels were also within the permitted level of 125 decibels. City police commissioner Aadhithya R said nearly 300 police officers were specially deployed to maintain law and order during the event, in addition to the regular deployment.

He said that the police had been directed to provide full support to the revenue officials to ensure that only the stipulated quantities of fireworks were used.

The event was preceded by intense arguments between the organizers and the officials when directives were issued to remove excess quantities. This led to delay in the start of the firework display.

The collector had earlier made it clear that only 20,000 palm-leaf crackers 300 Mathappu, 300 Chinese crackers, 300 Poothiri, and 150 Mazhathiri can be used by each wing during their display. ADM Reji P Joseph warned that potentially hazardous items like Amittu or Kuzhiminni should not be used.

ACP Sinoj said there were no reports of any untoward incident during the fireworks display. The event was held after several days on uncertainty following strict instructions of the collector that it can be held as per the Kerala high court order.

A scintillating Melam was held prior to the fireworks display and was led by Sukapuram Dileep.

Title: Kerala: VACB raids PSC coaching centres over irregularities
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Vigilance and Anti-Corruption Bureau ( VACB ) carried out raids in two private ‘PSC ( Public Service Commission ) coaching centres’ in the state capital on Sunday.

An inquiry was ordered into complaints against a couple of government Secretariat employees for their suspected ownership of the centres and possible influence they might have in the Kerala PSC to leak question papers, including those of the Kerala Administrative Services (KAS) preliminary exams, which was held on Saturday.

Though VACB’s special unit 2 team led by DSP Prasad could not catch any Secretariat employee red-handed during the raids, a fire and rescue department personnel was found giving lectures in one of the centres. The vigilance team, in the coming days, would be conducting a comprehensive inquiry against these government employees and will keep the coaching centres and other branches across the state on its radar, the officials said.

The vigilance inquiry against two Secretariat employees was ordered by general administration department (GAD) principal secretary K R Jyothilal following a request received from the PSC secretary. The PSC’s request for the vigilance probe against the duo employed in the GAD came after a group of candidates lodged a complaint in this regard raising the allegations. The vigilance team carried out the raids at two PSC coaching centres in Thampanoor - Lakshya and Veto – and the fire force personnel was caught from Veto. The VACB will recommend for necessary action against him, a VACB official said.

As per the preliminary evidence collected, one of the centres is owned by a secretariat employee while the other by a close relative of another employee. “There is no clear evidence to show that government employees are giving lectures at these centres, as they are keeping vouchers without names, but with just signatures,” the official said. The VACB, in the coming days, will also examine the assets of the employees against whom the allegations have been raised.

Meanwhile, PSC chairman M K Sakeer told reporters that the Commision will conduct their own inquiry into the functioning of these private ‘PSC coaching centres’ and into the allegations of involvement of government employees. “The PSC stands with candidates and will initiate action against coaching centres which are under the cloud. There will be more investigations in accordance with the complaints we receive,” he said, adding that government officials are not allowed to take coaching classes while in service.
