Title: Donald Trump India Visit: Delhi turns into fortress as Donald Trump comes calling
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Flags being erected at Shanti Path ahead of the visit by US President Donald Trump

NEW DELHI: Lutyens’ Delhi has been brought under unprecedented security cover in the wake of US President Donald Trump ’s visit. ITC Maurya, the hotel where Trump will check-in on Monday evening, has been brought under multiple layers of security cover with anti-sabotage teams from different agencies conducting checks on the routes to be taken by the visiting dignitary.

There will be traffic restrictions in place in the city on Monday and Tuesday. An advisory issued by Delhi Police stated that on Monday evening, traffic in Delhi Cantonment, Delhi-Gurugram Road (NH 48), Dhaula Kuan, Chanakyapuri, SP Marg, Ram Manohar Lohia roundabout, and the adjoining areas is likely to remain heavy.

Necessary diversions as per the ground situation may also be put in place. From forenoon till around 4pm on Tuesday, traffic flow is likely to remain heavy in Moti Bagh, Chanakyapuri, India Gate, areas around ITO, Delhi Gate and the adjoining areas of Central and New Delhi.

Traffic police have urged motorists and commuters to keep these factors in mind while planning their commutes. Travelers have also been asked to check the Delhi traffic police's website and its twitter handle for updates on necessary traffic diversions. Trump will stay till Tuesday night before leaving for the US.

The security agencies, who are working in close coordination with the US Secret Service, have put in place anti-drone detachment of National Security Guard, snipers, elite SWAT commandos, kite catchers, canine units and sharpshooters on highrise buildings. Parakram vans have also been deployed along the routes and areas in and around the hotel where Trump will be staying. Police personnel from six districts and nearly 40 companies of Central Armed Police Forces have been deployed.

Delhi Police personnel said that double barricading has been placed at all roads where Trump's convoy is likely to pass. The aerial surveillance of the route will also be conducted as part of the security measures.

Title: Woman killed, one injured in road accident
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A 27-year-old woman was killed and another woman was injured after a moped they were riding on came under the rear wheel of a tractor near old bus stand road in Ichalkaranji on Friday evening

The case has been registered with Ichalkaranji police.

The deceased has been identified as Monica Shailesh Parik who is a resident of Kalanagar, Ring road, Ichalkaranji.

According to the police, Monica and her friend were riding a moped from their residence to the old bus stand on Friday evening when the accident occurred.

“The duo was riding towards the old bus stand and while they were attempting to overtake a tractor-trolley carrying sugar cane in the same direction, Monica lost control of the moped and it went under the rear wheel of the trolley. Her friend fell on the side of the road. The passers-by immediately gathered at the spot and took the duo to the local government hospital where the hospital authorities declared Monica dead on arrival,” said a police officer.

“The driver of the tractor fled the spot after the accident and we have launched a search operation to nab him,” he said.

Title: Coimbatore: Five information kiosks installed
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

COIMBATORE: The city corporation has installed five information kiosks to ensure healthy interaction with public.

While a kiosk each is installed at Fun Mall, Prozone Mall and Brookefields, two are installed at the corporation zonal office in the south zone.

The kiosks would not just be used as a medium to create awareness about initiatives like source segregation and rainwater harvesting , but also to inform public about projects, like those implemented under the smart cities mission, a corporation official said.

Currently, people can take the ease of living (EoI) survey using the kiosks and watch a video about the projects the corporation is implementing under smart cities mission. Another video is expected to be ready within a week. “We plan to release a video once in 15 days. The interval will be reduced as the projects gain momentum,” the official said.

To ensure two-way communication through the kiosks, the corporation is planning to update the system. “Works are on to create a page to register public grievances and feedback about the services. In future, people will be able to pay taxes through the kiosks,” he said.

The civic body is also planning to install five more kiosks, mostly in corporation zonal offices.

Municipal administration minister S P Velumani had inaugurated the kiosks recently.

Title: Coimbatore: Three detained under Goondas Act for Kabbadi player’s murder
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Three youths, who were arrested on charges of murdering a kabaddi player after he won a match by roping in guest players, have been detained under Goondas Act.

Vijayakumar, 23, of Rajivgandhi Street at Nehru Nagar in Vadavalli, his brother R Kannan, 21, and his friend A Hariharan, 21, of Jothipuram near Periyanaickenpalayam, were jailed last month for murdering K Naveenkumar, 23, of Slum Clearance Board Colony at Ammankulam.

He was stabbed to death by the trio after his team won a kabaddi match, which was organized as part of Pongal celebrations on January 16, with the help of three guest players.

“The same evening, the trio waylaid Naveenkumar, who was accompanied by his friend Logeshwaran, 26, of Highways Colony on Trichy Road, and scolded him for preferring guest players to local youths. As they entered into a heated argument, Vijayakumar pulled out a knife from his pant pocket and stabbed Naveenkumar on his chest and abdomen five times. Logeshwaran also suffered a stab injury to his hand while trying to save his friend. The gang fled immediately after attacking the duo.”

Naveenkumar was rushed to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital , where he succumbed to his injuries on January 18.

The Ramanathapuram police registered a case under Section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code and arrested the trio and a 17-year-old boy, who was lodged in the juvenile home for his role in plotting the crime.

The Ramanathapuram police prepared a detailed report against the trio and requested city police commissioner Sumit Sharan to detain them under Goondas Act. The city top cop on Friday issued an order to detain the three under Goondas Act the order copies were served on them at the Coimbatore Central Prison .

Title: Minister launches online platform for water purity test
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Water resources and irrigation minister K Krishnankutty said drinking water is the right of every citizen and the state government is committed to ensuring this. In one year, 10 lakh more households will get drinking water through pipe connection, said the minister.

He was inaugurating the workshop organized by the socio-economic unit foundation of Unicef and Kerala rural water supply and sanitation agency as part of the Rebuild Kerala Initiative on Thursday. The minister also inaugurated the online platform for water purity test. With the online platform, the government is intending to make available the test results on water purity made by several agencies from each area. This online platform has been developed with the support of Unicef.

The workshop discussed measures for improving the community-based water supply scheme. Jalanidhi executive director Mrunmai Joshi, representatives from Unicef and other officials from the department attended the workshop.

Title: Delhi: Three foreigners in net with 14kg heroin
Content:
Heroin worth more than Rs 60 crore seized from three foreigners who had allegedly smuggled the contraband into... Read More

NEW DELHI: Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) made a huge seizure of over 14 kilograms of heroin worth more than Rs 60 crore and arrested three foreigners who had allegedly smuggled the contraband into the country.The operation led the agency to unearth a new route through which heroin was being sent to Mozambique and South Africa from Afghanistan and then routed to India and other Asian countries. The trail of investigation showed smuggling of more than 100kg of heroin worth Rs 400 crore with similar modus operandi.Rajesh Nandan Srivastava, deputy director general (operations), said that two women from Mozambique were arrested along with the receiver, a native of Ivory Coast based in Greater Noida. “The probe is at an initial stage. Efforts are being made to identify other members of this cartel,” he added.NCB sleuths had received an input about drug cartels exploring new routes to push heroin into the country and zeroed in on the Mozambique route. A few days ago, a trap was laid at IGI airport and two flights from Johannesburg in South Africa were scrutinised.“The two women from Mozambique were intercepted and after a search of their luggage 3.92kg and 5.65kg of heroin, respectively, was seized. The contraband was concealed in the lining of the trolley bags,” zonal director KPS Malhotra said. They were arrested under different sections of NDPS Act.The officials came to know that the receiver of the contraband was based in Sector 106, Greater Noida. A raid was conducted and the Ivory Coast national was arrested with 4.97kg heroin. The search also led to seizure of 20 empty bags whose linings were cut open. The accused man revealed that they were from earlier consignments and each bag held around 5kg of the drug.It was also found that one of the women from Mozambique had visited India in December 2019. “Their interrogation revealed that both had received the trolley bags at Maputo in Mozambique. They took a bus for Johannesburg from where they boarded a flight to India,” Malhotra said.The agency is now trying to trace the network of this cartel in Afghanistan and Mozambique. They have contacted their counterparts in these countries requesting for additions to the information obtained from the arrested smugglers.

Title: Hyderabad: Minor boy stabs 17-year-old over tiff
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A drunk 12-year-old boy allegedly attacked another boy, 17, with a knife when the latter failed to serve him chillies on time in Kompally on Saturday.

Petbasheerabad police said that a minor and his father consumed liquor at Alwal. Later, when they were returning to Kompally, they stopped enroute at Kompally Kaman to purchase snacks at a mirchi vendor.

After the accused placed the order for snacks, the victim allegedly failed to serve the snack in time besides refusing to take a Rs 500 note from the accused.

This angered the accused and he stabbed the victim. The victim was shifted to a hospital,” Petbasheerabad Inspector Mahesh said. The police registered a case under Sec-307 of IPC against the accused. The accused was sent to a state home.

Title: Coimbatore: Corporation to sign new contract with private firm to manage waste
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city corporation is planning to sign a new agreement with the private company that is treating a portion of the solid wastes generated in the city after coming to know that a part of the land at Vellalore it had leased to the company has been taken up for constructing the integrated bus stand.

“We are working to identify the exact portion of the leased area that falls under the area chosen to construct the bus stand. Once the land is identified, we plan to rewrite the agreement signed with the Coimbatore Integrated Waste Management Company Private Limited,” said a corporation official. “The overlapping area would not be more than five cents and has no civil structure, apart from the special school run for the children of those working in the dump yard. It can be shifted as there is sufficient space available adjacent to it.”

The agreement with the company ends in 2026, the official said. “The corporation does not want to make changes in the bus stand design only because of the agreement, which ends in a few years.”

The issue came to light recently after the company was asked to vacate the portion of land to begin construction work. The firm filed a complaint with the corporation office and with the collector’s office. The corporation, in 2008, had leased out 181 acres of land to the company for carrying out the waste management project.

Title: Coimbatore: One killed in Chettipalayam during jallikattu
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

COIMBATORE: What started as a grand celebration ended on a tragic note with one bull tamer being killed in the jallikattu that was held at Chettipalayam here on Sunday. While another one tamer is battling for life in the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH), 15 others are undergoing treatment at various hospitals.

Police identified the deceased as Subash Chandra Bose, 26, of Viralimalai in Pudukottai district. He was knocked down by a bull.

Chettipalayam has been known for motorsports events, thanks to Kari Motor Speedway. But on Sunday, the place in suburban Coimbatore came alive with large crowd flocking to the area to witness a ‘sport’ of different kind – jallikattu.

More than 800 bulls from across the state and as many bull tamers had landed at Chettipalayam for the third consecutive annual jallikattu.

The event was flagged off by local administration minister S P Velumani in the presence of Isha Yoga Foundation founder Sadhguru Jaggi Vasudev and district collector K Rajamani. “The pride of TamilNadu , Jallikattu is a fantastic expression of the natural valour and spirit of adventure of the Tamil Youth. This iconic event should be developed as a wonderful sport with proper rules and attention to safety of all including the animals,” Jaggi Vasudev tweeted after watching the event.

As the bulls were released from the vadivasal one after the other, the adrenaline rush among the bull tamers was palpable as they attempted to cling to the hump of the majestic bulls. Some of the tamers managed to cling to the hump for a while in a symbolic victory over the beast, while several bulls outdid the tamers and went untouched.

But around afternoon, several tamers started suffering injuries. Subash was knocked down by a bull and he was rushed to CMCH, where he died. Sixteen others, who suffered injuries, were sent to a private hospital from where six were referred to CMCH. “The condition of one of them is critical,” police said.

Title: Rajiv Swagruha: Telangana government’s bid plan may fall flat
Content:
Some of the flats which have been vacant for almost 10 years now have become nesting grounds for birds.

HYDERABAD: The state government’s ambitious plan of selling 3,700 flats constructed under Rajiv Swagruha scheme at Bandlaguda and Pocharam to raise revenue may not be successful unless repairs are carried out, civic amenities and other facilities are provided and an attractive package is offered.Earlier, the government had tried to sell the flats to earn over Rs 500 crore but the plan evoked nil response with only one applicant coming forward to purchase a flat. Later, the government decided to sell the flats to government employees at reasonable rates but this too failed to get the employees interested in occupying the houses. Those who had purchased the flats and are staying in the township say that the infrastructure needs to be improved.When this correspondent visited the project site in Bandlaguda near Nagole, security personnel were manning the entrance gates, however, a peep inside the vacant flats revealed their poor condition.Some of the flats which have been vacant for almost 10 years now have become nesting grounds for birds. In some of the flats, the viscera of dead pigeons has dried up and is yet to be cleared. The drinking water supply connection has been disconnected to one of the blocks in Rajiv Swagruha Sahabhavana township in Bandlaguda for non-payment of bills, while kitchen platforms are missing in some of the flats.C Rajender Kumar, manager of Sahabhavana Diamond Classic Flat Owners Welfare Association, said the situation was even worse in C block with the washrooms in the flats having no drainage connection. “Thanks to Rajiv Swagruha Corporation officials, works were taken up and connections have been provided. There is lot of work to be done and the corporation, of late, has taken up several works. But a lot more infrastructure needs to be put in place before the flats are put up for sale,” he said.Mayank Mishra, one of the flat owners, said the houses were good to stay in. “The township, which was once considered to be away from the city, is now in the midst of residential and commercial markets, however, any auction will fetch good rates only if the product is packaged properly,” he said.Telangana Non-Gazetted Officers’ association president Ravinder Reddy said that though the flats were offered to government employees, there were no takers as it was an unfinished product. “Bandlaguda and Pocharam Rajiv Swagruha townships are located between 20 km and 24 km away from Secretariat and most of the government offices in the city. Even the prices offered by the government then were considered too high for flats located far away from the core city. Of course, Bandlaguda is now part and parcel of the city,” he said.

Title: Coimbatore: Water vending machine at Ukkadam a huge hit
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A litre of water is sold for Rs 1 and 20 litres for Rs 7 at the plant. Those customers, who want a 20-litre bo... Read More

COIMBATORE: With more and more customers queuing up in front of the water vending machine run by a self-help group (SHG) at Ukkadam , the district administration is planning to rope in more SHGs.

The city corporation was planning to install 130 vending machines throughout the city. “We were not sure if the women SHG members would survive in the business, considering the huge competition in the water business. That’s why we wanted to implement the project on a pilot basis. Now that the members are doing good business, we are confident that their business would increase further. We are planning to introduce more SHGs in the project,” said a senior official with the Tamil Nadu corporation for development of women.

They are planning to invite five SHGs to manage vending machines in each of the zones, the official said. “Some have shown interest after we conducted talks with them.”

The corporation had inaugurated its first vending machine at the Ukkadam bus stand a month ago. Since then, SHG Thendral Sikana Nanaya Sangam has managed to sell 4,500 litres of drinking water per day.

“We plan to sell potable water to commercial establishments and for weddings and temple festivals, where bulk quantity is required. As of now, we are selling about 200 water cans per day apart from selling about 400 litres – a litre for Rs 1 – at the vending machine. We are hopeful that the business would expand in the coming months,” said S Krishnaveni, leader of the group.

The SHG members are also advertising the project, Krishnaveni said. “We are distributing pamphlets that explains that the project is a government initiative, at commercial spaces and apartments in the city. As a result, we have got some customers from RS Puram. Those who were not ready to buy water from us have started contacting us.”

But the SHG is facing huge opposition from private water vendors. “If we can find some sort of solution to tackle the opposition, we would definitely succeed in our business,” Krishnaveni said.

A litre of water is sold for Rs 1 and 20 litres for Rs 7 at the plant. Those customers, who want a 20-litre bottle delivered at their doorstep, need to pay only Rs 20.

The SHG gets Rs 3 for selling 20 litres at the plant and Rs 12 when delivered at the doorstep. The corporation gets Rs 1 when 20 litres are sold.

Title: Coimbatore: Eight-year-old boy drowns in PAP canal
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: An eight-year-old boy drowned in Parambikulam-Aliyar-Project (PAP) canal near Aliyar here on Friday evening while he was playing with his relatives near the canal.

The Aliyar police identified the deceased as K Kavin, of JJ Nagar at Angalakurichi. He was a Class III student . He is survived by his mother, who is a daily wage labourer, and an elder sister, a Class VII student. His father had died of some illness a few years ago. According to a police officer, the incident took place on Friday (February 21) evening when Kavin and his relatives went to PAP canal near Gopalasamy Puliyankandi Karupparayan Kovil for taking bath.

“He was playing with his relatives when he suddenly fell in the canal and drowned. A few of his kin immediately jumped into the canal to rescue the boy. However, he was washed away in the strong water current.” the officer said.

Title: Born blind, mother of seven-month-old boy gets vision and a new life
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bareilly: A 23-year-old woman, who was apparently born blind and had no hope of seeing in her life, got her eyesight, miraculously, thanks to a team of doctors and medical staff in Bareilly. It was a second life for her as the doctor said that “normally, the success rate in such delayed treatment is not 100 percent”.

Born in a poor family in Azamgarh district and married to a cane farmer Kallu Singh of Chandanpur village, Kanchan had lost all hope of “seeing the world” as her parents and husband had tried to cure her blindness, but without any success. Kanchan, who was blind in both her eyes, spent much of her childhood in solitude. She hardly had any friends. Added to her misery, she has a seven-month-old who is undernourished and requires urgent medical attention. So, the woman admitted her child to a nutrition rehabilitation centre at district hospital in Bareilly. Here, she met staff nurses and dietician who gave her some hope. She came to know for the first time that her “blindness could be cured and she would be able to see after an eye surgery”. On Thursday, she underwent a successful eye surgery, which wasn’t easy, and now she can see for the first time.

Kanchan profusely thanked the doctors and members of the medical team on Sunday. She told TOI, “I am so happy that I can see my son and take better care of him now. I had stopped having any expectations. Also, importantly, I didn’t have to spend money for my surgery. I am grateful to the doctors and nurses who cared for me and my child. My son is also healthy now and we will be discharged from the hospital soon.”

After giving birth to a boy, she was always depressed as she could hardly take care of her child. In fact, she blamed her child’s undernourished condition on her blindness. So, when the couple took their child to the district hospital, they were advised to admit him at the rehab centre. The baby was under weight and malnourished. At the rehab centre, mothers are usually allowed to stay with their child and Kanchan soon developed a good rapport with the staff. Dr Rosy Zaidi, a dietician, checked Kanchan’s eyes and took her to DN Singh, a government doctor. Dr Singh after examining her eyes suggested her to undergo an eye surgery. Following the successful surgery it was a delightful sight to see when her bandage was gradually removed from her eyes.

Eye surgeon Dr DN Singh told TOI, “The woman was blind because of cataract and her treatment could have been done earlier. We have performed cataract surgery with lens implantation which was successful. Normally the success in such delayed treatment is not 100 percent. However, the woman got her eyesight. We may provide advance lens at a later stage to improve her vision.”

Title: Twist in 2019 murder: Prime suspect’s rotting body found
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A CCTV footage of Sunil Kanaujia allegedly carrying his wife Bharti Pandey’s body parts in a bag

LUCKNOW: The March 2019 murder of a woman, whose dismembered body was recovered from different parts of the city, has taken a curious turn with the decomposed body of the prime suspect, her estranged husband, being found floating in the Gomti in January this year.

While a close relative has been able to identify the rotting corpse as that of 32-year-old Sunil Kanaujia from a metal bracelet, police have sought DNA analysis for a confirmed match.

The chopped body of Sunil’s wife, Bharti Pandey (30), was found in two bags 7km apart in Krishnanagar and Para on March 23 and 24, respectively.

Sunil went missing since then. “Last month, we fished out a decomposed body from the Gomti river . Sunil’s brother Anil came to Para police station recently and positive ID’d the body from a metal bracelet on the right hand. We have taken Anil’s blood and samples from the body for DNA analysis,” said Para SHO Triloki Singh.

After Bharti’s body parts were found in a red bag in Krishnanagar, police scanned CCTV camera footage procured from nearby houses and caught a man in the act. His physical features seemed to match with the description of Sunil, an aluminium factory worker in Alambagh.

Inquiries gave a motive to the case. Bharti, who worked at a noodles unit, was allegedly having an extramarital affair with colleague Ashish. Police also found a bloodstained bed linen and sharp-edged tools at Sunil’s house in Para, where the couple lived on rent for a year. Cops concluded that Sunil was the prime suspect, but had no way of confirming it because both he and Ashish went missing.

“Sunil was a native of Malda, Bengal, and married Bharti against the wishes of his parents in 2018. Bharti, originally from Asansol in Bengal, had married twice before. In fact, she came to Lucknow in 2016 with her second husband, but left him to marry Sunil,” SHO Singh said.

The officer maintained that autopsy of the body found in Gomti could not ascertain the exact cause of death because of its decomposed state. “The body has now been sent to a forensic lab for analysis. It will help us determine if the man was killed or he committed suicide,” the SHO added.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao: Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao invited for Trump’s dinner, to visit Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is likely to leave for Delhi on Tuesday to attend a dinner being hosted in honour of US President Donald Trump by President of India Ramnath Kovind.

Rashtrapathi Bhavan has extended invitation to the chief minister to attend the dinner to be held on the night of February 25 at 8 pm.

The chief minister is likely to meet union ministers during his Delhi visit to press the demands on various issues pertaining to the state.

Title: Girl dies of poisoning; kin cry foul, cops say suicide
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bareilly: After a 20-year-old Bareilly girl died of poisoning, her family alleged that she was abducted by unidentified people, taken to Pilibhit, thrashed and forced to consume poison. She breathed her last during treatment in Bareilly on Saturday night. However, Pilibhit police claimed that the girl barged into the marriage venue of her boyfriend in Barlhera area and tried to stop him from tying the knot with another girl. When she failed, she was consumed poison. Police took her to the community health centre before she was shifted to Bareilly.

Sources said Meenakshi Singh was a resident of Tataarpur Samaspur village in Meerganj, Bareilly. Her father had fixed her marriage in Moradabad. On Saturday morning, Meenakshi left for college but did not go there. In the evening, her father, SP Singh, received a call from Pilibhit police that she had taken poison and was admitted in hospital. Singh immediately rushed to Pilibhit and shifted her to a Bareilly hospital where she succumbed late on Saturday night.

Singh told TOI, “I believe that my daughter was abducted by someone and taken to Pilibhit, where she was thrashed and poisoned. My daughter was getting married in April and she did not have any affair with anyone but police there are trying to save the accused.”

Dr RK Gupta, a member of autopsy team in Bareilly, told TOI, “The reason of death is poisoning and there were no external injuries on the body. We have submitted the report to police.”

When TOI contacted SHO Barkhera police station in Pilibhit district, he said, “We will file an FIR once the family of the girl gives acomplaint. When we reached the spot, the girl was lying unconscious and people told us that she had consumed poison after she failed to stop the marriage of her boyfriend.”

Title: Another student held for stabbing in Gomtinagar Extension
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: Another law student was apprehended on Sunday in connection with the murder of Prashant Singh, the 20-year-old engineering dropout who was fatally stabbed in Gomtinagar Extension on Thursday, taking the total number of arrests to three.

Tarun Singh (19), the son of a businessman, was rounded up from his residence in Mahanagar. He studies in the same private university where the victim, his friends and the accused studied or study.

Earlier, Aman Bahadur, son of former BSP MLA, was arrested on Friday and law student Abhishek Pandey nabbed on Saturday.

Additional DCP (East) Amit Kumar said CCTV footage showed Tarun and the others breaking windows of the SUV in which Prashant was seated minutes before he was stabbed.

ACP (Gomtinagar) Santosh Kumar Singh said police were probing who tipped off Arpan about where Prashant was going in SUV. The driver of the vehicle will be quizzed again and a team had been set up to nab the others, the ACP added.

Title: Central sleuths begin probe after made-in-Pakistan live cartridges found in Kerala
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

A cartridge shell with the inscription ‘POF’, allegedly showing its Pakistani origin

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: National Investigation Agency ( NIA ), Military Intelligence and Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) sleuths reached Kollam on Sunday for a preliminary probe into the 14 live cartridges found abandoned at Muppathadi , Madathara near Kulathupuzha on the Thiruvananthapuram-Chenkotta interstate road.

While each team conducted separate probes, the Military Intelligence team led by Major Mukesh examined the cartridges kept at the Kulathupuzha police station and confirmed that they were made in Pakistan. The cartridges, they said, were brought here and abandoned recently.

The primary assumption of the investigators is that the cartridges are made in Pakistan Ordnance Factories (POF) as suggested from the markings on it. Police said the cartridges were made in 1981-82 period and could be used in modern long-range weapons. The investigators also doubt that these cartridges are used by Pakistan armed forces.

Earlier, state police chief Loknath Behera had discussions with police chiefs of other states. “The ATS has been entrusted with the task of probing the matter. Anoop Kuruvila John will be heading the probe,” said Behera. We have informed the central agencies about the incident, he added.

The DGP said he discussed the issue with his counterparts of other states to find out the involvement of any extremist organizations. He said all the possibilities will be probed.

Kollam SP (rural) S Harisankar said there was progress in the probe.

Passers by found the cartridges abandoned on the roadside at Muppathadi, Madathara on Saturday evening. They alerted Kulathupuzha police, who took the custody of the cartridges. There were 14 live cartridges, of which 12 have the marking 72 POF.

Earlier too there were incidents of finding cartridges and explosives from eastern part of Kollam district on the Tamil Nadu border. But there were no serious efforts to nab the culprits. There are allegations of letting loose forces which harboured terrorist Paravai Badusha. Also, there is no headway in the probe against those who planted a bomb at Kollam civil station a few years ago.

Title: Appoint green, legal experts on pollution board: Forum to governor Tamilisai Soundararajan
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Tamilisai Soundararajan

HYDERABAD: The Forum for Good Governance (FGG) has written to governor Tamilisai Soundararajan seeking her intervention in the appointment of an environmentalist to the post of chairpersons of the Telangana State Pollution Control Board (TSPCB) and for filling up the vacant posts of engineers and scientists in the board.

In the letter, FGG secretary M Padmanabha Reddy said, “The PCB’s functions and powers are technical in nature, and the chairperson of the board must have vast knowledge on technical and legal aspects.”

Under Sections of Water Act and Air Act, the eligibility criteria is to be followed for nominating a chairperson for the proper execution of the PCB’s works. “The PCB’s member secretary must have qualifications, knowledge and experience of scientific, engineering and management aspects of pollution control. The incumbent should possess a post-graduate degree in science, engineering and technology and adequate experience of working in the area of environment protection. Persons with scientific, technical or legal background and those from environmental field shall be appointed as board members,” said Reddy.

In 2005, the Supreme Court had issued guidelines stating that PCB chairperson should have a vision. “They must have an understanding of the complexity of modern science and technical sense. They must also understand the law. The chairperson shall fully involve himself in the task of environment construction,” the SC said.

Padmanabha Reddy said that over time, numerous industries, mines and quarries have come up and due to ease of doing business, approvals are granted easily. “These activities require strict monitoring and regular inspection by officers and scientists. Improving environment protection index is a prime duty of the government. All vacant posts should be filled up in PCB,” he said.

Title: S Y Quraishi: Former CEC SY Quraishi says election body attacking him because of political backing
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

SY Quraishi

NEW DELHI: Former chief election commissioner S Y Quraishi , who was recently accused by the Election Commission of “selective amnesia” after he questioned the poll body for not filing an FIR for hate speech in the Delhi assembly polls, has hit back alleging that the EC may have joined the issue with him due to “political backing”.

“It is possible that it is due to political backing. Let me recall that for the past two years, there have been numerous editorials published in newspapers where the EC has been subjected to abuses and criticism. Why doesn’t the EC respond to that first? If attacking their own man clears their conscience, it is fine,” Quraishi said.

The ex-CEC said if the EC had directed filing of FIR in the first set of hate speech cases against BJP’s Anurag Thakur and Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma, the latter would not have dared to repeat the same offence. Verma was barred twice from campaign on account of hate speech.

EC officials were quick to rebut Quraishi’s charge of “political backing”, saying the “insinuation was absurd besides being factually incorrect”.

“EC respects its former functionaries. It was the present commission that started the Sukumar Sen Lecture in memory of the first CEC. It also started a T N Seshan chair at India International Institute of Democracy and Election Management, mentored by ex-CEC N Gopalaswami. EC is willing to take all advice including gratuitous one being doled day in and day out by self-appointed EC spokespersons, that too through the media,” said an official who did not want to be identified.

Title: Self-help groups in Odisha seek technology for mushroom cultivation
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Odisha seek technology for mushroom cultivation

COIMBATORE: Facilitators of self-help groups (SHGs) in Odisha plan to tie-up with a city-based mushroom technology firm as well as other stakeholders here to adopt technology and methods to promote mushroom cultivation .

Sanjay Mishra, the head of a Bhubaneswar-based private firm chosen by the government of Odisha to work as a resource organisation for SHGs, on Sunday visited IVR Mushrooms, founded by Ravi of Ganapathi, to look at the possibilities for a tie-up.

Mishra said they plan to form 100 clusters each of 30 women SHGs to produce mushrooms, which have a good market value. “We plan to implement this in Odisha from April,” he said.

IVR Mushrooms offers solutions to mechanise the process of mushroom production.

The facilitators also plan to collaborate with Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) and educational institutions here. P Kumaravadivelu, head of KVK in Karamadai, said the centre is ready to train SHGs in Odisha.

Title: Bareilly youth caught taking Board exams for younger brother
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bareilly: A youth was booked for appearing in the UP Board High School Examination at the place of his younger brother in Nawabganj tehsil on Saturday.

Acting on a tip-off, Nawabganj sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) Kumar Dharmendra caught the youth, and later, the accused’s younger brother, who had been waiting for him outside the examination centre, was also caught by a flying squad team.

According to police, the accused belonged to Badagaon village in Nawabganj.

Police said the accused had changed the photograph on the admit card of his younger brother with the help of the school staff and appeared in the exam at Shree Krishna Inter Colleg. A student, however, brought the matter to the notice of the school staff, said police.

District inspector of schools (DIOS) Amarkant Singh told TOI, “A student was caught while writing exam at the place of his younger brother by forging the admit card. An FIR has been lodged under relevant sections.”

Nawabganj police station SHO Surendra Singh Pachori said, “We have booked both brothers for fraud. The accused had forged the admit card and attempted to cheat by impersonation. The younger brother is a juvenile, while we are trying to ascertain the age of the elder brother. If he is found to be above 18, then he could be sent to jail.”

“During questioning, the younger brother told us that their family was not aware of their move. He said his elder brother was trying to help him and he had never thought of such consequences,” added the SHO.

Title: 20 new ventilators at GMCH Trauma Centre
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nagpur: Adding to its capacity, the Trauma Centre of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) has received 20 new ventilators on Monday. After calibration, the 90-bed Centre will have life support on 37 beds. A senior doctor at Trauma Centre told TOI new ventilators will be functional in a week.

Trauma Centre at GMCH was started in 2016. It is equipped and staffed to provide care for patients suffering from traumatic injuries like falls and accidents.

Being a joint project of Central and state government, all patients get free treatment here. Emergency patients are getting speedy treatment as the facilities such as intervention radiology, CT Scans, MRI and others are available under one roof. It has two operation theatres, one surgical ICU ward, two ICU wards, and one general ward apart from a drugstore. Additional 20 ventilators will be a major boost for the Centre.

A senior official informed that 17 beds having ventilator support in the Centre always remained occupied. Apart from this, all 90 beds here remain occupied most of the times as the Centre receives patients from Nagpur and other cities and states as well.

As per the data, 4,161 patients were admitted to the Centre in 2019 and 1,218 major surgeries were performed. Average mortality rate of Centre remained under 21% in 2019.

In January 2020, the Centre treated 563 patients and conducted 164 surgeries. Interestingly, 56 of these were neurosurgeries. Mortality rate so far this year is down to 10.83%.

Title: Bareilly: Girl on oxygen support writes Class X board exams
Content:
Safia has been on continuous oxygen support as her lungs are too weak to breathe normally.

Safia Javed with her parents outside the examination centre

BAREILLY: Sixteen-year-old Safia Javed, who has been suffering from lung disease since the past five years and is appearing for the Class X board exams this year, has been granted permission to carry an oxygen cylinder to the examination hall. As she was unable to attend classes regularly, Safia is appearing in the UP Board exam as a private student. She has been on continuous oxygen support since the past one-and-a-half years as her lungs are too weak to breathe normally.Safia’s father, Sarvar Javed, a resident of Shahbad colony in Bareilly , told TOI, “My daughter had always been a class topper but her medical condition deteriorated over the past five years. She was a regular student but had to drop out of the high school exams as her health condition turned critical and she had to be hospitalised. I am sure she will secure excellent marks as she is a keen learner and studies hard.”“All her medical problems started about five years ago after she underwent a surgery for removal of stones from the gall bladder. A year later, she was diagnosed with tuberculosis and she underwent treatment at a private facility and showed signs of improvement but later we came to know that she was suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis. Her lungs often gets filled with fluid and she has to undergo preventive treatment. Doctors at the district hospital have put her on continuous oxygen support. She was bedridden for several months and when she showed signs of improvement she started studying again. Her doctors, the school principal and the teachers at the school have supported us in ensuring that my daughter could write the board exams.”Though Safia is determined to complete her studies, she didn’t tell TOI about her aspirations and only said, “Let time decide.” Her father said, “Safia is my only daughter and eldest among three siblings. I will ensure that she becomes very successful in life and I am willing to spend every penny I have to save her.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Akhilesh’s Dalit outreach to expand Muslim-Yadav combination
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

SP leaders paying tribute to Sant Gadge Maharaj at party office in Lucknow on Sunday

LUCKNOW: At a time when senior leaders of the BSP are quitting the party one after the other and long-term loyalists like Kunwar Fateh Bahadur Singh are revolting against the ‘dominance of Brahmins’ in the organisation, SP president Akhilesh Yadav is silently trying to make an inroads into the Dalit community.

Political observers feel that it is a bid to expand his party’s support base beyond traditional Muslim-Yadav combination in the run-up to the 2022 assembly elections. So, when the the birth anniversary of Sant Gadge Maharaj was celebrated at the SP headquarters in Lucknow on Sunday, it was just another addition to the party’s itinerary full of programmes to honour Dalit icons.

In the past one year, ever since BSP chief Mayawati unilaterally broke the walked out of the alliance with SP forged during the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, the SP has been organising functions in memory of Dalit ideologues like Jyotiba Phule and Chhatrapati Shahuji Maharaj, apart from party icons like Ram Manohar Lohia, Janeshwar Mishra and Karpoori Thakur. On December 6, the party observed the death anniversary of BR Ambedkar. Akhilesh has also instructed the cadre to display portrait of the architect of the Indian Constitution in their offices. Besides, he has also got statues of Ambedkar installed inside the party headquarters in Lucknow.

The effort to win over the Dalit constituency has gone beyond symbolism. Akhilesh has also changed his stance to support the ‘reservation in promotion’ policy of the BSP. He had opposed it during his regime. Besides, he has also been raising issues and concerns of the ‘bahujan samaj’ which was missing in his earlier speeches.

Moreover, despite Mayawati attacking Akhilesh and his party for the failure of the alliance in 2019 general elections, the SP chief has strictly avoided any direct attack on her. “ Akhilesh Yadav has been assiduously befriending Dalits since 2018, even before the general elections by burying the past animosity with the arch-rival BSP. He went the extra mile to forge the alliance and his wife Dimple touched Mayawati’s feet at an election rally,” says LU’s political scientist Ashutosh Mishra.

“It might have cost Akhilesh the 2019 elections, but his subsequent strategy in the past one year through symbolism and ideological compromises could help him in 2022 assembly elections and the traditional hostility of Dalits towards the powerful backward castes, like Yadavs, could be diluted,” he adds.

On the other hand appointing Brahmins to two key positions — leader of the party in Lok Sabha, Ritesh Pandey and Satish Chand Mishra in Rajya Sabha — by the BSP has not gone down well. A number of former MPs and ministers have left the party. Loyalists like Kunwar Fateh Bahadur Singh have questioned Mayawati’s ‘wisdom’ behind ‘Brahminisation of the Dalit party’.

“Akhilesh Yadav is trying to achieve a support base which even his father and SP founder, Mulayam Singh Yadav, couldn’t manage and limiting its appeal among Muslims and Yadavs. It will have to be seen how far successful he is in the next two years before state polls,” says an observer.

SP spokesperson Rajendra Chaudhary told TOI: “Akhilesh wants to fulfill the dream of two great leaders — Ram Manohar Lohia and Baba Saheb Ambedkar — to bring the poor and the vulnerable classes under one umbrella.”

Title: Coimbatore: Three jailed for trying to circulate fake notes
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

COIMBATORE: Three people were arrested for attempting to circulate counterfeit currency notes here on Saturday night. Police have seized from them fake notes with a face value of Rs 3.24 lakh.

A source with the Saravanampatti police station said S Kidhar Mohammed, 66, of Vadvalli and D Mahendran, 39, of Kavundampalayam were spotted near a petrol pump near Maniyakaranpalayam on Saturday night by a team led by sub-inspector P Suresh. “When we inquired with them, they gave contradictory statements. We then checked their bags and found counterfeit currency notes.”

The team took them to the police station, where they interrogated the duo .“They told us that the fake notes were printed by E Suryakumar, 32, of Thiruvalluvar Nagar on Thadagam Road, and that they were attempting to circulate them in shops. The two were carrying 300 fake notes of Rs 200 denomination each in two bags,” the source said.

Police subsequently conducted raid at Suryakumar’s house at Thiruvalluvar Nagar and seized counterfeit currency with a face value of Rs 2.64 lakh, printers, computers and scanners.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that Suryakumar was running an e-service centre at Kanuvai area. “As the business ran into huge losses, he approached Kidhar Mohammed, who was arrested for circulating counterfeit currency notes. Suryakumar learned from him the art of making fake notes and struck a deal with him and Mahendran to circulate them.”

Title: Fish exports: Fears prompt awareness drive
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: Aiming to sustain Indian fish export to the US, the European Union (EU), China, and Japan, the Marine Products Export Development Authority (MPEDA) and National Fisheries Development Board (NFDB), Hyderabad are taking up initiatives to spread awareness among aquaculture farmers.

The move comes in the wake of zero tolerance policies towards antibiotic residues in cultured shrimps by US and EU.

“In an attempt to improve fish exports, as part of the Blue Revolution, we are working on strict implementation of the norms to stop overdose of antibiotics,” said a senior executive at NFDB. “Meanwhile, we are also making sure that the stakeholders understand the risk of being blacklisted for a shipment with high residue of antibiotic substances.”

Agencies in the fisheries sector have decided to launch massive awareness campaign among aquaculture farmers.

Title: Relief for Bandhan Bank promoters?
Content:
Representational photo.

NEW DELHI: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) may offer a breather to Bandhan Bank to dilute its promoter holding after allowing another private lender Kotak Mahindra Bank time to reduce the holding of its promoters, while capping their voting rights.“RBI is looking to address the issue in a comprehensive manner in the coming days,” a source familiar with the discussions told TOI. The move is seen to be crucial to bring regulatory parity.The RBI’s bank licence rules mandate that promoters of private banks need to reduce their shareholding to 40% within three years, 20% in 10 years and pare it to 15% in 15 years.Currently, Bandhan Bank promoters hold 61% stake in the lender. Last September, RBI had disallowed the lender from opening new branches as it was not able to bring down the shareholding of non-operative financial holding company to 40%, which was prescribed in the licensing conditions. In addition, the regulator had ordered a freeze on the salary of the bank’s managing director and CEO Chandra Shekhar Ghosh. As a result, the new private sector player is stuck with a franchise of 1,094 branches across the country after a fast pace expansion in the initial five years of its operation.At the time of regulatory action, the promoter’s holding was estimated at over 82%, which subsequently came down following the merger of Gruh Finance, HDFC’s affordable housing finance arm.RBI special dispensation for Kotak Mahindra Bank, which got a licence in 2003 and was to reduce promoter holding several years ago, came after the lender dragged RBI to court in what was a rare move in the Indian banking sector where the banking regulator’s decisions are usually not challenged by entities that come under its purview. At the heart of the dispute was the bank’s plan of August 2018, when it had proposed to issue perpetual non-cumulative preference shares (PNCPS) to cut promoter holding to 19.7%, but it failed to convince RBI.The new stake dilution plan for Kotak Mahindra Bank promoters comes with a cap on voting rights. The “deal”, finalised by RBI last week, requires MD & CEO Uday Kotak to sell his 4% stake by August.

Title: GHMC appoints nodal officers for literacy survey
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) on Sunday appointed deputy commissioners as nodal officers for the purpose of conducting a survey to enumerate literacy rate in the city from February 24 to March 4.

The survey is being conducted by the Urban Community Development (UCD) wing of the GHMC under the ‘Each One Teach One’ initiative, following chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s call to achieve 100% literacy in the state at a conference on Tuesday.

The exercise will be taken up in all 150 wards of the GHMC and the nodal officers will assume the role of supervisors and prepare a fact sheet with details such as number of localities and households and approximate population to be covered under the survey. “Residential colonies, apartments, commercial areas and gated communities will be covered,” said Hyderabad Mayor Bonthu Rammohan.

As per the GHMC records, around 24,78,000 families constituting 97,97,000 people are residing in the city. For the survey, 8,681 enumerations have been drafted and each enumerator will cover around 250 to 300 households during the 10-day survey. The survey will be conducted from 7 am to 11 am.

Title: Kerala: Hi-tech labs to aid English learning
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Kerala Infrastructure and Technology for Education ( KITE ) has launched E3 (Enjoy, Enhance & Enrich) English, an ambitious project for enhancing and enriching the English language proficiency of students by making use of hi-tech lab facilities in schools.

“The project aims to enhance and enrich English learning of students in an enjoyable atmosphere effectively making use of technology in schools in Kerala,” said K Anvar Sadath, CEO , KITE.

The three-pronged project has three components. The first is Samagra e-Library, a digital repository of international standard digital books. The books will be available to all students in four levels. The books will be available to students in audio and video formats too. Already 200 digital multicoloured story books were uploaded to Samagra e-Library.

The second is e-Language lab, which will have language lab software that will provide opportunities for students to enhance their listening, speaking, reading, writing, pronunciation, grammar and vocabulary. Students can work in e-language lab alone with the support of the mentor teacher at their own pace of learning. KITE has already customized the engine for language lab by using Free and Open Source Software.

The third component, e-Broadcast, includes multimedia programmes. The broadcast lessons will help learners use English in conversational and academic contexts in an interactive mode. This shall also be screened in KITE Victers channel.

KITE has planned to provide training to all primary and upper primary teachers during mid-summer vacation for implementing E3 English in schools. E3 English teacher training will be a technology integrated training providing hands on experience to teachers on using Samagra e-Library and e-Language lab. Along with KITE, SCERT will do the academic monitoring of the project. The director of general education will monitor the implementation of the project in schools by teachers.

Title: Coimbatore: Defence innovation hub work set to begin soon
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Codissia Defence Innovation

COIMBATORE: With the Union government approving the detailed project report for the Codissia Defence Innovation and Atal Incubation Centre last week, the construction work of the centre will begin in May-June, said representatives of the Coimbatore District Small Industries Association (Codissia).

President of Codissia R Ramamurthy, at a session on defence indigenisation recently, informed about the development. He also said Codissia had transferred Rs 2.34 crore to the escrow account meant for the project last week.

In January 2018, the defence ministry granted Codissia Rs 20 crore for setting up a defence innovation centre. Of this, Rs 15 crore was for the innovation centre and Rs 5 crore was a soft working capital for innovating products. Later, after interactions, Ramamurthy said, the project was clubbed with the Atal Incubation Centre, through the Innovations for Defence Excellence (iDex) scheme.

The projected cost of the centre is Rs 45 crore. Codissia and the Atal Incubation Mission will invest Rs 10 crore each in the centre, which will come up at the Codissia Industrial Park near the city. Codissia will also invest another Rs 5 crore for land and building.

“In a week’s time, we expect the Centre to transfer Rs 2.34 crore. Another Rs 5 crore will likely be available with Codissia when the project work begins,” he said.

Ramamurthy said, in a recent meeting with officials from the defence ministry in New Delhi, the officials assured to discuss the project in a board meeting with defence production wing in two weeks. “We expect the ministry to sanction Rs 15 crore granted for the the innovation centre. With a nod from the Centre, we will start ordering machines using the grant,” he said, adding that a building plan for the centre was getting ready for an approval and mostly in May or June the construction work would begin

Besides, Codissia is in contact with defence forces on different works that they could pursue once the centre start functioning, he said.
