Title: Secunderabad: GHMC to take up road widening work around Moulali Kaman
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Development work around Moula Ali arch will be taken up at Rs 4 crore budget

SECUNDERABAD: In order to facilitate better flow of traffic between Kushaiguda and Tarnaka via the Moula Ali kaman (arch), the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) has decided to widen the abutting road.

Over the years, travelling through the archway became inconvenient as the narrow thoroughfare turned to be a bottleneck for larger vehicles such as buses, ambulances and trucks. Owing to this, motorists plying from Kushaiguda have to travel an additional four kilometres to reach Tarnaka via Housing Board Colony, ZTC and Lalapet flyover instead of directly coming through the archway.

“The road passing through the arch is so narrow that at a time, only one car or couple of two-wheelers can pass. The bottleneck leads to heavy traffic in the area. No ambulance, RTC or school buses, trucks can use the Moula Ali kaman road,” said Mohammed Imtiaz Raheem, owner of a hardware shop in the area.

To improve the traffic conditions in that area, the GHMC has decided to develop a 30 feet two lane-slip road on both sides of the arch. This will enable authorities to lay roads without demolishing the structure and simultaneously restoration works could also be taken up.

“We recently issued notices to 33 properties for land acquisition to take up the road widening works around the arch. Of the 33 properties, 17 have consented to accept the compensation. Once all the land is acquired, we will widen the road around the arch,” said Srinivas Reddy, GHMC zonal commissioner, Secunderabad .

The GHMC will take up the road widening work at a cost of ₹4 crore of which ₹2 crore is likely to be disbursed as compensation to property owners and the rest will be used for development work.

The 250-year-old Moula Ali kaman was built as a pathway to Moula Ali Dargah during the reign of the Qutb Shahi. The Nizams of Hyderabad are known to have taken out processions through the archway while visiting the shrine.

Title: Coimbatore: Textile association chants management mantras
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The federation is also planning to provide leadership training to managers and supervisors.

COIMBATORE: The Indian Texpreneurs Federation (ITF), which has 450 members in the state from across the textile value chain, has zeroed in on four core areas — integration, sustainability, financial restructuring and leadership skills — based on a research. It would apply these to improve overall business performance of textile industry in the state in the financial year 2020-21, ITF convener Prabhu Dhamodharan said.

The core areas were decided based on a research ITF did along with research firm Crisil Limited. While the association members are practising concepts such as sustainability and leadership training, they seek to increase participation in the next fiscal.

Value-addition is the way forward for the textile industry, Dhamodharan said. “The pressure on standalone spinning mills is higher than that on integrated or semi-integrated textile units. Of the 87 lakh spindles units represented in the federation, only 20% are integrated. It’s the right time for standalone spinning companies to move up the value chain to make value-added finished products. For this, ITF would set up an advisory cell with industry and external experts to guide members to step into integration and make high value-added products to improve their financial performance.”

Speaking of sustainability, the official said the State is leading in areas such as zero liquid discharge and the use of green energy. “Power accounts for 10% of the yarn cost. We are planning to bring down energy consumption. Ten ITF members have GreenCo certification and seven have Higg Index. We plan to triple these numbers,” he said.

However, many textile firms couldn’t afford the measures due to working capital crunch, said Damodharan. “We have requested the ministry of textiles for a one-time financial restructuring. This includes converting of working capital loans as long-term loans in account of non-availability of working capital, a moratorium of two years and infusion of new working capital.”

The federation is also planning to provide leadership training to managers and supervisors. “We had trained 400 managers and supervisors at the ITF Leadership Academy last year in areas such as communication skills, emotional intelligence, innovation and creativity. As a result, teamwork has become better. We plan to train 1,000 more managers and supervisors from textile firms in the coming financial year.”

Title: Jumbos from Nepal ruin houses, destroy crops in Pilibhit village
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Pilibhit: More than six months after two wild tuskers from Nepal strayed from their usual path, trampling crops and killing five people in Rohilkhand region, some wild elephants have again crossed the Indo-Nepal border into Pilibhit district and are currently foraging for food at Gorakhdibbi village.

According to villagers, one adult jumbo from Nepal was spotted at Gorakhdibbi village six days ago. Later, it was joined by two more elephants. These pachyderms have so far smashed as many as nine thatched houses and destroyed over seven acres of standing wheat crop.

This is the third time that the village has faced destruction by wild elephants in less than one year. Besides, the wild jumbos from Nepal usuallly cross the border in September-October, during the kharif season.

Villagers claimed they were yet to receive any help from either the forest department or district administration and all they have is a small quantity of crackers. By bursting crackers, they can keep the elephants away only for a short time. At the same time, they fear that the sound may infuriate the elephants and they may attack the villagers.

Gorakhdibbi, a hamlet of Nagari Khurd Kalan village panchayat under Kalinagar tehsil is situated on the edge of Lagga Bagga forest region of Pilibhit Tiger Reserve and Royal Shukla Phanta Wildlife Reserve in Nepal. The Lagga Bagga area is an elephant corridor that has been used by the pachyderms since time immemorial, said experts.

Deputy director of PTR Naveen Khandelwal said a major part of the land of Gorakhdibbi and neighbouring villages actually belongs to the forest department. This land was illegally allotted on lease to a number of villagers by the revenue department way back in 1955 and 1960. They were displaced from their original villages in what is Uttarakhand today in lieu of their land acquired for construction of the Nanak Sagar dam on river Devha in Udhamsingh Nagar district.

“In the real sense, the jumbos retreat to their own corridor which has now been transformed into agricultural fields. The department is fighting a legal battle in the high court to get the forest property concerned back into its possession,” he said.

Meanwhile, Paritosh Chandra Rai, husband of pradhan Champa Devi Rai of Nagaria Khurd Kalan, said the elephants had devoured and ruined over seven acres of standing wheat crop. “The elephants take rest on the banks of river Sharda and in the jungles of Lagga Bagga during daytime and barge into the village at night. They have smashed nine houses, leaving the inmates homeless,” Rai added.

“The residents here are spending sleepless nights as the jumbos silently infiltrate the village area at night. We are worried about our safety,” said Rai.

Two residents, Khargai Lal and Dineshwar Bairagi, told TOI that a team of forest department had visited the village on Saturday but left after spot inspection without making any efforts to push the elephants back into the jungle.

Title: Will allow old NPR format in Bihar: CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar

DARBHANGA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar said on Sunday that the National Population Register ( NPR ) will be implemented in the state in its old format as in 2011 Census. He reiterated that the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC) will not be implemented in Bihar .

While laying the foundation stones for schemes worth Rs79.09 crore at the regional centre of Maulana Azad National Urdu University (MANUU) in Chandanpatti under Hayaghat block in Darbhanga district, Nitish recalled the contributions of Maulana Azad in the freedom movement. He should be respected and remembered like Mahatma Gandhi. Azad was instrumental in spreading education in the country. Bihar government celebrates his birthday as Education Day since 2007 and now this is taking place in the entire country, he said.

The foundation laying schemes included 100-bed girls’ hostel at MANUU, polytechnic college to be constructed at the cost of Rs3.13 crore, boys hostel with Rs3.96 crore, 100-bed hostel with an estimated outlay of Rs4.24 crore in Madrassa Rahmania Afzal located in Biraul block.

Nitish also visited the stalls put by the district administration and handed over cheques to the beneficiaries of Student Credit Card, Mukhyamantri Shram Shakti Kaushal Vikas Yojana and Alpsankhyak Rozgar Rin Yojana. He praised the students of MANUU regional centre for implementing the Jal-Jeevan-Hariyal Abhiyan on the campus. He also said if this centre needs expansion, its VC should approach the government and additional land would be provided for that.

The CM further said his government has constructed 21,000 primary schools and added 3 lakh classrooms in the existing schools. Nitish further said his government has done a lot for the education of minority community students through providing different facilities in madrassas in the state.

Title: Woman, son among four arrested for killing husband
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bareilly: A woman and her son were among four arrested on Sunday in connection with the murder of a bus driver, 46, whose body was found abandoned in a roadside ditch under Asmauli police station limits in Sambhal on February 18.

Police claimed that victim Rakesh Kumar Ruhela’s wife, 43, had hatched a conspiracy, along with her paramour and son, 22, to kill her husband.

According to police, Ruhela, a resident of Double Fatak area in Moradabad, was an alcoholic and used to beat up his wife and son after getting drunk. Around seven months ago, he had rented a portion of his house to Shane Alam, who allegedly developed illicit relationship with his wife, said police, adding that the accused would be produced in a court on Monday.

Additional superintendent of police Alok Kumar Jaiswal said the autopsy report revealed that the driver was strangled. “Based on suspicion, we detained Alam, who confessed his crime during interrogation,” said the ASP.

“According to Alam, the driver’s wife and son were frustrated with his behaviour, and after he developed an intimate relationship with the victim’s wife, they decided to eliminate her husband. On February 17, Alam took Ruhela for booze where Alam’s friend Sonu Massy was already present. Both the friends strangled Ruhela and dumped his body,” said the ASP.

The ASP added that an FIR under sections 302 (murder), 120B (criminal conspiracy) and 201 (Causing disappearance of evidence of offence) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) was lodged against the four accused, who had been arrested.

Title: Two men held in Sambhal for killing girl for ‘honour’
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bareilly: In a suspected case of honour killing, a Haryana police team on Saturday arrested the victim’s father and brother in UP’s Sambhal district for allegedly killing her for marrying a boy of her choice against her family’s wish. The duo has confessed to their crime, police claimed.

Deepa, 21, of Allipur Bujurg village under Baniyather police station, had eloped with her beau Virendra Kumar, 24, of Amroha, some 10 months ago. They couple got married in Faridabad in Haryana. The two were distant relatives.

After some time, Deepa’s family learnt about the couple’s whereabouts and reached there. They assured the couple that they had accepted their decision but wanted to host a wedding function for them,

Believing them, Deepa returned home to Sambhal on May 16, 2019.

After reaching Sambhal, Deepa’s father, Veerpal, and uncle, Ramesh, allegedly killed her and secretly cremated her in an agriculture field, police said.

Unable to contact his wife, Kumar approached police and lodged an FIR at BGTP police station in Faridabad on January 20. On his complaint, Veerpal, Ramesh, Bulla and Ram Bahadur Giri were booked under IPC sections 365 (kidnapping), 452 (house trespass), 506 (criminal intimidation), 302 (murder), 120B (criminal conspiracy) and 34 (acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention).

Police said during interrogation, Veerpal and Ramesh confessed that they had strangled Deepa and cremated the body.

Title: Learning from past, Metro tweaks contracts to ensure speedy work
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

ON TRACK: Metro rail believes the new contracts will help it meet deadlines

CHENNAI: After terminating contracts with four companies involved in the construction of phase-1 and phase-1 extension lines of metro rail, Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) is tweaking its contracts with firms to ensure faster construction of the 118.9km phase-2 lines. The changes made in the contracts will help avoid additional cost of both the contractors and CMRL.

Wiser after building the 45km phase-1 over 10 years, CMRL thinks the new clauses would allow it to offload work from companies that are likely to not meet deadlines and, also keep a tab on contractors to avoid diverting metro rail funds for other projects they may be involved in. Revising clauses in construction contracts come at the time when CMRL has started floating tenders for building tunnels for a portion of the phase-2 lines. Amending the guidelines is crucial as it will be awarding contracts to several companies. It plans to split the lines into portions and float tenders, unlike in phase-1 where big stretches were given to a single firm for construction.

So far, tenders to build twin-tunnels between Kellys and Taramani Road covering 12km and a 9km line from Venugopal Nagar to Kellys have been floated. Awarding work on small stretches in phase-2 to firms also means that construction would not be affected on the entire corridor if work on a portion gets delayed.

A CMRL official said the option to offload work from one contractor, who may have a poor pace of construction or have other deficiencies, to another company involved in the same project at an already fixed rate, was introduced in phase-1 extension. This prevented loss of time on calling for new tenders to find a contractor.

“The clause made us work comfortably without the fear of time overrun. With a notice to the contractor, we can offload a particular work,” an official said. “We mostly offloaded those crucial areas of work that need to be finished on priority and hand it over to other contractors for further work such as installation of signals, communication systems and electrical work.”

The tweaks made to the contracts worked in favour of CMRL when it had to terminate the contract with IL&FS Transportation Networks Limited (ITNL) due to delay in construction of two underground stations at Sir Theagaraya College and Korukkupet. “We offloaded cut-and-cover work and gave it to one of our other contractors a year ago. Three months ago, we gave some portions of Theagaraya College station to another contractor. When we saw they were struggling with severe cash crunch for months and that work was slow, we didn’t have an option but to end their contract,” said another official.

CMRL officials said they ended contracts with four major companies involved in the construction of 45km phase-1 and 9km phase-1 extension, which included ITML KMB JV, Gammon MMS Devi, CCCL and Lanco. “Termination of contracts also meant we won’t be doing business with them anymore,” the official said.

Construction of a major portion of the underground line on Anna Salai was stalled for nearly a year after a Russian contractor abandoned work citing financial crisis. CMRL floated new tenders and awarded contract to companies to get the line ready for operations. Floating a fresh tender and awarding contract for an incomplete work takes time and new contractor may need time to procure equipment and materials. A metro rail official said they have brought in other changes like opening a common bank account to monitor use of funds by contractors and releasing of mobilisation funds in instalments to ensure contractors complete work on time.

“Earlier we released 10% of the funds at one go. We realised 10% is not required at the same time, so we decided to transfer it in three instalments. After the first instalment, they have to show us the progress before we release the rest of the money. If they don’t perform, we have a clause to encash their bank guarantee. The contractor cannot use the surplus money without completing the work,” the official said. “We also conduct checks every four months to ensure the company is not diverting funds.”

Title: Decision on appointment of T BJP chief soon
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: A decision by the BJP high command on appointing a new BJP president for the Telangana unit or continuing with incumbent K Laxman is likely to be finalised by month-end. The BJP has deputed two central observers to hold consultations with the party’s core committee members in the state and other senior leaders to take a call on the change of guard in the BJP Telangana unit. The two central observers will likely visit Hyderabad on Monday. tnn

Title: Parties, BCs to demand extension of SC/ST quota
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: Members of political parties, BC welfare associations and civil society organisations on Sunday unanimously decided to exert pressure on the state and Centre to ensure reservations for SCs and STs are continued without amendments.

It was also decided to demand the state and central governments to extend reservations to the backward classes in proportion to their population.

To achieve this, it was decided that support of various political parties in every state and at national level will be mobilised, meetings will be held and legal course of action will be taken.

Telangana Congress working president J Kusum Kumar, TDP state president L Ramana, Telangana BC Welfare Association president Yerra Satyanarayana, Congress MLC Ramulu Naik, national BC Welfare Association chairman R Krishnaiah, Samajwadi Party state chief Simhadri, Congress MLA T Jayaprakash Reddy among others were present at the meeting.

Title: Nagpur: Creative minds make fine items from waste
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bharatanatyam dancer by Manoj chopade

NAGPUR: Children learn how to make best out of waste in schools. But city-based artists and painters took the concept to a high level with creative minds making some of the finest pieces of art at a workshop organized by South Central Zone Cultural Centre (SCZCC).

The centre has come up with an innovative idea where scrap and unnecessary items in various organizations and offices are collected to make the best out of waste. The workshop titled ‘Scrap workshop’ is being conducted at SCZCC from February 22 to 28. Students and artists are showcasing the best of their ability to make beautiful items.

Milind Limbekar, a painter and artists, has taken the challenge of making a huge selfie point with the help of scrap wood. “I am working on making a big selfie point which will reflect Nagpur oranges, horses at Zero Mile and many more. It was a bit difficult to do wooden work, but the process was enjoyable,” he said.

Manoj Chopade, another artist participating in the workshop, has made a feminine figure of a Bharatanatyam dancer. “I have used complete metal scrap to piece the figure together. I have added details of pleats of the dress and posture of the dancer,” he said.

Raw and scrap material such as halogen lights, metal sheets and spotlights are provided to the artists who are making the best of it. “I have made a kinetic sculpture for which I used medium metal scrap material. It’s a great opportunity for local artists to show talent through the art,” said Shekhar Tandekar.

Students of the department of fine arts are helping these artists and also learning the skills of making such humongous objects with precision. “It’s been a very productive workshop as we are helping the artists. We are learning new things each day,” said Nilesh Varbhe, a student of fine arts.

Shashank Dande, programme officer at SCZCC, is coordinating the event with Muktadevi Mohite, head of the department of fine arts. Scarp material is provided to the artists.

Dande said, “It is a great opportunity for the students of the department of fine arts as they are spending quality time learning and understanding the art. Artists have teams of students and helpers who are looking after welding and arranging,” he said.

“The workshop aims to educate citizens about the beauty of transforming waste material into eye-catchy creative art objects. Scrap material was collected and provided to the artists whose creative minds instantly began the process of making the best out of it,” said Mohite.

Title: Venkaiah Naidu: Students should study in their mother tongue
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

M Venkaiah Naidu

WARANGAL: Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu on Sunday said that students should study in their mother tongue .

While inaugurating the three-day platinum jubilee celebrations of Andhra Vidyabhi Vardhini (AVV) institutions in Warangal, Naidu said, “Centre and state governments should make it mandatory that to get employment in a state, a person should learn the local language of that state.

He said people like former President, late Dr APJ Abdul Kalam studied in native language.

Naidu also said that Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is giving priority to Telugu and simultaneously supporting education in English language so that students get better employment opportunities.

He said teachers should also instil moral values in students for development of the society and well-being of the nation. The Vice-President said that he is happy that Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University (JNTU) has introduced a subject on moral values.

Emphasising on upholding democratic values, he said every public representative must maintain discipline, and not follow the path of destruction. If they do not agree with the government, they should stage a peaceful walkout the house. He advised the youth and children to maintain character and develop their skills. He said they should not use caste as a weapon.

Title: PMPML plans jingles & advertisements to improve ridership
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The PMPML is planning a series of jingles and advertisements on the television and radio to improve its ridership, which has more or less remained stagnant for almost a decade now.Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) CMD Nayana Gunde said the transport utility currently had many new buses in its fleet and its efforts to make things better were yielding better.“We feel that it is high time that the PMPML did something out of the box to properly market its services and encourage commuters to use the buses. The initiative — jingles and advertisements — is a part of it,” Gunde told TOI.Te advertisements would be on various television and radio channels. “The advertisements will be both entertaining and informative in nature. We will inform people about the PMPML and the number of buses in the past and the present operating daily. A strong point of the PMPML is its electric buses, which are doing a fairly good job. These e-buses will be highlighted in the advertisements too. The results, we hope, will be good,” she said.“The advertisements and jingles will also talk about the city’s pollution levels and encourage people to use buses more to reduce the load of private vehicles on the road. We recently had the ‘bus day’ and more than 1,800 of our vehicles were on the road that day. The ‘bus day’ will now be a regular feature every month. Work is on to ensure that the number of buses gradually increases on the road,” Gunde said.A PMPML official said the transport utility has around 125 e-buses and the vehicles have not yet suffered from any kind of breakdowns. “This year is crucial, as more buses will be added to the PMPML fleet and the Pune Metro services are also likely to start. The PMPML needs to have a proper marketing plan in place under such circumstances,” the official said.Experts and commuters have been raising concerns over the breakdowns of the PMPML buses . “The number of breakdowns has been less compared to what was in earlier years. At present, PMPML-owned buses are witnessing around 60 breakdowns a day. On the other hand, around 70 buses of private contractors are witnessing daily breakdowns,” PMPML traffic manager Anant Waghmare said.

Title: Purnia women icon of ‘new India’: PM Narendra Modi
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

PATNA: It was a proud moment for the women’s self-help group (SHG) in Purnia district of the state as PM Narendra Modi on Sunday hailed their skills and efforts of producing silk saris for the high-end market. Defying the past, they are weaving saris with yarn produced from cocoons of silk worms grown on mulberry trees that they cultivated with eyes set on making high income.

The PM, in his 62nd edition of Mann Ki Baat delivered on Sunday, described their venture as an example of “new India” that has been unfolding in the country, when skilled women have been coming forward for not only their empowerment, but also for highly imaginative economic activities. The PM described it as “kamaal” (very exceptional). Women members of the SHGs formed under the rural livelihood project under implementation in the state are called ‘didis’ (sisters).

“The ‘didis’ of Adarsh Jeevika Mahila Mulberry Production Group (in Purnia) have achieved something that can be called ‘kamaal’. Its impact is being felt in other villages, too,” Modi said, adding: “Several farmers and ‘didis’ are now not only getting silk saris woven, but are selling them from stalls in big fairs.”

PM Modi also recounted his experience at Delhi Hunar Haat last week, where he went around the stalls from various states, but the stall of the Adarsh Jeevika Mahila Group from Purnia and the “exceptional” story of its women members drew his attention.

At Delhi Hoonar Haat, he also relished Bihar’s famed ‘litti-chokha’ delicacy that has also begun to get popular even with the high-end restaurants, including in Mumbai. However, he selected the SHG from Purnia for the special mention, a district that he had also visited during the 2016 floods.

“This is the same region that has faced the calamity of flood for centuries. In such a situation, mustering resources for income by way of farming and other avenues has been a very difficult proposition. But, some women from Purnia charted out a different path,” the PM said.

He noted that they formed an SHG, started cultivating mulberry trees, grew silk worms on them, prepared silk yarn from their cocoons, and finally started weaving silk saris for the high-end market. “Earlier, women from this locality used to grow silk worms on their mulberry trees from cocoons for which they used to get a very nominal price, when purchasers of the same cocoons used to earn very high profits by making silk yarn from them,” the PM said.

“But today, women of Purnia have made a new beginning and have changed the picture completely. You will be surprised to know that the same women … are now getting thousands of rupees on the ‘saris’ that they weave,” he said.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Wife, son among four arrested for killing man in Sambhal

This story is from February 24, 2020

Title: Chennai Airport: Plan to get more cabs at airport stalled
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Taxis operated by a cooperative from the airport are expensive

CHENNAI: Hiring a cab has become a hassle for passengers who arrive at Chennai airport yet again.

After Ola’s contract got over by the end of January, passengers who arrive have to book cabs using apps as counters run by the aggregator are no longer available. Domestic passengers who have apps on their phones hail cabs, but those who do not, have to depend on the black-and-yellow taxis operated by drivers’ cooperative. But these taxis are expensive. International passengers who have heavy luggage have no option but to depend on touts.

Airport Authorities of India’s (AAI) attempt to rope in more cab aggregators is getting delayed. This has led to chaos in front of the international and domestic arrival terminals. The black-and-yellow taxis are not able to handle the crowd because the drivers cooperative, which has a counter outside the terminals, has only around 100 cabs at its disposal.

Since the only licensed app-cab operator has exited, there is no restriction for any cab company from entering the lane infront of the terminals to pick up passengers. Still, passengers have to walk to the parking lot to board the cabs.

Sources said AAI should try to rope in more cab operators by charging a fee rather than going for a tender which makes the operator to pay a licence fee in crores to bring their cabs to pick up passengers.

“The airport does not have its own transport policy for passengers who want to hire cabs from the arrival terminals. Only a premium operator with limited number of cabs has a counter at the terminal. Private airports have a fee system by which they allow multiple cab operators to pick passengers from terminals,” said an official.

The tender system might not be a good option because the operators might try to fix their terms and the licence fee proposed by AAI would not be viable for them, he said.

AAI held a meeting of cab operators in New Delhi to get feedback so that a tender can be floated to attract app-cabs at Chennai airport and other smaller airports. But the tender is yet to take off. All major airports in the country including AAI-run Kolkata airport has multiple cab operators. But in Chennai, it is a free for all and passengers are left to fend for themselves.

Title: Tweaking of EPF pension clauses will help cashew workers: MP
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Welcoming the Union government’s notification amending the commutation clauses with regard to employees’ provident fund ( EPF ) pension scheme , MP N K Premachandran said that the notification would be beneficial to cashew workers in the state.

The MP from Kollam had been raising his voice in the Parliament against ‘inhumane attitude’ of the EPFO (Employees’ Provident Fund Organisation), which had been effecting a monthly cut on the pension in the name of commutation, ‘never restoring the reduced pension and continuing it for life’.

“Payment of full pension to pensioners after realization of full amount of commuted pension was a major demand in the private members’ resolution I presented in the 16th Lok Sabha,” Premachandran said in a statement. The workers had not been receiving even the minimum monthly pension of Rs 1,000 due to EPFO’s anti-workers’ policy, wherein it had been deducting from pension even after recovering manifold the amount the PF pensioners and subscribers received under commutation, he said.

As per government’s assurance (on the resolution) in December 2015, a high-level empowered monitoring committee was formed to review and revamp the employees’ pension scheme of 1995 and to consider other issues including pension enhancement. However, the MP had to raise the issue in the Parliament as there was delay in issuing notification.

Another major issue is the earlier amendment of 10 years of continuous service as 10 years of continuous contributory service, ‘which had ousted 90% of the cashew workers from the pension scheme, as they needed attendance of 3,650 days to be entitled to pension’, the MP said.

Now, with the amendment (reverting to 10 years of continuous service), pension of thousands of cashew workers has been restored, he said.

Title: Rare annulus solar eclipse in June after almost 90 years: ARIES
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Nainital: The Aryabhatta Research Institute of Observational Sciences ( ARIES ) in Nainital has started preparations to host scientists from across the country and abroad for the annular solar eclipse which is scheduled to occur on June 21 this year.

Speaking to TOI, scientists from ARIES said that annular solar eclipses are rare occurrences — which happen when the moon covers the sun's centre, leading to the formation of a “ring of fire” or annulus around the moon. “An eclipse of this magnitude will be witnessed in India for the first time after 1933. The eclipse can be witnessed for only about 30 seconds. However, this time, many parts of the country will be able to see almost 100% of the eclipse. In Nainital for instance, one will be able to see almost 99% of the eclipse,” SB Pandey, scientist at ARIES, told TOI.

He added that the institute is preparing to have a national-level outreach programme in the run-up to the eclipse. “Several scientists from across the country as well as neighbouring countries are expected to visit the institute on the day. We will release the details of the programme soon.”

The scientist further said that many places in the state like Dehradun and Tehri will also witness almost 100% of the eclipse.

Title: Delhi: Newly elected MLAs to take oath on Monday
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

(Image credit: Delhi assembly's official website)

NEW DELHI: The first session of the seventh Delhi legislative assembly will begin on Monday with the newly elected MLAs taking their oath, which will be administered by the pro-tem speaker Shoaib Iqbal.

Lieutenant governor Anil Baijal had appointed Iqbal, who got elected to the House for the sixth time, as the pro-tem speaker on Thursday on the recommendation of the Aam Aadmi Party dispensation.

According to the business bulletin issued by Delhi assembly secretariat, the election of the full-time speaker of the House will also take place on Monday after all members take their oath. The election of the speaker will also be conducted by Iqbal.

Sources said Ram Niwas Goel , who was the speaker in the previous assembly, was likely to retain the post.

The seventh legislative assembly of Delhi has 62 members from AAP , while the remaining eight belong to BJP.

Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and his six ministers had taken the oath of office and secrecy at a mega event at Ramlila Maidan on February 16. The council of ministers assumed office the next day with the first meeting of the cabinet being held on February 19.

The second day of the assembly session on Tuesday will see LG Baijal addressing the House. The Delhi assembly secretariat on Thursday released a bulletin for the newly elected members, which not only included the detailed plan for the three-day session but also specified the details of how the members would take their oath.

In case a member fails to take oath on the specified day, he/she may do so on any subsequent sitting of the assembly after giving advance information to the secretary. While the first assembly session will end on Wednesday, Delhi government officials said the budget session is likely to be called in the third week of March. Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia , who also holds the charge of finance department, will present his sixth consecutive budget this year.

Title: Jafrabad Protest: Nobody speaks for us, say women at Jafrabad sit-in
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Women during a sit-in protest against CAA, NRC and NPR near Jafrabad metro station. (PTI Photo)

NEW DELHI: The women at northeast Delhi’s Jafrabad were prepared for any eventuality on Monday. As violence escalated and shops and homes were set ablaze just hundreds of metres away, young women formed a chain around the elderly. But that was not the only line of defence. Three human chains of mostly men, two string of police barricades and thick ropes tied around pillars were also put up as additional safeguards.

The air was still thick with black smoke and the smell of burned tyres, but the women did not mention the signs of violence. They, instead, dedicated the afternoon to “remembrance” of a time when they lived peacefully with their neighbours. Around 5pm, the crowd swelled up to thousands as more and more women left their houses to join the sit-in.

“This is not a time to allow communal sentiments to overwhelm our peaceful protest. All our children have grown up together in the same neighbourhood. We are sitting here to preserve that brotherhood,” said Ghuma, a woman in her early 20s.

The sit-in against CAA/NRC/NPR has, since Sunday, occupied a stretch under Jafrabad metro station. The signs of dissent are abundantly spread through the neighbourhood. Almost every shop’s shutters in the area have been spray-painted with slogans condemning the new citizenship law. There are banners on the dividers — maa aur mulk badal nahin sakte (you can’t change your mother and country) — reads one of them.

The women also had several complaints against the city administration and feared for their safety. “Police are supposed to make us feel safe, but they are instead supporting those who burn down our houses. We have no representation and nobody speaks for us. Why is the chief minister not here,” asked Nasreen.

About a kilometre away on the same main road, another group sat on sheets hurriedly spread out on the road. They occupied a stretch on Maujpur Chowk. A mic was arranged and a local made announcements to crowdsource a tent and food for the women. “We will not move unless Jafrabad is emptied out,” said a woman.

Occasionally, the group shouted provocative slogans, calling for the “traitors” to be shot. “Desh ke gaddaro ko,” echoed through the roads. “Kisko chahiye azadi. Hum de denge azadi (who wants freedom. We will give them freedom),” was another popular chant, so was “Humara yahi nara hai, Bharat desh humara hai.”

Although a string of barricades were put up between the two groups, distance was not the only factor separating them. The distrust for the other ran deeper than physical barriers. Rumours, fear mongering and misinformation was rampant. As a Citizenship (Amendment) Act supporter said, “We cannot live with those people anymore... But we have awakened now and we will teach them a lesson.”

Title: Army officers based in T, AP honoured
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Secunderabad: Four Army officers stationed in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh were felicitated at southern command’s investiture ceremony held in Mumbai recently.

Bar to Sena Medal was awarded to Major Girish Sharma, Sena Medal of Armed unit and Vishisht Seva medals were awarded to Major General Raju K Subramani (retired) of EME Corps, Major General Manjinder Singh, YSM of Madras regiment and Brigadier Rajiv Kumar of EME Corps.

A total of 51 army persons and 22 units were presented with gallantry and distinguished awards for their outstanding contribution in various fields by Lieutenant General CP Mohanty, general officer commanding-in-chief of the southern command. The investiture ceremony was held at the iconic Gateway of India.

Addressing the audience, Lt Gen Mohanty said, “Recognition of such acts of selfless service, motivates the rank and file in the Army, to re-dedicate themselves to uphold the honour and dignity of our great nation in the best traditions of the Indian Army”.

Title: Congress leaders seek high command help amid severe infighting
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: At a time when the state is heading for local body polls this year and assembly polls next year, the Congress in the state is facing severe infighting . If group wars used to be the issue till date, now the party is facing a new fight with the KPCC president on the one side and the group leaders on the other.

Now both the KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran and the group leaders have approached the party high command against each other.

The KPCC president has approached the high command for the leaders targeting him at the PAC meet, and the group managers have complained against the style of functioning of the party state president.

This infighting had come to the fore in the last political affairs committee (PAC) when the leaders targeted the KPCC president for his style of functioning. Irked over the criticisms, Ramachandran had approached the AICC leadership and emphasized that he would not convene the PAC anymore if the situation continues.

Ramachandran is adamant that the political affairs committee should not be a platform for character assassination. He was also irked over the way the leaders leaked the discussions of the PAC to the media.

Ramachandran informed the AICC leadership that he was being targeted since he was against MPs and MLAs being given party posts. However, the group managers are up in arms against the president over his lack of coordination with the senior leaders. “The KPCC president, the opposition leader and Oommen Chandy are the senior leaders heading the party in the state. There is a lack of coordination among the three. Then how will the party have an unanimous opinion on any issue,” said a senior party leader.

The PAC is the crucial body which decides on the policy of KPCC on all issues. If the KPCC president is unwilling to convene this, then how will the party function in the state, particularly when the elections are round the corner, asked a former KPCC president.

Title: Investiture ceremony to be held at JRC
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Bareilly: The Army’s Central Command is set to organise its investiture ceremony at Jat Regiment Centre on February 28, where Lieutenant General IS Ghuman, General Officer Commanding-in-Chief of Central Command, will present gallantry awards to five officers and 10 other ranks for displaying exceptional courage and 11 officers will be awarded for their distinguished services, said JRC sources.

Besides, 12 units of the Central Command will also be awarded citations in recognition of their exceptional performance and services.

Prominent among the award winners is Lance Havildar Vijay Kumar of 23 Battalion, the Parachute Regiment, who will be awarded the Sena Medal (Gallantry) posthumously for displaying exceptional courage and making the supreme sacrifice while fighting terrorists in Jammu and Kashmir. His wife will receive the award.

Title: For radiographers, going to work is like courting cancer
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indore: Lack of safety measures against radiation kills — around two and a half dozen radiographers either retired or working at government health facilities across state had suffered from different types of cancer in last two decades.

Of the 29 cancer affected radiographers, 10 worked or are working at health facilities in Indore. The information was compiled by president of MP Radiographer’s Association Shivakant Vajpai. In last two decades five out of those 29 radiographers have died.

‘Radiation kills’, ‘safety first’ are just tagline that have been pasted on hospital corridors while the ground reality remained highly vulnerable for both lab technicians and patients. Experts alleged that directorate of radiation safety — the body that oversees safety measures in X-ray, CT Scan, radiation and sonography units of government health facilities — works only on paper.

Vajpai said, “Radiographers working at health facilities in state are at risk because the norms are not followed properly.” Radiographers suffered from various types of cancer including blood, liver, food pipe, lung, lymphoma, testes cancer, rectum cancer among others.

The number could be more than 29 because many radiographers couldn’t disclose about their disease to association members, said Vajpai. There was one radiographer named KC Jain, who was diagnosed with radiation dermatitis and he died a few years back, said Vajpai. His fingers were removed initially to prevent infection but later his left hand had to be cut off, said Vajpai.

For a radiographer, it has become a death trap — like a labourer in a mine — who knows that his job might kill him someday. Only here, proper safety measures can shield the radiation and reduce chances of cancer exponentially. But, there’s way only if there is will. And government clearly lacks the will to change the grim reality.

The radiographers, who were diagnosed with cancer mostly didn’t even get monetary support from government. However, in state like Kerala, government pays radiation allowance in their salary and one month leave is granted every year to radiographers for improvement in health. Government cancer hospital superintendent Dr Ramesh Arya said that excess and repeated exposure to radiation can cause cancer. Proper precautions should be taken during exposure to patient in X-ray, CT Scan, Cobalt machine and sonography machine, said Arya.

Children are more prone to get affected by such exposure. In MY Hospital, radiographers were provided TDL badges and other precautionary measures are followed, said Arya.

Even though there is no patient-based study on cause of cancer amongst these radiographers in state but various articles in journals across world put radiation as a major cause of cancer.

It is tough to establish direct cause of cancer among patient because it requires patient specific studies, said Vajpai. But major reason behind such high number of radiographers suffering from cancer in state is lack of precautionary measures.

There is lack of regular and strict monitoring in state as directorate of radiation safety had been working only on paper, said Vajpai.

CMHO Praveen Jadia said, “There should be regular monitoring of X-ray, CT Scan and Sonography machines installed at health facilities. TDL badges, which are provided to radiographers, are regularly monitored to avoid over-exposure.”

Whenever a new machine is installed, a team of AERB visits the facility and also in between for checking preventive measures taken at facility, added Jadia.

Title: A race to spot avian delights
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Hyderabad: Denizens identified more than 220 species of birds, at the 11th edition of the Hyderabad bird race where bird lovers from around the twin cities came together to spot and record avian species on Sunday.

"It is important for the younger generation to participate in activities like this, and indulge in nature and it is good to see novices experiencing bird watching on their own" said P Raghuveer, vice chairman and managing director, Telangana State Forest Development Corporation (TSFDC).

"But it is also integral to the cause of bird conservation in our state that people constantly work towards improving the bird habitats for the birds residing here,” he added.

Around 18 teams comprising of 75 members with a huge number of first time birdwatchers participated in the dawn to dusk event organised by Deccan Birders in collaboration with Great Hyderabad Adventure Club (GHAC), and took to the landcapes across the city with their cameras and binoculars.

"I have been identifying and recording birds for quite some time now and even though more than 200 species were identified during the course of the event, the habitat destruction in our city is prevalent,” said Raghav S, who was participating in the event for the third time. “ With urbanisation of the city, habitats of the fauna is heavily disturbed. Throughout the day, along with looking for birds, we spent an ample amount of time coming up with ways to to preserve nature while making sure these beautiful avian creatures return to Hyderabad,” he added.

Most popular areas for bird watching were Ananthagiri Hills, Gandipet lake, Hussain Sagar, Manjeera Reservoir, Narsapur Forest Range and Himayat Sagar. Among the rare species which were spotted during the event were Indian Blue Robin, Ultramarine flycatcher, Eurasian Wryneck and Booted eagle. Experts said that the city lakes used to be a home for a lot of waders or shore birds, now the number has decreased drastically.

“Activities like these are important to inculcate in the people a sense of responsibility towards maintaining the environment in a good state and the protection of the other inhabitants of this earth and particularly the avifauna,” said Surekha Aitabathula, secretary, Deccan Birders.

Title: New centre in Indore to aid plastic manufacturers
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indore: Giving a shot in the arm to growing local plastic industry, Central Institute of Plastic Engineering and Technology (CIPET) will soon start a centre in Indore to extend assistance to manufacturers with innovative research and technical support.

Central department of chemicals and petrochemicals secretary P Raghavendra Rao and CIPET director general Dr SK Nayak gave in-principle sanction to start the centre in Indore during a meeting with representatives of plastic product manufacturers on the sidelines of CIPET governing body meeting. Rao said that sanctions for starting the centre will be issued soon. He asked the representatives to contact MSME department for suitable land for the institute and necessary sanctions.

CIPET, a premier national institution under central ministry of chemicals & fertilizers, helps industries in skill development, technology support services, academics and research (STAR) in all domains of plastics, including design, tooling, mould manufacturing, plastics processing, testing and quality assurance.

As of now, CIPET operates from 37 locations spread across the country catering to the needs of polymer and allied industries, said Indian Plast Pack forum president Sachin Bansal.

“Indore has been the leading centre of plastic manufacturing in Madhya Pradesh. CIPET has a centre in Bhopal. The manufacturers had to approach Bhopal for assistance,” he said adding the new centre will also help growing plastic manufacturing industry in Pithampur.

Bansal, who was part of the delegation that met senior officials, said apart from the in-principle sanction, chemicals and petrochemicals department joint secretary Kashi Nath Jha has also promised sanction for necessary equipment and machines for start of the institute in Indore.

Title: Mercury dips as rain, hail lash Doon; higher reaches of Uttrakhand see snow
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

People huddle to find shelter as a downpour hit Doon on Sunday

DEHRADUN: After witnessing a spell of dry weather and rising temperature, Dehradun witnessed a sudden downpour and hailstorm on Sunday afternoon, leaving several areas covered in a white blanket. As a result, temperatures dropped significantly, especially in the hills.

Apart from the state capital, several other places in both the hills and plains experienced intermittent thunderstorm and rain . The high-altitude places in the mid-hills received snowfall as well.

According to the Met department, several places in Tehri, Chamoli, Pauri, Almora, Champawat and Nainital districts also witnessed thunder shower activity.

“Dehradun witnessed strong thunderstorm activity on Sunday, with hail occurring at many places. Gusty winds, accompanied by heavy rainfall, also lashed the city for a brief period. High-altitude places, mainly located at 2,500 meters and above, received light snowfall too,” said Bikram Singh, director of the regional meteorological centre.

In Dehradun, the maximum temperature was recorded at 25.6 degrees Celsius, while the minimum remained at 11.1 degrees Celsius. The maximum temperature in Mukteshwar dropped to 10.5 degrees Celsius, two notches below normal, while the minimum temperature settled at 4.5 degrees Celsius.

The wet spell is likely to continue till February 26. The Met office has predicted another spell of thunder showers on February 25, with the possibility of snow in higher reaches of the state.

“Uttarakhand can expect dry weather from February 26. The mercury, which will see a drop due to the current wet spell, will start rising once again and settle above normal by the end of this month,” Singh said.

Title: Shifting utilities for development project huge task for PCMC
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

The civic body is implementing the Rs320 crore Smart City project across Pimple Gurav & Pimpri Saudagar

PUNE: Shifting utilities like water and drainage lines are proving to be the biggest challenge for the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation ( PCMC ), which is implementing the Rs 320 crore Smart City project across the twin suburbs of Pimple Gurav and Pimple Saudagar.

The two suburbs, earmarked for the city’s maiden Smart City project, have a cumulative spread of 5.08sqkm.

“We have to be extremely careful because there is only alternate day water supply in the city,” said Vijay Bhojane, the joint city engineer.

“These are old lines and they need to be relaid along the proposed cycle tracks and footpaths,” Bhojane added.

He said that parallel lines are being laid and when they are complete, the old lines will be either discontinued or networked, where necessary.

Both the suburbs have daily water supply ranging from 70 litres to 200 litres per person, depending on the geographical parameters like elevation, distance etc, thanks to the old lines that were laid a couple of decades ago. The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation hopes that relaying of lines and connecting them to the smart network (the SCADA system) will ensure more equitable distribution in future.

The area-based development involves resurfacing of tar roads to concrete, paving cycle tracks and footpaths.

Bhojane, who is also the in-charge of the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation’s Smart City project, said that all the elements of the road will be possible where the width is sanctioned at 18 metres. In 12-metre zone, it will only be concrete road.

The corporation has also planned a yoga park and butterfly park spread across an acre in Pimple Saudagar and Pimple Gurav, respectively.

The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation will relay 44 road sectors – 18 in Pimple Gurav and 26 in Pimple Saudagar. The tender date for completion of the project is November 2021 (including monsoons).

The Army, which shares its boundaries with both the suburbs, has started barricading its area for the development work to commence even in sectors, where there are no roads.

Consulting firm, KPMG and Singapore-based industrial and infrastructure consulting firm Surbana Jurong is providing project management and design services for the Pimpri Chinchwad Smart City.

Title: Work on Chandni Chowk parking halted over dues
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

New Delhi: North Delhi Municipal Corporation has issued a “stop-work” notice to the company constructing the parking-cum-commercial centre at Gandhi Maidan in Chandni Chowk for non-payment of the last two instalments, each amounting to Rs 150 crore.

Standing committee chairman Jai Prakash said, “According to the contract, the concessionaire was supposed to pay the amount in instalments to the civic body. However, despite our reminders, the last two instalments were not paid even after six months of the due date. We then decided to issue the stop-work order.”

The parking-cum-commercial centre is being constructed on 18,524 square metres at a cost of Rs 1,000 crore on a public-private partnership model. Of this, Rs 450 crore was to be given to the north corporation. The deadline to complete the structure is September 2020. It is estimated to have parking capacity for 2,400 cars and 81 tourist buses.

Jai Prakash said the civic agency is facing financial crisis, so a decision was taken to give its land for developing parking facilities on PPP model. “We want to improve civic services through the interest earned by our fixed deposits in banks. We have allocated various projects on the same concept in the past. However, if the purpose is not fulfilled, then there is no use leasing out our land,” he added.

One of the long-pending projects of the north corporation, it was conceived in 2013. However, construction started in March 2019 only after an order by Delhi high court.

The facility, an eight-storey building with three basements, will benefit traders in markets such as Chawri Bazaar, Kinari Bazaar, Khari Baoli, Nai Sadak and Dariba Kalan. Shoppers and tourists visiting the Walled City will also find space to park their vehicles in a neighbourhood where parking is a huge task. The basements will have parking facilities and public conveniences. The ground and upper floors will be used for parking and commercial purposes.

Title: In 2 months, 73% applicants in Doon fail automated driving tests
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Dehradun: Around 73% of those applying for driving licences (DLs) in Doon for four-wheelers, failed to pass the driving test on the new sensor-equipped automated test track set up in the city, reveals official data for the months of December 2019 and January 2020.

According to the data provided by the Regional Transport Office (RTO), Dehradun, 3,318 people failed the four-wheeler driving test among the 4,530 applicants of DLs who appeared for the test in the past two months. During this period, 1,755 people applied for two-wheeler DLs and among these, 851 (almost 45%) people failed the test.

Those seeking a new driving licence or renewal of the existing one, are required to reverse their car on an S-shaped bend and back their cars in one go as per the new test protocol. The two-wheeler drivers have to go around an 8-shaped loop without putting their legs down. The new pattern of tests gauges applicants on over 20 parameters that includes readings from sensors and camera-check on tracks to ensure and record the correct movement of the driver. The RTO has around five patterns to check the drivers of four-wheelers while three patterns are there for two-wheelers.

The new pattern of tests had started in the Jhajhra driving training and testing centre on July 15 last year.

Speaking on why so many people were not able to clear the driving tests, Arvind Pandey, assistant regional transport officer (ARTO), told TOI that the automatic driving tests are designed in a way to ensure that only good drivers get DLs. “Those who fail the driving test can re-appear for it after a week of failing the test. Those who fail the test for the third time may re-appear after 60 days,” added Pandey.

The RTO official added that “automated driving tests are the need of the hour as fatal accidents are increasing in the hill state.” “The rate of failures was low in the earlier test because it was far too simple,” he said.

As per the data of police and transport department, Uttarakhand witnessed 1468 accidents in 2018 in which 1047 people died while 1571 were injured. 2019 saw 976 accidents till August in which 694 people were killed.

Title: Laxman says Cong should accept CAA
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indore: Congress MLA Laxman Singh – Digvijaya Singh’s brother -- on Sunday said that his party should accept CAA as it was passed in Parliament by majority vote and states are bound by the parliamentary system to implement it. Congress called it his personal opinion.

Laxman, who was a BJP MP from 2004-2009 and rejoined Congress in 2013, said: “Adequate discussions have taken place on CAA. Adequate protests have been held. CAA has become a law. Majority in Parliament is required to change this law.”

Pointing out that Congress doesn’t have the numbers to change it, he told reporters in Indore that “it is fair to accept it”.

The Congress MLA from Chachoda seat in Guna district feels states will have to implement it. Asked about Madhya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath’s announcement not to implement CAA in the state, Laxman said, “He (Nath) is saying that. But many are saying that it should be implemented. They will hold discussions.”

“I personally feel that when a law is framed for the country, you have to accept it. We (Congress) have framed several laws by making amendments when our government was in power. How would we have felt if the law cleared by us wasn’t implemented by states? Parliament is not owned by a party. Everybody has to agree to majority decision,” he said.

Congress spokesperson Narendra Saluja said it was Laxman's "personal statement". "Everybody has a right to freedom of speech. The party high command takes a decision on such issues. The party has decided that it is against CAA. Every party worker is following the decision across the country," he told TOI. Laxman was critical of state government’s plan to host IIFA 2020 awards at Daly College, his alma mater. “It is good that IIFA is being held. It will give opportunities of employment. But to hold it in a school is not justified,” he said. “It is examination time. For 10-15 days loud sound will be played; rooms will be converted to make-up rooms. Thus I have requested to change the venue.”

He also said that state government is planning to make gaushalas economically independent during a meeting held at Residency Kothi in Indore. TNN

Title: Dehradun: Eight-year-old girl hangs self after fight with brother over TV channel
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative Image

DEHRADUN: An eight-year-old girl allegedly hanged herself at her home in GMS Road here on Friday after a fight with her brother over which TV channel to watch.

Police said that the girl locked herself in a room in a fit of rage. They added that her body was later found hanging from the ceiling fan inside the room. Her family then rushed her to a private hospital near Ballupur Chowk where she was declared brought dead.

A police officer said, “Her mother told us that she had a fight with her brother over watching a particular TV channel. As he refused to relent, she went inside the room and locked herself.”

The field unit of Vasant Vihar police station later did a videography of the entire room where she was found hanging and collected evidence from the spot.

Title: Kerala: Women’s League moves SC against triple talaq law
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Supreme Court (ANI File Photo)

KOZHIKODE: Indian Union Women’s League , the women’s wing of IUML , has filed a petition in the Supreme Court , challenging the constitutional validity of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019 , which criminalizes triple talaq .

The petition filed by Noorbeena Rasheed, national general secretary of Indian Union Women’s League, states that the Act violates Articles 14, 15 and 21 of the Constitution.

The petition, filed through advocate Zulfiker Ali P S, argued that the Act has introduced penal legislation, specific to a class of persons based on religious identity which can cause grave public mischief, which, if unchecked, may lead to polarization and disharmony in society. The petition said that by virtue of the SC order in the Shayara Bano case, the utterance of triple talaq is without legal sanction or effect.

“If the motive was to protect a Muslim wife in an unhappy marriage, no reasonable person can believe that the means to ensure it is by putting an errant husband in jail for three years and create a non-bailable offence for merely saying ‘TalaqTalaqTalaq’. The marriage survives, regardless of such utterance. It is difficult to imagine why the mere utterance of meaningless words should attract a three-year sentence for the husband,” the petition said.

It added that the intent behind the Act is not abolition of triple talaq but punishment of Muslim husbands. The petition said that that there was no benevolence or welfare apparent in the Act and added that protection of wives cannot be achieved by incarceration of husbands.tnn

Title: Silawat cleans dirty nullah in Sanwer
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Indore: Health minister Tulsiram Silawat on Sunday caught hold of a spade and jumped into a dirty nullah to clean it during his tour to Sanwer.

Clad in spic and span white kurta-pajama, the minister dug out dirt from the nullah and sewer lines to spread the message of cleanliness among people of his constituency.

He held a broom and cleaned the streets as people around cheered and later joined him in his efforts.

“I want citizens of Sanwer to take a pledge to keep city healthy, educated and clean,” Silawat said from a small podium erected on roadside.

Claiming that efforts were being made to make Sanwer an ideal city, the MLA said he had announced in 1980s that water from Narmada will be brought to Sanwer. The idea seemed farfetched at that time. But now, it is being realized.

“Soon people of Sanwer will get clean drinking water of Narmada,” he said.

He said funds have been sanctioned to construct internal roads of Sanwer and hospitals are being renovated.

He asked people of Sanwer to shun plastic and said that door-to-door campaign will be launched to distribute cloth bags to replace plastic bags.

SDM Ravish Shrivastava said 19 wards have been identified for the cleanliness campaign. Staff of different government departments was roped in to clean the city.

Title: Nagpur: BJP to protest over issues of ryots, development, women safety
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Representative image

Nagpur: The BJP will stage an agitation at all tehsil offices against the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government on Tuesday to protest its failure to provide relief to farmers, attacks on women and stoppage of development works.

Addressing a press conference on Sunday, former guardian minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule said that the government had promised a relief of Rs25,000 per hectare to farms and Rs50,000 per hectare to orchards for crop damage. “However, farmers are not even getting the relief sanctioned by the governor. Earlier, MVA leaders said that they would give a complete loan waiver to farmers but later put a cap of Rs2 lakh. The government has fooled the farmers and BJP will take it to task for that,” he added.

Bawankule claimed that crime had increased by 60% in the tenure of MVA as compared to the BJP government. “A young woman was torched in Hinganghat and a Prahar activist was shot dead in Akola. Such alarming incidents are taking place every day across the state,” he said.

Bawankule, who was energy minister for five years, lauded his successor Nitin Raut for proposing to provide free power to domestic consumers using less than 100 units. “It is unfortunate that finance minister Ajit Pawar is against this. We fully support Raut and this government should allocate the required funds from the budget so that he can fulfil his promise,” he said.

The ex-MLA praised chief minister Uddhav Thackeray for supporting the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Population Register (NPR) but said that he should also pay attention to development of the state.

Title: Kerala: Women’s League moves SC against triple talaq law
Content:
This story is from February 24, 2020

Supreme Court (ANI File Photo)

KOZHIKODE: Indian Union Women’s League , the women’s wing of IUML , has filed a petition in the Supreme Court , challenging the constitutional validity of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019 , which criminalizes triple talaq .

The petition filed by Noorbeena Rasheed, national general secretary of Indian Union Women’s League, states that the Act violates Articles 14, 15 and 21 of the Constitution.

The petition, filed through advocate Zulfiker Ali P S, argued that the Act has introduced penal legislation, specific to a class of persons based on religious identity which can cause grave public mischief, which, if unchecked, may lead to polarization and disharmony in society. The petition said that by virtue of the SC order in the Shayara Bano case, the utterance of triple talaq is without legal sanction or effect.

“If the motive was to protect a Muslim wife in an unhappy marriage, no reasonable person can believe that the means to ensure it is by putting an errant husband in jail for three years and create a non-bailable offence for merely saying ‘TalaqTalaqTalaq’. The marriage survives, regardless of such utterance. It is difficult to imagine why the mere utterance of meaningless words should attract a three-year sentence for the husband,” the petition said.

It added that the intent behind the Act is not abolition of triple talaq but punishment of Muslim husbands. The petition said that that there was no benevolence or welfare apparent in the Act and added that protection of wives cannot be achieved by incarceration of husbands.tnn
